6.20. 600#

6.20.1. Regularly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆrÉ›É¡jÊŠlÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: At a fixed time or interval; often.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œregularlyâ€ is to describe an action that occurs with consistent and predictable timing, following a fixed pattern.

What it really means: â€œRegularlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that is repeated at fixed intervals or with a high degree of frequency. It implies a sense of routine and consistency. For example, if you exercise regularly, you do it on a consistent basis, not randomly.

When to use it: Use it to describe an action that happens often or at a fixed time.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œregularly scheduled,â€ â€œregularly attend,â€ â€œregularly check.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI regularly check my email for new messages.â€

      • â€œShe regularly visits her grandparents on the weekends.â€

      • â€œThe bus runs regularly every 15 minutes during the day.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe study found that students who regularly review their notes tend to perform better in exams.â€

      • â€œThe company regularly publishes a financial report to inform its shareholders of its performance.â€

      • â€œA diet that regularly includes fresh fruits and vegetables is essential for good health.â€

      • â€œThe system requires users to regularly update their password to maintain security.â€

Synonyms: Frequently, often, consistently, routinely.

Opposite words: Rarely, seldom, irregularly, occasionally.

Where it comes from: From Latin regularis (according to rule).

6.20.2. Measurement#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆmÉ›Ê’É™mÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The process of finding a size, quantity, or degree of something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œmeasurementâ€ is the act of determining the size, quantity, or extent of something by comparing it to a standard unit.

What it really means: â€œMeasurementâ€ is the process of quantifying something, like length, weight, temperature, or volume. It is the result of this process, expressed in numerical form and a unit (e.g., â€œthe measurement is 5 centimetersâ€). It is a fundamental concept in science, engineering, and daily life.

When to use it: Use it when talking about the process or result of determining the size or quantity of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œtake a measurement,â€ â€œunit of measurement,â€ â€œaccurate measurement.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œBefore buying a new desk, you should take a measurement of the space.â€

      • â€œThe tailor took my waist measurement for the new trousers.â€

      • â€œThe doctor took a measurement of my blood pressure.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œAccurate measurement is crucial for conducting a reliable scientific experiment.â€

      • â€œThe report outlines a new system for the measurement of air quality in urban environments.â€

      • â€œThe study involves the measurement of changes in ocean temperature over several decades.â€

      • â€œThe architectâ€™s plans include precise measurements for all structural components.â€

Synonyms: Calculation, quantity, dimension, size, evaluation.

Opposite words: N/A.

Where it comes from: From Old French mesure, from Latin metiri (to measure).

6.20.3. Properly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆprÉ’pÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Correctly or appropriately; in a suitable manner.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œproperlyâ€ is to do something in the correct or appropriate way, in accordance with established rules, standards, or expectations.

What it really means: â€œProperlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that is performed correctly, appropriately, or in the right manner. It implies a sense of doing something well and according to the rules. If you do something properly, you are not cutting corners or making mistakes.

When to use it: Use it to describe an action that is done correctly or in the right way.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œdo something properly,â€ â€œbehave properly,â€ â€œwork properly.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œYou need to clean the kitchen properly before the guests arrive.â€

      • â€œThe new machine isnâ€™t working properly.â€

      • â€œYou must attach the seatbelt properly for it to be safe.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œTo ensure the accuracy of the data, all surveys must be filled out properly and completely.â€

      • â€œThe report states that the waste disposal system is not functioning properly and needs immediate repair.â€

      • â€œFor a plant to grow properly, it requires adequate sunlight and water.â€

      • â€œThe instructions specify how to properly install the software to avoid any errors.â€

Synonyms: Correctly, appropriately, suitably, rightly, adequately.

Opposite words: Improperly, incorrectly, wrongly, inadequately.

Where it comes from: From Latin proprius (oneâ€™s own, special).

6.20.4. Current#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkÊŒrÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Adj) Of the present time; (Noun) A flow of water or electricity.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning for the adjective is to be of or belonging to the present time. For the noun, it is a continuous flow or movement of water, air, or electricity.

What it really means: As an adjective, â€œcurrentâ€ means happening now or in the present moment (â€œthe current situationâ€). As a noun, it refers to a continuous flow of a fluid or energy (â€œan electric currentâ€ or â€œthe ocean currentâ€).

When to use it: Use the adjective to refer to the present time, or the noun to refer to a flow of a fluid or energy.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œcurrent affairs,â€ â€œcurrent events,â€ â€œat the current time.â€

    • (Noun) â€œelectric current,â€ â€œstrong current.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWhatâ€™s the current weather like outside?â€

      • â€œThe river has a very strong current after the rain.â€

      • â€œMy current job is much more challenging than my last one.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report analyzes the current trends in global economic development and their potential impact.â€

      • â€œScientists are studying the effects of melting glaciers on the currents of the Atlantic Ocean.â€

      • â€œThe document provides an overview of the current situation regarding public health in the region.â€

      • â€œThe device uses a low-voltage electric current to power its internal components.â€

Synonyms: (Adj) Present, existing, prevailing; (Noun) Flow, stream, movement.

Opposite words: (Adj) Past, former, old; (Noun) Stagnation.

Where it comes from: From Latin currere (to run).

6.20.5. Prediction#

  • Pronunciation: /prÉªËˆdÉªkÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A statement about what will happen in the future.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpredictionâ€ is a forecast or a calculated guess about a future event, often based on existing data, trends, or knowledge.

What it really means: A â€œpredictionâ€ is a statement or a guess about what might happen in the future. It is not a guaranteed fact but a statement of what is expected to occur. It can be a simple guess (e.g., â€œMy prediction is that it will rainâ€) or a complex scientific forecast (e.g., â€œThe weather prediction for tomorrow is sunnyâ€).

When to use it: Use it when talking about a forecast or a statement about a future event.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œmake a prediction,â€ â€œweather prediction,â€ â€œeconomic prediction.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œMy prediction is that our team will win the championship this year.â€

      • â€œThe weather prediction for this weekend is sunny, so we should plan a picnic.â€

      • â€œDonâ€™t take his prediction too seriously; heâ€™s just guessing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe reportâ€™s prediction of a rise in unemployment was based on the analysis of recent market trends.â€

      • â€œMaking an accurate prediction of future climate change requires complex modeling and vast amounts of data.â€

      • â€œThe economic prediction for the next quarter suggests a period of modest but sustained growth.â€

      • â€œOne of the key functions of scientific models is to enable the prediction of outcomes based on specific variables.â€

Synonyms: Forecast, forecast, guess, prophecy, prognosis, projection.

Opposite words: Retrospection, hindsight, memory.

Where it comes from: From Latin prae (before) + dicere (to say).

6.20.6. Approve#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆpruËv/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To officially agree to or accept something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œapproveâ€ is to officially or formally give oneâ€™s consent, support, or agreement to something, making it valid or acceptable.

What it really means: To â€œapproveâ€ means to say yes to a plan, proposal, or action. This can be a formal process (e.g., â€œthe committee approved the new budgetâ€) or a more informal one (e.g., â€œmy parents approved of my choice of universityâ€). It suggests that something has met a standard and is now acceptable.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of giving official consent or support.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œapprove of,â€ â€œapprove a plan,â€ â€œget approved.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œMy boss will need to approve my vacation request.â€

      • â€œI hope my parents approve of my new boyfriend.â€

      • â€œThe city council needs to approve the new building plans.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe board of directors is expected to approve the merger in todayâ€™s meeting.â€

      • â€œThe new drug will not be sold to the public until it has been approved by a regulatory agency.â€

      • â€œThe report recommends that the government approve the new legislation to address climate change.â€

      • â€œThe project proposal was carefully reviewed before being approved for funding.â€

Synonyms: Accept, authorize, sanction, consent to, endorse.

Opposite words: Disapprove, reject, veto, deny, refuse.

Where it comes from: From Old French aprover, from Latin approbare (to assent to, to prove).

6.20.7. Significant#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉªÉ¡ËˆnÉªfÉªkÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Important, notable, or meaningful.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsignificantâ€ is to be important or meaningful in its impact or effect, or to be large enough to be noticeable.

What it really means: â€œSignificantâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is important, has a large effect, or is notable enough to be mentioned. It can refer to an event (â€œa significant discoveryâ€), a person (â€œa significant figureâ€), or a quantity (â€œa significant amount of moneyâ€). It is often used to emphasize the importance or size of something.

When to use it: Use it to emphasize the importance, size, or effect of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œsignificant change,â€ â€œsignificant difference,â€ â€œa significant number.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThere has been a significant improvement in her health since she started exercising.â€

      • â€œThe new job came with a significant pay increase.â€

      • â€œThat was a very significant moment in my life.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe research found a statistically significant correlation between the two variables.â€

      • â€œThe discovery of the new planet is considered a significant event in the field of astronomy.â€

      • â€œThe report highlights the significant progress made in reducing carbon emissions over the last decade.â€

      • â€œThe policy change is expected to have a significant impact on the economy.â€

Synonyms: Important, notable, meaningful, substantial, consequential.

Opposite words: Insignificant, trivial, minor, negligible, unimportant.

Where it comes from: From Latin significare (to make a sign, to mean).

6.20.8. Generalisation#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒdÊ’É›nÉ™rÉ™laÉªËˆzeÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A broad statement or rule inferred from specific cases.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œgeneralisationâ€ is the process of forming a broad rule or concept from a limited number of specific examples, or the broad statement itself.

What it really means: A â€œgeneralisationâ€ is a conclusion or a broad statement that you make after observing a small number of examples. It is often a simplifying statement about a whole group or category. While they can be useful for understanding, they are not always accurate and can sometimes lead to stereotypes.

When to use it: Use it when talking about a broad statement or conclusion based on limited evidence.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œmake a generalisation,â€ â€œa sweeping generalisation,â€ â€œa broad generalisation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œYou canâ€™t make a generalisation about all teenagers just from knowing one.â€

      • â€œI think thatâ€™s a bit of a generalisation; not everyone feels that way.â€

      • â€œThe surveyâ€™s findings are too small to make a valid generalisation.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe researcher warned against making a generalisation from the small sample size used in the study.â€

      • â€œThe reportâ€™s conclusions are based on a generalisation of historical data, which may not apply to current conditions.â€

      • â€œThe authorâ€™s argument contains several sweeping generalisations that are not supported by evidence.â€

      • â€œWhile useful, a scientific generalisation must always be tested with further experiments and data.â€

Synonyms: Broad statement, assumption, oversimplification, axiom.

Opposite words: Specificity, detail, particularity.

Where it comes from: From the verb generalize, from Latin generalis (of a whole class).

6.20.9. Necessity#

  • Pronunciation: /nÉ™ËˆsÉ›sÉ™ti/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The state of being required or essential.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œnecessityâ€ is the compelling quality of being absolutely essential, required, or unavoidable. It refers to a need that cannot be ignored.

What it really means: A â€œnecessityâ€ is something that is absolutely required. It can be a thing, like food and water (â€œbasic human necessitiesâ€), or a condition, like the necessity of having a password to log in. It is used to describe something that is not optional.

When to use it: Use it to refer to something that is absolutely essential or required.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa matter of necessity,â€ â€œout of necessity,â€ â€œthe necessity of.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHaving a car is a necessity for me to get to work.â€

      • â€œFood and shelter are basic human necessities.â€

      • â€œThereâ€™s no necessity for us to leave so early; we have plenty of time.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report highlights the necessity of investing in renewable energy sources to combat climate change.â€

      • â€œIn some situations, a government may have to act out of economic necessity rather than choice.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the necessity of early childhood education for a childâ€™s cognitive development.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the legal necessity for all businesses to maintain accurate financial records.â€

Synonyms: Requirement, essential, prerequisite, need, obligation.

Opposite words: Optionality, choice, luxury, nonessential.

Where it comes from: From Latin necessitas (unavoidableness, need).

6.20.10. Perform#

  • Pronunciation: /pÉ™ËˆfÉ”Ëm/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To carry out an action or task; to entertain an audience.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œperformâ€ is to carry out a specific action or function, whether itâ€™s a routine task, a complex procedure, or a public display for an audience.

What it really means: To â€œperformâ€ means to do something. This can be a practical task like performing an operation, or a creative one like a musician performing on stage. The word suggests a sense of action and execution, often with a focus on how well the task is carried out (â€œto perform wellâ€).

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of carrying out a task, function, or artistic activity.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œperform a task,â€ â€œperform a play,â€ â€œperform a duty.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe doctor will perform a routine checkup tomorrow.â€

      • â€œThe band will perform live at the club tonight.â€

      • â€œIâ€™m not sure if I can perform well under this much pressure.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe team was instructed to perform a detailed analysis of the market data before the meeting.â€

      • â€œThe study aims to evaluate how well the new software performs under different operating conditions.â€

      • â€œIt is the responsibility of all employees to perform their duties with integrity and professionalism.â€

      • â€œThe robot was designed to perform a number of complex assembly tasks in the factory.â€

Synonyms: Do, execute, carry out, conduct, fulfill, enact.

Opposite words: Fail, neglect, abandon, omit.

Where it comes from: From Old French parfournir (to complete, to accomplish).

6.20.11. Credible#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkrÉ›dÉªbÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Able to be believed or trusted; convincing.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcredibleâ€ is to be worthy of belief or confidence, possessing a quality that makes something seem true or reliable.

What it really means: â€œCredibleâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is believable. It can refer to a person who is trustworthy (â€œa credible witnessâ€), a story that seems true (â€œa credible accountâ€), or evidence that is convincing (â€credible dataâ€). It is often used to assess the reliability of a source or a piece of information.

When to use it: Use it to describe a person, claim, or piece of evidence that is believable.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œcredible source,â€ â€œcredible threat,â€ â€œcredible explanation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œShe gave a very credible explanation for why she was late.â€

      • â€œThe journalist is a credible source of information about the countryâ€™s politics.â€

      • â€œI donâ€™t think his story is very credible.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œTo be considered a credible source, the research must be peer-reviewed and its data verifiable.â€

      • â€œThe report provides a credible analysis of the economic situation, backed by strong statistical evidence.â€

      • â€œThe committee determined that the witnessâ€™s testimony was not credible due to multiple contradictions.â€

      • â€œThe new security plan is designed to address every credible threat to the companyâ€™s network.â€

Synonyms: Believable, trustworthy, convincing, plausible, reliable.

Opposite words: Incredible, unbelievable, untrustworthy, dubious, implausible.

Where it comes from: From Latin credibilis (worthy of belief), from credere (to believe).

6.20.12. Vaguely#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆveÉªÉ¡li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that is not clear or definite.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œvaguelyâ€ is to do or say something in an indefinite, imprecise, or unclear manner, lacking specific detail.

What it really means: â€œVaguelyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that is done in a way that is not clear, precise, or detailed. It suggests a lack of clarity, either in thought or in expression. For example, if you remember something vaguely, you remember it without many details.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is not clear, precise, or definite.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œvaguely remember,â€ â€œvaguely familiar,â€ â€œvaguely aware.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI vaguely remember meeting her at the party last year.â€

      • â€œThe instructions were so vaguely written that I had to call for help.â€

      • â€œHe looked vaguely familiar, but I couldnâ€™t remember his name.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe document vaguely refers to a past agreement without providing specific dates or terms.â€

      • â€œThe reportâ€™s conclusions are vaguely defined, making it difficult to draw any firm conclusions.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is vaguely worded, which could lead to multiple interpretations.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s results are only vaguely correlated with the initial hypothesis.â€

Synonyms: Indefinitely, indistinctly, unclearly, loosely, imprecisely.

Opposite words: Clearly, precisely, explicitly, definitely, exactly.

Where it comes from: From Latin vagus (wandering).

6.20.13. Accurately#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÃ¦kjÊŠrÉ™tli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that is correct and precise.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œaccuratelyâ€ is to do something in a precise and correct manner, without errors or deviations from the facts.

What it really means: â€œAccuratelyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that is done without mistakes. It suggests a high degree of correctness, precision, and truthfulness. For example, if you measure something accurately, you get the exact right number.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done correctly and with precision.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œaccurately measure,â€ â€œaccurately predict,â€ â€œaccurately describe.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe clock on the wall doesnâ€™t tell the time accurately.â€

      • â€œYou need to follow the recipe accurately to get the best result.â€

      • â€œShe was able to accurately guess my age.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œTo ensure the safety of the structure, the engineers must accurately calculate the weight it can bear.â€

      • â€œThe research aims to accurately measure the impact of the new policy on the local economy.â€

      • â€œIt is difficult to accurately predict the outcomes of a complex social system without a great deal of data.â€

      • â€œThe report accurately describes the current state of the global climate, based on the latest scientific evidence.â€

Synonyms: Correctly, precisely, exactly, truthfully, reliably.

Opposite words: Inaccurately, incorrectly, imprecisely, vaguely, wrongly.

Where it comes from: From Latin accuratus (prepared with care), from ad- (to) + cura (care).

6.20.14. React#

  • Pronunciation: /riËˆÃ¦kt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To behave or respond in a particular way to something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œreactâ€ is to respond to a stimulus or event, often involuntarily or as a direct consequence of that stimulus.

What it really means: To â€œreactâ€ means to behave or respond to something that has just happened. It can be a sudden, emotional response (â€œShe reacted with surpriseâ€) or a more deliberate action (â€œThe government reacted to the crisisâ€). In chemistry, it also means to undergo a chemical change when two substances are combined.

When to use it: Use it to describe how someone or something responds to an event or a stimulus.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œreact to,â€ â€œreact with,â€ â€œreact negatively.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHow did he react when you told him the news?â€

      • â€œI donâ€™t think you should react so strongly to a small problem.â€

      • â€œThe medicine didnâ€™t react well with my system.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe study examines how different plant species react to changes in soil composition.â€

      • â€œThe financial market reacted negatively to the news of the trade dispute.â€

      • â€œThe report analyzes how public opinion reacts to new government policies.â€

      • â€œThe immune system can sometimes react to harmless substances, causing an allergic response.â€

Synonyms: Respond, answer, behave, reply, act in response.

Opposite words: Ignore, disregard, overlook, remain unaffected.

Where it comes from: From Latin re (back) + agere (to do, to act).

6.20.15. Complain#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™mËˆpleÉªn/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To express dissatisfaction or unhappiness about something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcomplainâ€ is to express dissatisfaction or distress about a problem, a person, or a situation, usually in a negative or critical way.

What it really means: To â€œcomplainâ€ means to express that you are unhappy or dissatisfied with something. This can be done verbally (e.g., â€œcomplain to the managerâ€) or in writing (e.g., â€œcomplain in an emailâ€). It is used when a person feels that something is wrong and wants it to be changed.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of expressing dissatisfaction or unhappiness.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œcomplain about,â€ â€œcomplain to,â€ â€œcomplain bitterly.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œShe always complains about the cold weather.â€

      • â€œI need to complain to the waiter about the food being cold.â€

      • â€œMy neighbors complain about my loud music every weekend.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œA significant number of customers complain about the lack of communication from the service provider.â€

      • â€œThe report found that workers complain most frequently about a lack of recognition for their efforts.â€

      • â€œThe government received numerous letters from citizens who complain about the new tax policy.â€

      • â€œThe study indicates that students who complain about academic pressure often have lower grades.â€

Synonyms: Grumble, protest, whine, object, grouse.

Opposite words: Praise, commend, compliment, approve.

Where it comes from: From Old French complaindre, from Latin com- (with, together) + plangere (to strike, to lament).

6.20.16. Validity#

  • Pronunciation: /vÉ™ËˆlÉªdÉ™ti/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The quality of being logically or factually sound; the state of being legally or officially acceptable.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œvalidityâ€ is the quality of being based on sound reasoning, facts, or legal authority. It is the state of being correct, true, or acceptable.

What it really means: â€œValidityâ€ is a noun that refers to the quality of being logically correct, factually true, or officially acceptable. It is used to question or confirm the truthfulness of a claim (â€œthe validity of the argumentâ€) or the legal status of a document (â€œthe passportâ€™s validityâ€).

When to use it: Use it to discuss the quality of being correct, true, or officially acceptable.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œquestion the validity,â€ â€œcheck the validity,â€ â€œthe validity of a claim.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWe need to check the validity of the claim before we believe it.â€

      • â€œThe validity of my bus pass expires next month.â€

      • â€œI question the validity of his excuse for being late.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s validity was questioned due to the small sample size and potential bias.â€

      • â€œThe report examines the validity of the data used to support the new policy recommendations.â€

      • â€œThe passportâ€™s validity is a crucial factor for international travel.â€

      • â€œThe court will determine the validity of the contract based on the legal principles set forth in the law.â€

Synonyms: Correctness, soundness, legitimacy, truth, accuracy, cogency.

Opposite words: Invalidity, falsehood, error, inaccuracy, illegitimacy.

Where it comes from: From Latin validus (strong, effective).

6.20.17. Widely#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆwaÉªdli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Over a large area or among many people.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œwidelyâ€ is to do something over a large area, to a great extent, or among a great number of people.

What it really means: â€œWidelyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that affects or involves many people or a large area. It suggests a broad scope. For example, if a belief is widely held, many people believe it. If a technology is widely used, it is very common.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is common, extensive, or involves many people.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œwidely used,â€ â€œwidely accepted,â€ â€œwidely known.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe news about the scandal was widely reported in the media.â€

      • â€œHis new book is widely available in all bookstores.â€

      • â€œThe internet is widely considered the most important invention of the 20th century.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe study found that the new app is widely used by people in different age groups across the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law was widely criticized for its potential negative impact on the economy.â€

      • â€œThe concept of sustainable development is now widely accepted as a global priority.â€

      • â€œThe species is widely distributed across all continents except Antarctica.â€

Synonyms: Broadly, extensively, commonly, generally, universally.

Opposite words: Narrowly, locally, rarely, specifically.

Where it comes from: From Old English wÄ«d (wide).

6.20.18. Formally#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆfÉ”ËmÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a formal manner or style; officially.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œformallyâ€ is to do something in an official, proper, or ceremonious manner, following rules and conventions.

What it really means: â€œFormallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that is done in a very proper or official way. It suggests that rules and conventions are being followed. For example, a business letter is written formally, and an agreement is signed formally. It is the opposite of doing something casually or informally.

When to use it: Use it to describe an action that is done in a very official, proper, or serious way.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œformally dressed,â€ â€œformally invite,â€ â€œformally announce.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œShe was formally introduced to the CEO at the company dinner.â€

      • â€œYou should write to them formally to express your concerns.â€

      • â€œThe new restaurant is very fancy, so we have to dress formally.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe committee formally approved the budget after a long discussion.â€

      • â€œThe government will formally announce the new policy at a press conference tomorrow.â€

      • â€œTo be considered for the position, candidates must formally submit a written application and a CV.â€

      • â€œThe report was formally presented to the board of directors for their review and approval.â€

Synonyms: Officially, properly, ceremoniously, conventionally.

Opposite words: Informally, casually, unofficially.

Where it comes from: From Old French formel, from Latin forma (form, shape).

6.20.19. Convertible#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™nËˆvÉœËtÉ™bÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Adj) Able to be changed into a different form; (Noun) A car with a folding roof.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the adjective is to be capable of being changed in form, function, or nature. The noun is a specific application of this quality, a car with a roof that can be converted.

What it really means: As an adjective, â€œconvertibleâ€ describes something that can be changed from one form to another. For example, a sofa bed is convertible from a sofa to a bed. As a noun, a â€œconvertibleâ€ is a type of car that has a roof that can be folded down or removed.

When to use it: Use the adjective to describe something that can be changed, or the noun to refer to a specific type of car.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œconvertible sofa,â€ â€œconvertible currency,â€ â€œeasily convertible.â€

    • (Noun) â€œdrive a convertible,â€ â€œbuy a convertible.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI bought a convertible car so I can enjoy the sun.â€

      • â€œMy friend has a convertible sofa bed for when guests stay over.â€

      • â€œThe old currency is still convertible at the bank for a limited time.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe study examines the convertible nature of different forms of energy, such as light and heat.â€

      • â€œThe report discusses the challenges of designing a single-use product that is also easily convertible for other purposes.â€

      • â€œThe company is exploring the use of a new material that is highly convertible and can be recycled into various forms.â€

      • â€œThe economic system relies on a convertible currency, meaning it can be exchanged for gold or other assets.â€

Synonyms: (Adj) Adaptable, changeable, transformable, adjustable; (Noun) Open-top car.

Opposite words: (Adj) Inconvertible, fixed, unchangeable.

Where it comes from: From Latin convertere (to turn around, to change).

6.20.20. Pattern#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆpÃ¦tÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A repeated decorative design or a regular arrangement of shapes or events.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpatternâ€ is a repeated and predictable arrangement of elements, whether in a design, a behavior, or a sequence of events.

What it really means: A â€œpatternâ€ is a regular and repeated arrangement. This can be a visual design (e.g., â€œa checkered patternâ€) or a sequence of actions or events that happens repeatedly (â€œa pattern of behaviorâ€). It suggests a sense of order and predictability.

When to use it: Use it to describe a repeated design or a predictable arrangement.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa pattern of behavior,â€ â€œa regular pattern,â€ â€œa floral pattern.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI noticed a pattern of small birds visiting my garden at the same time every morning.â€

      • â€œThe wallpaper has a beautiful floral pattern.â€

      • â€œHis sleep pattern has been very irregular lately.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report identifies a clear pattern of migration in the region over the last century.â€

      • â€œResearchers observed a consistent pattern of gene expression in the experimental group.â€

      • â€œThe study attempts to predict future economic trends by analyzing historical spending patterns.â€

      • â€œThe authorâ€™s writing style follows a recognizable pattern of using long, complex sentences.â€

Synonyms: Design, arrangement, sequence, form, model, regularity.

Opposite words: Randomness, unpredictability, chaos, disorder.

Where it comes from: From Old French patron (a model, a pattern).

6.20.21. Gradually#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÉ¡rÃ¦dÊ’ÊŠÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Slowly and in stages.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œgraduallyâ€ is to do something slowly and progressively, with small changes occurring over a period of time.

What it really means: â€œGraduallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe a change or a process that happens slowly and in small, incremental stages, not all at once. It suggests a smooth, step-by-step development. For example, if the weather gets colder gradually, it gets a little colder each day over a period of time.

When to use it: Use it to describe a slow, step-by-step change or process.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œgradually increase,â€ â€œgradually change,â€ â€œgradually improve.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe weather will gradually get warmer as we head into summer.â€

      • â€œHe is gradually learning to play the guitar by practicing a little bit each day.â€

      • â€œThe fog gradually lifted, revealing the mountains in the distance.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe research shows that a childâ€™s vocabulary develops gradually over a period of several years.â€

      • â€œThe report notes that a successful transition to renewable energy will occur gradually through a series of policy changes and technological innovations.â€

      • â€œThe patientâ€™s condition began to gradually improve after the new medication was administered.â€

      • â€œThe companyâ€™s profits have been gradually increasing since the new CEO took charge.â€

Synonyms: Slowly, progressively, steadily, incrementally.

Opposite words: Suddenly, abruptly, instantly, immediately.

Where it comes from: From Latin gradus (step, degree).

6.20.22. Anniversary#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÃ¦nÉªËˆvÉœËsÉ™ri/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The date on which an event took place in a previous year.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œanniversaryâ€ is the yearly recurrence of a specific, notable date or event.

What it really means: An â€œanniversaryâ€ is a day that is remembered and celebrated because a notable event happened on that day in a previous year. It is most commonly used for a wedding (wedding anniversary) or the founding of a company (company anniversary).

When to use it: Use it to refer to the yearly celebration of a past event.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œwedding anniversary,â€ â€œanniversary of an event,â€ â€œcelebrate an anniversary.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œMy parents are celebrating their 25th wedding anniversary next month.â€

      • â€œToday is the anniversary of the day we first met.â€

      • â€œThe company celebrated its 50th anniversary with a big party.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe country will observe the 100th anniversary of its independence with a national holiday.â€

      • â€œThe report commemorates the 50th anniversary of the first moon landing and its lasting impact on science.â€

      • â€œThe university hosted a conference to mark the 25th anniversary of the opening of its medical school.â€

      • â€œThe treaty was signed on the anniversary of the end of the war, as a symbol of lasting peace.â€

Synonyms: Commemoration, jubilee, commemoration.

Opposite words: N/A.

Where it comes from: From Latin annus (year) + vertere (to turn).

6.20.23. Improvement#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªmËˆpruËvmÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The process of getting better or making something better.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œimprovementâ€ is a positive change or enhancement that makes something better in quality, condition, or performance.

What it really means: An â€œimprovementâ€ is a positive change. It can be the act of making something better (â€œwe need to make an improvement to the processâ€) or the result of that act (â€œthe new software is a big improvementâ€). The word suggests a change from a previous state that was not as good.

When to use it: Use it to describe a positive change or enhancement.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œmake an improvement,â€ â€œa marked improvement,â€ â€œroom for improvement.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThere has been a huge improvement in her grades since she started studying more.â€

      • â€œThe new road is a great improvement to the traffic flow in the city.â€

      • â€œThereâ€™s always room for improvement in my cooking skills.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report identifies several areas where significant improvement is needed to meet international safety standards.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is expected to lead to a marked improvement in public health and sanitation.â€

      • â€œThe study concludes that technological innovation has been a key driver of improvement in agricultural productivity.â€

      • â€œThe governmentâ€™s plan for infrastructure improvement includes building new bridges and railways.â€

Synonyms: Enhancement, advancement, progress, betterment.

Opposite words: Deterioration, decline, worsening, regression.

Where it comes from: From Old French emprouver (to improve, to make better use of).

6.20.24. Foster#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆfÉ’stÉ™/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To encourage or promote the development of something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œfosterâ€ is to actively encourage the growth, development, or formation of something, often a positive quality or relationship.

What it really means: To â€œfosterâ€ means to help something grow or develop. It is used to describe the act of nurturing and encouraging something. For example, a teacher might â€œfoster a love of readingâ€ in their students, or a manager might â€œfoster a sense of teamworkâ€ in their employees.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of encouraging the growth or development of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œfoster a sense of,â€ â€œfoster creativity,â€ â€œfoster development.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe teacher tries to foster creativity in her students.â€

      • â€œWe need to foster a sense of community in our neighborhood.â€

      • â€œHis parents always tried to foster a love of learning in him.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe new educational policy is designed to foster critical thinking skills among young people.â€

      • â€œThe report highlights the importance of providing a supportive environment to foster economic development in the region.â€

      • â€œThe program aims to foster collaboration between different research institutions.â€

      • â€œThe governmentâ€™s initiatives seek to foster a climate of innovation among small businesses.â€

Synonyms: Promote, encourage, stimulate, cultivate, nurture.

Opposite words: Discourage, neglect, hinder, suppress, inhibit.

Where it comes from: From Old English fostrian (to nourish, to bring up).

6.20.25. Invent#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆvÉ›nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To create or design something that has not existed before.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œinventâ€ is to create a new device, process, or idea through original thought and experimentation, that has never existed before.

What it really means: To â€œinventâ€ means to come up with a new idea or to create a new product that no one has thought of before. The word suggests a high degree of originality and creativity. For example, Thomas Edison invented the light bulb. It can also be used informally to mean to make something up or to lie.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of creating something new or making something up.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œinvent a device,â€ â€œinvent a story,â€ â€œinvent a solution.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œMy grandfather likes to invent stories to tell his grandchildren.â€

      • â€œShe invented a new way to organize her books.â€

      • â€œWho do you think will invent the next great thing?â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œScientists are working to invent a new type of battery that can store more energy for longer periods.â€

      • â€œThe report discusses the challenges faced by companies that aim to invent groundbreaking technologies in a highly competitive market.â€

      • â€œThe patent office was created to protect the rights of those who invent new and useful processes.â€

      • â€œThe committee praised the team for their ability to invent a creative solution to a complex engineering problem.â€

Synonyms: Create, devise, originate, design, formulate, coin.

Opposite words: Copy, imitate, reproduce, borrow.

Where it comes from: From Latin invenire (to come upon, to find).

6.20.26. Relieve#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆliËv/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To cause a difficult or unpleasant feeling to become less intense.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrelieveâ€ is to reduce the intensity of pain, distress, or a burden, providing comfort or assistance.

What it really means: To â€œrelieveâ€ means to make a bad situation or a bad feeling better. It is used to describe the act of lessening pain (â€œto relieve a headacheâ€) or stress (â€œto relieve tensionâ€). It can also mean to take over someoneâ€™s duty or position (â€œto relieve the guardâ€).

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of making a bad situation or feeling better.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œrelieve pain,â€ â€œrelieve stress,â€ â€œrelieve a guard.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new medicine can relieve your headache very quickly.â€

      • â€œTalking to a friend can sometimes relieve the stress of a long day.â€

      • â€œIâ€™ll go relieve the babysitter so she can go home.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe governmentâ€™s new policy is intended to relieve the financial burden on low-income families.â€

      • â€œThe report highlights the need for a new program to relieve the overcrowding in the cityâ€™s public transportation system.â€

      • â€œThe charityâ€™s mission is to relieve poverty and hunger in developing countries.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is expected to relieve some of the pressure on overworked medical staff.â€

Synonyms: Ease, soothe, lessen, alleviate, mitigate.

Opposite words: Intensify, increase, aggravate, worsen, burden.

Where it comes from: From Old French relever (to lift up, to raise), from Latin re- (again) + levare (to lighten).

6.20.27. Plentifully#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆplÉ›ntÉªfÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In large amounts; in abundance.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œplentifullyâ€ is to have something in great abundance or in large quantities, far more than what is needed.

What it really means: â€œPlentifullyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that exists in large quantities. It suggests a sense of abundance and a lack of scarcity. For example, if food is available plentifully, there is a lot of it and no one needs to worry about running out.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that exists in large amounts or abundance.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œto be supplied plentifully,â€ â€œavailable plentifully.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe fruit trees in the garden are producing fruit plentifully this year.â€

      • â€œWater is available plentifully in the spring, so we donâ€™t need to worry.â€

      • â€œThe town square was plentifully decorated for the festival.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe regionâ€™s rich soil allows crops to grow plentifully, supporting a large agricultural industry.â€

      • â€œThe report suggests that the company has invested plentifully in research and development over the last decade.â€

      • â€œThe forest provides resources so plentifully that the local population can live sustainably without damaging the ecosystem.â€

      • â€œThe new technology ensures that clean energy can be produced plentifully and at a low cost.â€

Synonyms: Abundantly, copiously, generously, lavishly, profusely.

Opposite words: Scarcely, sparsely, minimally, meagerly, rarely.

Where it comes from: From Old French plente (fullness), from Latin plenus (full).

6.20.28. Breed#

  • Pronunciation: /briËd/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To mate animals to produce young; (Noun) A specific type of animal.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning for the verb is to mate animals or to produce offspring. For the noun, it is a specific type or variety of animal within a species, developed through selective mating.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œbreedâ€ means to produce young, usually of animals. It can be natural, as in wild animals that breed in the spring, or controlled by humans, as in a farmer who breeds cattle. As a noun, a â€œbreedâ€ is a particular type or variety of animal, such as a breed of dog or horse.

When to use it: Use the verb to talk about producing young, or the noun to refer to a specific type of animal.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œbreed animals,â€ â€œto breed true.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa specific breed,â€ â€œa pure breed.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWe are trying to breed our dogs to have a specific coat color.â€

      • â€œMy dog is a mixed breed, so Iâ€™m not sure what kind she is.â€

      • â€œRabbits breed very quickly, which is why there are so many of them.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe study aims to breed a new variety of corn that is resistant to drought.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the importance of preserving certain rare breeds of livestock for genetic diversity.â€

      • â€œScientists are working on a new technique to breed fish that grow faster in aquaculture farms.â€

      • â€œThe animalâ€™s unique characteristics are a result of careful selective breeding over many generations.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Reproduce, procreate, raise; (Noun) Variety, type, kind, strain.

Opposite words: (Verb) Sterilize.

Where it comes from: From Old English brÄ“dan (to give birth to, to nourish).

6.20.29. Rarely#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆrÉ›É™rli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Not often; seldom.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrarelyâ€ is to describe an action that occurs infrequently or at long intervals, suggesting that it is an unusual event.

What it really means: â€œRarelyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that happens very seldom or not often. It is the opposite of â€œoftenâ€ or â€œregularly.â€ For example, if it rarely snows where you live, it means that snowfall is an uncommon event.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that happens very seldom.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œrarely see,â€ â€œrarely happen,â€ â€œrarely used.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œIt rarely rains in the desert, so the plants have to be very tough.â€

      • â€œWe rarely see each other anymore since we moved to different cities.â€

      • â€œI rarely eat fast food because itâ€™s not very healthy.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report suggests that this type of complication rarely occurs in patients who receive the new treatment.â€

      • â€œThe species is so endangered that it is rarely seen in the wild anymore.â€

      • â€œIt is rarely the case that a single factor can explain a complex phenomenon like climate change.â€

      • â€œThe museumâ€™s collection contains artifacts that are so old and fragile they are rarely displayed to the public.â€

Synonyms: Seldom, infrequently, uncommonly, hardly ever.

Opposite words: Often, frequently, regularly, commonly.

Where it comes from: From Old French rare (thin, infrequent).

6.20.30. Excitedly#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªkËˆsaÉªtÉªdli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: With great enthusiasm and eagerness.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œexcitedlyâ€ is to do something with strong feelings of happiness and enthusiasm, showing a great deal of eagerness or anticipation.

What it really means: â€œExcitedlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that is done with great enthusiasm and eagerness. It suggests a sense of anticipation or happiness. For example, if a child opens a present excitedly, they are very happy and eager to see whatâ€™s inside.

When to use it: Use it to describe an action that is done with enthusiasm and eagerness.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œto speak excitedly,â€ â€œto jump excitedly,â€ â€œto wait excitedly.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe children waited excitedly for the birthday party to start.â€

      • â€œShe told me excitedly about her new job.â€

      • â€œHe ran excitedly into the room to show everyone his new toy.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the public reacted excitedly to the news of the new technological breakthrough.â€

      • â€œThe document describes how the early explorers excitedly reported their discoveries back to their home country.â€

      • â€œThe press conference ended as the scientists excitedly prepared to present their findings to a global audience.â€

      • â€œThe new policy was excitedly received by industry leaders who had been lobbying for change.â€

Synonyms: Enthusiastically, eagerly, eagerly, joyfully, passionately, animatedly.

Opposite words: Calmly, sadly, unenthusiastically, reluctantly, apathetically.

Where it comes from: From Latin excitare (to rouse, to stimulate).

6.20.31. Urgently#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÉœËdÊ’É™ntli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that requires immediate action or attention.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œurgentlyâ€ is to do something with a pressing need for immediate action, implying that a delay could have negative consequences.

What it really means: â€œUrgentlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that must be done right away. It conveys a sense of strong need or high priority. For example, if you need to speak to someone urgently, it means the matter cannot wait.

When to use it: Use it to describe an action that needs to be done immediately or with a high priority.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œneed to urgently,â€ â€œrequest urgently,â€ â€œact urgently.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI need you to come to my office urgently.â€

      • â€œThe patient needs to be seen urgently by a doctor.â€

      • â€œThey called me urgently to discuss the new project.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report highlights the urgently required need for new policies to address climate change.â€

      • â€œTo prevent the spread of the virus, the government must act urgently to implement public health measures.â€

      • â€œThe document states that the team must urgently resolve the technical issue to avoid a system-wide failure.â€

      • â€œInternational aid was urgently dispatched to the region following the natural disaster.â€

Synonyms: Immediately, pressingly, critically, desperately, instantly.

Opposite words: Casually, leisurely, slowly, calmly.

Where it comes from: From Latin urgere (to press, to push).

6.20.32. Accessible#

  • Pronunciation: /É™kËˆsÉ›sÉªbÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Easy to approach, enter, or use.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œaccessibleâ€ is the quality of being available or easy to reach, enter, or understand. It implies a lack of barriers.

What it really means: â€œAccessibleâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is easy to reach or use. It can refer to a physical place (â€œthe building is accessible to people in wheelchairsâ€) or information or a service (â€œthe information is not easily accessible onlineâ€).

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is easy to get to or to use.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œaccessible to,â€ â€œeasily accessible,â€ â€œpublicly accessible.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new ramp makes the building accessible to everyone.â€

      • â€œThis book is written in a simple style, so itâ€™s very accessible to beginners.â€

      • â€œThe information is not publicly accessible and requires a password to view.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe governmentâ€™s plan aims to make public transportation more accessible to residents in rural areas.â€

      • â€œThe report emphasizes the need for all educational materials to be digitally accessible to students with disabilities.â€

      • â€œTo ensure the accessible of clean water, the organization is installing new wells in remote villages.â€

      • â€œThe new museum was designed to be easily accessible to both local and international visitors.â€

Synonyms: Reachable, available, approachable, understandable.

Opposite words: Inaccessible, unreachable, unavailable, impenetrable.

Where it comes from: From Latin accessibilis, from accedere (to approach).

6.20.33. Originally#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆrÉªdÊ’ÉªnÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: From the beginning or in the first place.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œoriginallyâ€ is to refer to the initial or foundational state of something, before any changes or developments occurred.

What it really means: â€œOriginallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe how something was at the very start. It is often used to contrast the past state with the present state. For example, a house may have been originally a small cottage, but it has now been renovated and is much larger.

When to use it: Use it when talking about how something was in the beginning.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œoriginally from,â€ â€œoriginally intended,â€ â€œoriginally planned.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe restaurant was originally a small coffee shop.â€

      • â€œHe is originally from Germany, but he now lives in London.â€

      • â€œThe plan was originally to leave at 8 a.m., but weâ€™re running late.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe research article examines the species that originally inhabited the island before human settlement.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the purpose for which the building was originally designed, and how its function has since changed.â€

      • â€œThe data shows that the companyâ€™s market strategy was originally aimed at a younger demographic.â€

      • â€œThe word â€˜awfulâ€™ originally meant â€˜full of aweâ€™ before its meaning changed over time.â€

Synonyms: Initially, at first, primarily, at the outset.

Opposite words: Finally, subsequently, eventually.

Where it comes from: From Latin originalis (primitive).

6.20.34. Inconvenience#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉªnkÉ™nËˆviËniÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) Trouble or difficulty; (Verb) To cause trouble or difficulty.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning is a minor difficulty, problem, or disruption that causes trouble or annoyance, but not significant harm.

What it really means: As a noun, an â€œinconvenienceâ€ is a minor problem or a situation that causes a slight amount of trouble or annoyance. As a verb, to â€œinconvenienceâ€ someone means to cause them a slight amount of trouble or difficulty. Itâ€™s often used with an apology to minimize the issue.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a minor difficulty or to describe the act of causing one.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa slight inconvenience,â€ â€œcause an inconvenience.â€

    • (Verb) â€œinconvenience someone.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œIâ€™m sorry for the inconvenience, but the flight is delayed.â€

      • â€œI hope this doesnâ€™t inconvenience you too much.â€

      • â€œHaving to drive to the next town was a major inconvenience.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the temporary road closure may cause a minor inconvenience to local residents.â€

      • â€œWe apologize for any inconvenience caused by the unexpected system maintenance.â€

      • â€œTo avoid inconvenience, customers are advised to check the service status online before traveling.â€

      • â€œThe new regulations were implemented to prevent future inconveniences for international trade.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Nuisance, hassle, trouble; (Verb) Bother, disturb, trouble.

Opposite words: (Noun) Convenience, ease, comfort; (Verb) Assist, help, accommodate.

Where it comes from: From Latin in- (not) + convenire (to be suitable).

6.20.35. Correctly#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™ËˆrÉ›ktli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that is true or accurate.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcorrectlyâ€ is to do something without error, in a way that is factually or logically right according to a standard.

What it really means: â€œCorrectlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that is done without mistakes. It implies a sense of accuracy and truthfulness. For example, if you answer a question correctly, your answer is right. If you follow instructions correctly, you donâ€™t make any errors.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done without error or in a true way.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œanswer correctly,â€ â€œdo something correctly,â€ â€œspell something correctly.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œMake sure you spell my name correctly.â€

      • â€œI didnâ€™t answer the question correctly on the test.â€

      • â€œIf you follow the instructions correctly, the machine will work perfectly.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œTo ensure the accuracy of the experiment, all variables must be measured correctly and consistently.â€

      • â€œThe report argues that the data has not been interpreted correctly by the opposing researchers.â€

      • â€œThe software must be installed correctly for all its functions to work as intended.â€

      • â€œIt is crucial to cite sources correctly to avoid plagiarism and ensure academic integrity.â€

Synonyms: Accurately, rightly, precisely, properly, truly.

Opposite words: Incorrectly, wrongly, inaccurately, improperly.

Where it comes from: From Latin correctus (to make straight, to improve).

6.20.36. Destruction#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆstrÊŒkÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action or process of causing so much damage that something is destroyed.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdestructionâ€ is the total ruin or demolition of something, to the point where it ceases to exist or is no longer functional.

What it really means: â€œDestructionâ€ is a noun that refers to the act of destroying something or the state of being destroyed. It implies complete ruin, often on a large scale. This can be the destruction of a building, a forest, or an entire civilization.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of ruining or demolishing something, or the state of ruin.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œmass destruction,â€ â€œcause destruction,â€ â€œbring about destruction.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe fire caused the complete destruction of the old house.â€

      • â€œThe earthquake caused a lot of destruction in the city.â€

      • â€œThe flood led to the destruction of crops and homes.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report assesses the level of destruction caused by the hurricane on the coastal infrastructure.â€

      • â€œThe ongoing conflict has led to the widespread destruction of cultural heritage sites.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the environmental destruction caused by deforestation and industrial pollution.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to prevent the destruction of data from cyber attacks.â€

Synonyms: Ruin, devastation, demolition, annihilation, wreckage.

Opposite words: Creation, construction, preservation, restoration, building.

Where it comes from: From Latin destructio (a tearing down).

6.20.37. Angrily#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÃ¦Å‹É¡rÉªli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In an angry manner.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œangrilyâ€ is to do something with feelings of strong displeasure or annoyance, often expressed through a raised voice or aggressive behavior.

What it really means: â€œAngrilyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that is done in an angry way. It tells you that the person doing the action is feeling strong emotions like anger, frustration, or fury. For example, if someone speaks angrily, their tone of voice is sharp and aggressive.

When to use it: Use it to describe an action that is performed in an angry manner.

6.20.38. Excavate#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÉ›kskÉ™veÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To dig out material from the ground.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œexcavateâ€ is to dig a hole or to expose something buried by carefully removing the surrounding material.

What it really means: To â€œexcavateâ€ means to dig a hole or a trench in the ground. It is most often used in archaeology to describe the careful digging to find and remove old artifacts or buildings, or in construction for digging foundations. The word implies a systematic and careful process of removal.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of digging or uncovering something from the ground.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œexcavate a site,â€ â€œexcavate a fossil,â€ â€œexcavate a foundation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWe need to excavate the garden to plant the new trees.â€

      • â€œThe workers are going to excavate a large hole for the swimming pool.â€

      • â€œThe archaeologists plan to excavate the entire ancient city.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe team will excavate the site to a depth of three meters to search for pottery and other artifacts.â€

      • â€œThe report describes the techniques used to excavate the dinosaur fossils from the rock formation without causing damage.â€

      • â€œBefore construction can begin, engineers must excavate the area to prepare the foundation.â€

      • â€œHistorians often use new technology to help them excavate and interpret ancient texts.â€

Synonyms: Dig, unearth, uncover, hollow out, delve.

Opposite words: Bury, fill in, cover up.

Where it comes from: From Latin excavare (to hollow out).

6.20.39. Considerable#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™nËˆsÉªdÉ™rÉ™bÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Notably large in size, amount, or extent.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œconsiderableâ€ is to be large or important enough to be worthy of attention, having a significant size or impact.

What it really means: â€œConsiderableâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is large, great, or important. It is used to emphasize the scale or importance of something. For example, a â€œconsiderable amount of moneyâ€ is a large sum, and a â€œconsiderable challengeâ€ is a difficult one.

When to use it: Use it to emphasize the size, amount, or importance of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa considerable amount,â€ â€œa considerable number,â€ â€œa considerable challenge.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe spent a considerable amount of time on his project.â€

      • â€œThere has been a considerable improvement in the weather today.â€

      • â€œThe new building took a considerable amount of effort to complete.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report shows a considerable increase in consumer spending during the last quarter.â€

      • â€œThe study involved a considerable number of participants to ensure the statistical significance of the results.â€

      • â€œThe transition to a new system presents a considerable challenge for the entire organization.â€

      • â€œThe new dam has had a considerable impact on the local ecosystem and water supply.â€

Synonyms: Substantial, significant, large, great, notable, remarkable.

Opposite words: Insignificant, minor, negligible, trivial, slight.

Where it comes from: From Latin considerare (to look at closely).

6.20.40. Variance#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆveÉ™riÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The fact or quality of being different, or a disagreement.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œvarianceâ€ is the state of being different or a measure of the degree of difference between things, often from a standard or average.

What it really means: â€œVarianceâ€ is a noun that refers to a difference or a disagreement. In a general sense, it means a difference between two or more things (â€œa variance in their opinionsâ€). In a technical or scientific sense, it refers to a statistical measure of how far a set of numbers is spread out from their average value.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a difference or a statistical measure of difference.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa variance in,â€ â€œshow a variance,â€ â€œat variance with.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThereâ€™s a significant variance in the prices of the same item at different stores.â€

      • â€œHis actions were at variance with his stated beliefs.â€

      • â€œThe two weather reports showed a noticeable variance in their predictions.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe study found a high variance in the test scores of students from different educational backgrounds.â€

      • â€œThe report highlights a significant variance between the projected budget and the actual expenditures.â€

      • â€œThe legal document notes a variance in the testimony of the two witnesses.â€

      • â€œIn statistics, variance is a key measure of the dispersion of a set of data points around their mean.â€

Synonyms: Difference, discrepancy, variation, divergence, disagreement, inconsistency.

Opposite words: Agreement, consistency, uniformity, sameness, conformity.

Where it comes from: From Latin varians (varying).

6.20.41. Injure#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÉªndÊ’É™/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

What it really means: To â€œinjureâ€ means to cause harm or damage to a living thing. This can be a physical wound (â€œhe injured his knee playing footballâ€) or a mental harm (â€œhis words injured her feelingsâ€). It suggests an action that results in pain, damage, or suffering.

    • (Verb) â€œinjure oneself,â€ â€œinjure a person,â€ â€œinjure a reputation.â€

      • â€œHe fell and injured his ankle.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report details the number of people who were injured during the natural disaster.â€

      • â€œThe company was fined for failing to protect its workers, resulting in several employees being injured on the job.â€

      • â€œA strong policy is needed to prevent activities that might injure the delicate ecosystem of the protected forest.â€

      • â€œThe lawyer argued that the defendantâ€™s actions injured the reputation of the company.â€

Synonyms: Harm, hurt, damage, wound, impair, maim.

Opposite words: Heal, cure, mend, help, protect.

Where it comes from: From Latin injuria (an injury, wrong).

  • Pronunciation: /treÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A distinguishing quality or characteristic.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œtraitâ€ is a specific quality, characteristic, or feature that defines or distinguishes a person, an animal, or a plant.

What it really means: A â€œtraitâ€ is a specific quality or characteristic of a person or a thing. Itâ€™s often used to talk about personality, such as being kind or honest (â€œa key trait of his personalityâ€). It can also be a physical characteristic that is passed down genetically.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a distinguishing quality or characteristic.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa personality trait,â€ â€œa genetic trait,â€ â€œa distinguishing trait.â€

      • â€œHonesty is a trait I value highly in a friend.â€

Synonyms: Characteristic, quality, feature, attribute, property, aspect.

Where it comes from: From Old French trait (a stroke, a line).

6.20.43. Insufficiently#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉªnsÉ™ËˆfÉªÊƒÉ™ntli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: To an inadequate degree; not enough.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œinsufficientlyâ€ is to do something in an inadequate or lacking way, falling short of what is required or needed.

What it really means: â€œInsufficientlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that is done without a sufficient amount of something. It suggests a lack of something that is needed, such as money, time, or effort. For example, if a plant is watered insufficiently, it doesnâ€™t get enough water and may die.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done with a lack of what is needed.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œinsufficiently funded,â€ â€œinsufficiently prepared,â€ â€œinsufficiently tested.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe team was insufficiently prepared for the difficult match.â€

      • â€œThe governmentâ€™s plan was insufficiently funded, so it couldnâ€™t be completed.â€

      • â€œThe evidence was insufficiently clear to make a decision.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report argues that the current public transportation system is insufficiently developed to meet the cityâ€™s growing population.â€

      • â€œThe study was criticized for being insufficiently rigorous in its methodology and data collection.â€

      • â€œA key finding of the research is that the policy was insufficiently communicated to the public.â€

      • â€œThe new software, which was insufficiently tested before its release, has been causing numerous technical problems.â€

Synonyms: Inadequately, lacking, deficiently, poorly, sparingly.

Opposite words: Sufficiently, adequately, fully, completely, properly.

Where it comes from: From Latin in- (not) + sufficere (to be enough).

6.20.44. Honestly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÉ’nÉªstli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a truthful or fair way.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œhonestlyâ€ is to do something with truthfulness and sincerity, without lying, cheating, or deceit.

What it really means: â€œHonestlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that is done truthfully. It can mean telling the truth (â€œto answer a question honestlyâ€) or acting in a fair and upright manner (â€œto deal honestly with a customerâ€). It is also used conversationally to add emphasis, meaning â€œto be truthful with you.â€

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done truthfully or fairly.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œto speak honestly,â€ â€œto deal honestly,â€ â€œtell me honestly.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe answered all the questions honestly.â€

      • â€œTo be honestly with you, I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s a good idea.â€

      • â€œIf you behave honestly, you will always be trusted.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe survey asked participants to honestly report their daily habits and consumption patterns.â€

      • â€œThe report commends the company for its commitment to acting honestly and ethically in all its business dealings.â€

      • â€œFor a scientific study to be valid, all researchers must honestly report their findings, even if they contradict their hypothesis.â€

      • â€œThe document advises that all financial data be recorded honestly and transparently to avoid legal issues.â€

Synonyms: Truthfully, sincerely, candidly, fairly, ethically.

Opposite words: Dishonestly, deceitfully, untruthfully, fraudulently.

Where it comes from: From Old French honeste, from Latin honestus (honorable, respectable).

6.20.45. Consequent#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkÉ’nsÉªkwÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Happening as a result of something else.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œconsequentâ€ is to be a direct result or effect of a preceding event or action.

What it really means: â€œConsequentâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that happens as a direct result of something else. It is often used to link a cause and effect. For example, a flood could be a consequent effect of heavy rainfall. It is less common than its related adverb, â€œconsequently.â€

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is a direct result of a previous event.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œconsequent effect,â€ â€œconsequent change,â€ â€œconsequent result.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHis lack of sleep had a consequent effect on his mood.â€

      • â€œThe traffic jam was a consequent result of the car accident.â€

      • â€œThe increase in prices was a consequent change after the new tax was introduced.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report examines the economic effects of the policy and the consequent changes in consumer behavior.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the environmental damage and the consequent need for protective measures.â€

      • â€œThe study found that a rise in global temperatures has a consequent impact on melting polar ice caps.â€

      • â€œThe consequent need for a more sustainable energy source became evident after the oil crisis.â€

Synonyms: Resulting, resultant, ensuing, following, succeeding.

Opposite words: Antecedent, preceding, prior, initial.

Where it comes from: From Latin consequens (following).

6.20.46. Distinction#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆstÉªÅ‹kÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A difference or contrast between similar things or people.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdistinctionâ€ is the quality or fact of being different, especially a clear difference that makes one thing or person stand out from others.

What it really means: A â€œdistinctionâ€ is a difference between things that are otherwise similar. It can be a subtle difference that requires careful observation to notice (â€œthe distinction between the two wordsâ€). It can also mean a mark of honor or a special quality (â€œto graduate with distinctionâ€).

When to use it: Use it to refer to a difference or to a special honor.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œmake a distinction,â€ â€œa clear distinction,â€ â€œa mark of distinction.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œItâ€™s important to make a distinction between what is a fact and what is an opinion.â€

      • â€œThere is a clear distinction between his writing style and hers.â€

      • â€œHe graduated from university with distinction.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report draws a crucial distinction between correlation and causation in the data.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s findings are important for making a distinction between the two types of bacteria.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the key distinctions between the two competing theories of economic development.â€

      • â€œA distinction must be made between the companyâ€™s public image and its internal practices.â€

Synonyms: Difference, contrast, differentiation, separation, nuance.

Opposite words: Sameness, similarity, conformity, resemblance, uniformity.

Where it comes from: From Latin distinctio (a separation).

6.20.47. Confuse#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™nËˆfjuËz/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To make someone unable to think clearly or understand.
