Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œconfuseâ€ is to mix up or make something unclear, causing a lack of mental clarity or order.

What it really means: To â€œconfuseâ€ means to make someone feel unable to think clearly or understand something. It can also mean to mistake one thing for another (â€œI always confuse you with your brotherâ€). The word suggests a lack of order or clarity, either in a personâ€™s mind or in a situation.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of making something unclear or making someone unable to think clearly.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œconfuse someone,â€ â€œconfuse A with B,â€ â€œget confused.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe complicated instructions really confuse me.â€

      • â€œI always confuse you and your sister because you look so much alike.â€

      • â€œI think heâ€™s trying to confuse us so we donâ€™t know the truth.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe reportâ€™s use of jargon may confuse readers who are not experts in the field.â€

      • â€œThe data is presented in a way that is likely to confuse the public about the real state of the economy.â€

      • â€œItâ€™s easy to confuse the symptoms of the common cold with those of the flu.â€

      • â€œThe court case was complicated and designed to confuse the jury about the facts.â€

Synonyms: Perplex, bewilder, muddle, mystify, mix up.

Opposite words: Clarify, explain, enlighten, simplify, distinguish.

Where it comes from: From Latin confundere (to pour together).

6.20.48. Resolution#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒrÉ›zÉ™ËˆluËÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The act of finding a solution to a problem; a formal decision.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œresolutionâ€ is the firm determination to do something, or the process of finding a solution to a problem or conflict.

What it really means: A â€œresolutionâ€ is a solution to a problem (â€œthe resolution of a conflictâ€) or a firm decision to do something (â€œa New Yearâ€™s resolutionâ€). It can also be a formal statement of opinion or a promise. In technical terms, it refers to the quality of an image, showing its level of detail.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a solution, a firm decision, or a formal statement.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œfind a resolution,â€ â€œpass a resolution,â€ â€œhigh resolution.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWe need to find a peaceful resolution to our disagreement.â€

      • â€œMy New Yearâ€™s resolution is to exercise more.â€

      • â€œThe computer screen has a very high resolution, so the image is very clear.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report recommends a number of steps to achieve a rapid resolution of the conflict.â€

      • â€œThe United Nations Security Council passed a resolution condemning the actions of the aggressor nation.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s primary goal is to find a resolution to the problem of air pollution in urban areas.â€

      • â€œThe new cameraâ€™s high resolution allows for the detailed analysis of microscopic images.â€

Synonyms: Solution, conclusion, decision, determination, firmness.

Opposite words: Indecision, ambiguity, irresolution, problem, dispute.

Where it comes from: From Latin resolutio (a loosening, an analysis).

6.20.49. Component#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™mËˆpÉ™ÊŠnÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A part of a larger whole.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcomponentâ€ is a constituent part or element of a larger system or whole, which is necessary for its function.

What it really means: A â€œcomponentâ€ is one of the parts that make up a larger whole. For example, a carâ€™s engine is a component of the car. It can be a physical part of a machine or an abstract part of an idea or a system.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a part of a larger whole.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa key component,â€ â€œan essential component,â€ â€œa single component.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe engine is a very important component of the car.â€

      • â€œTrust is a key component of any healthy relationship.â€

      • â€œThe recipe has several main components that you need to prepare separately.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report analyzes the various components of the new economic policy and their potential impact.â€

      • â€œA successful education system must have a strong vocational component in addition to academic learning.â€

      • â€œThe study concludes that a lack of protein is a missing component in the diet of many people in the region.â€

      • â€œThe rocket is made up of thousands of individual components, all working together to function as a whole.â€

Synonyms: Part, element, section, piece, ingredient, constituent.

Opposite words: Whole, entirety, totality, sum.

Where it comes from: From Latin componere (to put together).

6.20.50. Thick#

  • Pronunciation: /Î¸Éªk/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Having a large distance between opposite sides; not thin.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œthickâ€ is to have a large or substantial dimension in one direction, such as a large depth or diameter, often suggesting solidity or density.

What it really means: â€œThickâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is not thin. It can refer to a physical object (â€œa thick bookâ€) or a fluid (â€thick soupâ€). It can also be used to describe air that is difficult to see through (â€œa thick fogâ€) or to describe something that is dense or plentiful (â€thick hairâ€).

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is not thin, dense, or plentiful.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œthick fog,â€ â€œa thick book,â€ â€œa thick accent.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI need a thick blanket for the cold weather.â€

      • â€œThe forest was so thick we couldnâ€™t see the path.â€

      • â€œHe has a very thick accent, so itâ€™s hard to understand him.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the outer layer of the material is a thick coating of protective plastic.â€

      • â€œThe study found that in areas with a thick canopy of trees, the air quality is significantly better.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of using thick glass for the windows to provide better insulation and soundproofing.â€

      • â€œThe thick walls of the ancient castle have survived many battles over the centuries.â€

Synonyms: Dense, broad, bulky, deep, substantial.

Opposite words: Thin, narrow, fine, sparse, watery.

Where it comes from: From Old English Ã¾icce (dense, compact).

6.20.51. Domestic#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉ™ËˆmÉ›stÉªk/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Adj) Relating to the home or family; (Noun) A household servant.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning is to be related to oneâ€™s own home, family, or country, as opposed to foreign or public.

What it really means: â€œDomesticâ€ is an adjective that refers to things related to the home, the family, or oneâ€™s own country. For example, â€œdomestic dutiesâ€ are household chores, and â€œdomestic flightsâ€ are flights within a single country. It is often used to distinguish from â€œforeign.â€

When to use it: Use it to describe things related to the home or oneâ€™s own country.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œdomestic violence,â€ â€œdomestic animal,â€ â€œdomestic affairs.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe dog is a domestic animal, so itâ€™s used to living with humans.â€

      • â€œMy job requires a lot of travel, both domestic and international.â€

      • â€œWe need to deal with a few domestic issues before we go on vacation.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report analyzes the growth of domestic tourism as a key driver of the national economy.â€

      • â€œThe governmentâ€™s new policy focuses on improving domestic production and reducing reliance on imports.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the need for a stronger legal framework to address cases of domestic violence.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how domestic energy consumption has changed over the last two decades.â€

Synonyms: (Adj) Household, family, internal, national, home-based; (Noun) Servant.

Opposite words: Foreign, international, global, external, public.

Where it comes from: From Latin domesticus (of the house).

6.20.52. Sustainable#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™ËˆsteÉªnÉ™bÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Able to be maintained at a certain rate or level.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsustainableâ€ is the ability to be maintained or upheld over a long period without exhausting natural resources or causing severe environmental damage.

What it really means: â€œSustainableâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that can be continued or maintained without a negative impact on the future. It is most often used in the context of the environment, such as â€œsustainable energyâ€ or a â€œsustainable economy.â€ The idea is to meet the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that can be maintained over time without causing harm.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œsustainable development,â€ â€œsustainable energy,â€ â€œsustainable living.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWe need to find a more sustainable way to manage our waste.â€

      • â€œThe restaurant focuses on using sustainable ingredients from local farms.â€

      • â€œRiding a bike to work is a sustainable form of transportation.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report outlines a new strategy for sustainable economic development that prioritizes environmental protection.â€

      • â€œThe study explores the challenges of transitioning to a sustainable energy system based entirely on renewable resources.â€

      • â€œThe concept of sustainable agriculture involves farming methods that do not deplete natural resources.â€

      • â€œInternational agreements are in place to ensure sustainable fishing practices in our oceans.â€

Synonyms: Viable, long-term, eco-friendly, maintainable, durable.

Opposite words: Unsustainable, temporary, unviable, damaging.

Where it comes from: From Latin sustinere (to hold up, to support).

6.20.53. Acceptability#

  • Pronunciation: /É™kËŒsÉ›ptÉ™ËˆbÉªlÉªti/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The quality of being satisfactory and able to be accepted.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œacceptabilityâ€ is the quality or state of being considered satisfactory, worthy, or suitable to be accepted by others or to meet a certain standard.

What it really means: â€œAcceptabilityâ€ is a noun that refers to the quality of being acceptable. It is used to talk about whether something meets a certain standard, rule, or expectation. For example, the â€œacceptability of the reportâ€ refers to whether the report is good enough to be approved.

When to use it: Use it to talk about the quality of being acceptable or satisfactory.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œthe acceptability of,â€ â€œto check for acceptability,â€ â€œa high degree of acceptability.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWe need to check the acceptability of the new products with our customers.â€

      • â€œThe acceptability of the new rule was discussed for a long time.â€

      • â€œThe low price gives this new car a high degree of acceptability in the market.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report assesses the public acceptability of the proposed new tax policy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the social and cultural factors that influence the acceptability of genetically modified foods.â€

      • â€œThe legal document outlines the criteria for the acceptability of evidence in court.â€

      • â€œThe new medical treatment must undergo rigorous testing to prove its safety and acceptability before it can be used on humans.â€

Synonyms: Acceptableness, suitability, approval, legitimacy, appropriateness.

Opposite words: Unacceptability, unsuitability, disapproval, rejection.

Where it comes from: From Latin acceptare (to take, to receive).

6.20.54. Intervention#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉªntÉ™ËˆvÉ›nÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action of becoming involved in a situation to influence its outcome.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œinterventionâ€ is the act of stepping in or interfering in a situation to influence its course, often to prevent a negative outcome.

What it really means: An â€œinterventionâ€ is the act of getting involved in a situation to change what is happening. This can be a military intervention in a country, a medical intervention to save a patient, or a social intervention to help a person with a problem. The word suggests a deliberate and often decisive action.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of getting involved in a situation.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œmilitary intervention,â€ â€œa medical intervention,â€ â€œrequire intervention.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe argument was so bad that it required the intervention of a teacher.â€

      • â€œI think he needs a medical intervention to help with his addiction.â€

      • â€œThe United Nations is considering a military intervention to stop the fighting.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report calls for a government intervention to regulate the financial sector and prevent future crises.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the effectiveness of early educational intervention on a childâ€™s long-term academic success.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the conditions under which international intervention is legally permissible.â€

      • â€œA swift intervention by the emergency services prevented a much larger disaster.â€

Synonyms: Interference, involvement, mediation, intercession, action, influence.

Opposite words: Non-intervention, abstention, noninterference, neglect.

Where it comes from: From Latin intervenire (to come between).

6.20.55. Fail#

  • Pronunciation: /feÉªl/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To be unsuccessful in achieving something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œfailâ€ is to be unsuccessful in achieving a goal or a desired outcome, or to fall short of an expectation.

What it really means: To â€œfailâ€ means to be unsuccessful at something. It can refer to a student who fails an exam, a machine that fails to work, or a plan that fails. The word suggests a lack of success or an inability to meet a standard.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of being unsuccessful or not working properly.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œfail a test,â€ â€œa plan fails,â€ â€œfail to do something.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI hope I donâ€™t fail my driving test this time.â€

      • â€œThe experiment failed because we used the wrong chemicals.â€

      • â€œHe failed to show up for our meeting, and Iâ€™m very upset.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report concludes that the project failed to meet its key objectives due to a lack of funding and poor management.â€

      • â€œWhen a governmentâ€™s policies fail to address the needs of its people, social unrest may follow.â€

      • â€œThe study examines why some new businesses fail within their first five years.â€

      • â€œThe new system is designed to notify users immediately if any of its components fail to operate correctly.â€

Synonyms: Flop, be unsuccessful, fall short, miscarry, disappoint.

Opposite words: Succeed, pass, achieve, triumph, win.

Where it comes from: From Old French faillir (to be lacking, to fall short).

6.20.56. Simultaneous#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒsÉªmÉ™lËˆteÉªniÉ™s/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Occurring at the same time.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsimultaneousâ€ is to happen or exist at the exact same time, indicating a synchrony of events.

What it really means: â€œSimultaneousâ€ is an adjective used to describe two or more things that happen at the same time. For example, simultaneous translation means that a speaker is being translated at the same time they are speaking. It suggests that there is no time lag between the events.

When to use it: Use it to describe things that happen at the same time.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œsimultaneous events,â€ â€œsimultaneous actions,â€ â€œsimultaneous translation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe two news channels were reporting the same story at the same time, giving a simultaneous broadcast.â€

      • â€œThe show has simultaneous performances in two different cities.â€

      • â€œYou canâ€™t do both tasks simultaneously; you have to do one after the other.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report analyzes the impact of two simultaneous economic policies on the national market.â€

      • â€œThe experiment requires the simultaneous measurement of temperature and pressure at several different points.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the legal challenges of two simultaneous lawsuits being brought against the company.â€

      • â€œThe study of astronomy often involves the simultaneous observation of the same star from different locations.â€

Synonyms: Concurrent, coexisting, synchronized, parallel, concurrent.

Opposite words: Separate, successive, sequential, consecutive.

Where it comes from: From Latin simul (at the same time).

6.20.57. Coherently#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™ÊŠËˆhÉªÉ™rÉ™ntli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that is logical and well-organized.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcoherentlyâ€ is to do something in a logical, consistent, and easy-to-understand manner, with all parts fitting together.

What it really means: â€œCoherentlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that is done in a way that is clear and easy to understand. It is often used to describe speech or writing that is well-organized and logical. For example, if you explain a complex idea coherently, you explain it in a way that makes sense and is easy to follow.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a clear, logical, and well-organized way.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œto speak coherently,â€ â€œto write coherently,â€ â€œto think coherently.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe was so tired that he could barely speak coherently.â€

      • â€œI need to write this essay coherently so my teacher can understand it.â€

      • â€œThe meeting went well because everyone was able to present their ideas coherently.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe reportâ€™s conclusions are presented coherently and are supported by a strong body of evidence.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s methodology is not explained coherently, which raises questions about the validity of its findings.â€

      • â€œFor an argument to be persuasive, it must be developed and articulated coherently.â€

      • â€œThe new software is designed to help users organize their thoughts and write more coherently.â€

Synonyms: Logically, clearly, consistently, rationally, lucidly.

Opposite words: Incoherently, illogically, chaotically, confusedly.

Where it comes from: From Latin cohaerere (to stick together).

6.20.58. Recession#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆsÉ›ÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A period of temporary economic decline.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrecessionâ€ is a period of general economic decline characterized by a decrease in economic activity, trade, and employment.

What it really means: A â€œrecessionâ€ is a period of time when the economy of a country is getting worse. This usually involves a decrease in business activity, a rise in unemployment, and a general feeling of financial uncertainty. Itâ€™s a natural part of the economic cycle, but a very difficult one.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a period of economic decline.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa deep recession,â€ â€œa global recession,â€ â€œto fall into a recession.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWe are worried about the economy going into a recession.â€

      • â€œMany people lost their jobs during the last recession.â€

      • â€œThe government is taking steps to prevent a recession.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report predicts that the country will enter a recession in the next two quarters if current trends continue.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the social impact of the 2008 global recession on unemployment rates and housing prices.â€

      • â€œThe governmentâ€™s response to the recession included a stimulus package to boost consumer spending.â€

      • â€œDuring a recession, businesses typically cut back on investment and hiring to reduce costs.â€

Synonyms: Downturn, slump, depression, decline, stagnation.

Opposite words: Boom, expansion, growth, prosperity, recovery.

Where it comes from: From Latin recessus (a going back).

6.20.59. Attribute#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÃ¦trÉªbjuËt/ (Noun), /É™ËˆtrÉªbjuËt/ (Verb)

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) A quality or characteristic; (Verb) To regard something as being caused by a particular person or thing.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is a characteristic quality or feature of a person or thing. The core meaning of the verb is to explain something by pointing to its cause.

What it really means: As a noun, an â€œattributeâ€ is a quality or characteristic of a person or thing (â€œone of her best attributes is her kindnessâ€). As a verb, to â€œattributeâ€ something to someone or something else means to say that they are the cause of it (â€œwe attribute the success to the hard work of the teamâ€).

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a quality, or the verb to explain a cause.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa key attribute,â€ â€œpersonal attributes.â€

    • (Verb) â€œattribute something to,â€ â€œto be attributed to.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe has all the attributes of a good leader.â€

      • â€œI attribute my success to a lot of hard work.â€

      • â€œThe failure of the project was attributed to a lack of communication.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report identifies several key attributes that are essential for success in the field of engineering.â€

      • â€œThe study concludes that the decline in the bird population can be attributed to changes in the local environment.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of honesty and integrity as core attributes of a public official.â€

      • â€œThe economic recovery was widely attributed to the governmentâ€™s timely and decisive policy interventions.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Quality, trait, feature, characteristic; (Verb) Ascribe, assign, credit, impute.

Opposite words: (Verb) Discredit, disavow, dissociate.

Where it comes from: From Latin attribuere (to assign).

6.20.60. Consume#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™nËˆsjuËm/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To eat, drink, or use up something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œconsumeâ€ is to use something up, often completely, whether it be food, resources, or energy.

What it really means: To â€œconsumeâ€ means to use something up. This can be food (â€œto consume a mealâ€), resources (â€œto consume a lot of electricityâ€), or goods (â€œto consume productsâ€). The word suggests an act of using or taking something into oneself or a system.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of eating, drinking, or using something up.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œconsume a product,â€ â€œconsume energy,â€ â€œconsume a lot of time.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWe consume a lot of fresh vegetables in our home.â€

      • â€œThe old car consumes a lot of fuel.â€

      • â€œThe project will consume all of my time this week.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report shows that households consume a significant amount of electricity for heating and cooling.â€

      • â€œThe study found that the average person consumes more processed food today than in the past.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the need for policies that encourage people to consume goods and services in a more sustainable way.â€

      • â€œModern factories are designed to consume less energy and produce less waste than older models.â€

Synonyms: Use up, utilize, eat, drink, devour, absorb.

Opposite words: Save, conserve, preserve, produce, create.

Where it comes from: From Latin consumere (to take completely).

6.20.61. Inevitably#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªËˆnÉ›vÉªtÉ™bli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that is certain to happen; unavoidably.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œinevitablyâ€ is that an outcome is certain to occur due to the circumstances, implying a sense of fate or logical necessity.

What it really means: â€œInevitablyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is sure to happen and cannot be avoided. It is often used when a result is a logical or predictable consequence of a situation. For example, if you donâ€™t study for a test, you will inevitably fail.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is certain to happen and cannot be prevented.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œinevitably lead to,â€ â€œinevitably result in,â€ â€œinevitably happen.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œIf you stay out in the sun without protection, youâ€™ll inevitably get sunburned.â€

      • â€œThe constant rain will inevitably lead to flooding.â€

      • â€œThe project was so behind schedule that it was inevitably going to fail.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report argues that the current economic policies will inevitably lead to a greater disparity between the rich and the poor.â€

      • â€œTo ignore the warnings about climate change will inevitably result in severe consequences for future generations.â€

      • â€œThe document states that the companyâ€™s expansion into new markets will inevitably create new jobs.â€

      • â€œThe failure of the first attempt was inevitably followed by a more carefully planned second effort.â€

Synonyms: Unavoidably, certainly, surely, predictably, bound to happen.

Opposite words: Avoidably, preventably, possibly, uncertainly.

Where it comes from: From Latin inevitabilis (unavoidable).

6.20.62. Resistance#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆzÉªstÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The act of opposing or withstanding something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œresistanceâ€ is the force or action that opposes or hinders another force, movement, or idea.

What it really means: â€œResistanceâ€ is a noun that refers to the act of opposing something or the power to withstand something. It can be a physical force, such as the air resistance that slows down a moving car, or a social or political opposition, such as the resistance of a population to an oppressive government.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of opposing or withstanding something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œoffer resistance,â€ â€œstrong resistance,â€ â€œpolitical resistance.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI met with a lot of resistance from my parents about my career choice.â€

      • â€œThe car is designed to have very little air resistance to make it more fuel-efficient.â€

      • â€œThe medication helps to build your bodyâ€™s resistance to the virus.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report highlights the strong resistance from local communities to the new construction project.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the increasing resistance of certain bacteria to common antibiotics.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the history of political resistance to colonial rule in the region.â€

      • â€œThe new law met with considerable resistance from civil liberty groups.â€

Synonyms: Opposition, defiance, stand, struggle, opposition.

Opposite words: Acceptance, compliance, submission, cooperation, obedience.

Where it comes from: From Old French resister, from Latin resistere (to stand back, to oppose).

6.20.63. Approach#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆprÉ™ÊŠtÊƒ/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To come near or nearer to something; (Noun) A way of dealing with a situation.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the verb is to move closer to something. The core meaning of the noun is a method or strategy used to deal with something.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œapproachâ€ means to come closer to a person, place, or thing. As a noun, an â€œapproachâ€ is a way of dealing with a problem or a way of thinking about something. For example, a scientific approach is a method of solving problems based on scientific principles.

When to use it: Use the verb to describe coming closer, or the noun to refer to a method.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œapproach a topic,â€ â€œapproach a deadline.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa different approach,â€ â€œa scientific approach.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œAs we approach the city, the traffic gets worse.â€

      • â€œI think we need a new approach to solving this problem.â€

      • â€œThe deadline for the project is approaching quickly.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report outlines a new approach to urban planning that prioritizes green spaces.â€

      • â€œThe study requires researchers to approach the data with a high degree of objectivity and care.â€

      • â€œThe new educational program takes a hands-on approach to teaching science.â€

      • â€œThe document states that the company must approach its expansion plans with caution to avoid financial risk.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Come near, advance, move toward; (Noun) Method, strategy, manner, way.

Opposite words: (Verb) Recede, retreat, depart, leave; (Noun) N/A.

Where it comes from: From Old French approchier (to draw near).

6.20.64. Raised#

  • Pronunciation: /reÉªzd/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb (past tense/past participle), Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) Lifted or brought to a higher position; (Adj) Elevated or lifted.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œraisedâ€ is to be moved to a higher level, whether physically, in a social context (as in â€œraised a childâ€), or in an abstract sense (as in â€œraised a questionâ€).

What it really means: â€œRaisedâ€ is the past tense of the verb â€œto raise.â€ It means to have lifted something up (â€œhe raised his handâ€) or to have increased something (â€œthe company raised the pricesâ€). As an adjective, it means elevated above the surrounding area (â€œa raised platformâ€). It can also refer to the process of bringing up a child.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of lifting or increasing something, or as an adjective for something that is elevated.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œraised a question,â€ â€œraised prices,â€ â€œraised a child.â€

    • (Adjective) â€œa raised platform,â€ â€œraised eyebrows.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe raised his hand to ask a question.â€

      • â€œMy parents raised me to be honest and kind.â€

      • â€œThe company raised the price of coffee by 10%.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report highlights several key issues that were raised by the committee during the meeting.â€

      • â€œThe study found that children who were raised in a supportive environment tend to perform better academically.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the new policy, which has raised concerns among environmental groups.â€

      • â€œThe governmentâ€™s new initiative is intended to improve the standard of living for all citizens and has raised hopes among the poor.â€

Synonyms: Lifted, elevated, increased, brought up, enhanced.

Opposite words: Lowered, dropped, decreased, reduced, diminished.

Where it comes from: From Old English rÃ¦ran (to raise).

6.20.65. Memory#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆmÉ›mÉ™ri/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The faculty of the mind by which information is encoded, stored, and retrieved.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œmemoryâ€ is the mental capacity to recall past events and information, as well as the specific recollections themselves.

What it really means: â€œMemoryâ€ is a noun that refers to the ability to remember things from the past. It can also refer to a specific recollection (â€œI have a fond memory of my childhoodâ€). In computing, it refers to the part of a computer that stores data (â€œthe computerâ€™s memory is fullâ€).

When to use it: Use it to refer to the ability to remember or a specific recollection.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œhave a good memory,â€ â€œa fond memory,â€ â€œshort-term memory.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have a terrible memory for names.â€

      • â€œVisiting my old school brought back a lot of good memories.â€

      • â€œThis computer has enough memory to run all the programs I need.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report examines the effects of aging on a personâ€™s short-term and long-term memory.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s findings suggest that regular exercise can improve cognitive functions, including memory.â€

      • â€œThe document serves as a way of preserving the memory of a historical event for future generations.â€

      • â€œThe new software is designed to optimize a computerâ€™s memory usage for better performance.â€

Synonyms: Recall, remembrance, recollection, retention.

Opposite words: Forgetfulness, amnesia, oblivion.

Where it comes from: From Latin memoria (mindful, remembering).

6.20.66. Appeal#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆpiËl/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To make a serious or urgent request; (Noun) A serious or urgent request.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the verb is to make an earnest plea. The core meaning of the noun is a strong request for help or a quality that makes something attractive.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œappealâ€ means to make a formal or serious request, often for help (â€œto appeal for calmâ€). As a noun, an â€œappealâ€ is such a request (â€œa public appeal for donationsâ€). It can also refer to the quality of being attractive or interesting (â€œthe movie has a wide appealâ€).

When to use it: Use the verb to describe making a serious request, and the noun to refer to such a request or a quality of attractiveness.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œappeal for help,â€ â€œappeal to authority.â€

    • (Noun) â€œpublic appeal,â€ â€œmass appeal,â€ â€œsex appeal.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI appeal to you to help me with this problem.â€

      • â€œThe charity launched a new appeal to raise money for the victims.â€

      • â€œThe simple design of the phone has a lot of appeal for many users.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report concludes with a powerful appeal to the international community for a unified response to the crisis.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the factors that contribute to the broad appeal of social media among different age groups.â€

      • â€œThe lawyerâ€™s final appeal to the court was based on new evidence that had not been previously considered.â€

      • â€œThe document states that the company plans to appeal the judgeâ€™s decision to a higher court.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Plead, beg, request, petition; (Noun) Plea, petition, request, charm.

Opposite words: (Verb) Reject, deny, refuse; (Noun) Rejection, repulsion.

Where it comes from: From Latin appellare (to address, to call upon).

6.20.67. Suspension#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™ËˆspÉ›nÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action of stopping or delaying something for a period of time.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsuspensionâ€ is the temporary stopping, removal, or hanging of something, often as a penalty or to hold something in a position.

What it really means: â€œSuspensionâ€ is a noun that refers to a temporary stop or delay of something. This can be the suspension of a student from school as a punishment, the suspension of a project due to a lack of funds, or the suspension of a carâ€™s wheels from the chassis. The word implies a temporary halt rather than a permanent end.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a temporary stopping or a temporary removal from a role.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa temporary suspension,â€ â€œa school suspension,â€ â€œthe suspension of services.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe was given a week-long suspension from the football team.â€

      • â€œThe suspension of the train service caused a lot of problems for commuters.â€

      • â€œThe carâ€™s suspension system is designed to provide a smooth ride.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report recommends the temporary suspension of all flights to and from the region to prevent the spread of the virus.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the effects of a school suspension on a studentâ€™s long-term academic performance.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the legal grounds for the suspension of a companyâ€™s business license.â€

      • â€œThe city council voted for the suspension of the new construction project pending further environmental review.â€

Synonyms: Postponement, delay, interruption, halt, pause.

Opposite words: Continuation, resumption, permanence, commencement.

Where it comes from: From Latin suspensio (a hanging up).

6.20.68. Implicitly#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªmËˆplÉªsÉªtli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that is not directly stated but is understood.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œimplicitlyâ€ is to do something in a way that is understood or suggested without being stated explicitly, relying on context or an unwritten agreement.

What it really means: â€œImplicitlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is understood or suggested without being directly said. It is the opposite of â€œexplicitly.â€ For example, if a manager trusts an employee, they implicitly give them the freedom to make decisions without asking for permission every time.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is understood without being directly stated.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œimplicitly understand,â€ â€œimplicitly agree,â€ â€œimplicitly assume.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWhen he agreed to help, he implicitly promised he would finish the task.â€

      • â€œTheir friendship was based on an implicitly understood code of loyalty.â€

      • â€œShe implicitly knew that she wasnâ€™t allowed to talk about the secret.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report argues that the governmentâ€™s current policies implicitly favor large corporations over small businesses.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s findings implicitly suggest a correlation between diet and health, even though it is not explicitly stated.â€

      • â€œThe document states that the two parties have a contract based on a set of implicitly agreed-upon terms.â€

      • â€œThe artistâ€™s work implicitly critiques the social norms of the era in which he lived.â€

Synonyms: Tacitly, indirectly, unspokenly, unstatedly, by implication.

Opposite words: Explicitly, directly, openly, overtly, clearly.

Where it comes from: From Latin implicitus (entangled, involved).

6.20.69. Appropriate#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆprÉ™ÊŠpriÉ™t/ (Adj) /É™ËˆprÉ™ÊŠpriËŒeÉªt/ (Verb)

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Adj) Suitable or proper in the circumstances; (Verb) To take something for oneâ€™s own use, typically without the ownerâ€™s permission.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the adjective is to be fitting or suitable for a specific situation. The core meaning of the verb is to take something for a particular use, often in an unauthorized manner.

What it really means: As an adjective, â€œappropriateâ€ means suitable, correct, or proper for a particular situation (â€appropriate clothing for the eventâ€). As a verb, to â€œappropriateâ€ means to take something for yourself without permission (â€œto appropriate public fundsâ€). The verb has a negative connotation, suggesting theft or misuse.

When to use it: Use the adjective to describe something suitable, or the verb to describe taking something for your own use.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œappropriate for,â€ â€œsocially appropriate,â€ â€œitâ€™s not appropriate.â€

    • (Verb) â€œappropriate funds,â€ â€œappropriate resources.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œMake sure you wear appropriate clothing for the job interview.â€

      • â€œThatâ€™s not an appropriate thing to say in front of children.â€

      • â€œThe government plans to appropriate land for the new highway.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report concludes that the companyâ€™s response to the crisis was both timely and appropriate.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the social cues that determine what constitutes appropriate behavior in different cultural contexts.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the legal grounds for the government to appropriate private property for public use.â€

      • â€œThe new regulations were put in place to ensure that all financial resources are used in the most appropriate way.â€

Synonyms: (Adj) Suitable, proper, fitting, apt; (Verb) Seize, take, commandeer, steal.

Opposite words: (Adj) Inappropriate, unsuitable, improper; (Verb) Return, give back.

Where it comes from: From Latin appropriare (to make oneâ€™s own).

6.20.70. Selfishly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆsÉ›lfÉªÊƒli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that shows concern only for oneself and not others.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œselfishlyâ€ is to act without consideration for the needs or feelings of others, prioritizing oneâ€™s own desires or benefits above all else.

What it really means: â€œSelfishlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that is done for oneâ€™s own benefit, with no thought for other people. It suggests a lack of empathy or a disregard for others. For example, if you eat the last piece of cake without offering it to anyone else, you are acting selfishly.

When to use it: Use it to describe an action that is done out of concern only for oneself.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œact selfishly,â€ â€œbehave selfishly,â€ â€œthink selfishly.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe selfishly took the last slice of pizza without asking anyone else.â€

      • â€œDonâ€™t act so selfishly; you need to think about others.â€

      • â€œThe child selfishly refused to share her toys with her friends.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report argues that the company selfishly pursued profits at the expense of environmental safety.â€

      • â€œThe study suggests that people who act selfishly often have a lower sense of empathy and social responsibility.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the negative consequences that arise when politicians behave selfishly rather than serving the public good.â€

      • â€œThe new law was designed to prevent individuals from selfishly hoarding essential resources during a crisis.â€

Synonyms: Egotistically, greedily, inconsiderately, self-centeredly.

Opposite words: Selflessly, generously, altruistically, thoughtfully, unselfishly.

Where it comes from: From Old English self (oneâ€™s own) + -ish (suffix meaning â€˜of the nature ofâ€™).

6.20.71. Task#

  • Pronunciation: /tÉ‘Ësk/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A piece of work to be done.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œtaskâ€ is a specific piece of work that needs to be completed, often as part of a larger project or duty.

What it really means: A â€œtaskâ€ is a piece of work that needs to be done. It can be a simple household chore (â€œa daily taskâ€) or a complex professional assignment (â€œa challenging taskâ€). It often implies a duty or an assigned piece of work that is part of a larger whole.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a piece of work that needs to be completed.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa difficult task,â€ â€œcomplete a task,â€ â€œa challenging task.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œMy main task for today is to clean the whole house.â€

      • â€œI gave the children a simple task to keep them busy.â€

      • â€œThe project requires us to complete several difficult tasks before the deadline.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report outlines the key tasks that must be completed by the team to meet the projectâ€™s objectives.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how different management styles affect an employeeâ€™s ability to complete a task efficiently.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the task of ensuring that all new employees receive the necessary training.â€

      • â€œThe new software is designed to automate a number of routine tasks and free up employee time for more complex work.â€

Synonyms: Duty, assignment, chore, job, mission, undertaking.

Opposite words: N/A.

Where it comes from: From Old French tasche (a tax, an assessment).

6.20.72. Available#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆveÉªlÉ™bÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Able to be used or obtained; at hand.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œavailableâ€ is the quality of being accessible, present, or ready for use, and not being in use or out of reach.

What it really means: â€œAvailableâ€ is an adjective that describes something that is ready to be used or can be obtained. This can be a person who is free to talk (â€œIâ€™m available to meet with you at 3 p.m.â€), a product that can be purchased (â€œthe product is not available in storesâ€), or a resource that is accessible (â€œthe information is available onlineâ€).

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is ready for use, or a person who is free.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œavailable for,â€ â€œavailable to,â€ â€œfreely available.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œIâ€™m available to help you with your homework after dinner.â€

      • â€œThis book is available at the library, so you donâ€™t need to buy it.â€

      • â€œThe doctor is not available right now; can you leave a message?â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that a wide range of educational resources are available to students through the universityâ€™s online portal.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the extent to which public services are available to residents in remote rural areas.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of making reliable data available to all researchers.â€

      • â€œThe new vaccine will be made available to the public in the next few weeks following its approval.â€

Synonyms: Accessible, obtainable, ready, at hand, on hand, free.

Opposite words: Unavailable, unobtainable, inaccessible, occupied.

Where it comes from: From Old French availer (to be of use).

6.20.73. Spiritual#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆspÉªrÉªtÊƒuÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Relating to the human spirit or soul, as opposed to physical or material things.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œspiritualâ€ is to be concerned with the non-physical, inner part of a person, often involving a sense of connection to something greater than oneself.

What it really means: â€œSpiritualâ€ is an adjective used to describe things related to the human spirit or soul, rather than to the physical body or material possessions. It can refer to religion (â€œa spiritual journeyâ€), personal beliefs, or a connection to something deeper and more meaningful than everyday life.

When to use it: Use it to describe something related to the human spirit, soul, or religion.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œspiritual beliefs,â€ â€œspiritual journey,â€ â€œspiritual health.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI find that spending time in nature is a very spiritual experience for me.â€

      • â€œHe is a very religious person and has strong spiritual beliefs.â€

      • â€œYoga helps me improve my physical and spiritual well-being.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report examines the role of spiritual practices in promoting mental health and resilience.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s findings suggest that a personâ€™s spiritual beliefs can have a significant impact on their ability to cope with illness.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of protecting the spiritual and cultural heritage of indigenous communities.â€

      • â€œThe new museum is designed to provide visitors with a sense of spiritual and emotional connection to the art.â€

Synonyms: Religious, inner, soulful, non-material, ethereal.

Opposite words: Physical, material, worldly, corporeal, secular.

Where it comes from: From Latin spiritualis (of the breath or spirit).

6.20.74. Cautionary#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkÉ”ËÊƒÉ™nÉ™ri/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Serving as a warning.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcautionaryâ€ is to provide a warning or to serve as an example to prevent a similar negative outcome in the future.

What it really means: â€œCautionaryâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that serves as a warning. For example, a cautionary tale is a story told to warn people about a particular danger. It suggests that there is a lesson to be learned from a negative experience to avoid repeating it.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that serves as a warning.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa cautionary tale,â€ â€œa cautionary note,â€ â€œa cautionary warning.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe story of the man who lost all his money is a cautionary tale about gambling.â€

      • â€œThe sudden rise in prices is a cautionary sign for the economy.â€

      • â€œThe movie is a cautionary story about the dangers of technology.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report serves as a cautionary reminder of the potential risks of investing in unstable foreign markets.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s findings are presented as a cautionary note to policymakers about the unintended consequences of the new legislation.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the history of a corporate scandal as a cautionary case study for business ethics students.â€

      • â€œThe recent flood is a cautionary example of the effects of global warming on extreme weather events.â€

Synonyms: Warning, admonitory, exemplary, monitory, forewarning.

Opposite words: N/A.

Where it comes from: From Latin cautio (a taking care, a warning).

6.20.75. Narrow#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆnÃ¦rÉ™ÊŠ/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Adj) Of small width; not wide; (Verb) To become smaller in width.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œnarrowâ€ is to have a limited size or scope, especially in terms of width or a restricted range of options.

What it really means: As an adjective, â€œnarrowâ€ describes something that has a small width, such as a narrow street or a narrow path. It can also refer to a limited range of choices or perspectives (â€œa narrow point of viewâ€). As a verb, to â€œnarrowâ€ means to become smaller in width or to reduce a range of possibilities (â€œto narrow down the listâ€).

When to use it: Use the adjective to describe something with a small width or a limited range, and the verb to describe the action of reducing in width or scope.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa narrow street,â€ â€œa narrow escape,â€ â€œa narrow focus.â€

    • (Verb) â€œnarrow down a list,â€ â€œnarrow the gap.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe bridge is too narrow for two cars to pass at the same time.â€

      • â€œWe need to narrow down the list of candidates to a few top choices.â€

      • â€œHe had a narrow escape when the car almost hit him.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report highlights the challenges of navigating the narrow alleyways of the old city.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s findings are based on a narrow selection of data, which may not be representative of the wider population.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines how the company plans to narrow the gap between its production costs and market prices.â€

      • â€œThe new policy has a narrow scope, focusing exclusively on a single demographic.â€

Synonyms: (Adj) Thin, restricted, confined, limited; (Verb) Constrict, reduce, limit.

Opposite words: (Adj) Wide, broad, expansive, extensive; (Verb) Widen, broaden, expand.

Where it comes from: From Old English nearu (confined, small).

6.20.76. Transmit#

  • Pronunciation: /trÃ¦nzËˆmÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To cause something to pass from one person or place to another.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œtransmitâ€ is to send, pass on, or convey something from a source to a receiver, often through a medium or over a distance.

What it really means: To â€œtransmitâ€ means to send something from one place to another. This can be information via a radio signal (â€œto transmit a messageâ€), a disease from one person to another (â€œto transmit a virusâ€), or a force from one part of a machine to another (â€œto transmit powerâ€).

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of sending or passing something from one place to another.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œtransmit a signal,â€ â€œtransmit a disease,â€ â€œtransmit information.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe radio station transmits its signal all over the country.â€

      • â€œDoctors are trying to understand how the disease is transmitted.â€

      • â€œThe carâ€™s gearbox transmits power from the engine to the wheels.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report examines the various methods used to transmit data securely over the internet.â€

      • â€œThe study highlights the importance of public health campaigns to prevent the transmission of infectious diseases.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the new system designed to transmit information from the satellite to the control center.â€

      • â€œThe cultural traditions and stories were transmitted orally from one generation to the next.â€

Synonyms: Send, convey, communicate, pass on, transfer, broadcast.

Opposite words: Receive, get, acquire.

Where it comes from: From Latin transmittere (to send across).

6.20.77. Peculiar#

  • Pronunciation: /pÉªËˆkjuËliÉ™/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Strange, unusual, or odd.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpeculiarâ€ is to be distinctively strange, unusual, or specific to one person, thing, or place, standing out from the normal.

What it really means: â€œPeculiarâ€ is an adjective that describes something as being strange, unusual, or odd. It can also mean that something is specific to one person or thing (â€œa peculiar smell that is unique to this houseâ€). The word suggests a certain oddness that makes something noteworthy or different from what is expected.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is strange, unusual, or specific to one thing.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa peculiar smell,â€ â€œa peculiar habit,â€ â€œthe peculiar character of.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThereâ€™s a peculiar smell coming from the kitchen.â€

      • â€œHe has a peculiar habit of humming to himself when heâ€™s thinking.â€

      • â€œThe painting has a peculiar charm that is hard to explain.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes the peculiar migratory patterns of this species of bird.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the peculiar linguistic features of the dialect spoken in the region.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the peculiar legal status of the territory, which is a key point of international dispute.â€

      • â€œThe artistâ€™s work is notable for its peculiar use of color and unconventional themes.â€

Synonyms: Strange, odd, unusual, eccentric, bizarre, distinct, specific.

Opposite words: Normal, common, ordinary, typical, usual, standard.

Where it comes from: From Latin peculiaris (of oneâ€™s own property).

6.20.78. Substantially#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™bËˆstÃ¦nÊƒÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: To a great extent; considerably.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsubstantiallyâ€ is to a degree that is significant, important, or considerable, affecting the fundamental nature or size of something.

What it really means: â€œSubstantiallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is large in amount, degree, or importance. It is often used to show a significant change or difference. For example, if a companyâ€™s profits increase substantially, it means they have increased by a large and noteworthy amount.

When to use it: Use it to describe a significant or considerable amount, degree, or change.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œsubstantially different,â€ â€œsubstantially increase,â€ â€œsubstantially reduce.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe price of the house has increased substantially since we bought it.â€

      • â€œThis new engine is substantially more powerful than the old one.â€

      • â€œThe new policy substantially reduced the amount of waste we produce.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report concludes that the new technology will substantially improve the efficiency of the manufacturing process.â€

      • â€œThe study found that the results were substantially different from the findings of previous research.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights how the companyâ€™s financial situation has improved substantially in the last quarter.â€

      • â€œThe new law will substantially alter the way that the government regulates the banking industry.â€

Synonyms: Considerably, significantly, greatly, largely, much.

Opposite words: Slightly, insignificantly, barely, negligibly.

Where it comes from: From Latin substantialis (of or belonging to substance).

6.20.79. Rebellion#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆbÉ›liÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: An act of open, organized, and armed resistance to an established government or ruler.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrebellionâ€ is the open, active, and often armed opposition to a person or group in authority, especially a government.

What it really means: â€œRebellionâ€ is a noun that refers to an act of opposing an authority, such as a government or a leader. It suggests a widespread, organized resistance, often involving violence. It can also refer to a less serious act of defiance against a norm or a parentâ€™s rules.

When to use it: Use it to refer to an act of open opposition to an authority.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa peasant rebellion,â€ â€œstudent rebellion,â€ â€œan act of rebellion.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe movie is about a student rebellion against the strict school principal.â€

      • â€œThe teenagerâ€™s dyed hair was a small act of rebellion against his parents.â€

      • â€œThe country has a long history of popular rebellion against foreign rulers.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report examines the social and economic factors that led to the rebellion in the 17th century.â€

      • â€œThe study suggests that a lack of political freedom can often lead to widespread popular rebellion.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the historical significance of the rebellion in shaping the countryâ€™s national identity.â€

      • â€œThe new law was passed to prevent any kind of rebellion or organized dissent from taking place.â€

Synonyms: Uprising, revolt, revolution, mutiny, insurgency, insurrection.

Opposite words: Obedience, submission, compliance, loyalty.

Where it comes from: From Latin rebellio (a renewal of war).

6.20.80. Elaborate#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªËˆlÃ¦bÉ™rÉ™t/ (Adj) /ÉªËˆlÃ¦bÉ™reÉªt/ (Verb)

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Adj) Detailed and complicated in design and planning; (Verb) To develop or present an idea in further detail.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the adjective is to be highly detailed and complex. The core meaning of the verb is to add more detail or explanation to an idea or plan.

What it really means: As an adjective, â€œelaborateâ€ describes something that is very detailed, complex, and intricate (â€œan elaborate planâ€). As a verb, to â€œelaborateâ€ means to give more detail or information about something (â€œcan you elaborate on that point?â€).

When to use it: Use the adjective to describe something with a lot of detail, and the verb to ask for or provide more detail.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œan elaborate plan,â€ â€œan elaborate design.â€

    • (Verb) â€œelaborate on,â€ â€œelaborate further.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œShe wore a very elaborate dress to the wedding.â€

      • â€œThe instructions are too complicated; can you elaborate on the second step?â€

      • â€œThe criminal had an elaborate plan to rob the bank.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report provides an elaborate analysis of the economic data from the last decade.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s methodology is elaborate and involves multiple stages of data collection and analysis.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines a new strategy and asks managers to elaborate on how they will implement it.â€

      • â€œThe elaborate design of the building is a clear example of neoclassical architecture.â€

Synonyms: (Adj) Intricate, complex, detailed, sophisticated; (Verb) Expand, detail, clarify, explain.

Opposite words: (Adj) Simple, plain, basic, straightforward; (Verb) Simplify, shorten.

Where it comes from: From Latin elaborare (to work out, to produce).

6.20.81. Conformity#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™nËˆfÉ”ËmÉªti/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The act of following rules or standards; behavior that is the same as the accepted norm.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œconformityâ€ is the behavior or action that aligns with accepted rules, norms, or expectations, often to fit in with a group.

What it really means: â€œConformityâ€ is a noun that refers to the act of behaving in a way that is similar to other people, to follow a rule, or to fit in with a group. It suggests a lack of individuality in order to adhere to a norm. For example, a student may wear a school uniform in conformity with the schoolâ€™s rules.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of following a rule or a norm.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œsocial conformity,â€ â€œin conformity with,â€ â€œa pressure to conformity.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe changed his style to be in conformity with the rest of his friends.â€

      • â€œThe company expects a certain degree of conformity from its employees.â€

      • â€œThere is a lot of pressure for conformity in high school.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report examines the sociological phenomenon of group conformity and its effects on individual decision-making.â€

      • â€œThe study found that a strong desire for conformity can stifle creativity and innovation in the workplace.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the need for all new products to be in strict conformity with international safety standards.â€

      • â€œThe pressure to social conformity is a major theme in many literary works of the 20th century.â€

Synonyms: Compliance, obedience, adherence, agreement, consistency.

Opposite words: Nonconformity, rebellion, defiance, individuality, dissent.

Where it comes from: From Latin conformare (to shape).

6.20.82. Functions#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆfÊŒÅ‹kÊƒÉ™nz/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun (plural), Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) The special purpose or role of a person or thing; (Verb) To work or operate.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is the specific purpose, duty, or task of something. The core meaning of the verb is to operate or perform its purpose.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œfunctionsâ€ refers to the purpose or role of something (â€œthe functions of a phoneâ€). As a verb, to â€œfunctionâ€ means to work or operate as it is supposed to (â€œthe machine is not functioning correctlyâ€).

When to use it: Use the plural noun to refer to the purpose or role of something, or the verb to describe its operation.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œthe functions of a device,â€ â€œthe bodyâ€™s functions.â€

    • (Verb) â€œfunction properly,â€ â€œfunction as a team.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œMy phone has many different functions, like a calculator and a camera.â€

      • â€œThe new printer isnâ€™t functioning properly; it keeps getting stuck.â€

      • â€œMy bodyâ€™s functions are returning to normal after the illness.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report examines the main functions of the new software and its various applications.â€

      • â€œThe study found that a lack of sleep can impair cognitive functions and lead to poor performance.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the legal functions and responsibilities of the new government agency.â€

      • â€œThe new engine is designed to function in a wide range of temperatures and climates.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Roles, duties, purposes, operations; (Verb) Work, operate, perform, run.

Opposite words: (Verb) Malfunction, fail.

Where it comes from: From Latin functio (a performance).

6.20.83. Prevent#

  • Pronunciation: /prÉªËˆvÉ›nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To stop something from happening or from being done.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpreventâ€ is to stop or hinder an action or event from occurring, often by taking a prior step to block it.

What it really means: To â€œpreventâ€ means to stop something from happening. This can be a person who prevents a crime, a policy that prevents a problem, or a medicine that prevents an illness. It implies an action taken to avoid a negative outcome.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of stopping something from happening.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œprevent a problem,â€ â€œprevent an accident,â€ â€œprevent something from happening.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWe need to install a security system to prevent theft.â€

      • â€œThe new traffic light will help to prevent accidents at this intersection.â€

      • â€œI put a lock on the door to prevent the dog from getting out.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report outlines a number of measures that the government can take to prevent future economic crises.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the effectiveness of public health campaigns in preventing the spread of infectious diseases.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of regular maintenance to prevent the machine from breaking down.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to prevent companies from engaging in unfair business practices.â€

Synonyms: Stop, hinder, impede, avert, block.

Opposite words: Allow, permit, enable, facilitate, encourage.

Where it comes from: From Latin praevenire (to come before, to anticipate).

6.20.84. Suspend#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™ËˆspÉ›nd/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To officially stop or delay something for a time.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsuspendâ€ is to temporarily stop or hang something, often as a penalty or to hold something in a position.

What it really means: To â€œsuspendâ€ means to temporarily stop or delay something. This can be a person who is suspended from their job as a punishment, a project that is suspended due to a lack of funds, or a meeting that is suspended for a break. It can also mean to hang something from above.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of temporarily stopping something or hanging something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œsuspend a student,â€ â€œsuspend a decision,â€ â€œsuspend a meeting.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe was suspended from school for fighting.â€

      • â€œThe judge decided to suspend the sentence until next month.â€

      • â€œThe construction of the building was suspended due to a lack of materials.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report recommends that the city council suspend the new law pending a full review of its environmental impact.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s findings led the company to suspend production of the product until a safety issue could be resolved.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the legal grounds for the government to suspend trade with a foreign country.â€

      • â€œThe committee voted to suspend the discussion until more data was made available.â€

Synonyms: Halt, postpone, delay, interrupt, defer.

Opposite words: Continue, resume, proceed, start.

Where it comes from: From Latin suspendere (to hang up).

6.20.85. Delete#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆliËt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To remove or erase something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdeleteâ€ is to remove, erase, or cancel something from existence, typically in a written or digital context.

What it really means: To â€œdeleteâ€ means to remove or erase something, usually from a document or a computer file. It implies a permanent removal, though in some cases, the information can be recovered. It is a very common word in the digital age.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of removing or erasing something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œdelete a file,â€ â€œdelete a message,â€ â€œdelete a user account.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI accidentally deleted the important email.â€

      • â€œCan you delete that picture from my phone?â€

      • â€œI need to delete all the old files to free up some space on my computer.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report recommends that all sensitive data be permanently deleted from the server after a certain period of time.â€

      • â€œThe new privacy policy gives users the right to request that their personal information be deleted.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the legal penalties for a company that fails to delete a userâ€™s data when requested.â€

      • â€œThe new software includes a feature that allows users to easily delete all temporary files.â€

Synonyms: Erase, remove, wipe out, cancel, expunge.

Opposite words: Add, save, restore, insert.

Where it comes from: From Latin deletus (destroyed, erased).

6.20.86. Openly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÉ™ÊŠpÉ™nli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Without hiding anything; in a way that is not secret.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œopenlyâ€ is to do something without secrecy or concealment, in a way that is honest, transparent, and public.

What it really means: â€œOpenlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that is done in a public or obvious way, without any secrecy or attempt to hide it. It suggests a sense of honesty, transparency, and sometimes defiance. For example, if you openly disagree with a decision, you donâ€™t hide your feelings.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done without secrecy.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œspeak openly,â€ â€œdisagree openly,â€ â€œopenly express.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œShe openly admitted that she had made a mistake.â€

      • â€œThe two politicians openly debated the new law on television.â€

      • â€œHe openly expressed his love for her in front of everyone.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report praises the company for its decision to openly share its financial data with the public.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how social media has allowed people to openly express their political views.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of a government that can openly and transparently address its shortcomings.â€

      • â€œThe professor openly encouraged students to challenge his ideas during the lecture.â€

Synonyms: Publicly, frankly, candidly, honestly, plainly, transparently.

Opposite words: Secretly, privately, covertly, slyly, hiddenly.

Where it comes from: From Old English open (not closed).

6.20.87. Extensively#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªkËˆstÉ›nsÉªvli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: To a great extent; widely.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œextensivelyâ€ is to do something over a large area, in great detail, or to a significant degree, covering a wide range.

What it really means: â€œExtensivelyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done on a large scale, in great detail, or over a wide area. It is used to show a large scope or a deep level of detail. For example, if a project is researched extensively, it means a lot of detailed work was done.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done on a large scale or with a lot of detail.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œresearch extensively,â€ â€œtravel extensively,â€ â€œdamage extensively.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe has traveled extensively throughout Europe and Asia.â€

      • â€œThe new building was damaged extensively in the fire.â€

      • â€œThe book is about a topic that has been extensively researched.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report concludes that the new technology has been tested extensively and is safe for public use.â€

      • â€œThe study is based on data collected from a large sample of participants and was extensively analyzed.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of protecting the extensively diverse ecosystem of the rainforest.â€

      • â€œThe new law will extensively regulate the use of social media platforms.â€

Synonyms: Widely, broadly, greatly, in-depth, thoroughly, comprehensively.

Opposite words: Narrowly, slightly, superficially, limitedly.

Where it comes from: From Latin extensivus (outspread).

6.20.88. Mandatory#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆmÃ¦ndÉ™tÉ™ri/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Required by law or rule; compulsory.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œmandatoryâ€ is that an action or rule is required or commanded by an authority, leaving no room for choice.

What it really means: â€œMandatoryâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is required or compulsory. It suggests that something must be done because of a law, a rule, or an order. For example, it is mandatory to wear a helmet when riding a motorcycle in many places.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is required or compulsory.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œmandatory training,â€ â€œmandatory requirement,â€ â€œmandatory fine.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWearing a seatbelt is mandatory in all cars.â€

      • â€œAttendance at the meeting is mandatory for all team members.â€

      • â€œAll employees must complete the mandatory training before they can start working.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report highlights the need for mandatory recycling programs in all major cities to reduce landfill waste.â€

      • â€œThe study found that companies with a mandatory retirement age often have a lower rate of employee satisfaction.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the new mandatory requirements for food safety and hygiene in all restaurants.â€

      • â€œThe governmentâ€™s new law makes it mandatory for all citizens to have health insurance.â€

Synonyms: Compulsory, obligatory, required, essential, necessary.

Opposite words: Optional, voluntary, non-essential, discretionary.

Where it comes from: From Latin mandatum (a command).

6.20.89. Measuring#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆmÉ›Ê’É™rÉªÅ‹/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb (present participle), Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To find the size, amount, or degree of something; (Noun) The act of taking a measurement.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œmeasuringâ€ is the process of determining the size, quantity, or degree of something by comparing it to a standard unit.

What it really means: â€œMeasuringâ€ is the present participle of the verb â€œto measure.â€ It means to find the size, amount, or degree of something using a standard unit. For example, you can be measuring the length of a table, measuring the temperature of water, or measuring a personâ€™s height.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of finding the size, amount, or degree of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œmeasuring the temperature,â€ â€œmeasuring progress,â€ â€œmeasuring success.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa measuring cup,â€ â€œthe act of measuring.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œIâ€™m measuring the ingredients for the cake.â€

      • â€œThe doctor is measuring my blood pressure.â€

      • â€œThe tailor is measuring me for a new suit.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report outlines a new method for measuring the effectiveness of the public transport system.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the challenges of measuring the social impact of a new government policy.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of measuring a projectâ€™s success against its original goals.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed for the precise measuring of temperature and humidity in a controlled environment.â€

Synonyms: Quantifying, assessing, gauging, evaluating, appraising.

Opposite words: N/A.

Where it comes from: From Old French mesure, from Latin metiri (to measure).

6.20.90. Unconsciously#

  • Pronunciation: /ÊŒnËˆkÉ’nÊƒÉ™sli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Without being aware; without conscious thought.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œunconsciouslyâ€ is to do something without awareness or deliberate thought, acting on impulse, habit, or a hidden mental process.

What it really means: â€œUnconsciouslyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that is done without a person being aware of it. It is the opposite of â€œconsciously.â€ It suggests that an action is an automatic response, a habit, or a reflex, rather than a deliberate decision.
