When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done without awareness or conscious thought.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œto do something unconsciously,â€ â€œunconsciously believe,â€ â€œunconsciously repeat.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI unconsciously reached for my phone when I heard the notification sound.â€

      • â€œHe was unconsciously tapping his foot during the whole meeting.â€

      • â€œSometimes, we unconsciously repeat the mistakes of our parents.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report argues that consumers are unconsciously influenced by the colors and fonts used in advertising.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how people unconsciously process information and form biases without even realizing it.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of being aware of the unconsciously held beliefs that can affect our decisions.â€

      • â€œMany of our daily habits and routines are performed unconsciously and are a result of conditioning.â€

Synonyms: Subconsciously, involuntarily, automatically, instinctively, reflexively.

Opposite words: Consciously, deliberately, intentionally, knowingly, purposefully.

Where it comes from: From Latin in- (not) + conscius (knowing).

6.20.91. Successful#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™kËˆsÉ›sfÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Having achieved a desired goal or result.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsuccessfulâ€ is the achievement of a desired outcome or goal, meeting a standard of success.

What it really means: â€œSuccessfulâ€ is an adjective used to describe a person or a thing that has achieved a desired goal or result. It suggests a positive outcome. A person can be successful in their career, a project can be successful, or an event can be successful.

When to use it: Use it to describe a person or a thing that has achieved a desired outcome.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa successful career,â€ â€œa successful project,â€ â€œa successful outcome.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe surgery was successful, and the patient is now recovering.â€

      • â€œShe had a very successful career as a lawyer.â€

      • â€œThe successful launch of the new product was celebrated by the whole team.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report examines the factors that contribute to a successful transition from school to the workplace.â€

      • â€œThe study found that a successful leader is often a good communicator and a strong decision-maker.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of setting clear goals for a project to be considered successful.â€

      • â€œThe new policy was a successful effort to reduce unemployment rates in the region.â€

Synonyms: Thriving, prosperous, victorious, fruitful, effective, accomplished.

Opposite words: Unsuccessful, failed, fruitless, ineffective, unsuccessful.

Where it comes from: From Latin successus (a coming up, a coming after).

6.20.92. Lately#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆleÉªtli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Recently; in the recent past.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œlatelyâ€ is to refer to a period of time that has just passed, indicating a recent change or event.

What it really means: â€œLatelyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that has happened recently. It is often used with the present perfect tense to talk about something that started in the past and continues to be true or relevant in the present. For example, â€œhave you seen any good movies lately?â€

When to use it: Use it to describe something that has happened recently.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œhave you seen lately,â€ â€œwhat have you been doing lately,â€ â€œlately Iâ€™ve been.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œIâ€™ve been feeling very tired lately.â€

      • â€œHave you heard from John lately? I havenâ€™t seen him in a while.â€

      • â€œThe weather has been very cold lately.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that consumer spending has increased lately, which is a sign of a recovering economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the new trends in social media that have emerged lately.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the increasing concerns about air pollution that have been lately raised by environmental activists.â€

      • â€œThere have been a number of new policy changes lately that have affected the local businesses.â€

Synonyms: Recently, newly, of late, latterly.

Opposite words: Formerly, previously, long ago, in the past.

Where it comes from: From Old English lat (slow, tardy).

6.20.93. Irreversible#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉªrÉªËˆvÉœËsÉ™bÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Not able to be changed back to a previous state.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œirreversibleâ€ is to be impossible to undo or change back to a previous state, signifying a permanent and final change.

What it really means: â€œIrreversibleâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that cannot be changed back to its original state. It suggests a permanent and final change. For example, the effects of climate change are often described as irreversible.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that cannot be changed back.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œirreversible damage,â€ â€œirreversible change,â€ â€œirreversible decision.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe damage to the old book is irreversible.â€

      • â€œHe made an irreversible decision to quit his job without a new one lined up.â€

      • â€œThe doctor said the injury to his knee was irreversible.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report warns of the irreversible damage that deforestation is causing to the local ecosystem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the long-term effects of a particular illness and the irreversible changes it causes to the body.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the irreversible social and cultural changes that have resulted from globalization.â€

      • â€œThe committeeâ€™s decision to close the factory had an irreversible impact on the local economy.â€

Synonyms: Permanent, final, unchangeable, lasting, irreparable.

Opposite words: Reversible, temporary, changeable, fixable, repairable.

Where it comes from: From Latin in- (not) + revertere (to turn back).

6.20.94. Consequence#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkÉ’nsÉªkwÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A result or effect of an action or condition.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œconsequenceâ€ is the outcome or result that follows from a previous action or event, often implying a significant or negative result.

What it really means: A â€œconsequenceâ€ is a result or an effect of something that has happened. It is often used to refer to a negative result (â€œthe consequences of his actionsâ€). It suggests a cause-and-effect relationship, where one thing leads to another.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a result or an effect of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œthe consequences of,â€ â€œtake the consequences,â€ â€œa negative consequence.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œFailing the exam was a direct consequence of not studying.â€

      • â€œHe will have to face the consequences of his actions.â€

      • â€œOne of the consequences of smoking is a high risk of lung cancer.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report analyzes the long-term consequences of the new economic policy on the national debt.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the social consequences of a high unemployment rate in a country.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the environmental consequences of industrial pollution on the local ecosystem.â€

      • â€œThe committeeâ€™s decision had a number of unintended consequences that no one had predicted.â€

Synonyms: Result, outcome, effect, repercussion, aftermath.

Opposite words: Cause, origin, reason, source, antecedent.

Where it comes from: From Latin consequi (to follow closely).

6.20.95. Observation#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉ’bzÉ™ËˆveÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action of watching something or someone carefully.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œobservationâ€ is the act of carefully watching or monitoring something, especially for a scientific or analytical purpose, and the insights gained from that process.

What it really means: â€œObservationâ€ is a noun that refers to the act of watching something carefully. It is a key part of scientific research, where a scientist makes observations of a phenomenon to understand it better. It can also refer to a comment or a remark that a person makes.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of watching something carefully or a comment that is made.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œmake an observation,â€ â€œcareful observation,â€ â€œunder observation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe scientist made a number of interesting observations about the behavior of the animals.â€

      • â€œI made the observation that he seemed a little sad today.â€

      • â€œThe police had the suspect under observation for a week.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report is based on a year of careful observation of the species in its natural habitat.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s findings are a result of detailed observation of the data and a critical analysis of the results.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of a clear and objective observation in all scientific research.â€

      • â€œOne of the main observations in the report is that a lack of resources is a major problem.â€

Synonyms: Watching, monitoring, scrutiny, study, remark, comment.

Opposite words: Disregard, inattention, neglect.

Where it comes from: From Latin observatio (a watching).

6.20.96. Society#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™ËˆsaÉªÉ™ti/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The community of people living in a particular country or region.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsocietyâ€ is a large group of people who live together in an organized community, sharing laws, institutions, and a common culture.

What it really means: â€œSocietyâ€ is a noun that refers to a group of people who live together in an organized community, sharing the same culture, laws, and institutions. It can refer to a whole country (â€œAmerican societyâ€) or to a smaller group of people who share a common interest (â€œa local history societyâ€).

When to use it: Use it to refer to an organized group of people.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œmodern society,â€ â€œa civilized society,â€ â€œa historical society.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWe have a responsibility to create a fair and just society for everyone.â€

      • â€œHe is a member of the local historical society.â€

      • â€œThe movie is a critique of modern society and its values.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report examines the social changes that have occurred in society as a result of technological innovation.â€

      • â€œThe study found that a strong sense of community is essential for a healthy and thriving society.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the need for laws that protect the rights of all citizens in a democratic society.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the challenges facing society today, such as poverty and inequality.â€

Synonyms: Community, civilization, populace, public, culture, humanity.

Opposite words: Individuality, solitude.

Where it comes from: From Latin societas (a fellowship).

6.20.97. Basic#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆbeÉªsÉªk/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Forming the most important or fundamental part of something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œbasicâ€ is to be the most fundamental, essential, or foundational part of something, without which it cannot exist or function.

What it really means: â€œBasicâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is fundamental or essential. It suggests that something is the starting point or the most important part of something else. For example, a basic need is a need that must be met for a person to survive.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is fundamental or essential.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa basic need,â€ â€œthe basic rules,â€ â€œa basic understanding.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œEveryone should have access to basic healthcare.â€

      • â€œI have a basic understanding of how the computer works.â€

      • â€œThe basic rules of the game are very simple.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report highlights the fact that many people still lack access to basic necessities like clean water and electricity.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the importance of a basic education in a childâ€™s development.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the basic principles of the new law, which are designed to protect the environment.â€

      • â€œThe research is based on a basic assumption that all participants will be honest in their responses.â€

Synonyms: Fundamental, essential, primary, simple, foundational, rudimentary.

Opposite words: Advanced, complex, sophisticated, elaborate, intricate.

Where it comes from: From Late Latin basica (a pedestal).

6.20.98. Suspicious#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™ËˆspÉªÊƒÉ™s/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Having or showing a cautious distrust of someone or something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsuspiciousâ€ is to have or show a feeling of distrust or doubt about a person or a situation, believing that something is wrong or deceitful.

What it really means: â€œSuspiciousâ€ is an adjective used to describe a feeling of distrust or doubt. You can be suspicious of a personâ€™s motives, or a situation can seem suspicious. It suggests that something seems wrong or out of place, and you feel that you need to be careful.

When to use it: Use it to describe a feeling of distrust or doubt.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œto be suspicious of,â€ â€œa suspicious person,â€ â€œa suspicious package.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œIâ€™m suspicious of anyone who offers me a free product.â€

      • â€œThe police found a suspicious package outside the building.â€

      • â€œHe acted in a very suspicious way, so I didnâ€™t trust him.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the companyâ€™s financial records contained several suspicious transactions.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a suspicious nature can affect a personâ€™s ability to form close relationships.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of being aware of suspicious activity in the workplace to prevent fraud.â€

      • â€œThe committeeâ€™s decision was met with a suspicious response from the public, who believed there was a hidden agenda.â€

Synonyms: Doubtful, distrustful, wary, questionable, dubious.

Opposite words: Trusting, credulous, confident, believing, unsuspecting.

Where it comes from: From Latin suspiciosus (full of suspicion).

6.20.99. Revolutionise#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒrÉ›vÉ™ËˆluËÊƒÉ™naÉªz/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To change something completely and fundamentally.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrevolutioniseâ€ is to bring about a dramatic and fundamental change in a way of doing something or thinking about something.

What it really means: To â€œrevolutioniseâ€ means to change something in a major, fundamental, and dramatic way. It suggests a major shift or a complete overhaul. For example, the internet has revolutionised the way we communicate.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of changing something completely.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œrevolutionise an industry,â€ â€œrevolutionise a process,â€ â€œrevolutionise the way.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new technology will revolutionise the way we live and work.â€

      • â€œThe invention of the printing press revolutionised the spread of knowledge.â€

      • â€œShe has a new idea that could revolutionise the whole company.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report argues that artificial intelligence will revolutionise the healthcare industry in the next decade.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how the rise of digital platforms has revolutionised the media landscape.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the companyâ€™s new product, which is designed to revolutionise the way people use their phones.â€

      • â€œThe new economic policy is intended to revolutionise the countryâ€™s manufacturing sector.â€

Synonyms: Transform, change, innovate, modernize, overhaul.

Opposite words: Preserve, maintain, stabilize, conserve.

Where it comes from: From Latin revolutio (a turning around).

6.20.100. Incident#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÉªnsÉªdÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: An event or occurrence.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œincidentâ€ is an occurrence or event, often a minor or unexpected one, that is part of a larger chain of events.

What it really means: An â€œincidentâ€ is an event or an occurrence, often a negative or unusual one. It is a more formal word for an event, and it is often used to refer to a small problem or a conflict. For example, a minor car accident could be called a traffic incident.

When to use it: Use it to refer to an event or occurrence, often a negative one.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa security incident,â€ â€œa minor incident,â€ â€œa diplomatic incident.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe police are investigating a strange incident that happened at the bank.â€

      • â€œThere was a minor incident in the playground, but no one was hurt.â€

      • â€œThe meeting was interrupted by a small incident with the projector.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report details a number of security incidents that occurred at the factory in the last year.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the factors that contribute to the frequency of workplace incidents and accidents.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear plan for responding to a major incident.â€

      • â€œThe recent border skirmish was a serious diplomatic incident that required a swift response.â€

Synonyms: Event, occurrence, episode, happening, affair.

Opposite words: N/A.

Where it comes from: From Latin incidere (to fall upon, to happen).

6.20.101. Bizarre#

  • Pronunciation: /bÉªËˆzÉ‘Ë/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Very strange or unusual.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œbizarreâ€ is to be strikingly unusual, strange, or grotesque, often in a way that is surprising or shocking.

What it really means: â€œBizarreâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is very strange or unusual. It is a stronger word than â€œpeculiarâ€ and suggests a very odd or surprising strangeness. For example, a bizarre dream is one that is very strange and hard to explain.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is very strange or unusual.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa bizarre story,â€ â€œa bizarre event,â€ â€œa bizarre coincidence.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe had a bizarre dream about a talking cat wearing a hat.â€

      • â€œThe movie had a bizarre and unexpected ending.â€

      • â€œThe whole situation was so bizarre that I didnâ€™t know what to think.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report details a number of bizarre and unexplained phenomena that have occurred in the region.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the bizarre mating rituals of a newly discovered species of deep-sea fish.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the bizarre and illogical nature of some of the legal precedents from the 18th century.â€

      • â€œThe artist is known for his bizarre and surreal paintings that challenge traditional norms.â€

Synonyms: Strange, weird, odd, eccentric, grotesque, outlandish.

Opposite words: Normal, ordinary, conventional, common, typical.

Where it comes from: From French bizarre (odd, fantastic).

6.20.102. Equally#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆiËkwÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In the same way or to the same extent.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œequallyâ€ is to do something to the same degree, in the same amount, or in the same manner, suggesting a state of balance or fairness.

What it really means: â€œEquallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in the same way or to the same extent. It is used to show a sense of balance or fairness. For example, if two people are treated equally, they are treated in the same way without any preference.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in the same way or to the same extent.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œequally important,â€ â€œtreat equally,â€ â€œshare equally.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWe shared the pizza equally among all the people at the table.â€

      • â€œItâ€™s a job that requires a lot of hard work, but itâ€™s equally rewarding.â€

      • â€œThe two brothers are equally responsible for the mess.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report argues that education and healthcare are equally important for a countryâ€™s development.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how different cultures place equally high value on family and community.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of ensuring that all citizens are equally protected under the law.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to equally distribute the resources among all the different departments.â€

Synonyms: Alike, in the same way, fairly, justly, identically.

Opposite words: Unequally, differently, unfairly, unevenly.

Where it comes from: From Latin aequalis (equal).

6.20.103. Preciously#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆprÉ›ÊƒÉ™sli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that shows great care and value.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpreciouslyâ€ is to do something with great care and caution, as if the object or thing is of great value or importance.

What it really means: â€œPreciouslyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that is done with great care, as if something is very valuable. It suggests that a person is treating something with a lot of love and attention because it is special. For example, you might handle a delicate antique vase preciously.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done with great care and value.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œhold preciously,â€ â€œtreat preciously,â€ â€œguard preciously.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe held the small baby preciously in his arms.â€

      • â€œThe old letters were stored away and guarded preciously.â€

      • â€œShe preciously kept the small gift he gave her.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the artifacts were stored preciously in a climate-controlled environment to prevent deterioration.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how people preciously hold on to traditions and cultural heritage in a globalized world.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of protecting and preserving the preciously rare species of animal.â€

      • â€œThe museumâ€™s most valuable painting is displayed and lit preciously to ensure no damage.â€

Synonyms: Carefully, delicately, lovingly, dearly, cautiously.

Opposite words: Carelessly, roughly, neglectfully, unceremoniously.

Where it comes from: From Latin pretiosus (of great value).

6.20.104. Approximately#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆprÉ’ksÉªmÉ™tli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Close to the actual amount or time; not exactly.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œapproximatelyâ€ is to be near or close to an exact value or number, but not precisely so.

What it really means: â€œApproximatelyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is close to an exact number or time, but not precise. It is a way of giving an estimate. For example, the distance to the city is approximately 10 kilometers.

When to use it: Use it to give an estimate that is not exact.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œapproximately 10,â€ â€œapproximately the same,â€ â€œapproximately 3 p.m.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe journey will take approximately three hours.â€

      • â€œThere were approximately 50 people at the party.â€

      • â€œThe new building is approximately the same size as the old one.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report states that the average worker in the factory earns approximately 15% more than the national average.â€

      • â€œThe study found that the population of the city has grown by approximately 200,000 in the last decade.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the cost of the project as being approximately 5 million dollars.â€

      • â€œThe new machine is designed to produce a product that is approximately 10 centimeters in length.â€

Synonyms: Roughly, nearly, about, around, close to.

Opposite words: Exactly, precisely, accurately.

Where it comes from: From Latin approximare (to come near).

6.20.105. Separation#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒsÉ›pÉ™ËˆreÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action or state of moving or being moved apart.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œseparationâ€ is the act or state of being divided or set apart from something or someone else.

What it really means: â€œSeparationâ€ is a noun that refers to the act of moving or being moved apart. This can be the separation of two people in a relationship, the separation of a family due to a war, or the separation of different materials in a factory. It suggests a physical or emotional division.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of moving or being moved apart.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa legal separation,â€ â€œa separation of powers,â€ â€œthe separation of church and state.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThey have decided to get a legal separation before getting a divorce.â€

      • â€œThe separation of the two friends was very difficult for them both.â€

      • â€œThe factory is designed for the separation of different types of plastic.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report examines the social and economic effects of the separation of the country into two independent states.â€

      • â€œThe study highlights the importance of the constitutional separation of powers to ensure a balanced government.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the historical and political factors that led to the separation of the two cultures.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to ensure the separation of public and private funding in the new project.â€

Synonyms: Division, parting, split, segregation, detachment.

Opposite words: Union, connection, unity, joining, combination.

Where it comes from: From Latin separatio (a dividing).

6.20.106. Significantly#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉªÉ¡ËˆnÉªfÉªkÉ™ntli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a sufficiently great or important way.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsignificantlyâ€ is to a degree that is important, notable, or meaningful, having a measurable and impactful effect.

What it really means: â€œSignificantlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a very important or noticeable way. It is used to emphasize the importance or the size of a change. For example, if a companyâ€™s profits increase significantly, it means they have increased by a very large and important amount.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in an important or noticeable way.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œsignificantly different,â€ â€œsignificantly increase,â€ â€œsignificantly affect.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new medication has significantly improved his condition.â€

      • â€œOur sales have significantly increased since we launched our new advertising campaign.â€

      • â€œThe two brothers are significantly different in their personalities.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report concludes that the new technology will significantly reduce the amount of time required for the process.â€

      • â€œThe study found that a personâ€™s diet can significantly affect their overall health and well-being.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the fact that the number of people living in poverty has significantly decreased in the last decade.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to significantly alter the way that the government regulates the banking industry.â€

Synonyms: Notably, considerably, greatly, importantly, markedly.

Opposite words: Insignificantly, slightly, barely, negligibly.

Where it comes from: From Latin significare (to signify).

6.20.107. Ideally#

  • Pronunciation: /aÉªËˆdiËÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a perfect or an ideal situation.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œideallyâ€ is to refer to a perfect or best-case scenario, representing a desired or optimal situation.

What it really means: â€œIdeallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is perfect or in an ideal situation. It is used to describe a desired outcome that may not always be possible. For example, ideally, we should all eat healthy food and exercise every day, but sometimes thatâ€™s not possible.

When to use it: Use it to describe a perfect or ideal situation.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œideally you should,â€ â€œideally we would,â€ â€œideally the best way.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œIdeally, we would go on vacation for a month, but we can only afford a week.â€

      • â€œIdeally, you should get eight hours of sleep every night.â€

      • â€œThe house is perfect, ideally located near the park and the school.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report argues that ideally, all children should have access to a quality education, regardless of their familyâ€™s income.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s findings suggest that ideally, a companyâ€™s success should be measured not just by its profits but also by its social and environmental impact.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the new system, which is designed to function ideally in a zero-gravity environment.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to be ideally suited for the needs of the working class.â€

Synonyms: Perfectly, optimally, preferably, in a perfect world.

Opposite words: Realistically, practically, in reality.

Where it comes from: From Greek idea (form, pattern).

6.20.108. Measure#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆmÉ›Ê’É™r/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To find the size, amount, or degree of something; (Noun) A standard unit or a course of action.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the verb is to determine the size, amount, or degree of something. The core meaning of the noun is a standard unit of measurement or a course of action taken to achieve an end.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œmeasureâ€ means to find the size, amount, or degree of something using a standard unit. As a noun, a â€œmeasureâ€ can be a standard unit, such as a meter, or it can be an action taken to achieve a goal (â€œwe need to take strong measures to protect the environmentâ€).

When to use it: Use the verb to describe finding the size of something, and the noun to refer to a unit or an action.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œmeasure the length,â€ â€œmeasure the temperature.â€

    • (Noun) â€œtake measures,â€ â€œa unit of measure.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI need to measure the length of the table before I buy a tablecloth.â€

      • â€œThe doctor took my temperature as a measure of my health.â€

      • â€œThe government is taking new measures to reduce crime.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report outlines a new method for measuring the effectiveness of a new marketing campaign.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the new measures that were implemented to reduce the amount of pollution in the city.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of using a standard measure for all data collection to ensure consistency.â€

      • â€œThe company is taking a number of measures to improve its employeesâ€™ health and well-being.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Gauge, assess, quantify, evaluate; (Noun) Action, step, unit, dimension, standard.

Opposite words: (Verb) Estimate, guess.

Where it comes from: From Old French mesure, from Latin metiri (to measure).

6.20.109. Overcome#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉ™ÊŠvÉ™ËˆkÊŒm/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To succeed in dealing with a problem or difficulty.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œovercomeâ€ is to successfully deal with or defeat a challenge, difficulty, or emotion, emerging as the winner or being stronger as a result.

What it really means: To â€œovercomeâ€ means to succeed in dealing with a problem or difficulty. It suggests a victory over a challenge, such as overcoming an illness, overcoming a fear, or overcoming a difficult obstacle.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of succeeding in dealing with a problem or difficulty.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œovercome a fear,â€ â€œovercome an obstacle,â€ â€œovercome a problem.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe had to overcome his fear of public speaking to give his presentation.â€

      • â€œThe team had to overcome a lot of challenges to win the championship.â€

      • â€œShe was able to overcome her illness with the help of a good doctor.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report examines the strategies that people use to overcome the challenges of living in a new country.â€

      • â€œThe study found that a personâ€™s resilience can help them to overcome adversity and bounce back from setbacks.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear plan to overcome any potential problems that may arise during the project.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help companies overcome the technical limitations of their old systems.â€

Synonyms: Defeat, conquer, surmount, triumph over, prevail.

Opposite words: Fail, surrender, yield, submit, succumb.

Where it comes from: From Old English ofercuman (to come upon, to defeat).

6.20.110. Fiercely#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆfÉªÉ™sli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a powerful, intense, or aggressive way.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œfiercelyâ€ is to do something with great intensity, aggression, or passion, suggesting a powerful and strong emotion.

What it really means: â€œFiercelyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done with a lot of energy, power, or aggression. It suggests a very strong or intense feeling, such as a fiercely competitive person or a storm that rages fiercely.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done with great intensity or aggression.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œto fight fiercely,â€ â€œfiercely competitive,â€ â€œlove fiercely.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe two teams fought fiercely for the championship.â€

      • â€œShe fiercely defended her children from any criticism.â€

      • â€œThe wind was blowing fiercely outside the window.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the two companies are fiercely competitive in the global market.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a parentâ€™s desire to protect their child can lead to them fiercely defending their childâ€™s actions.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the need for a strong and fiercely independent judiciary to protect the rule of law.â€

      • â€œThe new law was fiercely debated in the parliament before it was passed.â€

Synonyms: Intensely, violently, aggressively, passionately, powerfully.

Opposite words: Gently, calmly, mildly, softly, weakly.

Where it comes from: From Old French fier (proud, wild).

6.20.111. Admiration#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÃ¦dmÉ™ËˆreÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A feeling of respect and wonder.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œadmirationâ€ is a feeling of respect and approval for someone or something, often inspired by their qualities or achievements.

What it really means: â€œAdmirationâ€ is a noun that refers to a feeling of respect and wonder for someone or something. It suggests a deep appreciation for a personâ€™s qualities, skills, or achievements. For example, you might feel admiration for a great artist or a brave soldier.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a feeling of respect and wonder.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œhave admiration for,â€ â€œa feeling of admiration,â€ â€œwin admiration.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have a lot of admiration for her ability to stay calm under pressure.â€

      • â€œHe won the admiration of his colleagues with his hard work and dedication.â€

      • â€œThe whole country has a deep admiration for the Queenâ€™s long service.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report concludes with a note of admiration for the teamâ€™s ability to overcome such significant challenges.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s admiration for a particular celebrity can influence their consumer choices.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the admiration that the public has for the work of the national health service.â€

      • â€œThe new program is designed to inspire a feeling of admiration for the countryâ€™s rich cultural heritage.â€

Synonyms: Respect, esteem, reverence, awe, high regard.

Opposite words: Contempt, disdain, scorn, disgust, hatred.

Where it comes from: From Latin admiratio (a wondering at).

6.20.112. Profit#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆprÉ’fÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) A financial gain; (Verb) To get a financial gain.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is the financial gain obtained from a business activity, especially after all expenses have been subtracted. The core meaning of the verb is to obtain a financial or other advantage from a situation.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œprofitâ€ is the money that a business makes after all of its costs have been paid. As a verb, to â€œprofitâ€ means to gain something, usually money, from a situation.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a financial gain, and the verb to describe the act of gaining something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œmake a profit,â€ â€œa net profit,â€ â€œa healthy profit.â€

    • (Verb) â€œprofit from,â€ â€œprofit off of.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe company made a small profit this year.â€

      • â€œHe started a new business to profit from the growing demand for local goods.â€

      • â€œThe whole team was able to profit from the success of the project.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report analyzes the companyâ€™s financial records to determine its net profit for the last quarter.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how new businesses can increase their profit margins by reducing their operational costs.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of a government policy that encourages companies to profit in a socially responsible way.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to ensure that the public profits from the use of public resources.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Gain, earnings, income, revenue, return; (Verb) Benefit, gain, capitalize.

Opposite words: (Noun) Loss, deficit, debt; (Verb) Lose.

Where it comes from: From Latin proficere (to advance, to make progress).

6.20.113. Launch#

  • Pronunciation: /lÉ”ËntÊƒ/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To start or set in motion; (Noun) The act of starting or introducing something new.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the verb is to send something off, initiate a process, or introduce something new. The core meaning of the noun is the beginning or introduction of something, such as a product or a project.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œlaunchâ€ means to start something new, such as a product, a project, or a campaign. It can also mean to send something into the air, such as a rocket. As a noun, a â€œlaunchâ€ is the event when something new is started.

When to use it: Use the verb to describe starting something new, and the noun to refer to the event of starting something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œlaunch a product,â€ â€œlaunch an investigation,â€ â€œlaunch a boat.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa product launch,â€ â€œthe launch of a rocket,â€ â€œa successful launch.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe company plans to launch a new phone next month.â€

      • â€œThe launch of the new car was a big event.â€

      • â€œWe need to launch a new advertising campaign to increase sales.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report details the successful launch of the new satellite into orbit.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the marketing strategies that are most effective for a new product launch.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the new project, which is set to launch in the third quarter of this year.â€

      • â€œThe government plans to launch a new initiative to promote sustainable energy.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Start, initiate, begin, introduce, embark on; (Noun) Beginning, start, inauguration, initiation.

Opposite words: (Verb) End, finish, stop, cancel; (Noun) End, conclusion.

Where it comes from: From Old French lanchier (to throw a lance).

6.20.114. Imitation#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉªmÉªËˆteÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action of copying or reproducing something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œimitationâ€ is the act of copying, mimicking, or reproducing the behavior, appearance, or style of another person or thing.

What it really means: â€œImitationâ€ is a noun that refers to the act of copying something. It can be the imitation of a personâ€™s voice, the imitation of an artistâ€™s style, or a product that is an imitation of a more expensive brand.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of copying something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa good imitation,â€ â€œin imitation of,â€ â€œan act of imitation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe brand sells an imitation leather jacket that looks very real.â€

      • â€œHis accent is a very good imitation of a British person.â€

      • â€œThe childrenâ€™s artwork was a direct imitation of the teacherâ€™s.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report examines the economic effects of the widespread imitation of brand-name products.â€

      • â€œThe study found that a personâ€™s learning process is often based on the imitation of othersâ€™ behavior.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the legal challenges of dealing with the imitation of copyrighted material.â€

      • â€œThe new artwork is a brilliant imitation of the old masterâ€™s style.â€

Synonyms: Copy, replica, reproduction, mimicry, emulation.

Opposite words: Original, genuine, authentic, unique.

Where it comes from: From Latin imitatio (a copying).

6.20.115. Calm#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ‘Ëm/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective, Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Adj) Not feeling or showing strong emotions; (Noun) A state of peace; (Verb) To make someone peaceful.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcalmâ€ is to be free from disturbance, agitation, or strong emotion, possessing a state of tranquility and peace.

What it really means: As an adjective, â€œcalmâ€ describes a state of peace, free from strong emotions or agitation (â€œa calm seaâ€). As a noun, it is the state of peace itself (â€œa sense of calmâ€). As a verb, to â€œcalmâ€ means to make someone or something peaceful (â€œto calm a crying babyâ€).

When to use it: Use the adjective to describe a peaceful state, the noun to refer to a state of peace, and the verb to describe making someone peaceful.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa calm person,â€ â€œa calm voice,â€ â€œstay calm.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa sense of calm,â€ â€œthe eye of the calm.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œShe has a very calm voice, which makes it easy to listen to her.â€

      • â€œI like to go to the beach to find a sense of calm.â€

      • â€œHe tried to calm the crying child with a lullaby.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that a leaderâ€™s ability to remain calm during a crisis is essential for effective decision-making.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the effectiveness of mindfulness in promoting a state of calm and reducing stress.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of providing a calm and supportive environment for students with anxiety.â€

      • â€œThe new regulations were implemented to calm the publicâ€™s fears about the safety of the new product.â€

Synonyms: (Adj) Peaceful, tranquil, serene, relaxed; (Noun) Peace, tranquility, serenity; (Verb) Soothe, pacify, relax, settle.

Opposite words: (Adj) Agitated, chaotic, turbulent, anxious; (Noun) Chaos, turmoil, agitation; (Verb) Agitate, excite, disturb.

Where it comes from: From Old French calme, from Italian calma (stillness).

6.20.116. Enormously#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªËˆnÉ”ËmÉ™sli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: To a very great extent; extremely.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œenormouslyâ€ is to an immense or extremely large degree, far beyond the normal or expected.

What it really means: â€œEnormouslyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is very large in amount, degree, or size. It is a very strong way of saying â€œveryâ€ or â€œextremely.â€ For example, if you are enormously happy, you are extremely happy.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is very large in amount, degree, or size.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œenormously successful,â€ â€œenormously difficult,â€ â€œenormously important.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new project was enormously successful, and the companyâ€™s profits tripled.â€

      • â€œIâ€™m enormously grateful for all of your help.â€

      • â€œThe movie was enormously long and I fell asleep in the middle of it.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy has been enormously beneficial for the local economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the enormously complex and interconnected nature of the global financial system.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the enormously significant role that technology plays in modern education.â€

      • â€œThe new law was passed with an enormously large majority in parliament.â€

Synonyms: Extremely, immensely, hugely, greatly, tremendously.

Opposite words: Slightly, barely, negligibly, minimally.

Where it comes from: From Latin enormis (out of rule, immense).

6.20.117. Manageable#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆmÃ¦nÉªdÊ’É™bÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Able to be controlled or dealt with without difficulty.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œmanageableâ€ is to be within the capacity to be controlled, handled, or dealt with effectively, without overwhelming a person or system.

What it really means: â€œManageableâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is not too difficult to control or deal with. It suggests that a problem or a task is a size that a person or a team can handle. For example, a manageable workload is one that is not too large or overwhelming.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that can be controlled or dealt with without difficulty.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa manageable task,â€ â€œa manageable workload,â€ â€œa manageable size.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new car is a manageable size for driving in the city.â€

      • â€œI broke the project into small, manageable tasks.â€

      • â€œThe problem seemed big at first, but with a little effort, it became manageable.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report argues that the new policy has made the national debt a much more manageable problem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the strategies that people use to make a large and complex project more manageable.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of providing employees with a manageable workload to reduce stress and burnout.â€

      • â€œThe new software is designed to help users organize their data into manageable and easy-to-access files.â€

Synonyms: Controllable, easy, simple, achievable, handleable.

Opposite words: Unmanageable, difficult, hard, overwhelming, unwieldy.

Where it comes from: From Latin manus (hand).

6.20.118. Sentence#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆsÉ›ntÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) A set of words that is complete in itself; (Verb) To declare the punishment of a convicted person.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is a complete unit of thought in language. The core meaning of the verb is to officially declare the punishment for a crime.

What it really means: As a noun, a â€œsentenceâ€ is a set of words that expresses a complete thought. As a verb, to â€œsentenceâ€ a person means to officially declare their punishment for a crime they have been found guilty of.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a complete thought in language, and the verb to refer to a courtâ€™s punishment.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa long sentence,â€ â€œwrite a sentence.â€

    • (Verb) â€œsentence to,â€ â€œbe sentenced.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe book is written in long, complicated sentences.â€

      • â€œThe judge will sentence him to ten years in prison.â€

      • â€œI canâ€™t write a single sentence today; I have writerâ€™s block.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe reportâ€™s main argument is summarized in a clear and concise topic sentence.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the effectiveness of different types of prison sentences in reducing crime rates.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the legal grounds on which a judge can sentence a person to death.â€

      • â€œThe new language-learning software is designed to help students write grammatically correct sentences.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Phrase, clause, statement, verdict; (Verb) Punish, condemn, convict.

Opposite words: (Noun) Fragment, run-on; (Verb) Acquit, exonerate.

Where it comes from: From Latin sententia (opinion, way of thinking).

6.20.119. Doubtfully#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆdaÊŠtfÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that shows a lack of certainty or confidence.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdoubtfullyâ€ is to do something with a feeling of uncertainty, hesitation, or suspicion, lacking confidence in a belief or outcome.

What it really means: â€œDoubtfullyâ€ is an adverb used to describe an action that is done with a lack of certainty or confidence. It suggests that a person is not sure about something, and their actions reflect that feeling. For example, if you say â€œIâ€™m not sure,â€ you are speaking doubtfully.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done with a lack of certainty or confidence.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œto say doubtfully,â€ â€œto look doubtfully,â€ â€œto think doubtfully.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe looked at the map doubtfully, not sure if he was going the right way.â€

      • â€œShe said doubtfully, â€˜Are you sure this will work?â€™â€

      • â€œI doubtfully accepted his offer, not sure if I could trust him.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the committee doubtfully accepted the new proposal, citing concerns about its financial viability.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s lack of confidence can lead them to doubtfully express their opinions in a group setting.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of being able to address a customerâ€™s concerns when they speak doubtfully about a product.â€

      • â€œThe new policy was passed doubtfully, with a very narrow margin of votes.â€

Synonyms: Uncertainly, hesitantly, sceptically, suspiciously, unconfidently.

Opposite words: Confidently, certainly, assuredly, surely, definitely.

Where it comes from: From Old French douter (to fear, to doubt).

6.20.120. Accusations#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÃ¦kjuËˆzeÉªÊƒÉ™nz/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun (plural)

  • Simple Meaning: Claims that someone has done something wrong.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œaccusationsâ€ is formal or informal claims that a person has committed a wrongdoing or crime, often without definitive proof.

What it really means: â€œAccusationsâ€ is the plural form of the noun â€œaccusation.â€ It refers to claims that a person has done something wrong. It is often used in a legal context, where a person is charged with a crime, or in a more general sense, where a person is blamed for something.

When to use it: Use it to refer to claims that someone has done something wrong.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œmake accusations,â€ â€œface accusations,â€ â€œdeny accusations.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe made a lot of false accusations about his former partner.â€

      • â€œThe politician faced accusations of corruption from the opposition.â€

      • â€œShe strongly denied all the accusations that were made against her.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report examines the legal and ethical implications of making false accusations in the workplace.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s findings are a result of a careful analysis of the accusations made against the companyâ€™s management.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of a fair and just legal system that allows a person to respond to accusations.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to protect individuals from a number of accusations that are based on discrimination.â€

Synonyms: Claims, allegations, charges, indictments, assertions.

Opposite words: Defenses, exonerations, vindications.

Where it comes from: From Latin accusatio (a charge).

6.20.121. Prescription#

  • Pronunciation: /prÉªËˆskrÉªpÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: An official order from a doctor for a patient to get a particular medicine.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œprescriptionâ€ is a written order from a medical professional for a specific medicine or treatment, or a recommendation for a particular course of action.

What it really means: A â€œprescriptionâ€ is a noun that refers to a doctorâ€™s official order for a patient to get a particular medicine. You need a prescription to get certain medications from a pharmacy. It can also refer to a recommendation for a particular course of action (â€œa prescription for successâ€).

When to use it: Use it to refer to a doctorâ€™s order for medicine or a recommendation.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa doctorâ€™s prescription,â€ â€œget a prescription,â€ â€œa prescription for.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI need to go to the pharmacy to get my prescription filled.â€

      • â€œThe doctor gave me a prescription for some antibiotics.â€

      • â€œHe said the key to a happy life is a prescription of hard work and love.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report highlights the new regulations that have been put in place for a doctorâ€™s prescription of controlled substances.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the long-term effects of a doctorâ€™s prescription of a particular type of medication.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the new law, which is designed to make it easier for people to get their prescription filled.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is a clear prescription for the government to take a more active role in the economy.â€

Synonyms: (Medical) Order, direction, instruction; (General) Recommendation, formula, plan.

Opposite words: N/A.

Where it comes from: From Latin praescriptio (an order written beforehand).

6.20.122. Entirely#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆtaÉªÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Completely; totally.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œentirelyâ€ is to be whole, complete, or without any part missing, leaving no room for a partial state.

What it really means: â€œEntirelyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is complete or whole. It is a stronger word than â€œmostlyâ€ and suggests that something is 100% true or complete. For example, if you say â€œI entirely agree with you,â€ you mean you agree with every single point.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is complete or whole.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œentirely different,â€ â€œentirely agree,â€ â€œentirely new.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe story is entirely different from what I remember.â€

      • â€œHe was entirely to blame for the accident.â€

      • â€œThe new car is an entirely new design from the old one.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report concludes that the companyâ€™s financial situation has improved entirely due to the new CEOâ€™s leadership.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s findings are entirely consistent with the results of previous research.â€

      • â€œThe document states that the new law will entirely change the way that the government regulates the industry.â€

      • â€œThe new theory is entirely based on a set of assumptions that have not yet been proven.â€

Synonyms: Completely, totally, wholly, fully, absolutely.

Opposite words: Partially, incompletely, partly, somewhat.

Where it comes from: From Old French entier (whole, complete).

6.20.123. Briefly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆbriËfli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: For a short time; in a few words.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œbrieflyâ€ is to be short in duration or concise in expression, without unnecessary length.

What it really means: â€œBrieflyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done for a short time or is said in a few words. It suggests a lack of detail or a short duration. For example, if you briefly explained something, you didnâ€™t go into a lot of detail.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done for a short time or said in a few words.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œspeak briefly,â€ â€œexplain briefly,â€ â€œstay briefly.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œIâ€™ll briefly explain the rules before we start playing.â€

      • â€œShe was only in town for a few days, so we saw her briefly.â€

      • â€œCan you briefly summarize the main points of the article?â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report briefly outlines the main findings of the study before going into more detail.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s introduction briefly summarizes the existing literature on the topic.â€

      • â€œThe document states that the new policy will be briefly discussed at the next meeting.â€

      • â€œThe new lecture series will briefly touch on a number of different topics related to the history of art.â€

Synonyms: Shortly, concisely, quickly, for a moment, in a nutshell.

Opposite words: At length, extensively, in detail, for a long time.

Where it comes from: From Latin brevis (short).

6.20.124. Tidy#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆtaÉªdi/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Adj) Arranged neatly; (Verb) To make something neat.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the adjective is to be neat, orderly, and well-arranged. The core meaning of the verb is to make something neat by arranging things in an orderly fashion.

What it really means: As an adjective, â€œtidyâ€ describes something that is neat and well-arranged (â€œa tidy roomâ€). As a verb, to â€œtidyâ€ means to make something neat and orderly (â€œto tidy up your roomâ€).

When to use it: Use the adjective to describe something that is neat, and the verb to describe making something neat.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa tidy room,â€ â€œa tidy sum.â€

    • (Verb) â€œtidy up,â€ â€œtidy your desk.â€
