      • â€œYou should tidy your room before your friends come over.â€

      • â€œHe always keeps his desk very tidy.â€

      • â€œThe house was in a tidy condition when we arrived.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new software is designed to help users organize their data into a tidy and easy-to-access format.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a tidy workspace can lead to a more productive and efficient work environment.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of maintaining a tidy record of all financial transactions.â€

      • â€œThe new regulations were put in place to ensure that all public spaces are kept in a tidy state.â€

Synonyms: (Adj) Neat, orderly, clean, organized; (Verb) Clean up, arrange, organize.

Opposite words: (Adj) Messy, untidy, disorganized, chaotic; (Verb) Mess up, disorganize.

Where it comes from: From Old English tid (time).

6.20.125. Obstacle#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÉ’bstÉ™kÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A thing that blocks oneâ€™s way or prevents progress.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œobstacleâ€ is a physical or abstract barrier that hinders progress or makes it difficult to achieve a goal.

What it really means: An â€œobstacleâ€ is a noun that refers to something that blocks your way or makes it difficult for you to do something. It can be a physical thing, such as a rock in the road, or a more abstract thing, such as a lack of money or a fear.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a thing that blocks oneâ€™s way or prevents progress.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œan obstacle to,â€ â€œovercome an obstacle,â€ â€œa major obstacle.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe biggest obstacle to our success is a lack of funding.â€

      • â€œThe car had to swerve to avoid an obstacle in the road.â€

      • â€œHe had to overcome a number of obstacles to get his degree.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that a lack of resources is a major obstacle to the countryâ€™s economic development.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the psychological obstacles that people face when trying to change their habits.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the new policies that are designed to remove the legal obstacles to international trade.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help companies overcome the technical obstacles of their old systems.â€

Synonyms: Barrier, hindrance, impediment, hurdle, block, difficulty.

Opposite words: Advantage, aid, help, support, assistance.

Where it comes from: From Latin obstare (to stand in the way).

6.20.126. Proximity#

  • Pronunciation: /prÉ’kËˆsÉªmÉªti/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: Nearness in space, time, or relationship.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œproximityâ€ is the state of being close in distance, time, or a social relationship.

What it really means: â€œProximityâ€ is a noun that refers to the state of being near to something or someone. It is a more formal word for â€œnearness.â€ For example, the proximity of the new school to the residential area is a major benefit for families.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the state of being near to something or someone.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œin close proximity,â€ â€œthe proximity to,â€ â€œdue to the proximity.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe houses were built in close proximity to each other.â€

      • â€œDue to the proximity of the hurricane, we had to evacuate.â€

      • â€œI donâ€™t like to work in such close proximity to my boss.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new factoryâ€™s proximity to the river is a major concern for environmental groups.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s physical proximity to another person can affect their social interactions.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a fire station in close proximity to a hospital.â€

      • â€œThe new housing developmentâ€™s proximity to the city center is a major selling point.â€

Synonyms: Nearness, closeness, adjacency, vicinity, immediacy.

Opposite words: Distance, remoteness, farness.

Where it comes from: From Latin proximus (nearest).

6.20.127. Invitation#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉªnvÉªËˆteÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A written or spoken request to someone to go somewhere or to do something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œinvitationâ€ is an act of asking someone to participate in an event or activity, or to come to a place.

What it really means: An â€œinvitationâ€ is a noun that refers to a request to someone to come to an event, such as a party or a wedding. It can be a formal written card or a casual spoken request.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a request to someone to go somewhere or to do something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œan official invitation,â€ â€œa formal invitation,â€ â€œaccept an invitation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI received an invitation to his birthday party.â€

      • â€œHe gave me a verbal invitation to come over for dinner.â€

      • â€œThank you for the invitation; I would love to come.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the government has issued an official invitation to the foreign minister to visit the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how the use of a formal invitation can affect a personâ€™s decision to attend an event.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the legal requirements for a company to issue an official invitation to a foreign employee.â€

      • â€œThe new museum will host a special exhibition and has sent out invitations to a number of prominent artists.â€

Synonyms: Request, summons, call, bid, plea.

Opposite words: Rejection, exclusion, refusal.

Where it comes from: From Latin invitatio (a summoning).

6.20.128. Harmful#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆhÉ‘ËmfÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Causing or likely to cause harm.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œharmfulâ€ is to be injurious, damaging, or detrimental to a person, thing, or environment.

What it really means: â€œHarmfulâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that causes harm or damage. It suggests a negative or dangerous effect. For example, a harmful chemical is a chemical that can cause damage to a personâ€™s health.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that causes harm or damage.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œharmful effects,â€ â€œharmful chemicals,â€ â€œa harmful habit.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œSmoking is a very harmful habit.â€

      • â€œThe factoryâ€™s waste is harmful to the environment.â€

      • â€œEating too much sugar can have harmful effects on your teeth.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report concludes that the new pesticide has a number of harmful effects on the local ecosystem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the harmful psychological effects of bullying on children.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the new regulations that have been put in place to prevent the release of harmful chemicals into the air.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to protect consumers from harmful products that are sold online.â€

Synonyms: Damaging, injurious, detrimental, dangerous, unhealthy.

Opposite words: Harmless, beneficial, helpful, safe, advantageous.

Where it comes from: From Old English hearm (harm, injury).

6.20.129. Identification#

  • Pronunciation: /aÉªËŒdÉ›ntÉªfÉªËˆkeÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action of identifying someone or something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œidentificationâ€ is the process of recognizing and confirming the identity of a person or thing, or a document used for that purpose.

What it really means: â€œIdentificationâ€ is a noun that refers to the act of identifying someone or something. It can be the process of recognizing a person from a picture, or a document, such as a passport, that is used to prove a personâ€™s identity.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of identifying someone or something or a document used to prove identity.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œphoto identification,â€ â€œa form of identification,â€ â€œthe identification of a suspect.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI need to see some form of identification before I can let you in.â€

      • â€œThe police are working on the identification of the suspect.â€

      • â€œThe detective was able to make a positive identification of the stolen car.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new regulations require a number of different forms of identification for a person to open a bank account.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the new technologies that are being used for the identification of rare species of animals.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear process for the identification of all new employees.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to make it easier for people to get official forms of identification.â€

Synonyms: Recognition, authentication, verification, credentials, ID.

Opposite words: Misidentification.

Where it comes from: From Latin identitas (sameness).

6.20.130. Primary#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆpraÉªmÉ™ri/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Most important; main.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œprimaryâ€ is to be the first, most important, or fundamental in a series or hierarchy.

What it really means: â€œPrimaryâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is most important or main. It suggests that something is the first or the most essential thing to consider. For example, a primary goal is the most important goal.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is most important or main.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa primary concern,â€ â€œa primary goal,â€ â€œa primary source.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œMy primary goal for this year is to save enough money to buy a car.â€

      • â€œThe primary concern of the government is to create new jobs.â€

      • â€œThe primary reason I came here was to see you.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report argues that the primary cause of the problem is a lack of funding for the public education system.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the role of a childâ€™s primary caregiver in their early development.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of using a primary source of information for all historical research.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the primary needs of the working class.â€

Synonyms: Main, chief, principal, fundamental, key, essential.

Opposite words: Secondary, subordinate, minor, auxiliary, unimportant.

Where it comes from: From Latin primarius (of the first rank).

6.20.131. Dependent#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆpÉ›ndÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Adj) Relying on someone or something else for support; (Noun) A person who relies on another for support.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the adjective is to be controlled or influenced by something else. The core meaning of the noun is a person who relies on another for financial support.

What it really means: As an adjective, â€œdependentâ€ describes a person or a thing that relies on another person or a thing for support. For example, a child is dependent on their parents. It can also describe a situation where one thing relies on another (â€œour success is dependent on your helpâ€). As a noun, a â€œdependentâ€ is a person, usually a child, who relies on another for financial support.

When to use it: Use the adjective to describe a person or a thing that relies on another, and the noun to refer to a person who relies on another for support.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œdependent on,â€ â€œmutually dependent.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa financial dependent.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe success of the project is dependent on the teamâ€™s hard work.â€

      • â€œHe has two dependents to support, so he canâ€™t quit his job.â€

      • â€œThe country is dependent on foreign aid for its survival.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report argues that the countryâ€™s economy is too dependent on a single export.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the effects of a parentâ€™s unemployment on their dependent children.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of providing social support for all dependent members of the community.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to help people become less dependent on the government.â€

Synonyms: (Adj) Reliant, conditional, subject to, controlled by; (Noun) Ward, charge.

Opposite words: (Adj) Independent, self-reliant, autonomous; (Noun) Independent.

Where it comes from: From Latin dependere (to hang down from).

6.20.132. Trigger#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆtrÉªÉ¡É™r/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) An event or thing that causes something to happen; (Verb) To cause something to happen.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is a specific event or action that initiates a chain reaction. The core meaning of the verb is to start or activate a process or event.

What it really means: As a noun, a â€œtriggerâ€ is an event or a thing that causes something to happen. For example, a specific sound can be a trigger for a personâ€™s anxiety. As a verb, to â€œtriggerâ€ means to cause something to happen.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to an event that causes something to happen, and the verb to describe causing something to happen.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa trigger for,â€ â€œa psychological trigger.â€

    • (Verb) â€œtrigger an event,â€ â€œtrigger a response.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe loud noise was a trigger for my dogâ€™s anxiety.â€

      • â€œHis rude comment triggered an argument between us.â€

      • â€œThe new law could trigger a wave of protests.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that a specific chemical can trigger a powerful allergic reaction in some people.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the psychological triggers that can lead to a personâ€™s relapse into addiction.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of understanding the events that can trigger a financial crisis.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to trigger a new era of economic growth.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Catalyst, stimulus, cause, instigator; (Verb) Cause, prompt, activate, initiate, provoke.

Opposite words: (Noun) Result, outcome, effect; (Verb) Stop, prevent, inhibit.

Where it comes from: From Old English trygg (a trigger).

6.20.133. Erroneous#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªËˆrÉ™ÊŠniÉ™s/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Incorrect or based on a wrong idea.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œerroneousâ€ is to be wrong or incorrect, based on a mistaken belief or a false premise.

What it really means: â€œErroneousâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is incorrect or based on a wrong idea. It is a more formal word for â€œwrongâ€ or â€œmistaken.â€ For example, an erroneous belief is a belief that is not true.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is incorrect or based on a wrong idea.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œerroneous belief,â€ â€œerroneous conclusion,â€ â€œerroneous assumption.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe scientistâ€™s conclusion was based on an erroneous assumption.â€

      • â€œHe made an erroneous claim about the companyâ€™s financial status.â€

      • â€œThe test result was an erroneous reading.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report argues that the previous studyâ€™s findings were based on an erroneous methodology.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how an erroneous belief system can lead a person to make poor decisions.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of correcting any erroneous information in the public record.â€

      • â€œThe new law was passed to prevent the spread of erroneous information online.â€

Synonyms: Incorrect, wrong, mistaken, false, flawed.

Opposite words: Correct, accurate, valid, true, sound.

Where it comes from: From Latin erroneus (wandering).

6.20.134. Incidence#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÉªnsÉªdÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The occurrence or frequency of a disease, crime, or other unwanted thing.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œincidenceâ€ is the rate at which something, especially something negative, occurs or is reported, often used in a statistical or medical context.

What it really means: â€œIncidenceâ€ is a noun that refers to the rate or frequency of something, usually something negative, such as a disease or a crime. It is a more formal word for â€œrateâ€ or â€œoccurrence.â€ For example, the incidence of heart disease has decreased in the last decade.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the rate or frequency of something, usually something negative.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œthe incidence of,â€ â€œa high incidence.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe incidence of violent crime in the city has been increasing recently.â€

      • â€œThe doctor said the incidence of the flu is very high this year.â€

      • â€œWe are trying to reduce the incidence of workplace accidents.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the incidence of this particular illness is higher among older adults.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the factors that contribute to the high incidence of poverty in the region.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the new policies that are designed to reduce the incidence of traffic accidents.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to reduce the incidence of fraud in the financial industry.â€

Synonyms: Frequency, rate, occurrence, prevalence, regularity.

Opposite words: N/A.

Where it comes from: From Latin incidere (to fall upon).

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œleadingâ€ is to be in a position of first or most important, often in terms of influence, rank, or position.

What it really means: â€œLeadingâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is most important or main. It suggests that something is in a position of authority or is the most significant. For example, a leading cause of death is the main cause.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is most important or main.

Synonyms: Main, chief, principal, primary, foremost, preeminent.

6.20.136. Sufficiency#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™ËˆfÉªÊƒÉ™nsi/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The state or quality of being enough.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsufficiencyâ€ is the state of having or being enough of something, to a degree that meets a need or requirement without excess.

What it really means: â€œSufficiencyâ€ is a noun that refers to the state of having enough of something. It suggests that a person has what they need and nothing more. It is a more formal word for â€œenough.â€ For example, a personâ€™s income should provide for the sufficiency of their family.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the state of having enough of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa sufficiency of,â€ â€œto have sufficiency.â€

  • Examples:

      • â€œThe new budget will provide for the sufficiency of the schoolâ€™s needs.â€

      • â€œHe has a sufficiency of food and water to last him for a week.â€

      • â€œThe sufficiency of the evidence was a key point in the trial.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the countryâ€™s food supply is currently at a state of sufficiency to meet the needs of the population.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s feeling of sufficiency can affect their overall happiness and well-being.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a sufficiency of trained personnel to respond to a major emergency.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to ensure the sufficiency of the resources available for the new project.â€

Synonyms: Adequacy, enough, completeness, abundance, plenty.

Opposite words: Insufficiency, lack, shortage, deficiency, inadequacy.

Where it comes from: From Latin sufficere (to be enough).

6.20.137. Hardly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆhÉ‘Ëdli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Almost not; scarcely.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œhardlyâ€ is to a degree that is almost not or very little, suggesting that something is just barely happening or is unlikely.

What it really means: â€œHardlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is almost not happening. It suggests that something is very rare or unlikely. For example, if you say â€œI hardly know him,â€ you mean you know him very little.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is almost not happening.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œhardly ever,â€ â€œhardly anything,â€ â€œhardly anyone.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI hardly ever go to the movies anymore.â€

      • â€œThere was hardly anything left to eat after the party.â€

      • â€œThe new rules have hardly had any effect on the situation.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy has hardly had any impact on the unemployment rate in the country.â€

      • â€œThe studyâ€™s findings suggest that the new medication is hardly any more effective than the old one.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the fact that there is hardly any public support for the new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology has hardly been used in the industry, and its potential is still unknown.â€

Synonyms: Scarcely, barely, rarely, almost not.

Opposite words: Easily, frequently, often, a lot, much.

Where it comes from: From Old English heardlice (with great effort).

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÃ¦kwÉªËˆzÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The act of getting or obtaining something.

      • â€œThe new law is designed to make it easier for people to get the acquisition of a new home.â€

Synonyms: Gaining, obtaining, purchase, procurement, learning.

6.20.139. Exclude#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªkËˆskluËd/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To leave someone or something out of a group or activity.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œexcludeâ€ is to keep something or someone out of a group, a place, or a process.

What it really means: To â€œexcludeâ€ means to leave someone or something out of a group or an activity. It is the opposite of â€œinclude.â€ For example, if you exclude a person from a meeting, you donâ€™t let them in.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of leaving someone or something out.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œexclude from,â€ â€œexclude a possibility,â€ â€œexclude a person.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWe decided to exclude that possibility from our list of options.â€

      • â€œThe new policy will exclude a number of people from receiving the benefits.â€

      • â€œDonâ€™t exclude me from the conversation.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report argues that the new policy will exclude a large number of people from the social welfare program.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the factors that can lead to the exclusion of a person from a social group.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and objective process for deciding which applicants to exclude.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to exclude companies that do not meet the new safety standards.â€

Synonyms: Omit, leave out, bar, ban, prohibit, shut out.

Opposite words: Include, admit, welcome, accept, incorporate.

Where it comes from: From Latin excludere (to shut out).

6.20.140. Coincidence#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™ÊŠËˆÉªnsÉªdÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A surprising occurrence of two or more events at the same time, seemingly by chance.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcoincidenceâ€ is a remarkable or surprising set of events that occur at the same time but seem to have no direct causal link.

What it really means: A â€œcoincidenceâ€ is a noun that refers to a surprising event where two or more things happen at the same time, seemingly by chance. For example, it is a coincidence if you meet a person in a different city who you know from your hometown.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a surprising event where two or more things happen at the same time.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa strange coincidence,â€ â€œwhat a coincidence,â€ â€œby sheer coincidence.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œIt was a strange coincidence that we were both at the same coffee shop at the same time.â€

      • â€œBy sheer coincidence, I was thinking of you when you called.â€

      • â€œThe two events happened by coincidence and were not connected.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the two events, while happening at the same time, were a coincidence and not related to each other.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the human tendency to attribute meaning to coincidence and find patterns where none exist.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of not assuming a connection between two events just because of a coincidence.â€

      • â€œThe new policy was put in place at the same time as the new law, but this was a complete coincidence.â€

Synonyms: Chance, fluke, accident, serendipity, synchronicity.

Opposite words: Deliberate act, plan, design.

Where it comes from: From Latin coincidere (to fall together).

6.20.141. Regulation#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒrÉ›É¡juËˆleÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A rule or directive made and maintained by an authority.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œregulationâ€ is a rule, law, or directive created by an authority to control or govern a specific activity or area.

What it really means: A â€œregulationâ€ is a noun that refers to an official rule or law that is made and maintained by an authority. It is often used to refer to a rule that a company or a person must follow. For example, a new regulation on food safety was passed by the government.

When to use it: Use it to refer to an official rule or law.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œgovernment regulation,â€ â€œsafety regulation,â€ â€œa new regulation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe company has to follow all the new government regulations.â€

      • â€œThe new safety regulations for the workplace are very strict.â€

      • â€œThere is a new regulation about how to dispose of waste.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report examines the effects of a new government regulation on the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe study highlights the importance of having clear and consistent regulations in the financial industry.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the new regulations that have been put in place to protect the environment.â€

      • â€œThe new law is a good example of a new regulation that is designed to protect consumers.â€

Synonyms: Rule, law, directive, statute, ordinance, control.

Opposite words: Deregulation, freedom, anarchy.

Where it comes from: From Latin regulatio (a regulating).

6.20.142. Indifferent#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆdÉªfrÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Having no particular interest or sympathy; unconcerned.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œindifferentâ€ is to be unconcerned, without interest, or lacking a preference for one thing over another.

What it really means: â€œIndifferentâ€ is an adjective used to describe a person who has no particular interest or sympathy for something. It suggests a lack of concern or a neutral attitude. For example, a person can be indifferent to what they eat for dinner, meaning they donâ€™t care what they have.

When to use it: Use it to describe a person who has no particular interest or sympathy.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œindifferent to,â€ â€œan indifferent attitude.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe was indifferent to the outcome of the game, since he didnâ€™t care who won.â€

      • â€œThe governmentâ€™s indifferent attitude toward the crisis was widely criticized.â€

      • â€œIâ€™m indifferent to what we have for dinner tonight; you can choose.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the companyâ€™s indifferent approach to customer service has led to a loss of business.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s indifferent attitude to the suffering of others can be a sign of a mental health issue.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of not being indifferent to the social problems in the community.â€

      • â€œThe new law was passed despite the indifferent response of the public.â€

Synonyms: Unconcerned, apathetic, uninterested, unconcerned, neutral.

Opposite words: Concerned, interested, caring, enthusiastic, passionate.

Where it comes from: From Latin indifferens (not different).

6.20.143. Rescue#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆrÉ›skjuË/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To save someone from a dangerous or difficult situation; (Noun) An act of saving someone.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the verb is to save a person or thing from danger or harm. The core meaning of the noun is the act of saving someone from a perilous situation.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œrescueâ€ means to save someone or something from a dangerous or difficult situation. As a noun, a â€œrescueâ€ is the act of saving someone. For example, a lifeguard might rescue a person who is drowning, and that act would be a rescue.

When to use it: Use the verb to describe saving someone, and the noun to refer to the act of saving someone.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œrescue from,â€ â€œrescue a person.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa dramatic rescue,â€ â€œa fire rescue.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe firefighter was able to rescue the cat from the tree.â€

      • â€œHe jumped into the water to rescue the drowning child.â€

      • â€œThe dog was a rescue from the local animal shelter.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the governmentâ€™s intervention was a rescue of the failing industry.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the psychological effects of being a part of a search and rescue team.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear plan for the rescue of people from a burning building.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to rescue the countryâ€™s economy from a state of crisis.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Save, free, deliver, liberate; (Noun) Salvation, liberation, deliverance.

Opposite words: (Verb) Abandon, endanger, imperil; (Noun) Abandonment, peril.

Where it comes from: From Old French rescorre (to save).

6.20.144. Endure#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆdjÊŠÉ™r/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To suffer something difficult or unpleasant patiently.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œendureâ€ is to continue to exist or to suffer through a difficult or painful experience with resilience and patience.

What it really means: To â€œendureâ€ means to suffer through something difficult or unpleasant patiently. It suggests a certain level of strength and resilience. For example, a person can endure a difficult illness or a long period of hardship.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of suffering through something difficult patiently.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œendure pain,â€ â€œendure hardship,â€ â€œendure a difficult time.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œShe had to endure a lot of pain after the surgery.â€

      • â€œThe soldiers had to endure a long winter with very little food.â€

      • â€œI canâ€™t endure this heat; itâ€™s too hot.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the countryâ€™s population has had to endure a long period of political instability.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to endure stress can affect their overall health and well-being.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of providing support for people who have to endure a difficult and challenging time.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to help the countryâ€™s economy endure a period of low growth.â€

Synonyms: Tolerate, bear, withstand, suffer, persevere.

Opposite words: Surrender, give up, succumb, collapse, yield.

Where it comes from: From Latin indurare (to make hard).

6.20.145. Precise#

  • Pronunciation: /prÉªËˆsaÉªs/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Exact, accurate, and careful.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpreciseâ€ is to be exact, accurate, and sharply defined, without any ambiguity or vagueness.

What it really means: â€œPreciseâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is exact, accurate, and careful. It suggests a high level of detail and a lack of ambiguity. For example, a precise measurement is an exact measurement.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is exact, accurate, and careful.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa precise measurement,â€ â€œa precise answer,â€ â€œa precise time.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI need to know the precise time of the meeting.â€

      • â€œHe gave me a precise answer to my question.â€

      • â€œThe recipe calls for a precise amount of sugar.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report highlights the need for precise data collection to ensure the accuracy of the studyâ€™s findings.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s precise use of language can affect their ability to communicate effectively.â€

      • â€œThe document outlines the new system, which is designed to provide a precise reading of the temperature.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to provide a precise definition of the legal terms used in the document.â€

Synonyms: Exact, accurate, specific, correct, meticulous.

Opposite words: Imprecise, vague, approximate, inexact, general.

Where it comes from: From Latin praecisus (cut off, brief).

6.20.146. Purpose#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆpÉœËpÉ™s/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The reason for which something is done or created.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpurposeâ€ is the reason or intention behind an action, an object, or a personâ€™s existence, providing meaning and direction.

What it really means: â€œPurposeâ€ is a noun that refers to the reason for which something is done or created. It is the why behind an action or a thing. For example, the purpose of a car is to get from one place to another.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the reason for which something is done or created.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œthe purpose of,â€ â€œwith a purpose,â€ â€œa sense of purpose.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe purpose of this meeting is to discuss the new project.â€

      • â€œI have a strong sense of purpose in my life.â€

      • â€œThe new machine serves no purpose that I can see.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report outlines the purpose of the new policy, which is to reduce unemployment.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s sense of purpose can affect their overall happiness and well-being.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear purpose for all new projects.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to fulfill the purpose of protecting the environment.â€

Synonyms: Reason, intention, aim, goal, objective, function.

Opposite words: Pointlessness, aimlessness, futility, meaninglessness.

Where it comes from: From Old French porpos (an aim).

6.20.147. Acceptance#

  • Pronunciation: /É™kËˆsÉ›ptÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action of receiving something or the state of being received.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œacceptanceâ€ is the act of receiving or agreeing to something, or a state of being in harmony with a situation.

What it really means: â€œAcceptanceâ€ is a noun that refers to the act of receiving something or the state of being received. It can be the acceptance of an offer, the acceptance of a new idea, or the acceptance of a person into a group.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of receiving something or the state of being received.

      • â€œHe struggled to get the acceptance of his new friends.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to promote the acceptance of diversity in the workplace.â€

Synonyms: Approval, agreement, reception, endorsement, welcome.

Opposite words: Rejection, refusal, denial, disapproval.

Where it comes from: From Latin accipere (to take, to receive).

6.20.148. Efficient#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªËˆfÉªÊƒÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Achieving maximum productivity with minimum wasted effort or expense.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œefficientâ€ is to achieve a desired result without wasting resources, such as time, money, or energy.

What it really means: â€œEfficientâ€ is an adjective used to describe a person, a machine, or a process that works well and without wasting time, money, or energy. It suggests a high level of productivity and a lack of waste. For example, an efficient worker is a person who gets a lot of work done in a short amount of time.

When to use it: Use it to describe a person, a machine, or a process that works well without wasting resources.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œan efficient worker,â€ â€œan efficient system,â€ â€œan efficient use of resources.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new machine is very efficient and uses very little electricity.â€

      • â€œShe is a very efficient worker and gets a lot done in a short time.â€

      • â€œWe need to find a more efficient way to do this task.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report argues that the new system is a more efficient way to manage the companyâ€™s resources.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the factors that contribute to a personâ€™s ability to be a more efficient learner.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having an efficient public transport system to reduce traffic congestion.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to promote a more efficient use of the countryâ€™s energy resources.â€

Synonyms: Productive, effective, streamlined, organized, economical.

Opposite words: Inefficient, wasteful, unproductive, ineffective, clumsy.

Where it comes from: From Latin efficere (to carry out, to effect).

6.20.150. Disrupt#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªsËˆrÊŒpt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To interrupt an event, activity, or process by causing a disturbance or problem.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdisruptâ€ is to break apart or throw into disorder, thereby interrupting the normal course of something.

What it really means: To â€œdisruptâ€ means to interrupt an event or a process by causing a disturbance or a problem. It suggests that something is being broken or thrown into a state of disorder. For example, a sudden noise can disrupt a meeting.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of interrupting an event or a process.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œdisrupt a meeting,â€ â€œdisrupt a process,â€ â€œdisrupt a system.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe loud music from the neighborâ€™s house disrupted my sleep.â€

      • â€œA sudden power outage disrupted the whole city.â€

      • â€œWe had to stop the meeting because of a technical problem that disrupted the video call.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new technology has the potential to disrupt the entire industry.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a lack of funding can disrupt the educational process in a developing country.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the new laws that are designed to prevent protesters from disrupting public order.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to disrupt the flow of illegal goods into the country.â€

Synonyms: Interrupt, disturb, upset, interfere with, halt.

Opposite words: Continue, maintain, support, facilitate, assist.

Where it comes from: From Latin disrumpere (to break apart).

6.20.151. Anticipation#

  • Pronunciation: /Ã¦nËŒtÉªsÉªËˆpeÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action of expecting or predicting something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œanticipationâ€ is the feeling of excited expectation for something that is going to happen in the future.

What it really means: â€œAnticipationâ€ is a noun that refers to the feeling of expecting or predicting something. It is often used to describe a feeling of excitement or anxiety about a future event. For example, there was a lot of anticipation for the new movie.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the feeling of expecting or predicting something.

    • (Noun) â€œin anticipation of,â€ â€œa sense of anticipation,â€ â€œfull of anticipation.â€

      • â€œThe children were full of anticipation for their birthday party.â€

      • â€œIn anticipation of the storm, we bought extra food and water.â€

      • â€œThere was a lot of anticipation for the new album to be released.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the companyâ€™s stock price has risen in anticipation of the new productâ€™s release.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s level of anticipation can affect their experience of an event.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of planning in anticipation of any potential problems.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the publicâ€™s anticipation of a new economic crisis.â€

Synonyms: Expectation, foresight, hope, suspense, excitement.

Opposite words: Surprise, unexpectedness, doubt, dread.

Where it comes from: From Latin anticipatio (a taking before).

6.20.152. Dissolve#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆzÉ’lv/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To become or cause to become incorporated into a liquid so as to form a solution.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdissolveâ€ is to break down or be absorbed into a liquid, or to bring something to an end by breaking it apart.

What it really means: To â€œdissolveâ€ means to become or cause to become incorporated into a liquid. For example, sugar dissolves in water. It can also mean to bring something to an end, such as a marriage or a company.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of becoming or causing to become incorporated into a liquid, or to bring something to an end.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œdissolve in water,â€ â€œdissolve a company,â€ â€œdissolve a marriage.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œYou can dissolve the sugar in the hot tea.â€

      • â€œThe company decided to dissolve the partnership after a few years.â€

      • â€œThe protest was peaceful and dissolved on its own.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new chemical is designed to dissolve pollutants in the water.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the factors that can cause a company to dissolve its operations.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the legal process for a company to dissolve its partnership with another firm.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to help companies that are in a process of dissolving their business.â€

Synonyms: Melt, disintegrate, break up, terminate, end.

Opposite words: Solidify, form, create, establish, unite.

Where it comes from: From Latin dissolvere (to loosen, to break up).

  • Pronunciation: /fÉ™ËŒmÉªliËˆÃ¦rÉªti/

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The state of knowing something or someone very well.

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a good familiarity with the laws of the country.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to promote a sense of familiarity with the new government.â€

Synonyms: Acquaintance, knowledge, intimacy, closeness, expertise.

Where it comes from: From Latin familiaris (of a family).

6.20.154. Fairly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆfÉ›É™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: To a moderate extent; reasonably.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œfairlyâ€ is to a moderate or reasonable degree, suggesting something is not extreme but is a bit more than average.

What it really means: â€œFairlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something to a moderate extent or reasonably. It is a word used to soften a statement, and it suggests that something is not extremely good or bad, but somewhere in the middle. For example, â€œthe weather was fairly niceâ€ means it was nice, but not exceptionally nice.

When to use it: Use it to describe something to a moderate extent or reasonably.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œfairly well,â€ â€œfairly good,â€ â€œfairly easy.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe test was fairly easy, so I think I did well.â€

      • â€œIâ€™m fairly sure that Iâ€™ll be able to get there on time.â€

      • â€œThe food was fairly good, but not the best Iâ€™ve ever had.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy has been fairly successful in achieving its goals.â€

      • â€œThe study found that the new medicine is fairly effective in treating the disease.â€

      • â€œThe document states that the new law has been fairly well-received by the public.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is fairly simple to use and has a lot of potential.â€

Synonyms: Quite, reasonably, moderately, somewhat, rather.

Opposite words: Extremely, very, completely, totally.

Where it comes from: From Old English fager (beautiful, pleasing).

6.20.155. Repetitive#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆpÉ›tÉ™tÉªv/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Containing or characterized by repetition, especially when this is considered boring or uninteresting.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrepetitiveâ€ is to be marked by the constant recurrence of the same thing, which often leads to monotony or boredom.

What it really means: â€œRepetitiveâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is repeated many times, often to the point of being boring or uninteresting. For example, a repetitive task is a task that you have to do over and over again.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is repeated many times, often to the point of being boring or uninteresting.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa repetitive task,â€ â€œa repetitive song,â€ â€œa repetitive motion.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe work I do is very repetitive and boring.â€

      • â€œI donâ€™t like this song because the chorus is too repetitive.â€

      • â€œDoing this kind of work can lead to a repetitive strain injury.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that a repetitive work environment can lead to a decrease in employee motivation.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a repetitive learning process can affect a studentâ€™s ability to learn new things.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the new regulations that are designed to prevent workers from having to do repetitive tasks.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help companies automate repetitive tasks and free up their employees to do more creative work.â€

Synonyms: Monotonous, tedious, tiresome, unvaried.

Opposite words: Varied, diverse, exciting, stimulating, new.

Where it comes from: From Latin repetere (to repeat).

6.20.156. Widespread#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆwaÉªdsprÉ›d/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œwidespreadâ€ is to be present or prevalent across a broad area or among a large number of people, indicating broad distribution.

What it really means: â€œWidespreadâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is found or distributed over a large area or among many people. For example, widespread support for a new law means a lot of people support it.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is found or distributed over a large area or among many people.

    • (Adjective) â€œwidespread support,â€ â€œwidespread use,â€ â€œwidespread damage.â€

      • â€œThe new disease has become widespread in the country.â€

      • â€œThere was widespread damage after the hurricane.â€

      • â€œThe idea of going to the movies is a widespread form of entertainment.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that there is widespread concern about the effects of climate change.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the factors that contribute to the widespread use of social media among young people.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the new policies that are designed to address the widespread problem of poverty.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a result of widespread research and development in the field.â€

Synonyms: Extensive, prevalent, pervasive, common, general.

Opposite words: Limited, restricted, narrow, localized, isolated.

Where it comes from: From Old English wid (wide) and sprÃ¦d (spread).

6.20.157. Regulate#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆrÉ›É¡jÉ™leÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To control or maintain the rate or speed of a machine or system so that it operates properly.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œregulateâ€ is to control or govern something by rules or methods, ensuring that it operates according to a set standard.

What it really means: To â€œregulateâ€ means to control or maintain the rate or speed of a machine or system so that it operates properly. It can also mean to control something by rules or laws. For example, the government can regulate the financial industry.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of controlling or maintaining something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œregulate the temperature,â€ â€œregulate an industry,â€ â€œregulate a system.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe thermostat is used to regulate the temperature in the room.â€

      • â€œThe government needs to regulate the use of drones.â€

      • â€œThe new laws were put in place to regulate the online content.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new laws are designed to regulate the use of social media in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s body can regulate its own temperature in different environments.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent system to regulate the flow of traffic.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to regulate the use of natural resources in the country.â€

Synonyms: Control, govern, manage, adjust, supervise.

Opposite words: Deregulate, free, loosen, release, let go.

Where it comes from: From Latin regulare (to control by rule).

6.20.158. Failure#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆfeÉªljÉ™r/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The act of not succeeding in something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œfailureâ€ is the lack of success or the inability to achieve a desired outcome, whether in an action or an event.

What it really means: â€œFailureâ€ is a noun that refers to the act of not succeeding in something. It can be the failure of a plan, the failure of a project, or the failure of a person to achieve a goal.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of not succeeding in something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa complete failure,â€ â€œa failure to,â€ â€œa failure of.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe project was a complete failure because we ran out of money.â€

      • â€œHis failure to get the job was a big disappointment to him.â€

      • â€œThe governmentâ€™s failure to address the problem led to a lot of protests.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the failure of the previous policy was due to a lack of funding and public support.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the factors that can lead to a personâ€™s failure to achieve their goals.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of learning from past failures and not making the same mistakes again.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to prevent the failure of the countryâ€™s economy.â€

Synonyms: Defeat, collapse, downfall, disaster, shortcoming.

Opposite words: Success, achievement, victory, triumph, accomplishment.

Where it comes from: From Old French faillir (to fail).

6.20.159. Accidentally#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÃ¦ksÉªËˆdÉ›ntÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: By chance; unintentionally.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œaccidentallyâ€ is to occur or happen by chance or without deliberate intention.

What it really means: â€œAccidentallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that happens by chance or unintentionally. It suggests that something was not planned or done on purpose. For example, if you accidentally drop your phone, you didnâ€™t mean to do it.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that happens by chance or unintentionally.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œaccidentally on purpose,â€ â€œaccidentally deleted,â€ â€œaccidentally found.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI accidentally deleted all the files from my computer.â€

      • â€œShe accidentally ran into her old friend at the store.â€

      • â€œHe accidentally said the wrong thing and offended everyone.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the company accidentally released confidential information to the public.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s mistakes can accidentally lead to a new discovery.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear process to prevent employees from accidentally deleting important data.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to protect people who accidentally break the law.â€

Synonyms: Unintentionally, inadvertently, by mistake, by chance.

Opposite words: Intentionally, deliberately, on purpose, purposely.

Where it comes from: From Latin accidens (a happening).

6.20.160. Broadly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆbrÉ”Ëdli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In general terms; in a wide range of ways.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œbroadlyâ€ is to be in a wide or general way, without focusing on specific details.

What it really means: â€œBroadlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something in general terms or in a wide range of ways. It suggests that you are not going into a lot of detail, but are giving a general overview. For example, â€œthe book is broadly about historyâ€ means that it covers a lot of different historical topics.

When to use it: Use it to describe something in general terms or in a wide range of ways.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œbroadly speaking,â€ â€œbroadly similar,â€ â€œbroadly in agreement.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œBroadly speaking, I think youâ€™re right about that.â€

      • â€œThe two ideas are broadly similar, but there are some differences.â€

      • â€œWe are broadly in agreement on the main points of the plan.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is broadly in line with the governmentâ€™s long-term goals.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how the two different theories are broadly similar in their conclusions.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the new laws that are broadly designed to protect the environment.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is broadly applicable to a number of different industries.â€

Synonyms: Generally, widely, largely, in a general way, in the main.

Opposite words: Narrowly, specifically, precisely, exactly, particularly.

Where it comes from: From Old English brad (broad).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆsÉªmpÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Easily understood or done; not complicated.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsimpleâ€ is to be easy to understand or do, without any complexity or difficulty.

What it really means: â€œSimpleâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is easily understood or done. It suggests a lack of complexity or difficulty. For example, a simple recipe is a recipe that is easy to follow.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is easily understood or done.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa simple question,â€ â€œa simple task,â€ â€œa simple solution.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe instructions were so simple that I finished the task in no time.â€

      • â€œItâ€™s a very simple problem with an even more simple solution.â€

      • â€œI like to keep my life simple and not have a lot of things.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new software has a simple and easy-to-use interface.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s simple lifestyle can lead to a more fulfilling life.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of providing a simple explanation of the new policy.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to provide a simple and effective solution to the problem of unemployment.â€

Synonyms: Easy, straightforward, uncomplicated, basic, clear.

Opposite words: Complicated, difficult, complex, intricate, elaborate.

Where it comes from: From Latin simplex (simple, single).

6.20.162. Benefit#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆbÉ›nÉªfÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) An advantage or profit gained from something; (Verb) To receive an advantage.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is a positive effect or advantage that is gained from something. The core meaning of the verb is to receive a positive effect from something.

What it really means: As a noun, a â€œbenefitâ€ is an advantage or a profit that is gained from something. For example, a good education is a benefit to a personâ€™s life. As a verb, to â€œbenefitâ€ means to receive an advantage from something.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to an advantage or a profit, and the verb to describe receiving an advantage.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa clear benefit,â€ â€œfor the benefit of,â€ â€œto your benefit.â€

    • (Verb) â€œbenefit from,â€ â€œbenefit a person.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new gym is a great benefit to the community.â€

      • â€œI benefit from getting a good nightâ€™s sleep every night.â€

      • â€œThe new law is for the benefit of all the people.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy will have a number of social and economic benefits.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a person can benefit from a healthy diet and regular exercise.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the new policies that are designed to provide a number of benefits for the working class.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to benefit the entire industry by making it more efficient.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Advantage, gain, good, profit, help; (Verb) Gain, profit, help, assist.

Opposite words: (Noun) Disadvantage, drawback, harm, loss; (Verb) Harm, hurt, disadvantage.

Where it comes from: From Latin benefacere (to do good).

6.20.163. Currently#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkÊŒrÉ™ntli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: At the present time.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcurrentlyâ€ is to be at this very moment or in the present time period, indicating a temporary state.

What it really means: â€œCurrentlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is happening at the present time. It is a more formal word for â€œnow.â€ For example, the company is currently working on a new project.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is happening at the present time.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œcurrently in use,â€ â€œcurrently unavailable,â€ â€œcurrently working on.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe book is currently on my desk, so I can give it to you later.â€

      • â€œI am currently looking for a new job.â€

      • â€œThe system is currently down for maintenance.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the company is currently in a state of financial crisis.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the new policies that are currently being implemented by the government.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the fact that the new law is currently being debated in parliament.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is currently being tested and is not yet available to the public.â€

Synonyms: At present, at the moment, now, presently.

Opposite words: Previously, formerly, in the past.

Where it comes from: From Latin currens (running).

6.20.164. Sustain#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™ËˆsteÉªn/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To strengthen or support physically or mentally.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsustainâ€ is to keep something going or to provide the necessary support for it to continue, often over a long period.

What it really means: To â€œsustainâ€ means to strengthen or support something physically or mentally. It can also mean to keep something going over a long period of time. For example, a personâ€™s diet can sustain their health, or a company can sustain a long period of growth.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of strengthening or supporting something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œsustain life,â€ â€œsustain a project,â€ â€œsustain a business.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new engine can sustain a high speed for a long period of time.â€

      • â€œThe doctors were able to sustain the patientâ€™s life for another week.â€

      • â€œShe was able to sustain a long conversation with her friend.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to sustain the countryâ€™s economic growth.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s social connections can sustain their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent strategy to sustain the companyâ€™s growth.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to sustain the use of renewable energy sources.â€

Synonyms: Support, maintain, uphold, continue, keep going, bear.

Opposite words: Hinder, stop, harm, damage, prevent.

Where it comes from: From Latin sustinere (to hold up).

6.20.165. Preventive#

  • Pronunciation: /prÉªËˆvÉ›ntÉªv/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Designed to keep something undesirable from happening.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpreventiveâ€ is to be a measure or action taken to stop something undesirable from occurring in the first place.

What it really means: â€œPreventiveâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is designed to keep something undesirable from happening. It suggests that a person is taking action to stop a problem before it starts. For example, preventive medicine is medicine that is designed to stop a person from getting sick.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is designed to keep something undesirable from happening.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œpreventive measures,â€ â€œpreventive medicine,â€ â€œpreventive care.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe doctor advised me to take some preventive measures to avoid getting sick.â€

      • â€œThe company put in place a number of preventive measures to stop the spread of the virus.â€

      • â€œThe new laws are a preventive measure to stop the crime rate from rising.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a preventive measure designed to stop a financial crisis.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s preventive health care can affect their long-term health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear plan of preventive measures to address a potential emergency.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to be a preventive measure against a future war.â€

Synonyms: Precautionary, protective, defensive, deterrent.

Opposite words: Curative, restorative, remedial, therapeutic.

Where it comes from: From Latin praevenire (to come before).

6.20.166. Enslavement#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆsleÉªvmÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The state of being a slave or the act of making someone a slave.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œenslavementâ€ is the condition of being held in servitude or the act of forcing someone into that state, often against their will.

What it really means: â€œEnslavementâ€ is a noun that refers to the state of being a slave or the act of making someone a slave. It is a very strong and negative word that refers to the complete lack of freedom and control over oneâ€™s own life.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the state of being a slave or the act of making someone a slave.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œthe enslavement of,â€ â€œthe enslavement of a people,â€ â€œthe enslavement of a nation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new law is designed to prevent the enslavement of people in the country.â€

      • â€œThe documentary explored the history of enslavement in the world.â€

      • â€œShe was a victim of enslavement and had to fight for her freedom.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the enslavement of people is a serious human rights violation.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how the enslavement of people has affected the course of history.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the new international laws that are designed to prevent the enslavement of people.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the issue of modern enslavement in the country.â€

Synonyms: Slavery, bondage, servitude, subjugation, oppression.

Opposite words: Freedom, liberation, independence, autonomy.

Where it comes from: From Old English slÃ¦f (slave).

6.20.167. Deniable#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆnaÉªÉ™bÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Able to be denied.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdeniableâ€ is to be able to be disavowed or legitimately denied, suggesting a lack of definitive proof.

What it really means: â€œDeniableâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that can be denied. It suggests that there is no definitive proof of something, and so a person can deny that it happened. For example, a personâ€™s involvement in a crime can be deniable if there is no evidence.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that can be denied.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œplausibly deniable,â€ â€œeasily deniable,â€ â€œnot deniable.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHis involvement in the crime was deniable because there was no evidence.â€

      • â€œThe companyâ€™s claim was easily deniable because it was not backed up by facts.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is not deniable because it is a matter of public record.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the governmentâ€™s involvement in the scandal was deniable because of a lack of evidence.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s deniable actions can affect their reputation.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear record of all transactions so that they are not deniable.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to make it so that a personâ€™s actions are no longer deniable.â€

Synonyms: Disputable, questionable, refutable, challengeable.

Opposite words: Undeniable, irrefutable, undeniable, incontrovertible, obvious.

Where it comes from: From Latin denegare (to deny).

6.20.168. Disappear#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒdÉªsÉ™ËˆpÉªÉ™r/

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To cease to be visible.

      • â€œMy keys have disappeared, and I canâ€™t find them anywhere.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the species of bird has disappeared from the area due to a change in the environment.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s memory of an event can disappear over time.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear record of all transactions so that they do not disappear.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to prevent the disappearance of a personâ€™s rights.â€

Synonyms: Vanish, fade, vanish, dissolve, evaporate.

Opposite words: Appear, emerge, surface, materialize, show up.

Where it comes from: From Old French desapere (to disappear).

6.20.169. Mediation#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒmiËdiËˆeÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The act or process of mediating.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œmediationâ€ is the process of intervening in a dispute to help the parties reach an agreement, often through negotiation.

What it really means: â€œMediationâ€ is a noun that refers to the process of intervening in a dispute to help the parties reach an agreement. It is often used in a legal or business context, where a third party helps to resolve a conflict.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the process of intervening in a dispute to help the parties reach an agreement.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa process of mediation,â€ â€œlegal mediation,â€ â€œin need of mediation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe two countries are in a state of conflict and are in need of mediation.â€

      • â€œThe couple decided to go to mediation to try to save their marriage.â€

      • â€œThe company and the workers decided to go to mediation to resolve their dispute.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the use of mediation can be a more effective way to resolve a dispute than going to court.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to engage in mediation can affect their social relationships.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and objective process for mediation in the workplace.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to promote the use of mediation as a way to resolve legal disputes.â€

Synonyms: Arbitration, negotiation, conciliation, intervention, reconciliation.

Opposite words: Conflict, dispute, war, fight.

Where it comes from: From Latin mediare (to be in the middle).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆprÉ›zÉ™ntli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a short time; soon.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpresentlyâ€ is to be in a short time from now, or to be at the present moment (more commonly in formal English).

What it really means: â€œPresentlyâ€ is an adverb that can mean â€œsoonâ€ or â€œat the present time,â€ depending on the context. In formal English, it is often used to mean â€œat the present time,â€ but in informal English, it is often used to mean â€œsoon.â€

When to use it: Use it to mean â€œsoonâ€ or â€œat the present time.â€
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œpresently available,â€ â€œpresently in a state of.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œIâ€™ll be there presently; I just have to finish this task.â€

      • â€œHe is presently working on a new project.â€

      • â€œThe book is presently unavailable at the library, but you can check back later.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is presently being implemented by the government.â€

      • â€œThe study examines the new technologies that are presently being used in the industry.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the new laws that are presently being debated in parliament.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is presently in a state of development and is not yet available to the public.â€

Synonyms: Soon, shortly, in a moment, currently, at present.

Opposite words: Later, in the future, in the past.

Where it comes from: From Old French presenter (to present).

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Enough; adequate.

What it really means: â€œSufficientâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is enough or adequate. It suggests that a person has what they need and nothing more. For example, a personâ€™s income should be sufficient to provide for their family.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is enough or adequate.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œsufficient funds,â€ â€œsufficient evidence,â€ â€œsufficient time.â€

      • â€œI have sufficient funds to pay for the new car.â€

      • â€œThe police did not have sufficient evidence to charge him with the crime.â€

      • â€œThe report notes that the countryâ€™s food supply is sufficient to meet the needs of the population.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s feeling of sufficiency can affect their overall happiness and well-being.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a sufficient number of trained personnel to respond to a major emergency.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to ensure the sufficient allocation of resources for the new project.â€

Synonyms: Enough, adequate, ample, plenty, satisfactory.

Where it comes from: From Latin sufficere (to be enough).

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆsÉ›pÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

What it really means: â€œReceptionâ€ is a noun that refers to the action or process of receiving something. It can be the reception of a new idea, the reception of a new employee, or the reception of a new television signal.

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy has had a very positive reception among the public.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s reception of a new idea can affect their beliefs.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent process for the reception of new students into the university.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to promote a positive reception of diversity in the workplace.â€

Synonyms: Welcome, greeting, acceptance, response, feedback.

Where it comes from: From Latin receptio (a receiving).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkwÉ’lÉ™ti/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

  • Word Type: Noun

What it really means: â€œQualityâ€ is a noun that refers to the standard of something as measured against other things of a similar kind. It can be the quality of a product, the quality of a personâ€™s work, or the quality of a personâ€™s life.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the standard of something as measured against other things of a similar kind.

    • (Noun) â€œhigh quality,â€ â€œlow quality,â€ â€œa quality product.â€

    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThis is a very high-quality product that will last for years.â€

      • â€œThe quality of the food in this restaurant is not very good.â€

      • â€œWe need to improve the quality of our work to get more customers.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the quality of the new products has improved significantly.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s quality of life can be affected by their social connections.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of maintaining a high quality of service for all customers.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to promote the quality of education in the country.â€

Synonyms: Standard, excellence, value, grade, caliber.

Opposite words: Poor quality, inferiority.

Where it comes from: From Latin qualis (of what kind).

6.20.174. Remarkable#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆmÉ‘ËkÉ™bÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Worthy of attention; striking.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œremarkableâ€ is to be worthy of being noticed or remarked upon, often because of an extraordinary or unusual quality.

What it really means: â€œRemarkableâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is worthy of attention or striking. It suggests that something is so good or so unusual that it deserves to be noticed. For example, a remarkable achievement is an achievement that is very impressive.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is worthy of attention or striking.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa remarkable achievement,â€ â€œa remarkable person,â€ â€œa remarkable change.â€
