      • â€œIt was a remarkable achievement for such a young person.â€

      • â€œShe has a remarkable talent for singing.â€

      • â€œThe new technology has had a remarkable effect on the industry.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy has had a remarkable effect on the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s remarkable memory can be a sign of a high level of intelligence.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the remarkable achievements of the new government.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to promote the remarkable abilities of the countryâ€™s scientists.â€

Synonyms: Extraordinary, outstanding, noteworthy, impressive, amazing.

Opposite words: Unremarkable, ordinary, common, average, uninteresting.

Where it comes from: From Old French remarquer (to mark, to notice).

6.20.175. Fulfil#

  • Pronunciation: /fÊŠlËˆfÉªl/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To bring to completion or reality; to satisfy a requirement.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œfulfilâ€ is to bring to completion or to make a promise or expectation a reality.

What it really means: To â€œfulfilâ€ means to bring something to completion or to satisfy a requirement. It suggests that a person has done what they promised to do or that a requirement has been met. For example, a person can fulfil a promise or a contract.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of bringing something to completion or satisfying a requirement.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œfulfil a promise,â€ â€œfulfil a dream,â€ â€œfulfil a requirement.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI was able to fulfil my promise to my friend and help them move.â€

      • â€œHe was able to fulfil his dream of becoming a doctor.â€

      • â€œThe new car fulfils all of my needs and requirements.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy has been able to fulfil its original goals.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to fulfil their potential can affect their overall happiness and well-being.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear plan to fulfil the new requirements of the law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to fulfil the needs of the modern consumer.â€

Synonyms: Complete, achieve, accomplish, satisfy, meet.

Opposite words: Fail, neglect, abandon, disregard, disappoint.

Where it comes from: From Old English fullfillan (to fill up).

6.20.176. Expedition#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉ›kspÉªËˆdÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A journey undertaken by a group of people with a particular purpose, especially that of exploration.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œexpeditionâ€ is a journey or voyage undertaken for a specific purpose, such as exploration, research, or war.

What it really means: An â€œexpeditionâ€ is a noun that refers to a journey undertaken by a group of people with a particular purpose, such as exploration or research. It suggests that a person is going on a long and often difficult journey to achieve a goal.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a journey undertaken by a group of people with a particular purpose.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa scientific expedition,â€ â€œa military expedition,â€ â€œan exploration expedition.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new expedition to the Amazon rainforest will study the new species of plants.â€

      • â€œThe military expedition was a complete success and they were able to capture the enemy.â€

      • â€œThe exploration expedition to the North Pole was a very difficult journey.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new expedition to Mars is a major step in the history of space exploration.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s participation in an expedition can affect their mental and physical health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan for a new expedition.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to promote the use of scientific expeditions in the country.â€

Synonyms: Journey, voyage, trip, tour, exploration.

Opposite words: Retreat, return, stay.

Where it comes from: From Latin expeditio (a setting forth).

6.20.177. Incidentally#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉªnsÉªËˆdÉ›ntÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In an unplanned or secondary way; by the way.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œincidentallyâ€ is to be in a way that is not planned or is of secondary importance, often used to introduce a casual or related thought.

What it really means: â€œIncidentallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that happens in an unplanned or secondary way. It is often used to introduce a new topic in a conversation, and it is a more formal way of saying â€œby the way.â€

When to use it: Use it to describe something that happens in an unplanned or secondary way, or to introduce a new topic.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œincidentally,â€ â€œand incidentally,â€ â€œby the way, incidentally.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œIncidentally, I saw your brother at the store yesterday.â€

      • â€œI went to the store to buy some milk, and incidentally I also bought some bread.â€

      • â€œThe new policy, incidentally, also applies to people who live outside the city.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy, incidentally, also has a number of social benefits.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s incidentally acquired knowledge can affect their ability to learn new things.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of not getting distracted by incidentally related information.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address a number of different problems, incidentally also helping to reduce unemployment.â€

Synonyms: By the way, by chance, by the by, accidentally, coincidentally.

Opposite words: Intentionally, deliberately, on purpose, purposely.

Where it comes from: From Latin incidere (to fall upon).

6.20.178. Tendency#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆtÉ›ndÉ™nsi/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: An inclination toward a particular characteristic or type of behavior.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œtendencyâ€ is an inclination or disposition to act in a certain way, or for something to happen in a particular manner.

What it really means: â€œTendencyâ€ is a noun that refers to an inclination toward a particular characteristic or type of behavior. It suggests that a person or a thing is likely to do something. For example, a person can have a tendency to be late for appointments.

When to use it: Use it to refer to an inclination toward a particular characteristic or type of behavior.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa tendency to,â€ â€œa natural tendency,â€ â€œa strong tendency.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe has a tendency to be late for his appointments.â€

      • â€œThe weather has a tendency to change very quickly in this area.â€

      • â€œI have a natural tendency to be a bit shy in new situations.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy has a tendency to favor large companies over small businesses.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s tendency to procrastinate can affect their academic performance.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of understanding a personâ€™s natural tendency to avoid risk.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to correct the tendency of the government to overspend.â€

Synonyms: Inclination, predisposition, propensity, leaning, disposition.

Opposite words: Aversion, reluctance, disinclination, dislike.

Where it comes from: From Latin tendere (to stretch, to aim).

6.20.179. Gentle#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆdÊ’É›ntÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Having a mild, kind, or quiet nature.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œgentleâ€ is to be mild, soft, and kind in nature, without harshness, force, or violence.

What it really means: â€œGentleâ€ is an adjective used to describe a person who has a mild, kind, or quiet nature. It can also be used to describe an action that is not forceful or harsh. For example, a gentle touch is a touch that is not rough or strong.

When to use it: Use it to describe a person who has a mild, kind, or quiet nature, or an action that is not forceful.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa gentle touch,â€ â€œa gentle person,â€ â€œa gentle breeze.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œShe is a very gentle person who is always kind to everyone.â€

      • â€œThe new dog is very gentle with the children.â€

      • â€œA gentle breeze blew through the window.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a gentle approach to a very difficult problem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s gentle nature can affect their social relationships.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of using a gentle approach to a person who is in distress.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to provide a more gentle and humane way to deal with a person who has a mental illness.â€

Synonyms: Kind, mild, soft, tender, serene.

Opposite words: Harsh, rough, cruel, violent, aggressive.

Where it comes from: From Latin gentilis (of a clan or family).

  • Pronunciation: /kriËˆeÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To bring something into existence.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcreateâ€ is to bring something new into existence, whether itâ€™s a physical object, an idea, or a system.

What it really means: To â€œcreateâ€ means to bring something into existence. It is the act of making something new. For example, a person can create a new piece of art, or a company can create a new product.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of bringing something into existence.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œcreate a new product,â€ â€œcreate a new law,â€ â€œcreate a new system.â€

      • â€œI want to create a new painting for my living room.â€

      • â€œThe government is trying to create more jobs in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new company will create a new product that will change the world.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy will create a number of new opportunities for small businesses.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to create new ideas can affect their success in life.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear process to create a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to create a more efficient way to produce goods.â€

Synonyms: Make, produce, invent, design, generate.

Opposite words: Destroy, ruin, demolish, eliminate, abolish.

Where it comes from: From Latin creare (to make, to produce).

6.20.181. Inconveniently#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉªnkÉ™nËˆviËniÉ™ntli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that causes trouble or difficulty.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œinconvenientlyâ€ is to be in a way that causes difficulty, annoyance, or an obstacle to a plan.

What it really means: â€œInconvenientlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that happens in a way that causes trouble or difficulty. It suggests that something is happening at a bad time or in a bad place. For example, the bus arrived inconveniently late, so I missed my appointment.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that happens in a way that causes trouble or difficulty.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œinconveniently late,â€ â€œinconveniently located,â€ â€œinconveniently scheduled.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe meeting was inconveniently scheduled for a time when I was not available.â€

      • â€œThe store is inconveniently located far away from my house.â€

      • â€œThe bus arrived inconveniently late, and I missed my flight.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy was inconveniently announced at a time when the public was not paying attention.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s inconveniently scheduled appointments can affect their ability to manage their time.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of not inconveniently scheduling a meeting during a holiday.â€

      • â€œThe new law was inconveniently passed at a time when the government was in a state of crisis.â€

Synonyms: Awkwardly, unfortunately, unsuitably, untimely.

Opposite words: Conveniently, fortunately, suitably, timely.

Where it comes from: From Latin inconveniens (not fitting).

6.20.182. Monthly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆmÊŒnÎ¸li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective, Adverb

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œmonthlyâ€ is to happen, be paid, or occur once every month, indicating a specific, regular time frame.

What it really means: As an adjective, â€œmonthlyâ€ describes something that happens or is done once every month (â€œa monthly meetingâ€). As an adverb, â€œmonthlyâ€ means once every month (â€œI get paid monthlyâ€).

When to use it: Use the adjective to describe something that happens once a month, and the adverb to describe doing something once a month.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œmonthly meeting,â€ â€œmonthly report,â€ â€œmonthly payment.â€

    • (Adverb) â€œpaid monthly,â€ â€œreport monthly,â€ â€œmeet monthly.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have to pay my monthly rent on the first of the month.â€

      • â€œI get paid monthly, so I have to budget my money carefully.â€

      • â€œThe company holds a monthly meeting to discuss new projects.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the companyâ€™s monthly revenue has increased by 10%.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s monthly budget can affect their financial situation.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of providing a monthly report on all new projects.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to ensure that all employees are paid monthly.â€

Synonyms: Every month, once a month.

Opposite words: Weekly, annually, daily.

Where it comes from: From Old English monaÃ¾lic (monthly).

6.20.183. Domestication#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉ™ËŒmÉ›stÉªËˆkeÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The process of taming an animal or cultivating a plant to live in close association with humans.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdomesticationâ€ is the process of adapting a wild plant or animal for human use, often involving selective breeding.

What it really means: â€œDomesticationâ€ is a noun that refers to the process of taming an animal or cultivating a plant to live in close association with humans. It is the process of making a wild animal or plant a part of a personâ€™s life. For example, the domestication of dogs was a major step in the history of human civilization.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the process of taming an animal or cultivating a plant.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œthe domestication of,â€ â€œthe domestication of plants,â€ â€œthe domestication of animals.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe domestication of cats was a very long process that took thousands of years.â€

      • â€œThe domestication of plants led to the development of agriculture.â€

      • â€œThe new animal is in the process of domestication and is getting used to living with humans.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the domestication of animals has had a profound effect on the history of human civilization.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how the domestication of plants has affected the development of new technologies.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of a clear and consistent process for the domestication of new animals.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to promote the responsible domestication of wild animals.â€

Synonyms: Taming, cultivation, breeding, rearing, acculturation.

Opposite words: Wildness, ferality, savagery.

Where it comes from: From Latin domesticus (of the house).

6.20.184. Inevitable#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆÉ›vÉªtÉ™bÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Certain to happen; unavoidable.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œinevitableâ€ is to be certain to happen and impossible to prevent, regardless of any actions taken.

What it really means: â€œInevitableâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is certain to happen and unavoidable. It suggests that a person cannot do anything to stop something from happening. For example, a personâ€™s death is inevitable.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is certain to happen and unavoidable.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œan inevitable outcome,â€ â€œan inevitable result,â€ â€œan inevitable conclusion.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe teamâ€™s defeat was inevitable because they were not prepared.â€

      • â€œIt was inevitable that the two of them would fall in love.â€

      • â€œThe companyâ€™s downfall was inevitable because of its poor management.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is an inevitable result of the governmentâ€™s long-term goals.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s inevitable death can affect their outlook on life.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of preparing for the inevitable changes in the economy.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the inevitable problems that will arise from the new technology.â€

Synonyms: Unavoidable, certain, sure, destined, fated.

Opposite words: Avoidable, preventable, uncertain, unlikely, doubtful.

Where it comes from: From Latin inevitabilis (unavoidable).

6.20.185. Reversible#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆvÉœËsÉ™bÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Able to be turned the other way round or inside out.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œreversibleâ€ is to be able to be changed back to a previous state or condition, or to be used in two opposite ways.

What it really means: â€œReversibleâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that can be turned the other way round or inside out. It can also be used to describe something that can be changed back to its original state. For example, a reversible jacket can be worn on both sides. A reversible process can be reversed.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that can be turned the other way round or changed back to its original state.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa reversible jacket,â€ â€œa reversible process,â€ â€œa reversible change.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThis jacket is reversible, so you can wear it with either side facing out.â€

      • â€œThe damage to the house is not reversible, so we have to rebuild it.â€

      • â€œThe new drug is designed to have a reversible effect on the patientâ€™s condition.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the effects of climate change are not reversible and that we need to take action now.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s reversible decisions can affect their future.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent process for the reversible changes in the economy.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to have a reversible effect on the countryâ€™s population.â€

Synonyms: Convertible, interchangeable, changeable, adjustable.

Opposite words: Irreversible, permanent, unchangeable, fixed.

Where it comes from: From Latin revertere (to turn back).

6.20.186. Redundant#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆdÊŒndÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Not or no longer needed or useful.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œredundantâ€ is to be no longer necessary or useful, often because something else serves the same purpose or the purpose itself is gone.

What it really means: â€œRedundantâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is not or no longer needed or useful. It can be used to describe a person who has lost their job because their position is no longer needed, or it can be used to describe a part of a machine that is not needed.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is not or no longer needed or useful.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa redundant worker,â€ â€œa redundant feature,â€ â€œa redundant phrase.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new technology has made my job redundant, so I was laid off.â€

      • â€œThe new car has a redundant feature that I never use.â€

      • â€œThe sentence was redundant because it said the same thing twice.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy will make a number of government positions redundant.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s redundant skills can affect their ability to find a new job.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of removing redundant information from a document.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to make a number of old laws redundant.â€

Synonyms: Unnecessary, superfluous, excessive, surplus, superfluous.

Opposite words: Necessary, essential, vital, crucial, important.

Where it comes from: From Latin redundare (to overflow).

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒrÉ›zÉ™ËˆveÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: An arrangement to have something (a room, a table, etc.) held for oneâ€™s use at a later time.

What it really means: â€œReservationâ€ is a noun that refers to an arrangement to have something, such as a room or a table, held for oneâ€™s use at a later time. It can also refer to a feeling of doubt or hesitation about something. For example, a person can have a reservation about a new plan.

When to use it: Use it to refer to an arrangement to have something held, or a feeling of doubt or hesitation.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa dinner reservation,â€ â€œa hotel reservation,â€ â€œhave a reservation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI made a reservation for dinner at 8 pm.â€

      • â€œI have a reservation about the new plan; I donâ€™t think it will work.â€

      • â€œThe new hotel is so popular that you have to make a reservation weeks in advance.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy was met with a number of reservations from the public.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s reservations about a new idea can affect their decision to accept it.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of making a reservation for a flight in advance.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the reservations of the public about the new policy.â€

Synonyms: Booking, appointment, doubt, hesitation, misgiving.

Where it comes from: From Latin reservare (to keep back).

6.20.188. Dislike#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªsËˆlaÉªk/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To feel distaste for or hostility toward; (Noun) A feeling of distaste or hostility.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the verb is to feel a sense of aversion or disapproval toward something. The core meaning of the noun is the feeling of not liking something.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œdislikeâ€ means to feel distaste for or hostility toward something. It is the opposite of â€œlike.â€ As a noun, a â€œdislikeâ€ is a feeling of distaste or hostility.

When to use it: Use the verb to describe the act of feeling distaste for something, and the noun to refer to a feeling of distaste.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œdislike a person,â€ â€œdislike a food.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa strong dislike,â€ â€œhave a dislike for.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI dislike the taste of olives.â€

      • â€œShe has a strong dislike for people who are rude.â€

      • â€œI dislike the new rules that the company has put in place.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the public has a strong dislike for the new policy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s dislike for a particular food can affect their diet.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of understanding a personâ€™s dislike for a particular product.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the publicâ€™s dislike for the new tax.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Hate, detest, loathe, despise; (Noun) Hatred, aversion, distaste, antipathy.

Opposite words: (Verb) Like, love, enjoy, admire; (Noun) Liking, love, enjoyment, admiration.

Where it comes from: From Old English lician (to please).

    • (Adjective) â€œvarious kinds,â€ â€œvarious reasons,â€ â€œvarious methods.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address various problems that have been plaguing the country.â€

Synonyms: Different, diverse, numerous, multiple, assorted.

Where it comes from: From Latin varius (diverse).

6.20.190. Temporary#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆtÉ›mpÉ™rÉ™ri/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Lasting for only a limited period of time; not permanent.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œtemporaryâ€ is to be lasting for a limited time, indicating a non-permanent or transient state.

What it really means: â€œTemporaryâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that lasts for only a limited period of time. It suggests that something is not permanent and will change in the future. For example, a temporary solution is a solution that will only work for a short period of time.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that lasts for only a limited period of time.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa temporary solution,â€ â€œa temporary job,â€ â€œa temporary change.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have a temporary job for the summer, but Iâ€™m looking for a permanent one.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is a temporary solution to a bigger problem.â€

      • â€œThe new building is a temporary structure that will be replaced in a few years.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a temporary measure to address the countryâ€™s economic problems.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s temporary change in diet can affect their long-term health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear plan for a temporary change in the law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a temporary fix for a problem that will require a more permanent solution.â€

Synonyms: Provisional, short-term, transient, momentary, fleeting.

Opposite words: Permanent, lasting, long-term, endless, eternal.

Where it comes from: From Latin temporarius (of time).

6.20.191. Outdoor#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆaÊŠtdÉ”Ër/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Happening, existing, or used in the open air.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œoutdoorâ€ is to be happening or existing in the open air, outside of a building.

What it really means: â€œOutdoorâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that happens, exists, or is used in the open air. It suggests that something is not happening inside a building. For example, an outdoor concert is a concert that is held outside.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that happens, exists, or is used in the open air.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œoutdoor activities,â€ â€œoutdoor seating,â€ â€œoutdoor space.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWe love to do outdoor activities like hiking and camping.â€

      • â€œThe restaurant has a lot of outdoor seating for the summer.â€

      • â€œThe new house has a lot of outdoor space, which is great for parties.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to promote outdoor activities for children.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s exposure to outdoor light can affect their health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear plan for the use of outdoor spaces in the city.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to be used in outdoor environments.â€

Synonyms: Open-air, outside, external, alfresco.

Opposite words: Indoor, inside, internal.

Where it comes from: From Old English ut (out) and dura (door).

6.20.192. Close#

  • Pronunciation: /kloÊŠs/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A1

  • Word Type: Adjective, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Adj) A short distance away or apart in space or time; (Verb) To move so that an opening is covered.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the adjective is to be a short distance away in space or time. The core meaning of the verb is to cover an opening or bring something to an end.

What it really means: As an adjective, â€œcloseâ€ means a short distance away or apart in space or time. As a verb, to â€œcloseâ€ means to move so that an opening is covered or to bring something to an end.

When to use it: Use the adjective to describe a short distance, and the verb to describe covering an opening or bringing something to an end.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œclose to,â€ â€œa close friend,â€ â€œa close call.â€

    • (Verb) â€œclose the door,â€ â€œclose a meeting,â€ â€œclose a deal.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œMy house is close to the park, so I can walk there.â€

      • â€œI need to close the door because itâ€™s getting cold.â€

      • â€œThe two of them are very close friends.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy will bring the two countries close to a new agreement.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s close relationship with their family can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of bringing the meeting to a close in a timely manner.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help companies close more deals and increase their revenue.â€

Synonyms: (Adj) Near, next to, adjacent, intimate; (Verb) Shut, seal, end, finish, conclude.

Opposite words: (Adj) Far, distant, remote; (Verb) Open, begin, start.

Where it comes from: From Old French clos (closed).

6.20.193. Precaution#

  • Pronunciation: /prÉªËˆkÉ”ËÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A measure taken in advance to prevent something dangerous, unpleasant, or inconvenient from happening.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œprecautionâ€ is an action taken ahead of time to protect against a potential danger or problem.

What it really means: A â€œprecautionâ€ is a noun that refers to a measure taken in advance to prevent something dangerous, unpleasant, or inconvenient from happening. It suggests that a person is taking action to stop a problem before it starts. For example, a person can take a precaution by wearing a seatbelt in a car.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a measure taken in advance to prevent something dangerous or unpleasant from happening.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œtake a precaution,â€ â€œas a precaution,â€ â€œa precaution against.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œAs a precaution, I always wear a helmet when I ride my bike.â€

      • â€œThe company took a number of precautions to prevent the spread of the virus.â€

      • â€œThe new law is a precaution against a future financial crisis.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a precaution against a future war.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s precautions can affect their ability to avoid an accident.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of taking precautions when working with dangerous chemicals.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a precaution against a future cyber attack.â€

Synonyms: Safeguard, defense, forethought, care, prudence.

Opposite words: Carelessness, recklessness, negligence, imprudence.

Where it comes from: From Latin praecavere (to take care beforehand).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆseÉªfti/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The condition of being protected from or unlikely to cause danger, risk, or injury.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsafetyâ€ is the state of being protected from harm or danger, a condition of security.

What it really means: â€œSafetyâ€ is a noun that refers to the condition of being protected from or unlikely to cause danger, risk, or injury. It suggests that a person is in a state of security and is not in danger. For example, a personâ€™s safety is a top priority for the government.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the condition of being protected from or unlikely to cause danger.

    • (Noun) â€œpersonal safety,â€ â€œfor your safety,â€ â€œin safety.â€

      • â€œWe need to ensure the safety of all the children in the school.â€

      • â€œThe government is trying to improve the safety of the roads.â€

      • â€œYour safety is the most important thing to me.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to improve the safety of workers in the industry.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s feeling of safety can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear plan to ensure the safety of all citizens.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to improve the safety of the entire country.â€

Synonyms: Security, protection, well-being, freedom from danger.

Opposite words: Danger, risk, peril, threat, harm.

Where it comes from: From Old French sauf (safe).

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™nËˆsÉªstÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Acting or done in the same way over time, especially so as to be fair or accurate.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œconsistentâ€ is to be uniform or regular over time, without any significant changes or variations.

What it really means: â€œConsistentâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is acting or done in the same way over time. It suggests that something is predictable and reliable. For example, a personâ€™s work can be consistent if it is always of the same high quality.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is acting or done in the same way over time.

    • (Adjective) â€œa consistent effort,â€ â€œconsistent results,â€ â€œconsistent with.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is consistent with the governmentâ€™s long-term goals.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s consistent diet can affect their long-term health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a consistent approach to a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to provide consistent and reliable results.â€

Synonyms: Steady, constant, regular, uniform, reliable.

Opposite words: Inconsistent, irregular, unstable, unreliable, erratic.

Where it comes from: From Latin consistere (to stand together).

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The cost incurred in or required for something.

What it really means: â€œExpenseâ€ is a noun that refers to the cost incurred in or required for something. It suggests that a person has to spend money to get something. For example, the expense of a new car can be very high.

      • â€œThe new car was a great expense, but I needed it for my job.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s expenses can affect their financial situation.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of keeping a clear record of all business expenses.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to reduce the expense of producing goods.â€

Synonyms: Cost, charge, price, outlay, expenditure.

Opposite words: Income, profit, revenue, savings.

Where it comes from: From Latin expendere (to weigh out).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkÉ’nstÉ™ntli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

What it really means: â€œConstantlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that happens continuously over a period of time. It suggests that something is always happening. For example, the phone is constantly ringing.

  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œconstantly changing,â€ â€œconstantly complaining,â€ â€œconstantly working.â€

      • â€œThe weather is constantly changing in this area.â€

      • â€œShe is constantly complaining about her job, but she never quits.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of constantly monitoring the new technology for any problems.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the constantly changing needs of the country.â€

Synonyms: Always, continually, perpetually, regularly, incessantly.

Opposite words: Rarely, seldom, occasionally, never.

Where it comes from: From Latin constans (standing firm).

6.20.198. Forcefully#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆfÉ”Ësfl/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that uses force or strength.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œforcefullyâ€ is to be with great physical or emotional strength, often in an assertive or powerful manner.

What it really means: â€œForcefullyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done with a lot of force or strength. It suggests that a person is using their power to do something. For example, a person can forcefully open a door or forcefully make a point in a debate.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done with a lot of force or strength.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œforcefully open,â€ â€œforcefully argue,â€ â€œforcefully demand.â€

  • Examples:

      • â€œHe forcefully opened the door and walked inside.â€

      • â€œShe forcefully argued her point in the debate and won.â€

      • â€œThe government forcefully demanded that the company change its policy.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy was forcefully opposed by the public.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to forcefully argue their point can affect their success in a debate.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of forcefully addressing the new problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to forcefully address the issue of crime.â€

Synonyms: Powerfully, strongly, vigorously, aggressively, emphatically.

Opposite words: Gently, softly, weakly, mildly, passively.

Where it comes from: From Old French force (strength, power).

6.20.199. Comment#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkÉ’mÉ›nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) A spoken or written remark expressing an opinion or reaction; (Verb) To express an opinion or reaction.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is a remark that expresses an opinion or reaction. The core meaning of the verb is to express an opinion or reaction.

What it really means: As a noun, a â€œcommentâ€ is a spoken or written remark that expresses an opinion or a reaction. As a verb, to â€œcommentâ€ means to express an opinion or a reaction.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a spoken or written remark, and the verb to describe expressing an opinion.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa brief comment,â€ â€œno comment,â€ â€œa positive comment.â€

      • â€œI made a comment on the news article and got a lot of replies.â€

      • â€œHe commented on my new hairstyle and said he liked it.â€

      • â€œI donâ€™t have any comment on the matter, as I donâ€™t know enough about it.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy received a number of positive comments from the public.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s comment on a social media post can affect their social relationships.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of providing a comment on the new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people comment on the new products.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Remark, observation, statement, feedback; (Verb) Remark, observe, state, say.

Opposite words: (Noun) Silence, quiet; (Verb) Keep quiet, be silent.

Where it comes from: From Latin commentum (an invention, a commentary).

6.20.200. Absorption#

  • Pronunciation: /É™bËˆsÉ”ËrpÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The process of a substance being taken in by another substance.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œabsorptionâ€ is the process of a substance being taken in and assimilated by another substance or the state of being deeply engrossed in something.

What it really means: â€œAbsorptionâ€ is a noun that refers to the process of a substance being taken in by another substance. It can also refer to the process of a person being completely engrossed in something. For example, a sponge has a high rate of water absorption. A personâ€™s absorption in a book means they are completely focused on it.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the process of a substance being taken in, or the process of a person being completely engrossed in something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œwater absorption,â€ â€œthe absorption of a new idea,â€ â€œdeep in absorption.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new plant has a high rate of water absorption, which is good for the soil.â€

      • â€œI was so deep in absorption that I didnâ€™t notice the time passing.â€

      • â€œThe new product is designed to have a high rate of sound absorption.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to promote the absorption of new ideas into the economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s absorption in a new task can affect their ability to learn.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent process for the absorption of new employees.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to have a high rate of energy absorption.â€

Synonyms: Assimilation, soaking up, engrossment, immersion.

Opposite words: Emission, discharge, release, distraction, rejection.

Where it comes from: From Latin absorbere (to swallow up).

6.20.201. Happens#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆhÃ¦pÉ™nz/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To take place; occur.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œhappensâ€ is to occur or take place, indicating that an event is in progress or has come to pass.

What it really means: â€œHappensâ€ is a verb that means to take place or occur. It is used to describe something that is taking place or occurring. For example, a lot of things can happen in a day.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is taking place or occurring.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œwhat happens,â€ â€œit happens,â€ â€œwhen it happens.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œA lot of things can happen in a day, so you need to be ready for anything.â€

      • â€œI donâ€™t know what happens next, so Iâ€™m just going to wait and see.â€

      • â€œIt happens all the time, so donâ€™t worry about it too much.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy will change what happens to the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s decision can affect what happens in their life.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of being prepared for what happens in the future.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to prevent a lot of bad things from happening in the country.â€

Synonyms: Occurs, takes place, arises, ensues, transpires.

Opposite words: Stops, ends, ceases, prevents.

Where it comes from: From Old Norse happ (chance).

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆfÉ”Ërm/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To give (someone) facts or information.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œinformâ€ is to provide facts or knowledge to someone, thereby shaping their understanding or awareness.

What it really means: To â€œinformâ€ means to give someone facts or information. It is the act of telling someone something that they donâ€™t know. For example, a person can inform their boss that they are leaving the company.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of giving someone facts or information.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œinform a person,â€ â€œinform about,â€ â€œinform on.â€

      • â€œI need to inform my boss that I am leaving for the day.â€

      • â€œThe news is designed to inform people about what is happening in the world.â€

      • â€œI was informed that the meeting has been canceled.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to inform the public about the new laws.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to inform themselves can affect their decision-making.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of being informed about the new changes in the law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to inform people about the new products that are available.â€

Synonyms: Tell, notify, advise, update, educate.

Opposite words: Misinform, mislead, deceive, conceal, hide.

Where it comes from: From Latin informare (to shape, to instruct).

6.20.203. Transparent#

  • Pronunciation: /trÃ¦nsËˆpÃ¦rÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Allowing light to pass through so that objects behind can be distinctly seen.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œtransparentâ€ is to be easily seen through (literally or figuratively), suggesting clarity and a lack of concealment.

What it really means: â€œTransparentâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that allows light to pass through so that objects behind can be distinctly seen. It can also be used to describe something that is easy to understand and has nothing to hide. For example, a transparent government is a government that is open and honest with its people.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that allows light to pass through or something that is easy to understand.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa transparent window,â€ â€œa transparent process,â€ â€œa transparent government.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new window is so transparent that itâ€™s hard to tell if itâ€™s there.â€

      • â€œThe company has a very transparent process for hiring new employees.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to make the government more transparent to the public.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to create a more transparent and accountable government.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s transparent communication can affect their social relationships.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a transparent process for all business transactions.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to make the entire process more transparent and efficient.â€

Synonyms: Clear, see-through, obvious, open, honest.

Opposite words: Opaque, cloudy, secretive, dishonest, hidden.

Where it comes from: From Latin transparere (to be visible through).

6.20.204. Inferiority#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËŒfÉªÉ™riËˆÉ’rÉªti/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The state of being lower in status or quality than another or others.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œinferiorityâ€ is the state of being lower in quality, status, or value than something else.

What it really means: â€œInferiorityâ€ is a noun that refers to the state of being lower in status or quality than another or others. It can be a personâ€™s feeling of inferiority to another person or a productâ€™s inferiority to another product.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the state of being lower in status or quality than another or others.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa feeling of inferiority,â€ â€œa sense of inferiority,â€ â€œthe inferiority of a product.â€

  • Examples:

      • â€œHe has a strong sense of inferiority because he was not able to finish college.â€

      • â€œThe new productâ€™s inferiority to the old one was very clear.â€

      • â€œI have a feeling of inferiority when Iâ€™m around a lot of successful people.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the inferiority of the countryâ€™s educational system.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s feeling of inferiority can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of not allowing a feeling of inferiority to affect a personâ€™s decision-making.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the inferiority of the countryâ€™s infrastructure.â€

Synonyms: Subordination, secondariness, lowliness, mediocrity, inadequacy.

Opposite words: Superiority, dominance, excellence, quality, supremacy.

Where it comes from: From Latin inferior (lower).

6.20.205. Validation#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒvÃ¦lÉªËˆdeÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action of proving or declaring something valid.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œvalidationâ€ is the act of confirming or verifying that something is true, correct, or acceptable.

What it really means: â€œValidationâ€ is a noun that refers to the action of proving or declaring something valid. It can be the validation of a new idea or a new product, or it can be a personâ€™s feeling of validation from their friends.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the action of proving or declaring something valid.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œseek validation,â€ â€œgive validation,â€ â€œa form of validation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI need some validation from my boss that Iâ€™m doing a good job.â€

      • â€œThe new product needs to go through a lot of validation before it can be sold to the public.â€

      • â€œShe needs a lot of validation from her friends to feel good about herself.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is in need of validation from the public.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s validation from their peers can affect their self-esteem.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent process for the validation of new ideas.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is in need of validation from the government before it can be used.â€

Synonyms: Confirmation, approval, verification, authentication, endorsement.

Opposite words: Invalidity, rejection, disapproval, refutation, denial.

Where it comes from: From Latin validus (strong).

6.20.206. Habitable#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆhÃ¦bÉªtÉ™bÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Suitable or good enough to live in.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œhabitableâ€ is to be capable of supporting life or being lived in, indicating a suitability for a dwelling.

What it really means: â€œHabitableâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is suitable or good enough to live in. It suggests that a place is safe and comfortable for a person to live in. For example, a new house can be habitable if it has all the necessary amenities.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is suitable or good enough to live in.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa habitable planet,â€ â€œa habitable house,â€ â€œa habitable room.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new house is not habitable yet because it is still under construction.â€

      • â€œThe new planet is habitable, so we can move there in the future.â€

      • â€œThe room is not habitable because the roof is leaking.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to make the countryâ€™s housing more habitable.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s habitable environment can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear plan for making a new planet habitable.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to make a personâ€™s home more habitable and comfortable.â€

Synonyms: Livable, inhabitable, fit for habitation, suitable for living.

Opposite words: Uninhabitable, unlivable, unsuitable, unfit for living.

Where it comes from: From Latin habitare (to live in).

6.20.207. Severely#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉªËˆvÉªÉ™rli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: To a very great or intense degree.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œseverelyâ€ is to be to a very great or intense degree, often in a way that is serious or critical.

What it really means: â€œSeverelyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done to a very great or intense degree. It suggests that something is very serious or critical. For example, a person can be severely injured in an accident, or a person can be severely punished for a crime.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done to a very great or intense degree.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œseverely injured,â€ â€œseverely damaged,â€ â€œseverely punished.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe was severely injured in the car accident and had to go to the hospital.â€

      • â€œThe new building was severely damaged in the hurricane.â€

      • â€œThe new laws are designed to severely punish people who break the law.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy will severely affect the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s severely unhealthy diet can affect their long-term health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of addressing a personâ€™s severely low self-esteem.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to severely reduce the amount of pollution in the environment.â€

Synonyms: Greatly, intensely, acutely, harshly, strictly.

Opposite words: Slightly, mildly, gently, lightly, moderately.

Where it comes from: From Latin severus (serious, strict).

6.20.208. Crucial#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkruËÊƒÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Decisive or critical, especially in the success or failure of something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcrucialâ€ is to be of great importance or a pivotal point, where the outcome of something depends on it.

What it really means: â€œCrucialâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is decisive or critical. It suggests that something is very important and can determine the success or failure of something. For example, a personâ€™s decision can be crucial to the outcome of a project.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is decisive or critical.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa crucial decision,â€ â€œa crucial moment,â€ â€œa crucial role.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThis is a crucial moment in our lives, so we need to make the right decision.â€

      • â€œHe played a crucial role in the teamâ€™s success.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is a crucial step in addressing the countryâ€™s problems.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a crucial step in addressing the countryâ€™s economic crisis.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s crucial decisions can affect their long-term happiness.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of making a crucial decision in a timely manner.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a crucial step in the development of a new product.â€

Synonyms: Critical, vital, essential, pivotal, decisive.

Opposite words: Insignificant, unimportant, trivial, minor, non-essential.

Where it comes from: From Latin crux (cross, a reference to a cross-shaped road sign).

6.20.209. Extravagantly#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªkËˆstrÃ¦vÉ™É¡É™ntli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that is lacking in restraint in spending money or using resources.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œextravagantlyâ€ is to be in a way that is beyond what is reasonable or necessary, often involving excessive spending or showiness.

What it really means: â€œExtravagantlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a way that is lacking in restraint in spending money or using resources. It suggests that a person is spending too much money or is using too many resources. For example, a person can live extravagantly if they spend a lot of money on luxury items.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a way that is lacking in restraint in spending money or using resources.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œlive extravagantly,â€ â€œspend extravagantly,â€ â€œdress extravagantly.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œShe lives extravagantly and spends a lot of money on clothes and shoes.â€

      • â€œThe new car was extravagantly priced, so I couldnâ€™t afford it.â€

      • â€œHe dressed extravagantly for the party, and everyone noticed him.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to prevent the government from spending extravagantly on new projects.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s extravagantly spending habits can affect their financial situation.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of not spending extravagantly on unnecessary things.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to prevent companies from extravagantly using the countryâ€™s natural resources.â€

Synonyms: Lavishly, excessively, wastefully, immoderately, profusely.

Opposite words: Economically, frugally, modestly, sparingly, simply.

Where it comes from: From Latin extra (outside) and vagari (to wander).

6.20.210. Cultivate#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkÊŒltÉªveÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To prepare and use (land) for crops or gardening.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcultivateâ€ is to prepare and nurture something to promote its growth, whether itâ€™s a crop, a skill, or a relationship.

What it really means: To â€œcultivateâ€ means to prepare and use land for crops or gardening. It can also mean to try to acquire or develop a quality, sentiment, or skill. For example, a person can cultivate a new skill or cultivate a new relationship.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of preparing and using land for crops, or to try to acquire or develop a quality.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œcultivate a garden,â€ â€œcultivate a skill,â€ â€œcultivate a relationship.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI want to cultivate a new garden in my backyard.â€

      • â€œHe is trying to cultivate his public speaking skills.â€

      • â€œWe need to cultivate a good relationship with our new neighbors.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help farmers cultivate new crops.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to cultivate new skills can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear plan to cultivate new relationships with other countries.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people cultivate their own food at home.â€

Synonyms: Grow, nurture, develop, foster, acquire.

Opposite words: Neglect, abandon, ignore, destroy, stunt.

Where it comes from: From Latin cultivare (to till, to cultivate).

6.20.211. Neglect#

  • Pronunciation: /nÉªËˆÉ¡lÉ›kt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To fail to care for properly; (Noun) The state of being uncared for.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the verb is to fail to give proper care or attention to something. The core meaning of the noun is the state of being uncared for or overlooked.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œneglectâ€ means to fail to care for something properly. As a noun, â€œneglectâ€ is the state of being uncared for.

When to use it: Use the verb to describe the act of failing to care for something, and the noun to refer to the state of being uncared for.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œneglect a child,â€ â€œneglect a duty,â€ â€œneglect a task.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa state of neglect,â€ â€œchild neglect,â€ â€œanimal neglect.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe neglected his duties at work and was fired.â€

      • â€œThe new house was in a state of neglect and needed a lot of repairs.â€

      • â€œI donâ€™t want to neglect my friends, so I always make time for them.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the neglect of the countryâ€™s infrastructure.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s neglect of their health can affect their long-term well-being.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of not neglecting oneâ€™s responsibilities to the community.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to prevent the neglect of children in the country.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Ignore, disregard, overlook, abandon; (Noun) Inattention, disregard, carelessness, abandonment.

Opposite words: (Verb) Care for, attend to, cherish, nurture; (Noun) Care, attention, diligence, concern.

Where it comes from: From Latin negligere (to disregard, to neglect).

6.20.212. Include#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆkluËd/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To comprise or contain as part of a whole.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œincludeâ€ is to contain or have something as a part of a larger whole.

What it really means: To â€œincludeâ€ means to comprise or contain as part of a whole. It is the act of making something a part of a larger group or whole. For example, a group of people can include a new member, or a document can include a new section.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of comprising or containing as part of a whole.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œinclude in,â€ â€œinclude a person,â€ â€œinclude a section.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe price of the ticket includes a free meal and a drink.â€

      • â€œI want to include my friends in my new plan.â€

      • â€œThe new book will include a new chapter on the history of the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy will include a number of new laws.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s diet can include a variety of different foods.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan that will include all the necessary steps.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to include a number of new features.â€

Synonyms: Contain, comprise, involve, encompass, incorporate.

Opposite words: Exclude, omit, leave out, disregard, remove.

Where it comes from: From Latin includere (to shut in).

  • Pronunciation: /suËËŒpÉªÉ™riËˆÉ’rÉªti/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The state of being superior to someone or something else.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsuperiorityâ€ is the state of being higher in quality, status, or value than something else.

What it really means: â€œSuperiorityâ€ is a noun that refers to the state of being superior to someone or something else. It can be a personâ€™s feeling of superiority to another person or a productâ€™s superiority to another product.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the state of being superior to someone or something else.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa feeling of superiority,â€ â€œa sense of superiority,â€ â€œthe superiority of a product.â€

      • â€œHe has a strong sense of superiority because he is very rich.â€

      • â€œThe new productâ€™s superiority to the old one was very clear.â€

      • â€œI have a feeling of superiority when Iâ€™m around a lot of people who are not as successful as I am.â€

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the superiority of the countryâ€™s educational system.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s feeling of superiority can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of not allowing a feeling of superiority to affect a personâ€™s decision-making.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the superiority of the countryâ€™s infrastructure.â€

Synonyms: Dominance, excellence, supremacy, quality, advantage.

Opposite words: Inferiority, subordination, lowliness, mediocrity, inadequacy.

Where it comes from: From Latin superior (higher).

6.20.214. Similarly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆsÉªmÉªlÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a similar way.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsimilarlyâ€ is to be in a comparable or like manner, indicating a parallel action or state.

What it really means: â€œSimilarlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a similar way. It suggests that two things are alike in some way. For example, a person can similarly solve a problem in the same way as another person.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a similar way.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œsimilarly, I think,â€ â€œand similarly,â€ â€œsimilarly to.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe solved the problem, and I similarly solved it in the same way.â€

      • â€œThe two of them are very similar, and similarly their tastes in music are the same.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is similarly to the old one, but with a few changes.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is similarly to the old one in its approach to the problem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to solve a problem can be similarly to another personâ€™s ability.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan, and similarly a clear and consistent approach to the problem.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to be similarly to the old one, but with a few new features.â€

Synonyms: Likewise, in a similar fashion, equally, in the same way.

Opposite words: Differently, dissimilarly, uniquely, contrarily.

Where it comes from: From Latin similis (like).

6.20.215. Irrationally#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªËˆrÃ¦ÊƒÉ™nÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that is not based on or guided by reason.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œirrationallyâ€ is to be in a way that is not based on reason or logic, often driven by emotion or whim.

What it really means: â€œIrrationallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a way that is not based on or guided by reason. It suggests that a person is acting on their emotions rather than on logic. For example, a person can irrationally be afraid of a spider.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a way that is not based on or guided by reason.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œact irrationally,â€ â€œbehave irrationally,â€ â€œthink irrationally.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œShe was so angry that she acted irrationally and said some things she later regretted.â€

      • â€œHe is irrationally afraid of spiders, even though they are harmless.â€

      • â€œThe new policy was irrationally designed and will not work.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy was irrationally put in place by the government.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to think irrationally can affect their decision-making.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of not acting irrationally when in a state of crisis.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to prevent people from irrationally acting in a dangerous way.â€

Synonyms: Unreasonably, illogically, foolishly, senselessly, absurdly.

Opposite words: Rationally, logically, reasonably, sensibly, wisely.

Where it comes from: From Latin irrationalis (not rational).

6.20.216. Firmly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆfÉœËmli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that is strong and sure.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œfirmlyâ€ is to be with a strong, resolute, and unwavering grip or conviction.

What it really means: â€œFirmlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a way that is strong and sure. It suggests that a person is not going to change their mind or their position. For example, a person can firmly hold a belief or firmly hold a position in a debate.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a way that is strong and sure.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œfirmly believe,â€ â€œfirmly hold,â€ â€œfirmly planted.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe firmly believes that the new policy will not work.â€

      • â€œI firmly held the rope so that I wouldnâ€™t fall.â€

      • â€œHe stood firmly on his principles and would not be moved.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is firmly supported by the government.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s firmly held beliefs can affect their decision-making.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of firmly addressing the new problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to firmly establish the new governmentâ€™s power.â€

Synonyms: Steadfastly, resolutely, securely, strongly, determinedly.

Opposite words: Weakly, insecurely, loosely, hesitantly, uncertainly.

Where it comes from: From Old English firmian (to make firm).

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆvÉ›stÉªÉ¡eÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œinvestigateâ€ is to conduct a systematic search or examination to uncover facts or discover the truth.

What it really means: To â€œinvestigateâ€ means to carry out a systematic or formal inquiry to discover and examine the facts of an incident. It is the act of trying to find out what happened. For example, the police can investigate a crime.

When to use it: Use it to describe the act of carrying out a systematic or formal inquiry to discover and examine the facts.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œinvestigate a crime,â€ â€œinvestigate a claim,â€ â€œinvestigate a matter.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to help the government investigate the new problems in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help the government investigate the new problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to investigate a new idea can affect their decision-making.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent process for the investigation of a new claim.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help the government investigate the new problems in the country.â€

Synonyms: Examine, explore, research, inquire into, look into.

Where it comes from: From Latin investigare (to track down).

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªkËˆspoÊŠÊ’É™r/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The state of being exposed to contact with something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œexposureâ€ is the state of being brought into contact with something, often something new, unknown, or potentially harmful.

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆpÊŒblÉªk/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

  • Simple Meaning: (Adj) Of or concerning the people as a whole; (Noun) The community as a whole.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the adjective is to be related to the people as a whole, not just a private group. The core meaning of the noun is the entire community or a general body of people.

What it really means: As an adjective, â€œpublicâ€ describes something of or concerning the people as a whole. As a noun, the â€œpublicâ€ refers to the community as a whole.

  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œpublic opinion,â€ â€œpublic transport,â€ â€œpublic speaking.â€

    • (Noun) â€œthe general public,â€ â€œin public,â€ â€œthe publicâ€™s opinion.â€

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy has been met with a number of public protests.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the needs of the public.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to improve the publicâ€™s access to new information.â€

Where it comes from: From Latin publicus (of the people).

6.20.220. Relief#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆliËf/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A feeling of reassurance and relaxation following the release from anxiety or distress.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œreliefâ€ is the alleviation of pain, distress, or anxiety, bringing a sense of comfort or ease.

What it really means: â€œReliefâ€ is a noun that refers to a feeling of reassurance and relaxation following the release from anxiety or distress. It can also refer to the help or assistance that is given to people in need.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a feeling of reassurance and relaxation, or the help that is given to people in need.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa sense of relief,â€ â€œto your relief,â€ â€œdisaster relief.â€
