    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI felt a great sense of relief when I found my keys.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is a form of tax relief for the poor.â€

      • â€œThe new medicine will provide some relief from the pain.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a form of relief for the countryâ€™s economic problems.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s feeling of relief can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of providing relief to people who are in need.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to provide a form of relief to the countryâ€™s population.â€

Synonyms: Comfort, ease, succor, assistance, aid, alleviation.

Opposite words: Distress, pain, anxiety, discomfort, burden.

Where it comes from: From Old French relever (to raise up).

6.20.221. Fluctuation#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒflÊŒktÊƒuËˆeÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: An irregular rising and falling in number or amount; a variation.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œfluctuationâ€ is an irregular and unpredictable change in level, quantity, or value, indicating instability.

What it really means: â€œFluctuationâ€ is a noun that refers to an irregular rising and falling in number or amount. It suggests that something is not stable and is changing all the time. For example, the stock market can have a lot of fluctuations.

When to use it: Use it to refer to an irregular rising and falling in number or amount.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œprice fluctuation,â€ â€œcurrency fluctuation,â€ â€œa fluctuation in.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe stock market has had a lot of fluctuations recently, so Iâ€™m not sure if I should invest.â€

      • â€œThe price of gas has had a lot of fluctuations recently.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the fluctuations in the countryâ€™s economy.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the fluctuations in the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s fluctuation in mood can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the fluctuations in the price of oil.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the fluctuations in the countryâ€™s weather.â€

Synonyms: Variation, oscillation, instability, vacillation, change.

Opposite words: Stability, consistency, steadiness, uniformity.

Where it comes from: From Latin fluctuare (to wave, to be in constant motion).

6.20.222. Virtual#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆvÉœËrtÊƒuÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Not physically existing but made to appear to do so by a computer.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œvirtualâ€ is to be nearly or almost a particular thing, often existing as a computer-generated simulation rather than in physical reality.

What it really means: â€œVirtualâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is not physically existing but is made to appear to do so by a computer. It can also be used to describe something that is almost or very nearly a particular thing. For example, a virtual reality game is a game that is not real, but it seems to be.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is not physically existing but is made to appear to do so by a computer, or something that is almost a particular thing.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œvirtual reality,â€ â€œvirtual meeting,â€ â€œvirtual tour.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI had a virtual meeting with my boss, and it was great.â€

      • â€œThe new game is a virtual reality game, and itâ€™s so much fun.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a virtual tour of the new building.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to promote the use of virtual education in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s virtual social connections can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan for the use of virtual meetings.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to create a virtual world for people to explore.â€

Synonyms: Simulated, digital, computer-generated, theoretical.

Opposite words: Real, physical, tangible, actual, genuine.

Where it comes from: From Latin virtus (strength, virtue).

6.20.223. Adjustment#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆdÊ’ÊŒstmÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A small alteration or movement made to achieve a desired fit, appearance, or result.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œadjustmentâ€ is a small change or modification made to fit a new situation or achieve a better result.

What it really means: An â€œadjustmentâ€ is a noun that refers to a small alteration or movement made to achieve a desired fit, appearance, or result. It can be a personâ€™s adjustment to a new environment or a personâ€™s adjustment to a new policy.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a small alteration or movement made to achieve a desired fit, appearance, or result.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œmake an adjustment,â€ â€œa small adjustment,â€ â€œa period of adjustment.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI need to make a small adjustment to the settings on my computer.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is a small adjustment to the old one.â€

      • â€œThe new employee needs a period of adjustment to get used to the new company.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy will require a number of adjustments to the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s adjustment to a new environment can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of making a small adjustment to the new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to make a number of adjustments to the new product.â€

Synonyms: Modification, alteration, change, correction, adaptation.

Opposite words: Stability, constancy, rigidity, permanence.

Where it comes from: From Old French ajuster (to adjust).

6.20.224. Requirement#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆkwaÉªÉ™rmÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A thing that is needed or wanted.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrequirementâ€ is a thing that is needed or compulsory, often as a condition for something else to happen.

What it really means: A â€œrequirementâ€ is a noun that refers to a thing that is needed or wanted. It can be a personâ€™s requirement for a new job or a companyâ€™s requirement for a new product.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a thing that is needed or wanted.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œmeet a requirement,â€ â€œa legal requirement,â€ â€œa necessary requirement.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new job has a number of requirements that I donâ€™t have.â€

      • â€œThe new law is a legal requirement for all companies.â€

      • â€œThe new product has a number of requirements that I canâ€™t meet.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy will require a number of requirements from the public.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s requirements for a new job can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to meet the new requirements of the law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to meet the requirements of the new product.â€

Synonyms: Need, necessity, prerequisite, essential, condition.

Opposite words: Option, choice, preference, superfluity.

Where it comes from: From Old French requerir (to ask for).

6.20.225. Recognition#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒrÉ›kÉ™É¡ËˆnÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action or process of recognizing or being recognized.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrecognitionâ€ is the act of identifying or acknowledging someone or something based on previous knowledge or experience. It can also mean to show appreciation for something.

What it really means: â€œRecognitionâ€ is a noun that refers to the action or process of recognizing or being recognized. It can be a personâ€™s recognition of a face or a personâ€™s recognition of an achievement.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the action or process of recognizing or being recognized.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œrecognition of a problem,â€ â€œa lack of recognition,â€ â€œsocial recognition.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe received a lot of recognition for his work on the project.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is a recognition of the countryâ€™s economic problems.â€

      • â€œI donâ€™t need any recognition for what I did, I just want to help.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a recognition of the countryâ€™s need for change.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s recognition of their own weaknesses can affect their ability to succeed.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear process for the recognition of a new country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a recognition of the countryâ€™s need for new solutions to old problems.â€

Synonyms: Identification, acknowledgment, appreciation, awareness, fame.

Opposite words: Anonymity, disregard, ignorance, oversight, oblivion.

Where it comes from: From Latin recognoscere (to know again).

6.20.226. Decide#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆsaÉªd/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To make a choice from a number of alternatives.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdecideâ€ is to make a definite choice or judgment after considering all options, thereby bringing a matter to a close.

What it really means: To â€œdecideâ€ means to make a choice from a number of alternatives. It is the act of choosing what to do after thinking about all the options. For example, a person can decide to go to a new school or a person can decide to buy a new car.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of making a choice from a number of alternatives.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œdecide on,â€ â€œdecide to,â€ â€œdecide against.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI need to decide what to have for dinner, but I canâ€™t make up my mind.â€

      • â€œHe decided to go to the new school because it was closer to his house.â€

      • â€œThe company decided against the new policy because it was too expensive.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy was decided after a long period of debate.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to decide can affect their long-term happiness.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear process for the government to decide on new laws.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people decide on the best product for them.â€

Synonyms: Choose, determine, settle, resolve, conclude.

Opposite words: Waver, hesitate, postpone, delay.

Where it comes from: From Latin decidere (to cut off, to determine).

6.20.227. Corrupt#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™ËˆrÊŒpt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Adj) Having or showing a willingness to act dishonestly in return for money or personal gain; (Verb) To cause to become or to be immoral or dishonest.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the adjective is to be dishonest or immoral, often for personal gain. The core meaning of the verb is to cause someone or something to become dishonest or immoral.

What it really means: As an adjective, â€œcorruptâ€ describes someone or something that is willing to act dishonestly in return for money or personal gain. As a verb, to â€œcorruptâ€ means to cause someone or something to become immoral or dishonest.

When to use it: Use the adjective to describe a person or a thing that is dishonest or immoral, and the verb to describe the act of causing someone or something to become dishonest or immoral.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œcorrupt politician,â€ â€œcorrupt system,â€ â€œcorrupt data.â€

    • (Verb) â€œcorrupt a person,â€ â€œcorrupt a system,â€ â€œcorrupt a file.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new politician is very corrupt, and he only cares about money.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to help fight against a corrupt system.â€

      • â€œThe new file is corrupt and I canâ€™t open it.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to fight against a corrupt government.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s corrupt behavior can affect their reputation.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to prevent the new system from becoming corrupt.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to prevent a personâ€™s data from being corrupt.â€

Synonyms: (Adj) Dishonest, crooked, venal, immoral; (Verb) Taint, debase, pervert, bribe.

Opposite words: (Adj) Honest, moral, ethical, trustworthy; (Verb) Purify, improve, uplift, reform.

Where it comes from: From Latin corrumpere (to destroy, to corrupt).

6.20.228. Implication#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉªmplÉªËˆkeÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The conclusion that can be drawn from something although it is not explicitly stated.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œimplicationâ€ is an indirect suggestion or consequence that is not stated outright but is understood.

What it really means: An â€œimplicationâ€ is a noun that refers to the conclusion that can be drawn from something although it is not explicitly stated. It suggests that a person has to read between the lines to understand the true meaning of something. For example, a personâ€™s silence can have a lot of implications.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the conclusion that can be drawn from something although it is not explicitly stated.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œthe implication of,â€ â€œby implication,â€ â€œa negative implication.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new policy has a lot of negative implications for the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œI donâ€™t know what the implication of his words are, but I think he is trying to tell me something.â€

      • â€œThe new law is a implication of the governmentâ€™s desire to change the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy has a lot of negative implications for the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s implications can affect their social relationships.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan for the implication of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to have a lot of negative implications for the countryâ€™s economy.â€

Synonyms: Suggestion, inference, consequence, ramification, insinuation.

Opposite words: Statement, declaration, explicit meaning, direct consequence.

Where it comes from: From Latin implicare (to enfold, to involve).

6.20.229. Regular#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆrÉ›É¡jÉ™lÉ™r/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Arranged in or constituting a constant or definite pattern, especially with the same space between individual items.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œregularâ€ is to be consistent, uniform, or happening at fixed intervals, indicating a predictable pattern.

What it really means: â€œRegularâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is arranged in a constant or definite pattern. It suggests that something is predictable and reliable. For example, a personâ€™s heartbeat can be regular, or a personâ€™s work can be regular.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is arranged in a constant or definite pattern.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œregular exercise,â€ â€œregular meetings,â€ â€œregular basis.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe has a regular heartbeat, so he is not in danger.â€

      • â€œWe have regular meetings to discuss the new project.â€

      • â€œI go to the gym on a regular basis.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to promote a regular schedule for all employees.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s regular exercise can affect their long-term health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a regular approach to a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to provide regular and reliable results.â€

Synonyms: Consistent, uniform, steady, constant, orderly.

Opposite words: Irregular, inconsistent, erratic, uneven, sporadic.

Where it comes from: From Latin regularis (according to rule).

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆzÉªliÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The capacity to recover quickly from difficulties; toughness.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œresilienceâ€ is the ability to recover or bounce back from adversity, hardship, or change.

What it really means: â€œResilienceâ€ is a noun that refers to the capacity to recover quickly from difficulties. It suggests that a person is tough and can handle a lot of stress. For example, a personâ€™s resilience can be seen in their ability to overcome a difficult situation.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the capacity to recover quickly from difficulties.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œmental resilience,â€ â€œemotional resilience,â€ â€œa lack of resilience.â€

      • â€œHe has a lot of mental resilience, and he was able to overcome his problems.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to help the country build its economic resilience.â€

      • â€œThe new team has a lot of resilience, and they were able to win the game.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to build the countryâ€™s economic resilience.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s resilience can affect their ability to succeed in a new environment.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear plan to build the resilience of the countryâ€™s infrastructure.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help a person build their resilience to stress.â€

Synonyms: Toughness, durability, flexibility, elasticity, strength.

Opposite words: Fragility, weakness, inflexibility, vulnerability.

Where it comes from: From Latin resilire (to jump back).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆwiËknÉ™s/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The state or condition of lacking strength.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œweaknessâ€ is a lack of strength, power, or effectiveness, either physically or as a flaw in character or a system.

What it really means: â€œWeaknessâ€ is a noun that refers to the state or condition of lacking strength. It can be a personâ€™s weakness in a certain subject or a companyâ€™s weakness in a certain area.

  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa moment of weakness,â€ â€œa weakness for,â€ â€œa glaring weakness.â€

      • â€œHe has a weakness for chocolate, so he canâ€™t stop eating it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy has a number of weaknesses that need to be addressed.â€

      • â€œThe new teamâ€™s weakness was their lack of experience.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s weakness in a certain subject can affect their academic performance.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear plan to address the weakness of the countryâ€™s infrastructure.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the weakness of the old one.â€

Synonyms: Frailty, feebleness, flaw, shortcoming, vulnerability.

Opposite words: Strength, power, resilience, advantage, fortitude.

Where it comes from: From Old English wacnes (weakness).

  • Pronunciation: /pÉ™ËˆsÉ›pÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The way in which something is regarded, understood, or interpreted.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œperceptionâ€ is the process of using the senses to acquire information and interpret it, thereby forming a personal view or understanding.

What it really means: â€œPerceptionâ€ is a noun that refers to the way in which something is regarded, understood, or interpreted. It is a personâ€™s subjective understanding of something. For example, a personâ€™s perception of a new policy can be different from another personâ€™s.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the way in which something is regarded, understood, or interpreted.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œpublic perception,â€ â€œa change in perception,â€ â€œthe perception of a problem.â€

    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new policy has a lot of negative perception from the public.â€

      • â€œThe new marketing campaign is designed to change the perception of the company.â€

      • â€œI donâ€™t know what his perception of the situation is, but I think he is wrong.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to change the public perception of the government.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s perception of their own body can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the public perception of the new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to change the perception of the new product.â€

Synonyms: View, understanding, insight, impression, awareness.

Opposite words: Misconception, ignorance, blindness, unawareness.

Where it comes from: From Latin percipere (to take hold of, to understand).

6.20.233. Recently#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆriËsÉ™ntli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Not long ago; in the near past.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrecentlyâ€ is to be in the near past, indicating that an event happened not long ago.

What it really means: â€œRecentlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that happened not long ago. It suggests that something happened in the near past. For example, a person can recently have bought a new car, or a person can recently have started a new job.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that happened not long ago.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œrecently bought,â€ â€œrecently started,â€ â€œrecently discovered.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI recently bought a new car, and I love it.â€

      • â€œShe recently started a new job, and she is very happy.â€

      • â€œThe new technology was recently discovered and is very exciting.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy was recently put in place by the government.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s recently changed diet can affect their long-term health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the problems that have recently arisen.â€

      • â€œThe new law was recently passed and will have a lot of new changes.â€

Synonyms: Lately, newly, freshly, not long ago.

Opposite words: Formerly, long ago, in the past.

Where it comes from: From Old French receient (recent).

6.20.234. Respect#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆspÉ›kt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) A feeling of deep admiration for someone or something elicited by their abilities, qualities, or achievements; (Verb) To admire (someone or something) deeply, as a result of their abilities, qualities, or achievements.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is a feeling of admiration or esteem for someone or something. The core meaning of the verb is to show admiration or honor for someone or something.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œrespectâ€ is a feeling of deep admiration for someone or something. As a verb, to â€œrespectâ€ means to admire someone or something deeply.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a feeling of deep admiration, and the verb to describe the act of admiring someone or something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œshow respect,â€ â€œa lack of respect,â€ â€œwith all due respect.â€

    • (Verb) â€œrespect a person,â€ â€œrespect a law,â€ â€œrespect a decision.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have a lot of respect for him because he is a very good person.â€

      • â€œYou need to respect your elders and listen to what they have to say.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to help people respect the new changes in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a respect for the countryâ€™s traditions.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s respect for a new culture can affect their ability to live in a new country.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to respect the new laws of the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to respect a personâ€™s privacy.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Esteem, admiration, honor, reverence; (Verb) Admire, revere, honor, value.

Opposite words: (Noun) Disrespect, contempt, scorn, disdain; (Verb) Disrespect, scorn, disregard.

Where it comes from: From Latin respectus (regard, consideration).

6.20.235. Qualification#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒkwÉ’lÉªfÉªËˆkeÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: An official document showing that a person has completed a course of study or passed an examination.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œqualificationâ€ is an achievement, skill, or attribute that makes a person suitable for a particular job or task.

What it really means: A â€œqualificationâ€ is a noun that refers to an official document showing that a person has completed a course of study or passed an examination. It can also refer to a quality or accomplishment that makes a person suitable for a job. For example, a person can have a lot of qualifications for a new job.

When to use it: Use it to refer to an official document showing that a person has completed a course of study or passed an examination, or to refer to a quality or accomplishment that makes a person suitable for a job.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œhave a qualification,â€ â€œa lack of qualification,â€ â€œa professional qualification.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe has a lot of qualifications for the new job, so I think he will get it.â€

      • â€œThe new job has a number of qualifications that I donâ€™t have.â€

      • â€œI have a professional qualification that will help me get the new job.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help people get the necessary qualifications for a new job.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s qualifications can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent process for the qualification of a new employee.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people get the necessary qualifications for a new job.â€

Synonyms: Certification, credential, skill, aptitude, eligibility.

Opposite words: Disqualification, unsuitability, ineligibility.

Where it comes from: From Latin qualis (of what kind).

6.20.236. Delay#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆleÉª/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To make someone or something late or slow; (Noun) A period of time by which something is late or postponed.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the verb is to cause a pause or postponement, making something happen later than planned. The core meaning of the noun is the period of time during which this postponement occurs.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œdelayâ€ means to make someone or something late or slow. As a noun, a â€œdelayâ€ is a period of time by which something is late or postponed.

When to use it: Use the verb to describe the act of making something late, and the noun to refer to a period of time by which something is late.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œdelay a meeting,â€ â€œdelay a project,â€ â€œdelay a decision.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa short delay,â€ â€œa long delay,â€ â€œwithout delay.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new policy will delay the project by a few weeks.â€

      • â€œThere was a delay on the train, so I was late for work.â€

      • â€œI need to make a decision without any delay.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy will delay the countryâ€™s economic growth.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s delay in a certain decision can affect their long-term happiness.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address any delay in the new project.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to prevent any delay in the production of new products.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Postpone, defer, hold up, hinder; (Noun) Postponement, deferment, slowdown, setback.

Opposite words: (Verb) Hasten, accelerate, advance, hurry; (Noun) Haste, speed, promptness.

Where it comes from: From Old French delaier (to delay).

6.20.237. Refusal#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆfjuËzÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The act of refusing to do or accept something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrefusalâ€ is the act of saying no to a request, demand, or offer, indicating a firm denial.

What it really means: â€œRefusalâ€ is a noun that refers to the act of refusing to do or accept something. It suggests that a person is not willing to do or accept something. For example, a personâ€™s refusal to go to a new school can be a problem.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of refusing to do or accept something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa flat refusal,â€ â€œa refusal to,â€ â€œa refusal of.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new policy was met with a flat refusal from the public.â€

      • â€œI was very surprised by his refusal to help me.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to help people who have a refusal of service.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy was met with a refusal from the government.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s refusal to accept a new idea can affect their ability to learn.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address a personâ€™s refusal to follow the new laws.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to prevent a personâ€™s refusal to use the new products.â€

Synonyms: Denial, rejection, noncompliance, veto, declination.

Opposite words: Acceptance, agreement, consent, approval, compliance.

Where it comes from: From Old French refuser (to refuse).

6.20.238. Distribution#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒdÉªstrÉªËˆbjuËÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action of sharing something out among a number of recipients.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdistributionâ€ is the process of spreading or giving out something to a group of people or places.

What it really means: â€œDistributionâ€ is a noun that refers to the action of sharing something out among a number of recipients. It can be the distribution of a new product or the distribution of a new policy.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the action of sharing something out among a number of recipients.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œincome distribution,â€ â€œthe distribution of resources,â€ â€œa wide distribution.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to improve the distribution of wealth in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new product has a very wide distribution, so itâ€™s easy to find.â€

      • â€œThe new company is in charge of the distribution of the new product.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to improve the distribution of resources in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s distribution of their time can affect their productivity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan for the distribution of the new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to improve the distribution of new products.â€

Synonyms: Allocation, dissemination, sharing, circulation, apportionment.

Opposite words: Collection, gathering, accumulation, centralization.

Where it comes from: From Latin distribuere (to divide up).

6.20.239. Densely#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆdÉ›nsli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a close-packed or crowded way.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdenselyâ€ is to be in a concentrated or crowded manner, with things close together.

What it really means: â€œDenselyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a close-packed or crowded way. It suggests that things are very close together. For example, a forest can be densely populated with trees, or a city can be densely populated with people.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a close-packed or crowded way.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œdensely populated,â€ â€œdensely packed,â€ â€œdensely forested.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe city is densely populated with people, so itâ€™s always crowded.â€

      • â€œThe forest is densely packed with trees, so itâ€™s hard to walk through.â€

      • â€œThe new building is densely packed with people, so itâ€™s very loud.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the densely populated areas of the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s densely packed schedule can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the densely populated areas of the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the densely packed areas of the country.â€

Synonyms: Tightly, compactly, thickly, crowdedly, compactly.

Opposite words: Sparsely, loosely, thinly, widely.

Where it comes from: From Latin densus (thick, dense).

6.20.240. Abundance#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆbÊŒndÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A very large quantity of something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œabundanceâ€ is to have a very large or plentiful quantity of something, often more than is needed.

What it really means: â€œAbundanceâ€ is a noun that refers to a very large quantity of something. It suggests that there is more than enough of something. For example, a country can have an abundance of natural resources.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a very large quantity of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œan abundance of,â€ â€œin abundance,â€ â€œa wealth of abundance.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new country has an abundance of natural resources, so itâ€™s very wealthy.â€

      • â€œThe new company has a lot of money, so they have an abundance of new products.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to help the country have an abundance of food.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help the country have an abundance of natural resources.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s abundance of food can affect their health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the abundance of a certain problem.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help the country have an abundance of new products.â€

Synonyms: Plenty, profusion, wealth, richness, surplus.

Opposite words: Scarcity, lack, shortage, deficiency, dearth.

Where it comes from: From Latin abundare (to overflow).

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™ËˆsteÉªnÉ™bli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that can be continued or maintained at a certain level.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsustainablyâ€ is to be in a way that can be maintained over the long term without depleting resources or causing harm.

What it really means: â€œSustainablyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a way that can be continued or maintained at a certain level. It suggests that a person is doing something in a way that is not harmful to the environment. For example, a person can live sustainably by using renewable energy.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a way that can be continued or maintained at a certain level.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œlive sustainably,â€ â€œgrow sustainably,â€ â€œdevelop sustainably.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new company is trying to grow sustainably by using renewable energy.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to help the country develop sustainably.â€

      • â€œI am trying to live sustainably by using less plastic.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help the country develop sustainably.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to live sustainably can affect their health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to sustainably develop the countryâ€™s infrastructure.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help the country sustainably produce new products.â€

Synonyms: Continuously, perpetually, enduringly, long-lastingly.

Opposite words: Unsustainably, temporarily, fleetingly.

Where it comes from: From Latin sustinere (to hold up).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkraÊŠdÉªd/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: (Of a space) filled with people to the point of being uncomfortable.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcrowdedâ€ is to be filled with an excessive number of people or things, leading to a feeling of being cramped or overfull.

What it really means: â€œCrowdedâ€ is an adjective used to describe a space that is filled with people to the point of being uncomfortable. It suggests that there are too many people in a small space. For example, a bus can be crowded with people.

When to use it: Use it to describe a space that is filled with people to the point of being uncomfortable.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa crowded room,â€ â€œa crowded street,â€ â€œa crowded bus.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new bus is very crowded in the morning, so I always have to stand.â€

      • â€œThe new store is very crowded on the weekends, so I avoid going there.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the crowded areas of the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the crowded areas of the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s crowded living conditions can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the crowded areas of the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the crowded areas of the country.â€

Synonyms: Packed, full, congested, overflowing, teeming.

Opposite words: Empty, deserted, sparse, spacious, uncrowded.

Where it comes from: From Old English crudan (to press).

What it really means: â€œProgressionâ€ is a noun that refers to the process of developing or moving gradually towards a more advanced state. It suggests that a person or a thing is getting better over time. For example, a personâ€™s progression in a new job can be very quick.

  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa rapid progression,â€ â€œa slow progression,â€ â€œthe progression of a disease.â€

      • â€œHis progression in the new job was very quick, so he was promoted in a few months.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan for the progression of a new project.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help the countryâ€™s progression in a new direction.â€

Synonyms: Advance, development, improvement, evolution, growth.

6.20.244. Restriction#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆstrÉªkÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A limiting condition or measure.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrestrictionâ€ is a limiting condition or rule that prevents or controls an action, access, or use.

What it really means: â€œRestrictionâ€ is a noun that refers to a limiting condition or measure. It suggests that a person is not allowed to do something or is not allowed to have something. For example, a new law can have a lot of restrictions.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a limiting condition or measure.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa restriction on,â€ â€œunder a restriction,â€ â€œa legal restriction.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new law has a number of restrictions on what you can and canâ€™t do.â€

      • â€œI am under a restriction that I canâ€™t leave the house after 10 PM.â€

      • â€œThe new policy has a lot of restrictions on the use of new technology.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a restriction on the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s restriction in a certain area can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the restriction of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to have a number of restrictions on its use.â€

Synonyms: Limitation, constraint, prohibition, curb, barrier.

Opposite words: Freedom, liberty, allowance, permission, deregulation.

Where it comes from: From Latin restringere (to tie back, to confine).

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to save the countryâ€™s precious resources.â€

Synonyms: Valuable, cherished, treasured, priceless, rare.

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to randomly generate new ideas.â€

      • â€œThe new glass is very fragile, so you have to be careful with it.â€

      • â€œThe new country has a very fragile economy, so itâ€™s in danger of collapsing.â€

      • â€œThe new peace treaty is very fragile, so it could break at any time.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the fragile peace in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help the countryâ€™s fragile economy.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to have a strict adherence to the new rules.â€

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that avoids damage or risk.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a way that avoids damage or risk.

    • (Adverb) â€œdrive carefully,â€ â€œhandle carefully,â€ â€œread carefully.â€

      • â€œI need to carefully drive my car in the rain so that I donâ€™t get into an accident.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to carefully address a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to carefully handle a new product.â€

Synonyms: Cautiously, attentively, meticulously, prudently, thoughtfully.

Where it comes from: From Old English carful (full of care).

6.20.254. Eliminate#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªËˆlÉªmÉªneÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To completely remove or get rid of (something).

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œeliminateâ€ is to completely remove, get rid of, or do away with something.

What it really means: To â€œeliminateâ€ means to completely remove or get rid of something. It is the act of getting rid of something that is not needed. For example, a company can eliminate a new product that is not selling well.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of completely removing or getting rid of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œeliminate a problem,â€ â€œeliminate a person,â€ â€œeliminate a product.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to eliminate the new problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new company is trying to eliminate a lot of its old products.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to eliminate a lot of old laws that are no longer needed.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to eliminate the new problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to eliminate a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to eliminate the new problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to eliminate a lot of old problems.â€

Synonyms: Remove, get rid of, eradicate, abolish, terminate.

Opposite words: Introduce, add, include, create, maintain.

Where it comes from: From Latin eliminare (to turn out of doors).

6.20.255. Notoriously#

  • Pronunciation: /noÊŠËˆtÉ”ËriÉ™sli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that is well known, typically for some bad quality or deed.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œnotoriouslyâ€ is to be in a manner that is widely and unfavorably known, often for a negative reason.

What it really means: â€œNotoriouslyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a way that is well known, typically for some bad quality or deed. It suggests that a person or a thing is famous for a bad reason. For example, a person can be notoriously bad at their job.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a way that is well known, typically for some bad quality or deed.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œnotoriously bad,â€ â€œnotoriously difficult,â€ â€œnotoriously expensive.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new car is notoriously unreliable, so I donâ€™t want to buy it.â€

      • â€œThe new job is notoriously difficult, so I donâ€™t know if I can do it.â€

      • â€œThe new law is notoriously bad, so I donâ€™t think it will work.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is notoriously bad for the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s notoriously bad reputation can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the notoriously bad problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is notoriously expensive, so it will not be widely used.â€

Synonyms: Infamously, reputedly, widely known, famously (in a negative sense).

Opposite words: Honorably, reputably, famously (in a positive sense), unremarkably.

Where it comes from: From Latin notorius (known).

6.20.256. Challenge#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆtÊƒÃ¦lÉªndÊ’/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) A call to someone to participate in a competitive situation or fight to decide who is superior in terms of ability or strength; (Verb) To invite someone to engage in a contest.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is a demanding or difficult task or situation that tests oneâ€™s abilities. The core meaning of the verb is to question the validity or authority of something or to invite someone to a contest.

What it really means: As a noun, a â€œchallengeâ€ is a difficult task or situation. As a verb, to â€œchallengeâ€ means to question the validity or authority of something.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a difficult task or situation, and the verb to describe the act of questioning the validity or authority of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new challenge,â€ â€œface a challenge,â€ â€œa great challenge.â€

    • (Verb) â€œchallenge a claim,â€ â€œchallenge a person,â€ â€œchallenge a law.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new job is a great challenge for me, but I think I can do it.â€

      • â€œHe challenged my claim that the new policy would not work.â€

      • â€œThe new law is a challenge to the old one.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a challenge to the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s challenge to a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the challenge of a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a challenge to the old one.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Obstacle, difficulty, test, task; (Verb) Question, dispute, confront, defy.

Opposite words: (Noun) Advantage, ease, simplicity, solution; (Verb) Accept, agree, support, comply.

Where it comes from: From Old French chalengier (to accuse).

6.20.257. Pollute#

  • Pronunciation: /pÉ™ËˆluËt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To contaminate (water, air, or soil) with harmful or poisonous substances.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpolluteâ€ is to make something dirty or unsafe by introducing harmful substances.

What it really means: To â€œpolluteâ€ means to contaminate water, air, or soil with harmful or poisonous substances. It is the act of making something dirty or unsafe. For example, a company can pollute a river with its waste.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of contaminating water, air, or soil with harmful or poisonous substances.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œpollute the air,â€ â€œpollute the water,â€ â€œpollute the soil.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new factory will pollute the air with a lot of smoke.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to prevent companies from polluting the river.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help the country pollute less.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to prevent companies from polluting the environment.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s pollute of the environment can affect their health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to prevent the new technology from polluting the environment.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to help the country pollute less.â€

Synonyms: Contaminate, taint, foul, poison, corrupt.

Opposite words: Purify, clean, cleanse, sanitize, decontaminate.

Where it comes from: From Latin polluere (to soil, to defile).

6.20.258. Obligation#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉ’blÉªËˆÉ¡eÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: An act or course of action to which a person is morally or legally bound; a duty or commitment.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œobligationâ€ is a moral or legal duty that a person is bound to perform, a sense of being required to do something.

What it really means: â€œObligationâ€ is a noun that refers to an act or course of action to which a person is morally or legally bound. It suggests that a person has a duty or a commitment to do something. For example, a personâ€™s obligation to their family is to take care of them.

When to use it: Use it to refer to an act or course of action to which a person is morally or legally bound.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa moral obligation,â€ â€œa legal obligation,â€ â€œa sense of obligation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have a moral obligation to help my friends when they are in need.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is a legal obligation for all companies.â€

      • â€œI feel a sense of obligation to help the new employee.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a legal obligation for all companies.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s obligation to their family can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address a personâ€™s obligation to the community.â€

      • â€œThe new law is a legal obligation for all citizens.â€

Synonyms: Duty, responsibility, commitment, liability, requirement.

Opposite words: Freedom, choice, option, right, exemption.

Where it comes from: From Latin obligare (to bind to).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆhÉªndÉ™r/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To create difficulties for (someone or something), resulting in delay or obstruction.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œhinderâ€ is to make it difficult for someone or something to do something, thereby causing a delay or an obstruction.

What it really means: To â€œhinderâ€ means to create difficulties for someone or something, resulting in delay or obstruction. It is the act of making it hard for someone to do something. For example, a personâ€™s lack of experience can hinder their ability to get a new job.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of creating difficulties for someone or something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œhinder a person,â€ â€œhinder a project,â€ â€œhinder a process.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new policy will hinder the projectâ€™s progress.â€

      • â€œHis lack of experience will hinder his ability to get a new job.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to hinder the new problems in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy will hinder the countryâ€™s economic growth.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s hinder of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to prevent the new technology from hinder the new project.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to hinder the new problems in the country.â€

Synonyms: Obstruct, impede, hamper, delay, block.

Opposite words: Help, assist, facilitate, advance, promote.

Where it comes from: From Old English hindrian (to hold back).

6.20.260. Exception#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªkËˆsÉ›pÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A person or thing that is excluded from a general statement or rule.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œexceptionâ€ is a person or thing that is not included in a general rule or principle, standing out from the rest.

What it really means: An â€œexceptionâ€ is a noun that refers to a person or a thing that is excluded from a general statement or rule. It suggests that something is not part of the normal rule. For example, a person can be an exception to a new law.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a person or a thing that is excluded from a general statement or rule.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œwith the exception of,â€ â€œas an exception,â€ â€œa rare exception.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new law applies to everyone, with the exception of the police.â€

      • â€œI will make an exception for you because you are my friend.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is a rare exception to the old one.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy applies to everyone, with the exception of the government.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s exception to a new law can affect their ability to live in a new country.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the exception of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to have a number of exceptions to the new rules.â€

Synonyms: Exclusion, exemption, anomaly, deviation, peculiarity.

Opposite words: Rule, norm, generality, regularity, inclusion.

Where it comes from: From Latin excipere (to take out).

What it really means: â€œFamiliarlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a way that is well known from long or close association. It suggests that a person is very comfortable with something. For example, a person can familiarly speak to a friend.

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to help people familiarly use the new system.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people familiarly use the new products.â€

Synonyms: Intimately, informally, casually, openly, comfortably.

Opposite words: Formally, distantly, reservedly, stiffly.

Where it comes from: From Latin familiaris (of a family).

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s vote in a new election can affect the countryâ€™s future.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to ensure that the new election is fair.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to help people vote in the new election.â€

6.20.264. Admission#

  • Pronunciation: /É™dËˆmÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The process or fact of entering or being allowed to enter a place or an organization.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œadmissionâ€ is the act of allowing entry or access to a place, an organization, or a fact.

What it really means: â€œAdmissionâ€ is a noun that refers to the process or fact of entering or being allowed to enter a place or an organization. It can also refer to the act of confessing or acknowledging something. For example, a personâ€™s admission to a new school can be a great thing, or a personâ€™s admission of a mistake can be a good thing.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the process or fact of entering or being allowed to enter a place or an organization, or to the act of confessing or acknowledging something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œget admission,â€ â€œa public admission,â€ â€œa private admission.â€

    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI was so happy when I got my admission to the new school.â€

      • â€œHis public admission of his mistake was very surprising.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to help people get admission to a new country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help people get admission to a new school.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s admission of a mistake can affect their reputation.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan for the admission of a new person to a new country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people get admission to a new school.â€

Synonyms: Entry, access, acceptance, confession, acknowledgment.

Opposite words: Exclusion, rejection, denial, refusal, dismissal.

Where it comes from: From Latin admittere (to send to, to allow to enter).

6.20.265. Habit#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆhÃ¦bÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A settled or regular tendency or practice, especially one that is hard to give up.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œhabitâ€ is a regular, repeated behavior or practice that is difficult to stop or change.

What it really means: A â€œhabitâ€ is a noun that refers to a settled or regular tendency or practice, especially one that is hard to give up. It suggests that a person is doing something that they do all the time. For example, a person can have a bad habit of smoking, or a person can have a good habit of exercising.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a settled or regular tendency or practice.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa good habit,â€ â€œa bad habit,â€ â€œform a habit.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have a bad habit of smoking, and Iâ€™m trying to quit.â€

      • â€œExercising every day is a good habit that I have.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to help people form a good habit of saving money.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help people form a good habit of saving money.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s bad habit can affect their long-term health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to help people form a good habit of exercising.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people form a good habit of saving money.â€

Synonyms: Custom, practice, routine, tendency, pattern.

Opposite words: Deviation, exception, novelty, irregularity.

Where it comes from: From Latin habitus (state, condition).

  • Pronunciation: /É™dËˆvÉ‘Ëns/

    • (Verb) â€œadvance a cause,â€ â€œadvance a plan,â€ â€œadvance a position.â€

      • â€œThe new policy will advance the countryâ€™s economic growth.â€

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy will advance the countryâ€™s economic growth.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to advance the countryâ€™s infrastructure.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is an advance in the field of medicine.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Progress, move forward, develop, improve; (Noun) Progress, development, breakthrough, improvement.

Opposite words: (Verb) Retreat, regress, fall back, halt; (Noun) Retreat, regression, setback.

Where it comes from: From Old French avancier (to move forward).

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆdÊ’ÊŒst/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œadjustâ€ is to make a small change to something to make it more suitable or effective for a new situation.

What it really means: To â€œadjustâ€ means to alter or move something slightly in order to achieve a desired fit, appearance, or result. It is the act of making a small change to something. For example, a person can adjust a new policy to make it more effective.

    • (Verb) â€œadjust to,â€ â€œadjust a policy,â€ â€œadjust a plan.â€

      • â€œI need to adjust the settings on my computer so that I can see better.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is a small adjust to the old one.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy will adjust to the new problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s adjust to a new environment can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to adjust the new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to adjust to the new problems in the country.â€

Synonyms: Alter, modify, adapt, fine-tune, regulate.

Opposite words: Maintain, keep, preserve, fix, stabilize.

Where it comes from: From Old French ajuster (to adjust).

6.20.268. Excessively#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªkËˆsÉ›sÉªvli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: To an extent or degree that is too great or extreme.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œexcessivelyâ€ is to be beyond what is normal, necessary, or reasonable, indicating a degree that is too much.

What it really means: â€œExcessivelyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done to an extent or degree that is too great or extreme. It suggests that something is done in a way that is not normal or reasonable. For example, a person can be excessively tired, or a new law can be excessively strict.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done to an extent or degree that is too great or extreme.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œexcessively strict,â€ â€œexcessively loud,â€ â€œexcessively tired.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new law is excessively strict, and a lot of people are not happy about it.â€

      • â€œThe new car is excessively loud, so I canâ€™t drive it at night.â€

      • â€œI am excessively tired, so I canâ€™t do any work.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is excessively strict, and it will have a lot of negative effects.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s excessively loud music can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the excessively high cost of a new product.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is excessively expensive, so it will not be widely used.â€

Synonyms: Overly, unduly, immoderately, inordinately, disproportionately.

Opposite words: Moderately, reasonably, adequately, sufficiently.

Where it comes from: From Latin excedere (to go out, to go beyond).

6.20.269. Disastrous#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆzÉ‘ËstrÉ™s/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Causing great damage.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdisastrousâ€ is to cause a catastrophe or a great amount of damage, often with negative consequences.

What it really means: â€œDisastrousâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that causes great damage. It suggests that a person or a thing has a very bad effect on something. For example, a new policy can be disastrous for a countryâ€™s economy, or a new project can be disastrous for a company.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that causes great damage.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa disastrous policy,â€ â€œa disastrous outcome,â€ â€œa disastrous mistake.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new policy was a disastrous mistake, and it had to be changed.â€

      • â€œThe new project had a disastrous outcome, and the company lost a lot of money.â€

      • â€œThe new law is disastrous for the countryâ€™s economy, so it needs to be changed.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy was a disastrous mistake, and it had a lot of negative effects.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s disastrous decisions can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the disastrous effects of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a disastrous mistake, and it will not be widely used.â€

Synonyms: Catastrophic, ruinous, calamitous, devastating, terrible.

Opposite words: Fortunate, successful, beneficial, prosperous.

Where it comes from: From Latin dis (apart) and astrum (star), meaning â€œill-starred.â€

6.20.270. Adversely#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÃ¦dvÉœËsli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that is harmful, unfavorable, or detrimental.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œadverselyâ€ is to be in a way that is harmful or unfavorable, having a negative effect on something.

What it really means: â€œAdverselyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a way that is harmful, unfavorable, or detrimental. It suggests that a person or a thing has a negative effect on something. For example, a new policy can adversely affect a countryâ€™s economy.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a way that is harmful, unfavorable, or detrimental.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œadversely affect,â€ â€œadversely impact,â€ â€œadversely influenced.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new policy will adversely affect the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe new project had an adversely impact on the companyâ€™s reputation.â€

      • â€œThe new law is adversely influencing the new problems in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy will adversely affect the countryâ€™s economic growth.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s adversely affected mental health can affect their ability to work.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the adversely affected areas of the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is adversely impacting the old one.â€

Synonyms: Negatively, unfavorably, detrimentally, harmfully.

Opposite words: Positively, favorably, beneficially, advantageously.

Where it comes from: From Latin adversus (turned toward, hostile).

6.20.271. Deliberately#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆlÉªbÉ™rÉ™tli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Consciously and intentionally; on purpose.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdeliberatelyâ€ is to be with careful thought and intention, indicating that an action was not accidental.

What it really means: â€œDeliberatelyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done consciously and intentionally. It suggests that a person is doing something on purpose, not by accident. For example, a person can deliberately break a rule.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done consciously and intentionally.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œdeliberately slow,â€ â€œdeliberately ignore,â€ â€œdeliberately deceive.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe deliberately broke the new rule, so he was punished.â€

      • â€œThe new law was deliberately designed to help the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe new project was deliberately made to be very difficult.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy was deliberately designed to help the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s deliberately bad decisions can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the deliberately caused problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology was deliberately made to be very difficult.â€

Synonyms: Intentionally, on purpose, consciously, knowingly, purposefully.

Opposite words: Accidentally, unintentionally, inadvertently, unknowingly.

Where it comes from: From Latin deliberatus (considered, weighed).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆmÉªsÉªÅ‹/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Not present or included when expected or supposed to be.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œmissingâ€ is to be absent or not in its expected place, indicating a gap or an absence.

What it really means: â€œMissingâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is not present or included when expected or supposed to be. It suggests that a person or a thing is not where it should be. For example, a personâ€™s car can be missing.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is not present or included when expected or supposed to be.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa missing person,â€ â€œa missing piece,â€ â€œa missing link.â€

  • Examples:

      • â€œMy car is missing, so I canâ€™t go to work.â€

      • â€œThe new puzzle has a missing piece, so I canâ€™t finish it.â€

      • â€œThe new report has a lot of missing information, so itâ€™s not very useful.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy has a lot of missing information.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s missing family member can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the missing information in the new system.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the missing information.â€

Synonyms: Absent, lost, gone, unaccounted for, vanished.

Opposite words: Present, found, located, existing.

Where it comes from: From Old English missan (to miss).

6.20.273. Explanation#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉ›ksplÉ™ËˆneÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A statement or account that makes something clear.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œexplanationâ€ is an account or statement that clarifies or provides reasons for a particular event or idea.

What it really means: An â€œexplanationâ€ is a noun that refers to a statement or account that makes something clear. It is the act of making something clear. For example, a person can give an explanation for why they were late.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a statement or account that makes something clear.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œgive an explanation,â€ â€œa clear explanation,â€ â€œa simple explanation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI need a clear explanation for why you were late.â€

      • â€œThe new policy has a lot of confusing parts, so I need a simple explanation.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to give an explanation for the new changes in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy has a lot of confusing parts, so a clear explanation is needed.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s explanation of a new idea can affect their ability to learn.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to give an explanation for the new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to give a clear explanation of how it works.â€

Synonyms: Clarification, elucidation, interpretation, justification, reason.

Opposite words: Confusion, mystery, ambiguity, puzzle.

Where it comes from: From Latin explanare (to make level, to explain).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÉ¡loÊŠbÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: All over the world.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œgloballyâ€ is to be on a worldwide scale or in a comprehensive manner, encompassing the entire planet or a whole system.

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to help the countryâ€™s economy on a globally scale.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is having a globally impact on the world.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the globally problems in the world.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to have a globally impact on the world.â€

Synonyms: Worldwide, internationally, universally, comprehensively.

Opposite words: Locally, regionally, nationally, domestically.

Where it comes from: From Latin globus (sphere).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆtrÉªviÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

What it really means: â€œTrivialâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is of little value or importance. It suggests that something is not worth a lot of attention. For example, a personâ€™s problems can be trivial compared to other peopleâ€™s problems.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is of little value or importance.

    • (Adjective) â€œa trivial matter,â€ â€œa trivial problem,â€ â€œa trivial amount.â€
