6.20.276. Imply#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªmËˆplaÉª/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To suggest something without saying it directly.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œimplyâ€ is to suggest or hint at something indirectly, so that it is understood without being explicitly stated.

What it really means: To â€œimplyâ€ means to suggest something without saying it directly. It is the act of hinting at something. For example, a personâ€™s silence can imply a lot of things.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of suggesting something without saying it directly.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œimply that,â€ â€œimply a lot,â€ â€œimply a lot of things.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI donâ€™t know what he is trying to imply, but I think he is trying to tell me something.â€

      • â€œThe new policy seems to imply that the government is not doing a good job.â€

      • â€œHis silence seems to imply that he is not happy with the new decision.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy seems to imply that the government is not doing a good job.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s body language can imply a lot of things.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the imply problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology seems to imply that the old one is not good enough.â€

Synonyms: Suggest, hint, insinuate, intimate, allude.

Opposite words: State, express, declare, articulate, specify.

Where it comes from: From Latin implicare (to enfold, to involve).

6.20.277. Susceptibility#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™ËŒsÉ›ptÉ™ËˆbÉªlÉªti/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The state or fact of being likely or liable to be influenced or harmed by a particular thing.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsusceptibilityâ€ is the state of being easily influenced, affected, or harmed by something.

What it really means: â€œSusceptibilityâ€ is a noun that refers to the state or fact of being likely or liable to be influenced or harmed by a particular thing. It suggests that a person or a thing is very vulnerable to something. For example, a personâ€™s susceptibility to a new disease can be very high.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the state or fact of being likely or liable to be influenced or harmed by a particular thing.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œsusceptibility to,â€ â€œa high susceptibility,â€ â€œa low susceptibility.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have a high susceptibility to a new disease, so I need to be careful.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to help the country reduce its susceptibility to a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address a personâ€™s susceptibility to a new idea.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to reduce the countryâ€™s susceptibility to a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s susceptibility to a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the susceptibility of the new system to a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to reduce a personâ€™s susceptibility to a new problem.â€

Synonyms: Vulnerability, sensitivity, proneness, liability, weakness.

Opposite words: Resistance, immunity, resilience, insusceptibility.

Where it comes from: From Latin suscipere (to take up).

6.20.278. Ensure#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆÊƒÊŠÉ™r/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To make certain that something will occur or be the case.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œensureâ€ is to make certain that something will happen without fail.

What it really means: To â€œensureâ€ means to make certain that something will occur or be the case. It is the act of making sure that something will happen. For example, a person can ensure that they are on time for a meeting.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of making certain that something will occur or be the case.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œensure that,â€ â€œensure success,â€ â€œensure safety.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI need to ensure that I am on time for my meeting, so I will leave early.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to ensure that everyone is safe.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to ensure that the countryâ€™s economy is stable.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to ensure that the countryâ€™s economy is stable.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to ensure their own safety can affect their long-term health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to ensure the new system is working correctly.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to ensure that the new products are safe.â€

Synonyms: Guarantee, secure, certify, make certain, confirm.

Opposite words: Jeopardize, endanger, risk, imperil.

Where it comes from: From Old French enseurer (to assure, to make safe).

6.20.279. Implementation#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉªmplÉ™mÉ›nËˆteÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The process of putting a decision, plan, or agreement into effect.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œimplementationâ€ is the process of carrying out or putting a plan or decision into action.

What it really means: â€œImplementationâ€ is a noun that refers to the process of putting a decision, plan, or agreement into effect. It is the act of putting something into practice. For example, the implementation of a new policy can take a long time.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the process of putting a decision, plan, or agreement into effect.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œthe implementation of,â€ â€œduring implementation,â€ â€œsuccessful implementation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe implementation of the new policy will take a long time.â€

      • â€œThe new project is in the implementation phase, so we need to work hard.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to help the implementation of the new changes in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the implementation of the new policy will take a long time.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s implementation of a new plan can affect their success.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan for the implementation of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help the implementation of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Execution, application, fulfillment, enactment, realization.

Opposite words: Non-implementation, failure, neglect, inaction.

Where it comes from: From Latin implere (to fill up).

6.20.280. Mandate#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆmÃ¦ndeÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C2

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) An official order or commission to do something; (Verb) To give (someone) a mandate to do something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is an official order or a clear command given by a higher authority. The core meaning of the verb is to officially require or command an action.

What it really means: As a noun, a â€œmandateâ€ is an official order or commission to do something. As a verb, to â€œmandateâ€ means to give someone a mandate to do something.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to an official order, and the verb to describe the act of giving an official order.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa clear mandate,â€ â€œa popular mandate,â€ â€œan electoral mandate.â€

    • (Verb) â€œmandate that,â€ â€œmandate a new policy,â€ â€œmandate a new law.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new law is a mandate from the government, so we have to follow it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy was mandate by the new leader, so we have to follow it.â€

      • â€œThe new project is a mandate from the new company, so we have to do it.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a mandate from the government.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s mandate to do something can affect their motivation.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the mandate of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a mandate from the new company.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Command, order, directive, decree; (Verb) Order, command, require, authorize.

Opposite words: (Noun) Request, suggestion, option; (Verb) Request, suggest, allow.

Where it comes from: From Latin mandatum (a command).

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œgrowthâ€ is the process of increasing in size, development, or importance, signifying a positive change.

    • (Noun) â€œeconomic growth,â€ â€œpersonal growth,â€ â€œa period of growth.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to help the countryâ€™s economic growth.â€

      • â€œThe new project is a great opportunity for my personal growth.â€

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help the countryâ€™s economic growth.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s growth in a new skill can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the growth of a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a growth in the field of medicine.â€

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

      • â€œThe new technology is a reflection of the companyâ€™s ambition to become a new leader.â€

6.20.283. Compulsory#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™mËˆpÊŒlsÉ™ri/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Required by law or a rule; obligatory.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcompulsoryâ€ is to be required by a rule or law, meaning that it is not optional and must be done.

What it really means: â€œCompulsoryâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is required by law or a rule. It suggests that a person has to do something, and they donâ€™t have a choice. For example, school is compulsory for all children.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is required by law or a rule.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œcompulsory education,â€ â€œcompulsory military service,â€ â€œcompulsory voting.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œIn my country, education is compulsory for all children until the age of 16.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to make voting compulsory for all citizens.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is a compulsory measure to address the new problems in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a compulsory measure to address the new problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s compulsory education can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the compulsory nature of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to be a compulsory tool for all employees.â€

Synonyms: Obligatory, mandatory, required, necessary, essential.

Opposite words: Optional, voluntary, elective, non-compulsory.

Where it comes from: From Latin compellere (to drive together, to compel).

6.20.284. Approval#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆpruËvÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action of approving something; formal permission.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œapprovalâ€ is the act of formally agreeing to something, giving permission or consent.

What it really means: â€œApprovalâ€ is a noun that refers to the action of approving something. It is the act of giving formal permission. For example, a person needs to get approval from their boss to take a day off.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the action of approving something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œget approval,â€ â€œa lack of approval,â€ â€œformal approval.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI need to get approval from my boss to take a day off.â€

      • â€œThe new policy has a lot of public approval, so it will be implemented.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to get the publicâ€™s approval.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy has a lot of public approval.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s approval of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to get the approval of the new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to get the publicâ€™s approval.â€

Synonyms: Consent, permission, authorization, sanction, endorsement.

Opposite words: Disapproval, rejection, refusal, veto.

Where it comes from: From Old French aprover (to approve).

6.20.285. Adopt#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆdÉ’pt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To take on or assume (an attitude, policy, or course of action) or to take (a child) as oneâ€™s own.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œadoptâ€ is to formally take something as your own, whether itâ€™s a child, a policy, or a practice.

What it really means: To â€œadoptâ€ means to take on or assume a new policy or course of action. It can also refer to the act of taking a child as oneâ€™s own. For example, a country can adopt a new policy, or a person can adopt a new child.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of taking on or assuming a new policy or course of action, or to the act of taking a child as oneâ€™s own.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œadopt a new policy,â€ â€œadopt a new child,â€ â€œadopt a new plan.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new company is going to adopt a new policy to help its employees.â€

      • â€œThe new couple is going to adopt a new child.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to help people adopt a new way of living.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help the country adopt a new way of living.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s adopt of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to help the country adopt a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help the company adopt a new way of working.â€

Synonyms: Assume, take on, embrace, espouse, choose.

Opposite words: Reject, abandon, discard, renounce, forsake.

Where it comes from: From Latin adoptare (to choose for oneself).

6.20.286. Maintenance#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆmeÉªntÉ™nÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The process of preserving a condition or situation or of keeping something in good repair.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œmaintenanceâ€ is the process of keeping something in proper working order or condition, ensuring it remains functional.

What it really means: â€œMaintenanceâ€ is a noun that refers to the process of preserving a condition or situation or of keeping something in good repair. It is the act of keeping something working properly. For example, a personâ€™s car needs a lot of maintenance.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the process of preserving a condition or situation or of keeping something in good repair.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œcar maintenance,â€ â€œbuilding maintenance,â€ â€œsystem maintenance.â€

  • Examples:

      • â€œMy car needs a lot of maintenance, so itâ€™s very expensive.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to help the maintenance of the countryâ€™s infrastructure.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to help the maintenance of the new system.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help the maintenance of the countryâ€™s infrastructure.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s maintenance of their health can affect their long-term happiness.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan for the maintenance of the new system.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help the maintenance of the new products.â€

Synonyms: Upkeep, preservation, repair, servicing, conservation.

Opposite words: Neglect, deterioration, decay, disrepair.

Where it comes from: From Old French maintenir (to hold in the hand, to maintain).

6.20.287. Compete#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™mËˆpiËt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To strive to gain or win something by defeating or establishing superiority over others who are trying to do the same.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcompeteâ€ is to strive against others to achieve a goal or win a prize, demonstrating a rivalry.

What it really means: To â€œcompeteâ€ means to strive to gain or win something by defeating or establishing superiority over others who are trying to do the same. It is the act of trying to be better than others. For example, a person can compete in a race.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of striving to gain or win something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œcompete with,â€ â€œcompete for,â€ â€œcompete against.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI am going to compete in a race this weekend, and I hope I win.â€

      • â€œThe new company is trying to compete with other companies in the same industry.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to help the countryâ€™s companies compete with other countries.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help the countryâ€™s companies compete with other countries.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to compete can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to help the countryâ€™s companies compete in a new market.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help the company compete with other companies.â€

Synonyms: Contend, rival, vie, challenge, struggle.

Opposite words: Cooperate, collaborate, unite, join.

Where it comes from: From Latin competere (to come together, to be suitable).

6.20.288. Limitation#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒlÉªmÉªËˆteÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A restricting condition or measure.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œlimitationâ€ is a restricting condition or a boundary that constrains or holds something back.

What it really means: â€œLimitationâ€ is a noun that refers to a restricting condition or measure. It suggests that a person or a thing is not allowed to do something or is not allowed to have something. For example, a new law can have a lot of limitations.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a restricting condition or measure.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa limitation on,â€ â€œa major limitation,â€ â€œa legal limitation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new law has a lot of limitations on what you can and canâ€™t do.â€

      • â€œI am under a limitation that I canâ€™t leave the house after 10 PM.â€

      • â€œThe new policy has a lot of limitations on the use of new technology.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a limitation on the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s limitation in a certain area can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the limitation of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to have a number of limitations on its use.â€

Synonyms: Restriction, constraint, boundary, cap, drawback.

Opposite words: Freedom, liberty, advantage, opportunity.

Where it comes from: From Latin limitare (to bound, to limit).

What it really means: â€œHorizonâ€ is a noun that refers to the limit of a personâ€™s knowledge, experience, or interest. It suggests that a person is not aware of something. For example, a person can have a narrow horizon.

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆstÉœËrbÉªÅ‹/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Causing anxiety or worry.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdisturbingâ€ is to be causing feelings of worry, anxiety, or unease, disrupting a sense of calm.

What it really means: â€œDisturbingâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that causes anxiety or worry. It suggests that something is upsetting or unsettling. For example, a new law can be disturbing for a lot of people.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that causes anxiety or worry.

      • â€œThe new technology is very disturbing for a lot of people.â€

Synonyms: Upsetting, unsettling, worrying, alarming, troubling.

Where it comes from: From Latin disturbare (to disturb).

6.20.291. Respectively#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆspÉ›ktÉªvli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Separately or individually in the order already mentioned.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrespectivelyâ€ is to be in a way that corresponds to the order of a list, connecting one list of items to a second list.

What it really means: â€œRespectivelyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done separately or individually in the order already mentioned. It suggests that a person or a thing is related to another person or thing in a certain order. For example, a person can have two jobs, and they are a doctor and a lawyer, respectively.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done separately or individually in the order already mentioned.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œfirst and second, respectively,â€ â€œA and B, respectively,â€ â€œX and Y, respectively.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have two jobs, and I am a doctor and a lawyer, respectively.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to help the countryâ€™s economy and social problems, respectively.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the new problems and old problems, respectively.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help the countryâ€™s economy and social problems, respectively.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s respectively different jobs can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the new problems and old problems, respectively.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help the companyâ€™s new products and old products, respectively.â€

Synonyms: Individually, separately, sequentially.

Opposite words: Collectively, jointly, together.

Where it comes from: From Latin respicere (to look back).

6.20.293. Blind#

  • Pronunciation: /blaÉªnd/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective, Verb

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the adjective is to be unable to see, lacking sight. The core meaning of the verb is to cause someone to lose their sight.

What it really means: As an adjective, â€œblindâ€ describes someone who is unable to see. As a verb, to â€œblindâ€ means to cause someone to lose their sight.

When to use it: Use the adjective to describe a person who is unable to see, and the verb to describe the act of causing someone to lose their sight.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa blind person,â€ â€œblind faith,â€ â€œturn a blind eye.â€

    • (Verb) â€œblind a person,â€ â€œblind with a light.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new law is designed to help blind people in the country.â€

      • â€œHe has a blind faith in the new leader, so he will follow him.â€

      • â€œI will turn a blind eye to what you did this time.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help blind people in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s blind faith can affect their decision-making process.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the blind spots in the new system.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help blind people.â€

Synonyms: (Adj) Sightless, unsighted, unseeing; (Verb) Dazzle, obscure, deprive of sight.

Opposite words: (Adj) Seeing, sighted; (Verb) Enlighten, clarify.

Where it comes from: From Old English blind (blind).

      • â€œHe speaks sparingly, but when he does, he has something important to say.â€

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help people use the countryâ€™s natural resources sparingly.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to sparingly use their money can affect their long-term wealth.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to be used sparingly.â€

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆfroÊŠzÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

6.20.298. Regret#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆÉ¡rÉ›t/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) A feeling of sadness, repentance, or disappointment over something that has happened or been done; (Verb) To feel sad, repentant, or disappointed over something that has happened or been done.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is a feeling of sadness or disappointment about a past event or choice. The core meaning of the verb is to feel sorry or remorseful for a past action.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œregretâ€ is a feeling of sadness, repentance, or disappointment over something that has happened or been done. As a verb, to â€œregretâ€ means to feel sad, repentant, or disappointed over something that has happened or been done.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a feeling of sadness, and the verb to describe the act of feeling sad.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œhave a lot of regret,â€ â€œa sense of regret,â€ â€œno regrets.â€

    • (Verb) â€œregret doing something,â€ â€œregret a decision,â€ â€œregret a mistake.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have a lot of regret for not studying for my exam, so I failed it.â€

      • â€œI regret my decision to buy the new car, because it is very expensive.â€

      • â€œI have no regrets for what I did, because I did what I thought was right.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a source of regret for a lot of people.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s regret for a past decision can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the regret of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a source of regret for a lot of people.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Remorse, sorrow, repentance, disappointment; (Verb) Lament, mourn, repent, rue.

Opposite words: (Noun) Satisfaction, contentment, joy; (Verb) Be happy with, be glad about.

Where it comes from: From Old French regreter (to bewail).

6.20.299. Disqualify#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªsËˆkwÉ’lÉªfaÉª/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To officially declare (someone) ineligible to participate in an activity or competition.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdisqualifyâ€ is to officially declare someone as ineligible or unfit for a competition or position, removing their right to participate.

What it really means: To â€œdisqualifyâ€ means to officially declare someone ineligible to participate in an activity or competition. It is the act of removing a personâ€™s right to participate. For example, a person can be disqualified from a race if they cheat.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of officially declaring someone ineligible to participate in an activity or competition.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œdisqualify from,â€ â€œdisqualify for,â€ â€œdisqualify a person.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe was disqualified from the race because he cheated.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to disqualify a person from a new job if they have a criminal record.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to disqualify a person from a new program.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to disqualify a person from a new program.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s disqualify from a new job can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the disqualify of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to disqualify a person from a new program.â€

Synonyms: Eliminate, bar, exclude, ban, ineligible.

Opposite words: Qualify, enable, allow, permit, authorize.

Where it comes from: From Latin dis (apart) and qualis (of what kind).

6.20.300. Irregular#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªËˆrÉ›É¡jÉ™lÉ™r/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Not regular in shape, arrangement, or pattern.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œirregularâ€ is lacking a consistent or predictable pattern, shape, or schedule, deviating from what is normal or expected.

What it really means: â€œIrregularâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is not regular in shape, arrangement, or pattern. It suggests that something is not consistent or predictable. For example, a person can have an irregular heartbeat, or a new building can have an irregular shape.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is not regular in shape, arrangement, or pattern.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œirregular heartbeat,â€ â€œirregular shape,â€ â€œirregular schedule.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œMy heartbeat is irregular, so I need to see a doctor.â€

      • â€œThe new building has an irregular shape, so it is very unique.â€

      • â€œI have an irregular schedule, so I canâ€™t plan a lot of things.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is an irregular one, and it is not consistent with the old one.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s irregular heartbeat can affect their health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the irregular problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the irregular problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: Uneven, inconsistent, asymmetrical, abnormal, erratic.

Opposite words: Regular, consistent, even, symmetrical, normal.

Where it comes from: From Latin in- (not) and regula (rule).

6.20.301. Transformation#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒtrÃ¦nsfÉ™ËˆmeÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A marked change in form, nature, or appearance.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œtransformationâ€ is a complete and significant change in form, character, or function, often leading to an improved state.

What it really means: â€œTransformationâ€ is a noun that refers to a marked change in form, nature, or appearance. It suggests that a person or a thing has changed completely. For example, a new project can lead to a transformation of a company, or a new law can lead to a transformation of a country.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a marked change in form, nature, or appearance.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa complete transformation,â€ â€œa dramatic transformation,â€ â€œa personal transformation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new project led to a complete transformation of the company, and it is now a market leader.â€

      • â€œHe had a personal transformation after he started to exercise and eat healthy.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to lead to a transformation of the countryâ€™s economy.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to lead to a transformation of the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s transformation of their life can affect their happiness.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the transformation of a new system.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a transformation of the old one.â€

Synonyms: Change, alteration, conversion, metamorphosis, evolution.

Opposite words: Stagnation, continuation, stability, permanence.

Where it comes from: From Latin transformare (to change in shape).

6.20.302. Essential#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªËˆsÉ›nÊƒÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Absolutely necessary.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œessentialâ€ is to be absolutely necessary or fundamental to the existence or success of something.

What it really means: â€œEssentialâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is absolutely necessary. It suggests that a person or a thing cannot do without something. For example, food and water are essential for survival.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is absolutely necessary.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œessential for,â€ â€œessential to,â€ â€œessential ingredient.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œFood and water are essential for survival.â€

      • â€œA good education is essential for a successful career.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the essential needs of the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the essential needs of the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s essential skills can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the essential problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is an essential tool for all employees.â€

Synonyms: Vital, crucial, necessary, fundamental, indispensable.

Opposite words: Unnecessary, nonessential, optional, superfluous, trivial.

Where it comes from: From Latin essentia (being, essence).

6.20.303. Memorial#

  • Pronunciation: /mÉ™ËˆmÉ”ËriÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun, Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) A statue, building, or other structure established to remind people of a person or event; (Adj) Serving as a memorial.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is an object or a ceremony that serves as a reminder of a person, event, or group, preserving their memory. The core meaning of the adjective is to be intended to commemorate.

What it really means: As a noun, a â€œmemorialâ€ is a statue, building, or other structure established to remind people of a person or event. As an adjective, â€œmemorialâ€ means serving as a memorial. For example, a new park can be a memorial to a great leader.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a statue, building, or other structure established to remind people of a person or event. Use the adjective to describe something that serves as a memorial.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa war memorial,â€ â€œa public memorial,â€ â€œa memorial service.â€

    • (Adjective) â€œmemorial plaque,â€ â€œmemorial stone.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new park is a memorial to a great leader, so it is a very important place.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to create a memorial to the new heroes in the country.â€

      • â€œI am going to attend the memorial service for my grandfather.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to create a memorial to the new heroes in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s memorial to a lost loved one can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to create a memorial to a new event.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a memorial to the old one.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Monument, commemoration, remembrance, tribute; (Adj) Commemorative, dedicatory.

Opposite words: (Noun) Oblivion, forgetfulness.

Where it comes from: From Latin memorialis (relating to memory).

6.20.304. Distinct#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆstÉªÅ‹kt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Clearly different or separate.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdistinctâ€ is to be clearly different from something else, making it easily identifiable or noticeable.

What it really means: â€œDistinctâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is clearly different or separate. It suggests that a person or a thing is very unique. For example, a new building can have a distinct design, or a new country can have a distinct culture.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is clearly different or separate.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa distinct difference,â€ â€œa distinct design,â€ â€œa distinct culture.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new building has a distinct design, so it is very unique.â€

      • â€œThe new country has a distinct culture, so it is very interesting.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to have a distinct impact on the countryâ€™s economy.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to have a distinct impact on the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s distinct personality can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the distinct problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology has a distinct design, so it is very unique.â€

Synonyms: Separate, different, unique, individual, specific.

Opposite words: Indistinct, similar, same, identical, ambiguous.

Where it comes from: From Latin distinguere (to separate, to distinguish).

6.20.305. Opposition#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉ’pÉ™ËˆzÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A resistance or dissent expressed in action or argument.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œoppositionâ€ is the act of resisting, disagreeing with, or standing against something, often in a political or social context.

What it really means: â€œOppositionâ€ is a noun that refers to a resistance or dissent expressed in action or argument. It suggests that a person or a thing is against something. For example, a new law can face a lot of opposition from the public.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a resistance or dissent expressed in action or argument.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œstrong opposition,â€ â€œin opposition to,â€ â€œthe political opposition.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new law faced a lot of opposition from the public, so it was not implemented.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is in opposition to the old one, so it will not be implemented.â€

      • â€œThe new leader has a lot of opposition from the political parties.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is in opposition to the old one.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s opposition to a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the opposition of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is facing a lot of opposition from the old one.â€

Synonyms: Resistance, disagreement, conflict, defiance, protest.

Opposite words: Agreement, support, acceptance, approval, harmony.

Where it comes from: From Latin opponere (to set against).

6.20.306. Differentiate#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒdÉªfÉ™ËˆrÉ›nÊƒieÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To recognize or ascertain what makes (someone or something) different.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdifferentiateâ€ is to recognize or show the difference between two or more things, making them distinct from one another.

What it really means: To â€œdifferentiateâ€ means to recognize or ascertain what makes someone or something different. It is the act of telling the difference between two things. For example, it can be hard to differentiate between two very similar products.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of recognizing or ascertaining what makes someone or something different.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œdifferentiate between,â€ â€œdifferentiate from,â€ â€œdifferentiate a product.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI canâ€™t differentiate between the two products, so I donâ€™t know which one to buy.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to differentiate between a good and a bad behavior.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to differentiate between a good and a bad country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to differentiate between a good and a bad behavior.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to differentiate between two ideas can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to differentiate between a new and an old problem.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to differentiate between a new and an old product.â€

Synonyms: Distinguish, contrast, separate, discriminate, discern.

Opposite words: Confuse, mix up, equate, unify, homogenize.

Where it comes from: From Latin differre (to carry apart, to differ).

6.20.307. Command#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™ËˆmÉ‘Ënd/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To give an authoritative order; (Noun) An authoritative order.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the verb is to give an authoritative order or to be in charge of something. The core meaning of the noun is an authoritative instruction or a position of control.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œcommandâ€ means to give an authoritative order. As a noun, a â€œcommandâ€ is an authoritative order. For example, a leader can command their soldiers to attack, or a new law can be a command from the government.

When to use it: Use the verb to refer to the act of giving an authoritative order, and the noun to refer to an authoritative order.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œcommand a person,â€ â€œcommand a group,â€ â€œcommand an order.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa direct command,â€ â€œa clear command,â€ â€œunder my command.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe leader command the soldiers to attack, and they did it.â€

      • â€œThe new law is a command from the government, so we have to follow it.â€

      • â€œI am in command of this project, so you have to listen to me.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a command from the government.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to command a group can affect their leadership skills.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the command of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a command from the new company.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Order, instruct, direct, mandate; (Noun) Order, directive, decree, instruction.

Opposite words: (Verb) Plead, beg, request; (Noun) Request, plea, entreaty.

Where it comes from: From Latin commandare (to commit, to entrust).

6.20.308. Casually#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkÃ¦Ê’ÊŠÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a relaxed and informal way.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcasuallyâ€ is to be in a relaxed, informal, or unplanned manner, without much thought or formality.

What it really means: â€œCasuallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a relaxed and informal way. It suggests that a person is not taking something too seriously. For example, a person can be casually dressed, or a person can talk casually about a new topic.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a relaxed and informal way.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œdressed casually,â€ â€œtalk casually,â€ â€œwalk casually.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI am dressed casually today because I am not going to work.â€

      • â€œWe talked casually about the new project, and we came up with a great idea.â€

      • â€œHe walked casually into the room, and he didnâ€™t seem to be worried.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is not a formal one, but a casually implemented one.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s casually approach to a new problem can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the casually problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to be used casually by all employees.â€

Synonyms: Informally, relaxedly, unceremoniously, nonchalantly.

Opposite words: Formally, seriously, stiffly, ceremoniously.

Where it comes from: From Latin casualis (relating to a chance).

6.20.309. Hesitation#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒhÉ›zÉªËˆteÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action of pausing before saying or doing something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œhesitationâ€ is the act of pausing or being reluctant before acting or speaking, often due to uncertainty or doubt.

What it really means: â€œHesitationâ€ is a noun that refers to the action of pausing before saying or doing something. It suggests that a person is not sure about something. For example, a person can have a lot of hesitation before they make a big decision.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the action of pausing before saying or doing something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa momentâ€™s hesitation,â€ â€œwithout hesitation,â€ â€œno hesitation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI had a momentâ€™s hesitation before I made the big decision, but I am happy with it now.â€

      • â€œThe new law was implemented without any hesitation from the government.â€

      • â€œHe answered the question without any hesitation, so he knew the answer.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy was implemented without any hesitation from the government.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s hesitation can affect their decision-making process.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the hesitation of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology was implemented without any hesitation from the new company.â€

Synonyms: Doubt, uncertainty, reluctance, indecision, pause.

Opposite words: Certainty, decisiveness, confidence, resolve, promptness.

Where it comes from: From Latin haesitare (to stick fast, to hesitate).

6.20.310. Violation#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒvaÉªÉ™ËˆleÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action of violating something; an act of disrespect or disrespect.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œviolationâ€ is the act of breaking or failing to comply with a law, rule, or agreement.

What it really means: â€œViolationâ€ is a noun that refers to the action of violating something. It suggests that a person has done something that is against the law or a rule. For example, a person can be punished for a violation of the law.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the action of violating something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa serious violation,â€ â€œin violation of,â€ â€œa violation of human rights.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe was punished for a violation of the law, so he went to jail.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is a violation of human rights, so it should not be implemented.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the violation of the old law.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a violation of human rights.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s violation of a new rule can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the violation of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a violation of the old one.â€

Synonyms: Breach, infringement, contravention, transgression, trespass.

Opposite words: Compliance, adherence, observance, respect, obedience.

Where it comes from: From Latin violare (to treat with violence, to injure).

6.20.311. Complaint#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™mËˆpleÉªnt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A statement that something is unsatisfactory or unacceptable.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcomplaintâ€ is an expression of dissatisfaction, unhappiness, or grievance about something.

What it really means: A â€œcomplaintâ€ is a noun that refers to a statement that something is unsatisfactory or unacceptable. It is the act of expressing dissatisfaction. For example, a person can make a complaint about a new product.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a statement that something is unsatisfactory or unacceptable.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œmake a complaint,â€ â€œa formal complaint,â€ â€œa lot of complaints.â€

  • Examples:

      • â€œI have a lot of complaints about the new product, so I am going to return it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the complaints of the public.â€

      • â€œThe new law is a result of a lot of complaints from the public.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the complaints of the public.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s complaints about a new job can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the complaints of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a result of a lot of complaints from the old one.â€

Synonyms: Grievance, protest, objection, grumbling, dissatisfaction.

Opposite words: Praise, compliment, approval, satisfaction.

Where it comes from: From Old French compleinte (lamentation).

6.20.312. Boost#

  • Pronunciation: /buËst/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To help or encourage (something) to increase or improve; (Noun) A source of help or encouragement.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the verb is to help or encourage something to increase or improve, giving it a lift. The core meaning of the noun is a source of help or encouragement that leads to an increase or improvement.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œboostâ€ means to help or encourage something to increase or improve. As a noun, a â€œboostâ€ is a source of help or encouragement. For example, a new policy can boost a countryâ€™s economy, or a new project can give a company a boost.

When to use it: Use the verb to refer to the act of helping or encouraging something to increase or improve, and the noun to refer to a source of help or encouragement.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œboost the economy,â€ â€œboost morale,â€ â€œboost a career.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa boost to morale,â€ â€œa confidence boost.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to boost the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œI am going to buy a new car to give myself a boost.â€

      • â€œThe new project is a boost to the companyâ€™s morale.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to boost the countryâ€™s economy.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to boost their morale can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to give a boost to a new project.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to give a boost to the companyâ€™s productivity.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Increase, enhance, raise, promote, stimulate; (Noun) Increase, lift, stimulus, improvement.

Opposite words: (Verb) Decrease, lower, hinder, depress; (Noun) Decrease, setback, obstacle, detriment.

Where it comes from: From Middle English boste (to boast).

6.20.313. Precisely#

  • Pronunciation: /prÉªËˆsaÉªsli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a precise manner; exactly.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpreciselyâ€ is to be in an exact, accurate, or careful manner, leaving no room for error or ambiguity.

What it really means: â€œPreciselyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a precise manner. It suggests that a person is doing something exactly as it should be done. For example, a person can measure something precisely.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a precise manner.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œmeasure precisely,â€ â€œexplain precisely,â€ â€œstate precisely.â€

      • â€œI need to measure the ingredients precisely to make the new cake.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the new problems precisely.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the new problems precisely.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to measure things precisely.â€

Synonyms: Exactly, accurately, correctly, specifically, explicitly.

Opposite words: Imprecisely, vaguely, loosely, roughly, generally.

Where it comes from: From Latin praecidere (to cut off).

6.20.314. Violate#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆvaÉªÉ™leÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To break or fail to comply with (a rule or formal agreement).

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œviolateâ€ is to break or fail to comply with a law, rule, or agreement, often in a way that is disrespectful or harmful.

What it really means: To â€œviolateâ€ means to break or fail to comply with a rule or formal agreement. It is the act of doing something that is against the law or a rule. For example, a person can violate the law if they speed.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of breaking or failing to comply with a rule or formal agreement.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œviolate the law,â€ â€œviolate a rule,â€ â€œviolate a contract.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe will violate the law if he speeds, so he should not do it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to prevent people from violating the new rules.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to punish people who violate the old law.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to prevent people from violating the new rules.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s violate of a new rule can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the violate of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to prevent people from violating the new rules.â€

Synonyms: Break, infringe, breach, transgress, disobey.

Opposite words: Obey, comply, follow, honor, respect.

Where it comes from: From Latin violare (to treat with violence, to injure).

6.20.315. Prospect#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆprÉ’spÉ›kt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The possibility or likelihood of some future event occurring.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œprospectâ€ is a future possibility, an expectation, or a potential outcome, often with a sense of hope or anticipation.

What it really means: â€œProspectâ€ is a noun that refers to the possibility or likelihood of some future event occurring. It suggests that a person or a thing has a good chance of doing something. For example, a new company can have a good prospect of success.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the possibility or likelihood of some future event occurring.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa good prospect,â€ â€œthe prospect of,â€ â€œa future prospect.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new company has a good prospect of success, so I am going to invest in it.â€

      • â€œThe prospect of a new job is very exciting, so I am very happy.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to improve the prospects of a new country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to improve the prospects of a new country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s prospect of a new career can affect their motivation.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to improve the prospects of a new project.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a good prospect for the companyâ€™s future.â€

Synonyms: Possibility, potential, chance, outlook, future.

Opposite words: Impossibility, unlikelihood, hopelessness, certainty (in some contexts).

Where it comes from: From Latin prospectus (view, outlook).

6.20.316. Elimination#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªËŒlÉªmÉªËˆneÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The complete removal or destruction of something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œeliminationâ€ is the process of getting rid of something completely or removing it from a group or system.

What it really means: â€œEliminationâ€ is a noun that refers to the complete removal or destruction of something. It is the act of getting rid of something. For example, the elimination of a disease can be a great achievement.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the complete removal or destruction of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œthe elimination of,â€ â€œa process of elimination,â€ â€œcomplete elimination.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe elimination of the new disease is a great achievement for the country.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to help the elimination of a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the elimination of the old law.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help the elimination of a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s elimination of a bad habit can affect their health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the elimination of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help the elimination of a new problem.â€

Synonyms: Removal, eradication, destruction, obliteration, termination.

Opposite words: Introduction, creation, establishment, inclusion, addition.

Where it comes from: From Latin eliminare (to put out of the threshold).

6.20.317. Abuse#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆbjuËs/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) The improper use of something; (Verb) To use something improperly.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is the improper or harmful use of something or the mistreatment of a person. The core meaning of the verb is to use something improperly or to mistreat someone.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œabuseâ€ is the improper use of something. As a verb, to â€œabuseâ€ means to use something improperly. It can also refer to the act of treating a person badly. For example, a person can abuse their power, or a person can be a victim of abuse.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to the improper use of something. Use the verb to refer to the act of using something improperly.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œpower abuse,â€ â€œsubstance abuse,â€ â€œchild abuse.â€

    • (Verb) â€œabuse power,â€ â€œabuse a person,â€ â€œabuse a privilege.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new law is designed to prevent the abuse of power.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the abuse of new technology.â€

      • â€œHe was a victim of abuse, so he needs a lot of help.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to prevent the abuse of power.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s abuse of a new privilege can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the abuse of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to prevent the abuse of new information.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Misuse, mistreatment, exploitation, harm; (Verb) Misuse, mistreat, harm, violate.

Opposite words: (Noun) Proper use, care, protection; (Verb) Use properly, protect, care for.

Where it comes from: From Latin abusus (misuse).

6.20.318. Consistently#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™nËˆsÉªstÉ™ntli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In every case or on every occasion; invariably.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œconsistentlyâ€ is to be in a way that is unchanging or reliable over time, always acting in the same manner.

What it really means: â€œConsistentlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in every case or on every occasion. It suggests that a person or a thing is very reliable and predictable. For example, a person can consistently get a good grade on an exam.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in every case or on every occasion.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œconsistently good,â€ â€œconsistently bad,â€ â€œconsistently high.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe consistently gets a good grade on an exam, so he is a very smart student.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is consistently good, so it will be implemented.â€

      • â€œThe new law is consistently bad, so it will be changed.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is consistently good, and it will have a lot of positive effects.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s consistently good attitude can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the consistently bad problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is consistently good, so it will be widely used.â€

Synonyms: Always, invariably, constantly, steadily, reliably.

Opposite words: Inconsistently, erratically, sporadically, unreliably.

Where it comes from: From Latin consistere (to stand together, to be firm).

6.20.319. Rejection#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆdÊ’É›kÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The act of rejecting; a refusal to accept or consider.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrejectionâ€ is the act of refusing to accept, approve, or consider something, a dismissal.

What it really means: â€œRejectionâ€ is a noun that refers to the act of rejecting something. It is a refusal to accept or consider something. For example, a person can get a rejection letter from a new job.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of rejecting something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œface rejection,â€ â€œa letter of rejection,â€ â€œa feeling of rejection.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI got a rejection letter from the new job, so I am very sad.â€

      • â€œThe new policy faced a lot of rejection from the public, so it was not implemented.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to prevent the rejection of new ideas.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy faced a lot of rejection from the public.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s rejection from a new job can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the rejection of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is facing a lot of rejection from the old one.â€

Synonyms: Refusal, dismissal, denial, refusal, repudiation.

Opposite words: Acceptance, approval, welcome, adoption, consideration.

Where it comes from: From Latin reicere (to throw back).

6.20.320. Resolve#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆzÉ’lv/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To settle or find a solution to (a problem, dispute, or contentious matter); (Noun) Firm determination to do something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the verb is to find a solution to a problem or to make a firm decision. The core meaning of the noun is firm determination or a strong intention.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œresolveâ€ means to settle or find a solution to a problem. As a noun, â€œresolveâ€ is firm determination to do something. For example, a person can resolve a problem, or a person can have a strong resolve to succeed.

When to use it: Use the verb to refer to the act of settling or finding a solution to a problem, and the noun to refer to firm determination.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œresolve a problem,â€ â€œresolve a dispute,â€ â€œresolve an issue.â€

    • (Noun) â€œfirm resolve,â€ â€œa lack of resolve.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI need to resolve this problem before the deadline.â€

      • â€œI have a strong resolve to succeed, so I will not give up.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to resolve the new problems in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to resolve the new problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s resolve can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to resolve a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to resolve the new problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Solve, settle, fix, determine, decide; (Noun) Determination, willpower, firmness, conviction, purpose.

Opposite words: (Verb) Aggravate, complicate, ignore; (Noun) Indecision, hesitation, weakness, vacillation.

Where it comes from: From Latin resolvere (to loosen, to undo).

6.20.321. Intensely#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆtÉ›nsli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: With extreme force or severity.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œintenselyâ€ is to be in a concentrated, powerful, or extreme manner, with great force or feeling.

What it really means: â€œIntenselyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done with extreme force or severity. It suggests that a person is doing something with a lot of passion and emotion. For example, a person can intensely focus on a new project.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done with extreme force or severity.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œintensely focused,â€ â€œintensely bright,â€ â€œintensely cold.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI am intensely focused on this new project, so I will not be distracted.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is intensely debated, so it is a very important topic.â€

      • â€œThe new law is intensely discussed, so it will have a big impact.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is intensely debated, and it will have a lot of positive and negative effects.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s intensely focused approach to a new problem can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the intensely discussed problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is intensely bright, so it is very powerful.â€

Synonyms: Fiercely, powerfully, extremely, severely, deeply.

Opposite words: Mildly, gently, lightly, moderately, faintly.

Where it comes from: From Latin intendere (to stretch out, to aim at).

6.20.322. Mystery#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆmÉªstÉ™ri/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: Something that is difficult or impossible to understand or explain.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œmysteryâ€ is something that is unexplained, puzzling, or secret, a situation or event whose cause is not known.

What it really means: A â€œmysteryâ€ is a noun that refers to something that is difficult or impossible to understand or explain. It suggests that something is a puzzle and a person does not know the answer. For example, the mystery of the universe is very interesting.

When to use it: Use it to refer to something that is difficult or impossible to understand or explain.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa complete mystery,â€ â€œsolve a mystery,â€ â€œthe mystery of.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe mystery of the new problem is very interesting, so I want to solve it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is a mystery to a lot of people, so they donâ€™t know what to do.â€

      • â€œThe new law is a mystery to the public, so they are not happy about it.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a mystery to a lot of people.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s mystery about a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the mystery of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a mystery to a lot of people.â€

Synonyms: Puzzle, enigma, riddle, conundrum, secret.

Opposite words: Explanation, solution, clarity, certainty, fact.

Where it comes from: From Latin mysterium (a secret rite or doctrine).

6.20.323. Substance#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆsÊŒbstÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A particular kind of matter with uniform properties.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsubstanceâ€ is a type of matter or a physical material. It can also refer to the most important or essential part of something.

What it really means: â€œSubstanceâ€ is a noun that refers to a particular kind of matter with uniform properties. It can also refer to the most important part of something. For example, a new product can have a new substance, or a new report can have a lot of substance.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a particular kind of matter with uniform properties, or to the most important part of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa harmful substance,â€ â€œthe substance of an argument,â€ â€œthe substance of the matter.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new product has a new substance, and it is very good for your health.â€

      • â€œThe new report has a lot of substance, so it is very useful.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the substance of the new problem.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the substance of the new problem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s substance use can affect their health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the substance of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a new substance that can be used to make new products.â€

Synonyms: Material, matter, essence, core, gist, significance.

Opposite words: Insignificance, triviality, triviality.

Where it comes from: From Latin substantia (being, essence).

6.20.324. Recovery#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆkÊŒvÉ™ri/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A return to a normal state of health, mind, or strength.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrecoveryâ€ is the process of returning to a normal or healthy state after an illness, injury, or difficult period.

What it really means: â€œRecoveryâ€ is a noun that refers to a return to a normal state of health, mind, or strength. It is the act of getting better after a problem. For example, a person can have a quick recovery after a new disease.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a return to a normal state of health, mind, or strength.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa quick recovery,â€ â€œa full recovery,â€ â€œa long recovery.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI had a quick recovery after the new disease, so I am very happy.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to help the countryâ€™s economic recovery.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to help a personâ€™s recovery after a new problem.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help the countryâ€™s economic recovery.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s recovery from a new problem can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the recovery of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help a personâ€™s recovery after a new problem.â€

Synonyms: Restoration, healing, rehabilitation, revival, recuperation.

Opposite words: Decline, deterioration, setback, relapse.

Where it comes from: From Old French recovrer (to recover).

6.20.325. Subscription#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™bËˆskrÉªpÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: An amount of money that you pay regularly to receive a service, product, or membership.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsubscriptionâ€ is a regular payment made to receive a product, service, or membership for a set period.

What it really means: A â€œsubscriptionâ€ is a noun that refers to an amount of money that you pay regularly to receive a service, product, or membership. It is the act of paying for something on a regular basis. For example, a person can have a subscription to a new magazine.

When to use it: Use it to refer to an amount of money that you pay regularly to receive a service, product, or membership.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa monthly subscription,â€ â€œa yearly subscription,â€ â€œa subscription service.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have a monthly subscription to the new magazine, so I get it every month.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to help people get a subscription to a new service.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the subscription of a new product.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to help people get a subscription to a new service.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s subscription to a new magazine can affect their knowledge.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the subscription of a new product.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a subscription service.â€

Synonyms: Membership, fee, contribution, payment, enrollment.

Opposite words: Cancellation, unsubscribing, termination.

Where it comes from: From Latin subscribere (to write underneath, to subscribe).

6.20.326. Immensely#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªËˆmÉ›nsli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: To a great extent; extremely.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œimmenselyâ€ is to be to a great degree, extremely, or hugely, often used to emphasize a quality or quantity.

What it really means: â€œImmenselyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done to a great extent. It suggests that a person or a thing is very big or very important. For example, a new project can be immensely successful.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done to a great extent.

      • â€œThe new technology is immensely popular, so it will be widely used.â€

Synonyms: Extremely, hugely, greatly, vastly, enormously.

Opposite words: Slightly, barely, insignificantly, negligibly.

Where it comes from: From Latin immensus (immeasurable).

6.20.327. Thrown#

  • Pronunciation: /Î¸roÊŠn/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To propel with force through the air by a movement of the arm and hand.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œthrownâ€ is the past participle of â€˜throwâ€™, meaning to have propelled something through the air with force. It can also mean to have been put into a state or situation.

What it really means: â€œThrownâ€ is the past participle of the verb â€œthrowâ€. It is the act of propelling something with force through the air. For example, a person can have thrown a ball.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of propelling something with force through the air.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œthrown a ball,â€ â€œthrown a party,â€ â€œthrown into a situation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have thrown the ball to my dog, and he caught it.â€

      • â€œI was thrown into a new situation, and I didnâ€™t know what to do.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who have been thrown into poverty.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who have been thrown into poverty.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s thrown into a new job can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the thrown into a new situation.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help the people who have been thrown into a new world.â€
