      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to make the public admire a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a work of art that people can admire.â€

Synonyms: Respect, approve, praise, look up to, esteem.

Opposite words: Despise, dislike, hate, scorn, look down on.

Where it comes from: From Latin admirari (to wonder at).

6.20.380. Temporarily#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆtÉ›mpÉ™rÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: For a limited period of time; not permanently.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œtemporarilyâ€ is to be for a short or limited time, not in a lasting or permanent way.

What it really means: â€œTemporarilyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done for a limited period of time. It suggests that a person or a thing will not last forever. For example, a new store can be closed temporarily.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done for a limited period of time.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œtemporarily closed,â€ â€œtemporarily unavailable,â€ â€œtemporarily out of order.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new store is temporarily closed, so I canâ€™t buy a new product.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to be temporarily implemented.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to be temporarily in effect.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to be temporarily implemented.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s temporarily job can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the temporarily problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is temporarily unavailable.â€

Synonyms: Briefly, for a while, provisionally, for the time being.

Opposite words: Permanently, perpetually, forever, enduringly.

Where it comes from: From Latin tempus (time).

6.20.381. Severe#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉªËˆvÉªÉ™r/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: (Of something bad or undesirable) very great; intense.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsevereâ€ is to be very great, intense, or strict, often used to describe something unpleasant or negative.

What it really means: â€œSevereâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is very great or intense. It suggests that something is very bad. For example, a person can have a severe headache.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is very great or intense.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa severe headache,â€ â€œa severe punishment,â€ â€œa severe storm.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have a severe headache, so I need to go to the doctor.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the severe problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is a severe one, so it will have a big impact.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the severe problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s severe problem can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the severe problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the severe problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: Harsh, strict, intense, serious, critical.

Opposite words: Mild, gentle, lenient, light, moderate.

Where it comes from: From Latin severus (serious, strict).

6.20.382. Especially#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªËˆspÉ›ÊƒÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: To a great extent; more than usual.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œespeciallyâ€ is to be particularly or more than is usual, highlighting a specific instance or quality.

What it really means: â€œEspeciallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done to a great extent. It suggests that something is more important than something else. For example, a person can like a new movie, especially the ending.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done to a great extent.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œespecially good,â€ â€œespecially important,â€ â€œespecially difficult.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI like the new movie, especially the ending, so it is a good one.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is especially important, so it will have a big impact.â€

      • â€œThe new law is especially difficult to understand.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is especially important.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s especially good attitude can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the especially difficult problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is especially useful.â€

Synonyms: Particularly, notably, exceptionally, mainly, primarily.

Opposite words: Generally, ordinarily, commonly, normally.

Where it comes from: From Old French especial (special).

6.20.383. Rapidly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆrÃ¦pÉªdli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Very quickly; at a great rate.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrapidlyâ€ is to be happening at a great speed or rate, indicating a fast pace of change or movement.

What it really means: â€œRapidlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done very quickly. It suggests that a person or a thing is moving very fast. For example, a new company can grow rapidly.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done very quickly.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œgrow rapidly,â€ â€œchange rapidly,â€ â€œspread rapidly.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new company is growing rapidly, so it is a very successful one.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the rapidly changing problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the rapidly growing problems.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the rapidly changing problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s rapidly changing career can affect their motivation.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the rapidly growing problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is changing rapidly.â€

Synonyms: Quickly, swiftly, speedily, fast, promptly.

Opposite words: Slowly, leisurely, gradually, steadily.

Where it comes from: From Latin rapiditas (swiftness).

6.20.384. Instinctively#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆstÉªÅ‹ktÉªvli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Without conscious thought; by natural instinct.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œinstinctivelyâ€ is to be acting on a natural impulse or innate drive, without deliberate thought or planning.

What it really means: â€œInstinctivelyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done without conscious thought. It suggests that a person is doing something naturally. For example, a person can instinctively protect their child.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done without conscious thought.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œreact instinctively,â€ â€œknow instinctively,â€ â€œact instinctively.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe instinctively protected his child, so he is a good father.â€

      • â€œI instinctively knew that the new policy was not a good one.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who act instinctively.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who act instinctively.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s instinctively decision can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the instinctively problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people who act instinctively.â€

Synonyms: Naturally, intuitively, automatically, spontaneously, without thinking.

Opposite words: Consciously, deliberately, intentionally, thoughtfully, rationally.

Where it comes from: From Latin instinctus (instigation).

6.20.385. Distortion#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆstÉ”ËrÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action of distorting or the state of being distorted.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdistortionâ€ is the action of twisting or changing something from its original or true shape, meaning, or state, often in a way that makes it inaccurate.

What it really means: â€œDistortionâ€ is a noun that refers to the action of distorting or the state of being distorted. It suggests that something is not in its original shape or state. For example, a new image can have a distortion in it.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the action of distorting or the state of being distorted.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa distortion of the truth,â€ â€œa sound distortion,â€ â€œa visual distortion.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new image has a distortion in it, so I canâ€™t use it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is a distortion of the old one, so it will not work.â€

      • â€œThe new law is a distortion of the truth, so it will not be implemented.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a distortion of the old one.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s distortion of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the distortion of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to fix the distortion of a new sound.â€

Synonyms: Twist, perversion, misrepresentation, alteration, corruption.

Opposite words: Clarity, accuracy, fidelity, truth, precision.

Where it comes from: From Latin distorquere (to twist).

6.20.386. Restrict#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆstrÉªkt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To put a limit on; keep under control.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrestrictâ€ is to limit, confine, or keep something within certain bounds, preventing its free movement or growth.

What it really means: To â€œrestrictâ€ means to put a limit on or keep something under control. It is the act of limiting something. For example, a new law can restrict a personâ€™s freedom.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of putting a limit on or keeping something under control.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œrestrict a personâ€™s freedom,â€ â€œrestrict access to,â€ â€œrestrict the number of.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new law is designed to restrict a personâ€™s freedom, so it is a bad one.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to restrict the number of people who can enter the new building.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to restrict the amount of money that a person can spend.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to restrict the number of people who can enter the new building.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s restriction of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to restrict the new problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to restrict the access to new information.â€

Synonyms: Limit, confine, constrain, curb, regulate.

Opposite words: Allow, permit, free, open, expand.

Where it comes from: From Latin restringere (to bind back).

6.20.387. Spread#

  • Pronunciation: /sprÉ›d/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To open out (something) so that it covers a larger area; (Noun) The extent, width, or area of something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the verb is to extend over a larger area, causing something to be distributed widely. The core meaning of the noun is the extent or range of something.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œspreadâ€ means to open out something so that it covers a larger area. As a noun, â€œspreadâ€ is the extent, width, or area of something. For example, a new disease can spread very fast.

When to use it: Use the verb to refer to the act of opening out something so that it covers a larger area, and the noun to refer to the extent, width, or area of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œspread a rumor,â€ â€œspread a disease,â€ â€œspread a blanket.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa wide spread,â€ â€œthe spread of a disease.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new disease is spreading very fast, so we need to be careful.â€

      • â€œI need to spread the new blanket on the bed.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to prevent the spread of a new disease.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to prevent the spread of a new disease.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s spread of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the spread of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to prevent the spread of a new problem.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Disperse, scatter, expand, propagate; (Noun) Extension, range, diffusion, breadth.

Opposite words: (Verb) Contract, shrink, gather, contain; (Noun) Concentration, containment, reduction.

Where it comes from: From Old English sprÃ¦dan (to spread).

6.20.388. Durability#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒdjÊŠÉ™rÉ™ËˆbÉªlÉ™ti/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The ability to withstand wear, pressure, or damage.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdurabilityâ€ is the quality of being able to last a long time or withstand wear and tear.

What it really means: â€œDurabilityâ€ is a noun that refers to the ability to withstand wear, pressure, or damage. It suggests that a new product can last for a long time. For example, a new car can have great durability.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the ability to withstand wear, pressure, or damage.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œgreat durability,â€ â€œa lack of durability,â€ â€œthe durability of a product.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new car has great durability, so it will last for a long time.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the durability of a new system.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the durability of a new product.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the durability of a new system.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s durability can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the durability of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to have great durability.â€

Synonyms: Strength, resilience, robustness, longevity, permanence.

Opposite words: Fragility, weakness, impermanence, vulnerability.

Where it comes from: From Latin durabilis (lasting).

6.20.389. Eligible#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÉ›lÉªdÊ’É™bÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Having the right to do or obtain something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œeligibleâ€ is to meet the necessary conditions or requirements to be able to do or receive something.

What it really means: â€œEligibleâ€ is an adjective used to describe someone who has the right to do or obtain something. It suggests that a person can do something. For example, a person can be eligible for a new job.

When to use it: Use it to describe someone who has the right to do or obtain something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œeligible for,â€ â€œeligible to,â€ â€œlegally eligible.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI am eligible for the new job, so I am going to apply.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to make more people eligible for a new service.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to make more people eligible for a new right.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to make more people eligible for a new service.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s eligibleity for a new career can affect their motivation.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the eligibleity of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to make more people eligible for a new product.â€

Synonyms: Qualified, entitled, a candidate for, suitable, permissible.

Opposite words: Ineligible, disqualified, unsuitable, unfit.

Where it comes from: From Latin eligere (to choose).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆdÉ›vÉ™steÉªtÉªÅ‹/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Highly destructive or damaging.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdevastatingâ€ is to be causing a great deal of damage, destruction, or emotional distress.

What it really means: â€œDevastatingâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is highly destructive or damaging. It suggests that something is very bad. For example, a new storm can be devastating.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is highly destructive or damaging.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa devastating storm,â€ â€œa devastating loss,â€ â€œa devastating impact.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new storm was devastating, and it destroyed a lot of things.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the devastating problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is a devastating one, so it will have a big impact.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the devastating problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s devastating loss can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the devastating problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a devastating one, so it will not be implemented.â€

Synonyms: Destructive, ruinous, damaging, catastrophic, disastrous.

Opposite words: Constructive, beneficial, helpful, positive, harmless.

Where it comes from: From Latin devastare (to lay waste).

6.20.391. Capacity#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™ËˆpÃ¦sÉ™ti/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The maximum amount that something can contain.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcapacityâ€ is the maximum amount or volume that something can hold or the ability to do something.

What it really means: â€œCapacityâ€ is a noun that refers to the maximum amount that something can contain. It suggests that a new place can hold a lot of people. For example, a new building can have a large capacity.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the maximum amount that something can contain.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œmaximum capacity,â€ â€œstorage capacity,â€ â€œthe capacity to do something.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new building has a maximum capacity of 100 people, so we canâ€™t let more people in.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the capacity of a new system.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the capacity of a new place.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the capacity of a new system.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s capacity to do a new job can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the capacity of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to increase the capacity of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Volume, size, space, ability, potential, power.

Opposite words: Limitation, inability, incapacity.

Where it comes from: From Latin capax (able to hold much).

6.20.392. Supply#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™ËˆplaÉª/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) A stock of a resource from which a person or place can be provided with the necessary amount of that resource; (Verb) To make (something) available to someone.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is a stock or quantity of a resource that is available. The core meaning of the verb is to provide or make something available to someone.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œsupplyâ€ is a stock of a resource from which a person or place can be provided with the necessary amount of that resource. As a verb, to â€œsupplyâ€ means to make something available to someone. For example, a new company can supply a new product.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a stock of a resource, and the verb to refer to the act of making something available to someone.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa limited supply,â€ â€œa supply chain,â€ â€œthe supply of goods.â€

    • (Verb) â€œsupply a product,â€ â€œsupply a service,â€ â€œsupply a person.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new company will supply a new product to the market.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the supply of a new resource.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the supply of a new product.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the supply of a new resource.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s supply of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the supply of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to supply a new service.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Stock, provision, reserve, source; (Verb) Provide, furnish, deliver, equip.

Opposite words: (Noun) Demand, lack, shortage, scarcity; (Verb) Withhold, deny, remove.

Where it comes from: From Latin supplere (to fill up).

6.20.393. Deliberate#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆlÉªbÉ™rÉ™t/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Done consciously and intentionally.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdeliberateâ€ is to be done on purpose and with careful consideration, not by chance or accident.

What it really means: â€œDeliberateâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is done consciously and intentionally. It suggests that a person is doing something on purpose. For example, a new mistake can be a deliberate one.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done consciously and intentionally.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa deliberate mistake,â€ â€œa deliberate act,â€ â€œa deliberate choice.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new mistake was a deliberate one, so I am very angry.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is a deliberate one, so it will have a big impact.â€

      • â€œThe new law is a deliberate one, so it will have a big impact.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is a deliberate one, and it will have a lot of positive and negative effects.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s deliberate choice can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the deliberate problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a deliberate one, so it will be widely used.â€

Synonyms: Intentional, planned, conscious, purposeful, calculated.

Opposite words: Accidental, unintentional, unplanned, spontaneous.

Where it comes from: From Latin deliberare (to weigh in the mind).

6.20.394. Conflict#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkÉ’nflÉªkt/ (noun), /kÉ™nËˆflÉªkt/ (verb)

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) A serious disagreement or argument; (Verb) To be incompatible or at variance.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is a serious disagreement, struggle, or clash between opposing ideas, people, or forces. The core meaning of the verb is to be incompatible or at odds with something.

What it really means: As a noun, a â€œconflictâ€ is a serious disagreement or argument. As a verb, to â€œconflictâ€ means to be incompatible or at variance. For example, a new policy can cause a lot of conflict.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a serious disagreement or argument, and the verb to refer to the act of being incompatible or at variance.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa serious conflict,â€ â€œa conflict of interest,â€ â€œa family conflict.â€

    • (Verb) â€œconflict with,â€ â€œideas conflict.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new policy caused a lot of conflict, so it was not implemented.â€

      • â€œMy new idea is in conflict with the old one, so I need to change it.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the conflict in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy caused a lot of conflict.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s conflict with a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the conflict in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is in conflict with the old one.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Dispute, disagreement, clash, battle, opposition; (Verb) Clash, disagree, collide, differ.

Opposite words: (Noun) Agreement, harmony, peace, accord; (Verb) Agree, harmonize, align.

Where it comes from: From Latin conflictus (a striking together).

6.20.395. Undeniable#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÊŒndÉªËˆnaÉªÉ™bÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Plainly true; incapable of being denied.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œundeniableâ€ is to be impossible to dispute or question, a fact that is plainly and certainly true.

What it really means: â€œUndeniableâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is plainly true. It suggests that a new fact cannot be denied. For example, a new fact can be undeniable.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is plainly true.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œundeniable fact,â€ â€œundeniable evidence,â€ â€œundeniable truth.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new fact is an undeniable one, so you have to believe it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is based on undeniable evidence, so it will be implemented.â€

      • â€œThe new law is based on undeniable truth.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is based on undeniable evidence.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s undeniable talent can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the undeniable problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is an undeniable success.â€

Synonyms: Incontrovertible, indisputable, irrefutable, unquestionable, certain.

Opposite words: Deniable, questionable, debatable, dubious, uncertain.

Where it comes from: From Old French denier (to deny).

6.20.396. Recklessly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆrÉ›klÉ™sli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Without thinking or caring about the consequences of an action.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrecklesslyâ€ is to be acting in a way that is careless or without concern for potential danger or consequences.

What it really means: â€œRecklesslyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done without thinking or caring about the consequences of an action. It suggests that a person is doing something very carelessly. For example, a person can drive recklessly.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done without thinking or caring about the consequences of an action.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œdrive recklessly,â€ â€œact recklessly,â€ â€œspend recklessly.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe was driving recklessly, so he got into a car accident.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who act recklessly.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who spend recklessly.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who act recklessly.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s recklessly decision can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the recklessly problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to prevent people from acting recklessly.â€

Synonyms: Carelessly, heedlessly, rashly, irresponsibly, without caution.

Opposite words: Cautiously, carefully, prudently, responsibly, thoughtfully.

Where it comes from: From Old English reccan (to care for).

6.20.397. Treat#

  • Pronunciation: /triËt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To behave towards or deal with in a certain way; (Noun) An event or item that is out of the ordinary and gives great pleasure.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the verb is to behave toward someone or deal with something in a specific way. The core meaning of the noun is a special pleasure or indulgence.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œtreatâ€ means to behave towards or deal with something in a certain way. As a noun, a â€œtreatâ€ is an event or item that is out of the ordinary and gives great pleasure. For example, a person can treat a new problem, or a person can get a new treat.

When to use it: Use the verb to refer to the act of behaving towards or dealing with something in a certain way, and the noun to refer to a special pleasure.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œtreat a person,â€ â€œtreat a disease,â€ â€œtreat a problem.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa special treat,â€ â€œa little treat,â€ â€œitâ€™s my treat.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI treat my new friend with respect, so we are very close.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to treat a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to treat a new disease.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to treat a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to treat a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to treat a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to treat a new disease.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Handle, manage, deal with, behave towards; (Noun) Pleasure, delight, gift, luxury.

Opposite words: (Verb) Neglect, ignore, mistreat, harm; (Noun) Misery, hardship, chore.

Where it comes from: From Old French traitier (to handle, to deal with).

6.20.398. Conventionally#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™nËˆvÉ›nÊƒÉ™nÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that is based on or in accordance with what is generally done or believed.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œconventionallyâ€ is to be in a way that is traditional, customary, or widely accepted by society.

What it really means: â€œConventionallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a way that is based on what is generally done or believed. It suggests that a person is doing something in a normal way. For example, a person can dress conventionally.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a way that is based on what is generally done or believed.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œdressed conventionally,â€ â€œthink conventionally,â€ â€œbehave conventionally.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI am dressed conventionally today because I am going to a meeting.â€

      • â€œHe thinks conventionally, so he is not a very creative person.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who behave conventionally.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who behave conventionally.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s conventionally attitude can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the conventionally problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to be used conventionally.â€

Synonyms: Traditionally, customarily, ordinarily, normally, regularly.

Opposite words: Unconventionally, unusually, uniquely, originally.

Where it comes from: From Latin conventio (agreement, assembly).

6.20.399. Validate#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆvÃ¦lÉªdeÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To check or prove the validity or accuracy of (something).

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œvalidateâ€ is to confirm, prove, or check the accuracy or legitimacy of something. It can also mean to make someone feel that their feelings are justified.

What it really means: To â€œvalidateâ€ means to check or prove the validity or accuracy of something. It is the act of confirming that something is true. For example, a new study can validate a new theory.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of checking or proving the validity or accuracy of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œvalidate a theory,â€ â€œvalidate a claim,â€ â€œvalidate an argument.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new study is designed to validate the new theory, so it is a very important one.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to validate the new problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to validate the new ideas.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to validate the new problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to validate a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to validate a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to validate a new theory.â€

Synonyms: Confirm, prove, verify, substantiate, authenticate.

Opposite words: Invalidate, disprove, discredit, refute.

Where it comes from: From Latin validus (strong, powerful).

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆpriËÊƒieÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To recognize the full worth of.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œappreciateâ€ is to recognize the value or significance of something or to be grateful for it.

What it really means: To â€œappreciateâ€ means to recognize the full worth of something. It is the act of being grateful for something. For example, a person can appreciate a new gift.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of recognizing the full worth of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œappreciate a gift,â€ â€œappreciate a person,â€ â€œappreciate a new idea.â€

      • â€œI appreciate the new gift, so I am very happy.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to make people appreciate the new government.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to make people appreciate the new country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to make people appreciate the new government.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to appreciate a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to make people appreciate a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to make people appreciate the new system.â€

Synonyms: Value, cherish, be grateful for, be thankful for, recognize.

Opposite words: Disregard, undervalue, scorn, neglect, be ungrateful for.

Where it comes from: From Latin appretiare (to value, to appraise).

6.20.401. Ancient#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆeÉªnÊƒÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Belonging to the very distant past and no longer in existence.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œancientâ€ is to be from a very long time ago, relating to a historical period that is no longer current.

What it really means: â€œAncientâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that belongs to the very distant past. It suggests that a new thing is very old. For example, a new book can have ancient stories.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that belongs to the very distant past.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œancient history,â€ â€œancient civilization,â€ â€œancient stories.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI like to read about ancient history, so I am very interested in it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is based on ancient ideas, so it is not a good one.â€

      • â€œThe new law is based on ancient laws.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is based on ancient ideas.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ancient knowledge can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the ancient problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is a ancient one, so it will not work.â€

Synonyms: Old, historical, archaic, bygone, long ago.

Opposite words: Modern, new, recent, current, contemporary.

Where it comes from: From Latin ante (before).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆslaÉªtli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œslightlyâ€ is to be to a small extent or degree, indicating a minor difference or change.

    • (Adverb) â€œslightly different,â€ â€œslightly taller,â€ â€œslightly better.â€

      • â€œThe new project is slightly different from the old one, so I need to change it.â€

      • â€œHe is slightly taller than me, so he is a good basketball player.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the slightly different problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is slightly better than the old one.â€

Synonyms: A little, somewhat, a bit, marginally, minimally.

Opposite words: Greatly, considerably, immensely, significantly, very.

Where it comes from: From Old English sliht (smooth).

6.20.403. Decline#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆklaÉªn/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To become smaller, fewer, or less; (Noun) A gradual and continuous loss of strength, numbers, or value.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the verb is to decrease in quantity, quality, or strength or to refuse an offer. The core meaning of the noun is a gradual decrease or a downward trend.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œdeclineâ€ means to become smaller, fewer, or less. As a noun, a â€œdeclineâ€ is a gradual and continuous loss of strength, numbers, or value. For example, a new company can decline in value.

When to use it: Use the verb to refer to the act of becoming smaller, fewer, or less, and the noun to refer to a gradual and continuous loss of strength, numbers, or value.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œdecline in value,â€ â€œdecline a request,â€ â€œdecline an invitation.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa rapid decline,â€ â€œa slow decline.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new companyâ€™s value is declineing, so I need to sell my shares.â€

      • â€œI had to decline the new invitation because I was too busy.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the decline of a new country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the decline of a new country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s decline in health can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the decline of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is in decline.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Decrease, diminish, reduce, refuse, reject; (Noun) Decrease, reduction, downturn, deterioration.

Opposite words: (Verb) Increase, grow, accept; (Noun) Increase, growth, rise, improvement.

Where it comes from: From Latin declinare (to bend down).

6.20.404. Offend#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆfÉ›nd/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To cause to feel upset, annoyed, or resentful.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œoffendâ€ is to cause someone to feel upset, annoyed, or insulted, often by a remark or action that is disrespectful.

What it really means: To â€œoffendâ€ means to cause to feel upset, annoyed, or resentful. It is the act of saying or doing something that makes someone unhappy. For example, a person can offend someone with a new joke.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of causing to feel upset, annoyed, or resentful.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œoffend a person,â€ â€œoffend a group,â€ â€œoffend a country.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe offended me with his new joke, so I donâ€™t want to talk to him anymore.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who offend others.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who offend the new country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who offend others.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to offend others can affect their social relationships.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who offend a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to prevent people from offending others.â€

Synonyms: Insult, upset, annoy, displease, anger.

Opposite words: Please, delight, soothe, compliment, appease.

Where it comes from: From Latin offendere (to strike against).

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™ËˆsÉ›ptÉ™bÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Likely or liable to be influenced or harmed by a particular thing.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsusceptibleâ€ is to be easily influenced, affected, or harmed by something, making one vulnerable.

What it really means: â€œSusceptibleâ€ is an adjective used to describe someone who is likely or liable to be influenced or harmed by a particular thing. It suggests that a person can be easily affected by something. For example, a person can be susceptible to a new disease.

When to use it: Use it to describe someone who is likely or liable to be influenced or harmed by a particular thing.

    • (Adjective) â€œsusceptible to,â€ â€œsusceptible to a disease,â€ â€œsusceptible to a new idea.â€

      • â€œI am susceptible to the new disease, so I need to be careful.â€

      • â€œHe is susceptible to a new idea, so he is a very creative person.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who are susceptible to a new problem.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who are susceptible to a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s susceptibleity to a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the susceptibleity of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help the people who are susceptible to a new problem.â€

Synonyms: Vulnerable, prone, exposed, open, liable.

Opposite words: Immune, resistant, invulnerable, unaffected, protected.

Where it comes from: From Latin suscipere (to take up).

  • Pronunciation: /daÉªËˆvÉœËrsÉªti/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the diversity of a new country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the diversity of a new group.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s diversity of ideas can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the diversity of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the diversity of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Variety, assortment, heterogeneity, multiplicity, mix.

Where it comes from: From Latin diversitas (difference).

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆflÉ›kÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œreflectionâ€ is the image cast back from a surface, or the process of deep, careful thought about something.

    • (Noun) â€œa moment of reflection,â€ â€œa mirror reflection,â€ â€œa deep reflection.â€

      • â€œI am having a moment of reflection, so I donâ€™t want to talk to anyone.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the reflection of a new idea.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s reflection of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the reflection of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the reflection of a new problem.â€

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a severe, cruel, or unkind way.

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to prevent people from treating others harshly.â€

Synonyms: Severely, cruelly, unkindly, sternly, stringently.

Where it comes from: From Old Norse harr (rough, crude).

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆpleÉªs/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of taking the place of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œreplace a new car,â€ â€œreplace a new employee,â€ â€œreplace a new part.â€

      • â€œI am going to replace my old car with a new one, so I am very excited.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to replace the old one.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to replace the old one.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to replace the old one.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to replace a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to replace a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to replace the old one.â€

Synonyms: Substitute, supersede, supplant, exchange, take over.

Opposite words: Keep, retain, maintain, hold on to.

Where it comes from: From Old French replacer (to place again).

6.20.413. Primarily#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆpraÉªmÉ™rÉªli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: For the most part; mainly.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œprimarilyâ€ is to be for the most part, or to be the most important aspect of something.

What it really means: â€œPrimarilyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is for the most part. It suggests that a new thing is the main reason for something. For example, a new problem is primarily caused by a new thing.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is for the most part.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œprimarily because of,â€ â€œprimarily for,â€ â€œprimarily to.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new problem is primarily because of a new thing, so we need to fix it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the problems that are primarily caused by a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the problems that are primarily caused by a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the problems that are primarily caused by a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s primarily focus on a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the problems that are primarily caused by a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the problems that are primarily caused by a new system.â€

Synonyms: Mainly, chiefly, mostly, essentially, fundamentally.

Opposite words: Secondarily, incidentally, unimportantly.

Where it comes from: From Latin primarius (of the first rank).

6.20.414. Industry#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÉªndÉ™stri/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: Economic activity concerned with the processing of raw materials and manufacture of goods in factories.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œindustryâ€ is a group of businesses that produce a specific type of goods or services. It also means diligence or hard work.

What it really means: â€œIndustryâ€ is a noun that refers to economic activity concerned with the processing of raw materials and manufacture of goods in factories. It suggests that a new place has a lot of new factories. For example, a new city can have a lot of new industry.

When to use it: Use it to refer to economic activity concerned with the processing of raw materials and manufacture of goods in factories.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œthe manufacturing industry,â€ â€œthe food industry,â€ â€œthe fashion industry.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new city has a lot of new industry, so it has a lot of new jobs.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the industry of a new country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the industry of a new country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the industry of a new country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s industry can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the industry of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the industry of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Business, sector, trade, commerce, manufacturing.

Opposite words: Agriculture, idleness, laziness.

Where it comes from: From Latin industria (diligence).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÉªmÉªdÊ’/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A representation of the external form of a person or thing in art.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œimageâ€ is a visual representation of something, or a personâ€™s reputation or public perception.

What it really means: â€œImageâ€ is a noun that refers to a representation of the external form of a person or thing in art. It suggests that a new thing is being shown. For example, a new photo can be a new image.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a representation of the external form of a person or thing in art.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa digital image,â€ â€œa public image,â€ â€œa company image.â€

    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI need to get a new image for my new profile, so I am going to take a new photo.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the image of a new country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the image of a new company.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the image of a new country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s image can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the image of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the image of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Picture, likeness, representation, reputation, persona.

Opposite words: Reality, substance, object, non-image.

Where it comes from: From Latin imago (likeness).

6.20.416. Heavily#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆhÉ›vÉªli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: To a great degree; in large amounts.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œheavilyâ€ is to be to a great degree or in large amounts, often suggesting something is difficult or intense.

What it really means: â€œHeavilyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done to a great degree. It suggests that a new thing is being done a lot. For example, a new project is being worked on heavily.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done to a great degree.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œrain heavily,â€ â€œrely heavily on,â€ â€œinvest heavily.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new project is being worked on heavily, so it will be done soon.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who rely heavily on a new system.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who rely heavily on a new system.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who rely heavily on a new system.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to rely heavily on a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who rely heavily on a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the people who rely heavily on a new system.â€

Synonyms: Greatly, intensely, extensively, strongly, severely.

Opposite words: Lightly, slightly, gently, minimally.

Where it comes from: From Old English hefig (heavy).

6.20.417. Worsen#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆwÉœËrsÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To make or become worse.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œworsenâ€ is to make something that is already bad become even more so.

What it really means: To â€œworsenâ€ means to make or become worse. It is the act of making a bad thing even worse. For example, a new problem can worsen a new situation.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of making or becoming worse.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œworsen a situation,â€ â€œworsen a problem,â€ â€œworsen a disease.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new problem is going to worsen the situation, so we need to fix it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the problems that worsen a new situation.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the problems that worsen a new situation.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the problems that worsen a new situation.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to worsen a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the problems that worsen a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to prevent people from worsening a new problem.â€

Synonyms: Aggravate, deteriorate, exacerbate, decline, intensify.

Opposite words: Improve, better, alleviate, enhance, help.

Where it comes from: From Old English wyrsa (worse).

6.20.418. Redundancy#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆdÊŒndÉ™nsi/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The state of being no longer needed or useful.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œredundancyâ€ is the state of being no longer needed, especially in employment, or the repetition of information that is unnecessary.

What it really means: â€œRedundancyâ€ is a noun that refers to the state of being no longer needed or useful. It suggests that a new person is being laid off. For example, a new company can have a lot of redundancy.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the state of being no longer needed or useful.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œjob redundancy,â€ â€œmass redundancy,â€ â€œfunctional redundancy.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new company has a lot of redundancy, so a lot of people are going to lose their jobs.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the redundancy of a new resource.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the redundancy of a new problem.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the redundancy of a new resource.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s redundancy of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the redundancy of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the redundancy of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Superfluity, surplus, excess, unnecessary, duplication.

Opposite words: Necessity, essentiality, usefulness, need.

Where it comes from: From Latin redundare (to overflow).

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to defend a new system.â€

Synonyms: Protect, guard, shield, safeguard, uphold.

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆspÉ›ÊƒÉ™lti/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A pursuit, area of study, or skill to which someone has devoted much time and effort.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œspecialtyâ€ is a particular area of skill, knowledge, or expertise that someone is an expert in.

What it really means: â€œSpecialtyâ€ is a noun that refers to a pursuit, area of study, or skill to which someone has devoted much time and effort. It suggests that a new person is very good at a new thing. For example, a new personâ€™s specialty is a new thing.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a pursuit, area of study, or skill to which someone has devoted much time and effort.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa medical specialty,â€ â€œa culinary specialty,â€ â€œa new specialty.â€

  • Examples:

      • â€œHis new specialty is a new thing, so he is a very good one.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s specialty can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the specialty of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the specialty of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Expertise, field, forte, niche, area of focus.

Opposite words: Incompetence, amateurism, generality, lack of skill.

Where it comes from: From Latin species (kind, sort).

6.20.421. Structure#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆstrÊŒktÊƒÉ™r/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) The arrangement of and relations between the parts of something; (Verb) To construct or arrange according to a plan.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is the way something is arranged and organized. The core meaning of the verb is to organize or arrange something in a particular way.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œstructureâ€ refers to the arrangement of and relations between the parts of something. As a verb, to â€œstructureâ€ means to construct or arrange according to a plan. For example, a new building can have a new structure.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to the arrangement of and relations between the parts of something, and the verb to refer to the act of constructing or arranging according to a plan.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa solid structure,â€ â€œthe structure of an essay,â€ â€œsocial structure.â€

    • (Verb) â€œstructure an argument,â€ â€œstructure a new lesson.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new building has a new structure, so it is a very interesting one.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the structure of a new group.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the structure of a new country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the structure of a new group.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s structure of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the structure of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the structure of a new system.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Arrangement, organization, composition, framework; (Verb) Organize, arrange, construct, design.

Opposite words: (Noun) Disorganization, chaos, mess; (Verb) Disorder, disorganize.

Where it comes from: From Latin struere (to build).

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªËˆfÉªÊƒÉ™ntli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that achieves maximum productivity with minimum wasted effort or expense.

What it really means: â€œEfficientlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a way that achieves maximum productivity with minimum wasted effort or expense. It suggests that a new thing is being done well. For example, a new person is working efficiently.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a way that achieves maximum productivity with minimum wasted effort or expense.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œwork efficiently,â€ â€œoperate efficiently,â€ â€œuse efficiently.â€

      • â€œHe is working efficiently, so he will be done soon.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to help people work efficiently.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to work efficiently can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to help people work efficiently.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people work efficiently.â€

Synonyms: Effectively, competently, productively, skillfully, quickly.

Opposite words: Inefficiently, wastefully, ineffectively, poorly, slowly.

Where it comes from: From Latin efficere (to accomplish).

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆtÉ›nd/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

    • (Verb) â€œattend a meeting,â€ â€œattend a school,â€ â€œattend a new event.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to encourage people to attend a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people attend a new event.â€

Synonyms: Be present, be there, go to, show up, participate in.

Where it comes from: From Latin attendere (to give heed to).

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆÃ¦kjÊŠrÉ™tli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a way that is not accurate or correct.

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to prevent people from talking inaccurately.â€

Synonyms: Incorrectly, wrongly, mistakenly, erroneously, imprecisely.

Opposite words: Accurately, correctly, precisely, exactly, rightly.

Where it comes from: From Latin in- (not) and accuratus (careful).

6.20.425. Wide#

  • Pronunciation: /waÉªd/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the wide range of problems in the new system.â€

Where it comes from: From Old English wid (wide).

6.20.427. Eventually#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªËˆvÉ›ntÊƒuÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In the end, especially after a long delay, dispute, or series of problems.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œeventuallyâ€ is to be happening at some later time, especially after a long process or a series of events.

What it really means: â€œEventuallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that happens in the end. It suggests that a new thing is going to happen, but it will take some time. For example, a new problem will be fixed eventually.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that happens in the end.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œwill eventually happen,â€ â€œwill eventually be done,â€ â€œwill eventually be fixed.â€

    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new problem will be fixed eventually, so we donâ€™t need to worry about it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the problems that will eventually happen.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the problems that will eventually happen.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the problems that will eventually happen.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s eventually decision can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the problems that will eventually happen.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the problems that will eventually happen.â€

Synonyms: Finally, ultimately, in the end, in due course, at last.

Opposite words: Immediately, now, instantly, right away.

Where it comes from: From Latin eventus (outcome).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆfÉ”ËrtÊƒÉ™nÉ™tli/

    • (Adverb) â€œfortunately, I have,â€ â€œfortunately, he was,â€ â€œfortunately, the new law.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s fortunately decision can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the problems that fortunately didnâ€™t happen.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the problems that fortunately didnâ€™t happen.â€

Synonyms: Luckily, luckily, happily, providentially.

Opposite words: Unfortunately, sadly, regrettably, unluckily.

Where it comes from: From Latin fortuna (luck).

6.20.429. Sanction#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆsÃ¦Å‹kÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) A threatened penalty for disobeying a law or rule; (Verb) To give official permission for.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is a penalty for breaking a rule, often used by a government. The core meaning of the verb is to give official approval or permission.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œsanctionâ€ refers to a threatened penalty for disobeying a law or rule. As a verb, to â€œsanctionâ€ means to give official permission for. For example, a new country can have a new sanction.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a threatened penalty for disobeying a law or rule, and the verb to refer to the act of giving official permission for.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œeconomic sanctions,â€ â€œinternational sanctions,â€ â€œimpose sanctions.â€

    • (Verb) â€œsanction a new law,â€ â€œsanction a new policy.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new country has a new sanction, so it is in a lot of trouble.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the sanction of a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the sanction of a new problem.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the sanction of a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to sanction a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the sanction of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the sanction of a new problem.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Penalty, punishment, restriction, embargo; (Verb) Approve, authorize, permit, ratify.

Opposite words: (Noun) Reward, approval; (Verb) Forbid, prohibit, veto, reject.

Where it comes from: From Latin sanctio (to make holy, to make binding).

6.20.430. Inhibition#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉªnhÉªËˆbÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A feeling that makes one self-conscious and unable to act in a relaxed or natural way.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œinhibitionâ€ is a feeling of self-consciousness or restraint that prevents a person from acting freely or naturally.

What it really means: â€œInhibitionâ€ is a noun that refers to a feeling that makes one self-conscious and unable to act in a relaxed or natural way. It suggests that a new person is feeling very shy. For example, a new person can have a lot of inhibition.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a feeling that makes one self-conscious and unable to act in a relaxed or natural way.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa lack of inhibition,â€ â€œsocial inhibition,â€ â€œshed inhibitions.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe has a lot of inhibitions, so he canâ€™t talk to anyone.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the inhibition of a new idea.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the inhibition of a new idea.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the inhibition of a new idea.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s inhibition can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the inhibition of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the inhibition of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Shyness, restraint, self-consciousness, reluctance, reserve.

Opposite words: Confidence, freedom, spontaneity, extroversion.

Where it comes from: From Latin inhibere (to hold in).

6.20.431. Offensive#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆfÉ›nsÉªv/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Causing someone to feel deeply hurt, upset, or angry.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œoffensiveâ€ is to be causing insult, annoyance, or displeasure, or to be related to an attack.

What it really means: â€œOffensiveâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that causes someone to feel deeply hurt, upset, or angry. It suggests that a new thing is not nice. For example, a new joke can be very offensive.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that causes someone to feel deeply hurt, upset, or angry.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œan offensive joke,â€ â€œan offensive remark,â€ â€œan offensive smell.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new joke was very offensive, so I donâ€™t want to talk to him anymore.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the offensive problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the offensive problems in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the offensive problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s offensive attitude can affect their social relationships.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the offensive problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to prevent people from acting offensively.â€

Synonyms: Insulting, rude, disrespectful, distasteful, aggressive.

Opposite words: Inoffensive, polite, respectful, pleasant, agreeable.

Where it comes from: From Latin offendere (to strike against).

6.20.432. Pretend#

  • Pronunciation: /prÉªËˆtÉ›nd/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To behave so as to make it appear that something is the case when in fact it is not.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpretendâ€ is to behave as if something is true when it is not, or to make believe.

What it really means: To â€œpretendâ€ means to behave so as to make it appear that something is the case when in fact it is not. It is the act of acting. For example, a new child can pretend to be a new superhero.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of behaving so as to make it appear that something is the case when in fact it is not.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œpretend to be a new person,â€ â€œpretend to be happy,â€ â€œpretend to be a new thing.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new child is going to pretend to be a new superhero, so he is very happy.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who pretend to be something they are not.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who pretend to be something they are not.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who pretend to be something they are not.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to pretend can affect their mental health.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who pretend to be something they are not.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to prevent people from pretending to be something they are not.â€

Synonyms: Feign, simulate, act, make believe, fake.

Opposite words: Be real, be genuine, be authentic, confess.

Where it comes from: From Latin praetendere (to stretch forth).

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆvaÉªd/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To separate into parts; (Noun) A point of disagreement or a distinction.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the verb is to separate something into two or more parts. The core meaning of the noun is a split or a difference between two groups or ideas.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œdivideâ€ means to separate into parts. As a noun, a â€œdivideâ€ is a point of disagreement or a distinction. For example, a new person can divide a new group.

When to use it: Use the verb to refer to the act of separating into parts, and the noun to refer to a point of disagreement or a distinction.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œdivide a group,â€ â€œdivide a country,â€ â€œdivide a new idea.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa social divide,â€ â€œa political divide.â€

      • â€œThe new person is going to divide the new group, so it is a very bad one.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the divide in a new country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the divide in a new country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to divide a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the divide in a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the divide in a new system.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Split, separate, partition, sever; (Noun) Split, schism, rift, chasm.

Opposite words: (Verb) Unite, join, combine, merge; (Noun) Unity, agreement, union, harmony.

Where it comes from: From Latin dividere (to force apart).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆtÉ›mprÉ™tÊƒÉ™r/

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the temperature of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Heat, warmth, coldness, fever, climate.

6.20.444. Exaggerate#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªÉ¡ËˆzÃ¦dÊ’É™reÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To represent something as being larger, better, or worse than it really is.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of representing something as being larger, better, or worse than it really is.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œexaggerate a problem,â€ â€œexaggerate a story,â€ â€œexaggerate a new idea.â€

      • â€œHe is going to exaggerate the new problem, so I donâ€™t believe him.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who exaggerate a new problem.â€
