    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who exaggerate a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to exaggerate can affect their credibility.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who exaggerate a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to prevent people from exaggerateing a new problem.â€

Synonyms: Overstate, embellish, inflate, amplify, magnify.

Opposite words: Understate, minimize, downplay, lessen.

Where it comes from: From Latin exaggerare (to heap up).

6.20.445. Frequent#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆfriËkwÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Adjective) Happening or done often; (Verb) To visit a place often.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the adjective is to be happening or appearing often. The core meaning of the verb is to visit a place regularly.

What it really means: As an adjective, â€œfrequentâ€ describes something that happens often. As a verb, to â€œfrequentâ€ means to visit a place often. For example, a new person can be a frequent visitor to a new place.

When to use it: Use the adjective to describe something that happens often, and the verb to refer to the act of visiting a place often.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa frequent visitor,â€ â€œa frequent problem,â€ â€œa frequent new idea.â€

    • (Verb) â€œfrequent a new place,â€ â€œfrequent a new store.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe is a frequent visitor to the new place, so he knows a lot about it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the frequent problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the frequent problems in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the frequent problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s frequent ideas can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the frequent problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the frequent problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: (Adjective) Common, repeated, regular, numerous; (Verb) Patronize, haunt, visit often.

Opposite words: (Adjective) Infrequent, rare, occasional, seldom; (Verb) Avoid, shun.

Where it comes from: From Latin frequens (crowded, numerous).

6.20.446. Findings#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆfaÉªndÉªÅ‹z/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun (Plural)

  • Simple Meaning: The results of an investigation or inquiry.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œfindingsâ€ is the results, conclusions, or information that are discovered or revealed after an investigation or study.

What it really means: â€œFindingsâ€ is a plural noun that refers to the results of an investigation or inquiry. It suggests that a new study has new results. For example, a new study can have new findings.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the results of an investigation or inquiry.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œresearch findings,â€ â€œstudy findings,â€ â€œreport findings.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new study has new findings, so we need to address them.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the findings of a new study.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the findings of a new report.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the findings of a new study.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s findings can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the findings of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the findings of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Results, conclusions, discoveries, outcomes, data.

Opposite words: Hypotheses, assumptions, unknowns, speculations.

Where it comes from: From Old English findan (to find).

6.20.447. Distinguish#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆstÉªÅ‹É¡wÉªÊƒ/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To recognize or treat (someone or something) as different.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdistinguishâ€ is to recognize a difference between two or more things, or to make something stand out.

What it really means: To â€œdistinguishâ€ means to recognize or treat someone or something as different. It is the act of seeing the difference between two things. For example, a new person can distinguish between two things.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of recognizing or treating someone or something as different.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œdistinguish between two things,â€ â€œdistinguish oneself,â€ â€œdistinguish a new idea.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe can distinguish between two things, so he is a very smart person.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to distinguish between two problems.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to distinguish between two problems.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to distinguish between two problems.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to distinguish between two ideas can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to distinguish between two laws.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to distinguish between two systems.â€

Synonyms: Differentiate, separate, tell apart, discern, recognize.

Opposite words: Confuse, mix up, obscure, blend.

Where it comes from: From Latin distinguere (to separate).

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

When to use it: Use it to refer to an improvement in the condition or strength of something.

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the revival of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Resurgence, restoration, renewal, renaissance, comeback.

Opposite words: Decline, collapse, deterioration, demise, fall.

Where it comes from: From Latin re- (again) and vivere (to live).

6.20.449. Importantly#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªmËˆpÉ”ËrtÉ™ntli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a significant way; with great consequence.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œimportantlyâ€ is to be in a significant way, or to emphasize the importance of a statement.

What it really means: â€œImportantlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a significant way. It suggests that a new thing is a very important one. For example, a new thing is, importantly, a good one.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a significant way.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œimportantly, it should be noted,â€ â€œimportantly, the new law,â€ â€œimportantly, we need to address.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œImportantly, we need to address the new problem, so we need to fix it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the problems that are importantly caused by a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the problems that are importantly caused by a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the problems that are importantly caused by a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s importantly decision can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the problems that are importantly caused by a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the problems that are importantly caused by a new system.â€

Synonyms: Significantly, crucially, critically, essentially, notably.

Opposite words: Unimportantly, insignificantly, negligibly, trivially.

Where it comes from: From Latin importare (to carry in, to matter).

6.20.450. Inherit#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆhÉ›rÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To receive (money, property, or a title) as an heir at the death of the previous holder.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œinheritâ€ is to receive property, money, or characteristics from a person who has died, or to get something from a previous generation.

What it really means: To â€œinheritâ€ means to receive money, property, or a title as an heir at the death of the previous holder. It is the act of getting something from a dead person. For example, a new person can inherit a new house.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of receiving money, property, or a title as an heir at the death of the previous holder.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œinherit a house,â€ â€œinherit a new job,â€ â€œinherit a new problem.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe is going to inherit the new house, so he is very happy.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the problems that we inherit from a new generation.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the problems that we inherit from a new generation.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the problems that we inherit from a new generation.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to inherit a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the problems that we inherit from a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the problems that we inherit from a new system.â€

Synonyms: Succeed, come into, receive, acquire, get.

Opposite words: Disinherit, forfeit, give up, renounce.

Where it comes from: From Latin hereditare (to be an heir).

6.20.451. Equation#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªËˆkweÉªÊ’É™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A statement that the values of two mathematical expressions are equal.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œequationâ€ is a mathematical statement of equality, or a situation where multiple factors must be considered together.

What it really means: â€œEquationâ€ is a noun that refers to a statement that the values of two mathematical expressions are equal. It suggests that a new thing is being used to solve a new problem. For example, a new problem can be solved with a new equation.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a statement that the values of two mathematical expressions are equal.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa chemical equation,â€ â€œa mathematical equation,â€ â€œa new equation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new problem can be solved with a new equation, so we need to find it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the equation of a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the equation of a new problem.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the equation of a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s equation of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the equation of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the equation of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Formula, calculation, identity, balance, equivalence.

Opposite words: Inequality, imbalance.

Where it comes from: From Latin aequare (to make equal).

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆlÊŒktÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: Unwillingness or hesitation to do something.

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the reluctance of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Unwillingness, hesitation, disinclination, aversion, resistance.

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the weak points in the new system.â€

Synonyms: Feeble, frail, fragile, infirm, powerless.

Where it comes from: From Old Norse veikr (weak).

6.20.459. Variable#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆvÉ›É™riÉ™bÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun, Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) An element, feature, or factor that is liable to vary or change; (Adjective) Not consistent or having a fixed pattern.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is a factor that can change or be changed. The core meaning of the adjective is to be likely to change or be inconsistent.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œvariableâ€ refers to an element, feature, or factor that is liable to vary or change. As an adjective, â€œvariableâ€ means not consistent or having a fixed pattern. For example, a new experiment can have a new variable.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to an element, feature, or factor that is liable to vary or change, and the adjective to describe something that is not consistent or having a fixed pattern.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa dependent variable,â€ â€œa control variable,â€ â€œa new variable.â€

    • (Adjective) â€œa variable temperature,â€ â€œa variable speed.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new experiment has a new variable, so we need to control it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the variable problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the variable problems in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the variable problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s variable ideas can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the variable problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the variable problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Factor, element, component, unknown; (Adjective) Changeable, fluctuating, inconsistent, unstable.

Opposite words: (Noun) Constant, invariable; (Adjective) Constant, stable, fixed, uniform.

Where it comes from: From Latin variabilis (changeable).

6.20.460. Argue#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÉ‘ËrÉ¡juË/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To give reasons or cite evidence in support of an idea, action, or theory, typically with the aim of persuading others to share oneâ€™s view.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œargueâ€ is to present reasons for or against an idea or action, or to engage in a verbal disagreement.

What it really means: To â€œargueâ€ means to give reasons or cite evidence in support of an idea, action, or theory, typically with the aim of persuading others to share oneâ€™s view. It is the act of trying to convince someone. For example, a new person can argue for a new idea.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of giving reasons or citing evidence in support of an idea, action, or theory.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œargue for a new idea,â€ â€œargue against a new law,â€ â€œargue with a new person.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe is going to argue for the new idea, so he is very passionate about it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who argue against it.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who argue against it.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who argue against it.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to argue for a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who argue against a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people argue for a new idea.â€

Synonyms: Debate, contend, assert, reason, dispute.

Opposite words: Agree, concur, concede, assent.

Where it comes from: From Latin arguere (to make clear, to prove).

6.20.461. Appearance#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆpÉªÉ™rÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The way that someone or something looks.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œappearanceâ€ is the way something or someone looks, or the act of coming into view.

What it really means: â€œAppearanceâ€ is a noun that refers to the way that someone or something looks. It suggests that a new thing looks a certain way. For example, a new person has a new appearance.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the way that someone or something looks.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa good appearance,â€ â€œa bad appearance,â€ â€œa new appearance.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe has a good appearance, so he is a very handsome person.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the appearance of a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the appearance of a new problem.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the appearance of a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s appearance can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the appearance of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the appearance of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Look, look, impression, semblance, facade.

Opposite words: Reality, substance, essence, being.

Where it comes from: From Latin apparere (to appear).

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆskrÉªpÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s description of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the description of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Account, portrayal, depiction, explanation, narrative.

Where it comes from: From Latin describere (to write down).

What it really means: To â€œcontainâ€ means to have or hold something within. It is the act of holding something. For example, a new box can contain a new thing.

  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œcontain a new thing,â€ â€œcontain a new problem,â€ â€œcontain a new idea.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to contain a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to contain a new system.â€

Synonyms: Hold, include, comprise, encompass, restrain.

Where it comes from: From Latin continere (to hold together).

Where it comes from: From Latin respectare (to look back at, to regard).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆlÉ›ktÊƒÉ™r/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) An educational talk to an audience, especially one of students in a university; (Verb) To deliver a lecture.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is an educational talk given to an audience. The core meaning of the verb is to give such a talk, often in a critical or admonishing way.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œlectureâ€ refers to an educational talk to an audience. As a verb, to â€œlectureâ€ means to deliver a lecture. For example, a new professor can give a new lecture.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to an educational talk to an audience, and the verb to refer to the act of delivering a lecture.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new lecture,â€ â€œa university lecture,â€ â€œa new lecture hall.â€

    • (Verb) â€œlecture a new class,â€ â€œlecture a new group.â€

    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new professor is going to give a new lecture, so I canâ€™t wait to learn.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the lecture of a new professor.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the lecture of a new professor.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the lecture of a new professor.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s lecture can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the lecture of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the lecture of a new system.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Talk, speech, discourse, sermon; (Verb) Talk, speak, address, admonish.

Opposite words: (Noun) Conversation, discussion; (Verb) Listen, be silent.

Where it comes from: From Latin lectura (reading).

Synonyms: Disclose, expose, uncover, divulge, show.

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆstrÊŒkÊƒÉ™n/

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the instruction of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to give people a new instruction.â€

Synonyms: Direction, order, command, guidance, teaching.

Where it comes from: From Latin instruere (to build, to teach).

6.20.469. Leave#

  • Pronunciation: /liËv/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To go away from; (Noun) Time off from work or duty.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the verb is to depart from a place or a person. The core meaning of the noun is permission to be absent from work or duty.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œleaveâ€ means to go away from. As a noun, â€œleaveâ€ refers to time off from work or duty. For example, a new person can leave a new place.

When to use it: Use the verb to refer to the act of going away from, and the noun to refer to time off from work or duty.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œleave a place,â€ â€œleave a job,â€ â€œleave a new idea.â€

    • (Noun) â€œsick leave,â€ â€œvacation leave,â€ â€œa new leave.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI am going to leave the new place, so I need to say goodbye.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who leave a new job.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who leave a new job.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who leave a new job.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to leave a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who leave a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people leave a new system.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Depart, exit, abandon, quit; (Noun) Absence, vacation, furlough, time off.

Opposite words: (Verb) Arrive, stay, remain, come; (Noun) Presence, attendance.

Where it comes from: From Old English laefan (to allow to remain).

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the innovation of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Novelty, change, originality, creativity, new idea.

6.20.471. Process#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆprÉ‘ËsÉ›s/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) A series of actions or steps taken in order to achieve a particular end; (Verb) To perform a series of mechanical or chemical operations on (something) in order to change or preserve it.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of the noun is a series of actions or steps leading to a result. The core meaning of the verb is to perform a set of actions on something to change or handle it.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œprocessâ€ refers to a series of actions or steps taken in order to achieve a particular end. As a verb, to â€œprocessâ€ means to perform a series of mechanical or chemical operations on something. For example, a new thing can have a new process.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a series of actions or steps taken in order to achieve a particular end, and the verb to refer to the act of performing a series of mechanical or chemical operations on something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa long process,â€ â€œa new process,â€ â€œthe legal process.â€

    • (Verb) â€œprocess data,â€ â€œprocess an order,â€ â€œprocess a new thing.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new thing has a new process, so it is a very interesting one.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the process of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the process of a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the process of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s process of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the process of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the process of a new system.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Procedure, method, system, operation, series; (Verb) Handle, manage, treat, prepare.

Opposite words: (Noun) Stagnation, inaction; (Verb) Neglect, ignore, halt.

Where it comes from: From Latin procedere (to go forward).

6.20.472. Reverse#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆvÉœËrs/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun, Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To move backward; (Noun) A change to an opposite direction, order, or condition; (Adjective) Opposite or contrary to what is usual or expected.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning is to change to the opposite direction, position, or order, whether in motion, sequence, or a situation.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œreverseâ€ means to move backward. As a noun, â€œreverseâ€ refers to a change to an opposite direction, order, or condition. As an adjective, â€œreverseâ€ means opposite or contrary to what is usual or expected. For example, a new car can go in reverse.

When to use it: Use the verb to refer to the act of moving backward, the noun to refer to a change to an opposite direction, and the adjective to describe something that is opposite or contrary to what is usual or expected.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œreverse a car,â€ â€œreverse a trend,â€ â€œreverse a new law.â€

    • (Noun) â€œin reverse,â€ â€œa reverse trend.â€

    • (Adjective) â€œa reverse order,â€ â€œa reverse gear.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new car can go in reverse, so it is a very useful one.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to reverse the new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to reverse the new problem.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to reverse the new problem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to reverse a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to reverse a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to reverse a new system.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Invert, turn around, undo, go backward; (Noun) Opposite, inverse, contrary; (Adjective) Opposite, backward, inverted.

Opposite words: (Verb) Forward, advance, proceed; (Noun) Forward, advance; (Adjective) Forward, direct, usual.

Where it comes from: From Latin revertere (to turn back).

6.20.473. Outweigh#

  • Pronunciation: /aÊŠtËˆweÉª/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To be heavier or more significant than.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œoutweighâ€ is to be more important, significant, or powerful than something else.

What it really means: To â€œoutweighâ€ means to be heavier or more significant than. It is the act of being more important. For example, a new thing can outweigh a new problem.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of being heavier or more significant than.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œoutweigh the benefits,â€ â€œoutweigh the risks,â€ â€œoutweigh the new problem.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new thing is going to outweigh the new problem, so we donâ€™t need to worry about it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the problems that outweigh the benefits.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the problems that outweigh the benefits.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the problems that outweigh the benefits.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to outweigh a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the problems that outweigh a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the problems that outweigh the benefits.â€

Synonyms: Surpass, exceed, override, eclipse, be more important than.

Opposite words: Be outweighed by, fall short, be less than.

Where it comes from: From Old English utweigan (to weigh out).

6.20.474. Temptation#

  • Pronunciation: /tÉ›mpËˆteÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The desire to do something, especially something wrong or unwise.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œtemptationâ€ is a strong desire to do something that is forbidden, wrong, or unwise.

What it really means: â€œTemptationâ€ is a noun that refers to the desire to do something, especially something wrong or unwise. It suggests that a new person has a strong desire to do a new thing. For example, a new person can have a new temptation.

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the temptation of a new country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the temptation of a new group.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s temptation can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the temptation of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the temptation of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Allure, enticement, pull, lure, desire.

Opposite words: Repulsion, discouragement, deterrent, resistance.

Where it comes from: From Latin temptare (to test, to try).

6.20.475. Concern#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™nËˆsÉœËrn/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) A matter of interest or importance to someone; (Verb) To relate to or be about.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œconcernâ€ is a matter of worry or importance to someone, or the act of a matter being relevant to a person or situation.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œconcernâ€ refers to a matter of interest or importance. As a verb, to â€œconcernâ€ means to relate to or be about. For example, a new law can be a big concern.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a matter of interest or importance, and the verb to refer to the act of relating to or being about something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa big concern,â€ â€œa new concern,â€ â€œa matter of concern.â€

    • (Verb) â€œconcern a new thing,â€ â€œa new thing concerns me.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new law is a big concern for many people, so we need to address it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the concern of a new group.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the concern of a new country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the concern of a new group.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s concern can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the concern of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the concern of a new system.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Worry, anxiety, issue, matter, interest; (Verb) Affect, involve, relate to, be about.

Opposite words: (Noun) Indifference, unconcern; (Verb) Disregard, ignore.

Where it comes from: From Old French concerner (to concern, to regard).

6.20.476. Decisive#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆsaÉªsÉªv/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Settling an issue; producing a definite result.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdecisiveâ€ is to be firm, conclusive, and able to make decisions quickly and with authority.

What it really means: â€œDecisiveâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is settling an issue; producing a definite result. It suggests that a new person is very good at making decisions. For example, a new person can be very decisive.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is settling an issue; producing a definite result.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa decisive person,â€ â€œa decisive moment,â€ â€œa decisive new law.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe is a very decisive person, so he is a very good leader.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the decisive problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to be a decisive one.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to be a decisive one.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s decisive idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to be decisive for a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to be a decisive one for a new system.â€

Synonyms: Conclusive, resolute, firm, determined, influential.

Opposite words: Indecisive, hesitant, wavering, inconclusive, weak.

Where it comes from: From Latin decidere (to cut off, to determine).

6.20.477. Avoidance#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËˆvÉ”ÉªdÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action of keeping away from or not doing something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œavoidanceâ€ is the act of staying away from a person, place, or situation, or the act of deliberately not doing something.

What it really means: â€œAvoidanceâ€ is a noun that refers to the action of keeping away from or not doing something. It suggests that a new person is not doing a new thing. For example, a new person is doing a lot of avoidance.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the action of keeping away from or not doing something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa lot of avoidance,â€ â€œtax avoidance,â€ â€œa new avoidance.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe is doing a lot of avoidance of the new problem, so we need to address it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the avoidance of a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the avoidance of a new problem.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the avoidance of a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s avoidance of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the avoidance of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the avoidance of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Evasion, circumvention, elusion, preclusion.

Opposite words: Confrontation, engagement, embrace, pursuit.

Where it comes from: From Old French esvuidier (to empty out).

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆhÃ¦ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To intensify, increase, or further improve the quality, value, or extent of.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œenhanceâ€ is to improve the quality, value, or attractiveness of something, or to make it better.

What it really means: To â€œenhanceâ€ means to intensify, increase, or further improve the quality, value, or extent of. It is the act of making a new thing better. For example, a new policy can enhance a new thing.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of intensifying, increasing, or further improving the quality, value, or extent of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œenhance a new thing,â€ â€œenhance a new policy,â€ â€œenhance a new law.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to enhance the new thing, so it is a very good one.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to enhance the new thing, so it is a very good one.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to enhance the new thing, so it is a very good one.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to enhance the new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to enhance a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to enhance a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to enhance a new system.â€

Synonyms: Improve, boost, elevate, intensify, upgrade.

Opposite words: Diminish, decrease, weaken, worsen, degrade.

Where it comes from: From Old French enhaucer (to raise).

  • Pronunciation: /daÉªËˆvÉœËrs/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Showing a great deal of variety; very different.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdiverseâ€ is to be composed of many different kinds or elements, or to be varied.

What it really means: â€œDiverseâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is showing a great deal of variety; very different. It suggests that a new group has many different people. For example, a new group can be very diverse.

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the diverse problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: Varied, assorted, mixed, manifold, various.

Opposite words: Homogeneous, uniform, similar, same.

Where it comes from: From Latin diversus (turned in different directions).

6.20.480. Subtly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆsÊŒtli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a delicate or understated way.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsubtlyâ€ is to be in a way that is not obvious or easily noticed, often in a clever or delicate manner.

What it really means: â€œSubtlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a delicate or understated way. It suggests that a new thing is being done without being noticed. For example, a new person can subtly change a new thing.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a delicate or understated way.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œsubtly change,â€ â€œsubtly suggest,â€ â€œsubtly hint.â€

  • Examples:

      • â€œHe is going to subtly change the new thing, so nobody will notice it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the problems that are subtly caused by a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the problems that are subtly caused by a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the problems that are subtly caused by a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s subtly behavior can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the problems that are subtly caused by a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the problems that are subtly caused by a new system.â€

Synonyms: Imperceptibly, delicately, indirectly, gently, quietly.

Opposite words: Obviously, clearly, overtly, loudly, bluntly.

Where it comes from: From Latin subtilis (fine, thin, delicate).

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆlÊŒktÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Simple Meaning: Unwilling and hesitant; disinclined.

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the reluctant people in the new system.â€

Synonyms: Unwilling, hesitant, disinclined, averse, loath.

Opposite words: Willing, eager, ready, keen, enthusiastic.

Where it comes from: From Latin reluctari (to struggle against).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆprÃ¦ktÉªkÉ™l/

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to be a practical one for a new system.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the replacement of a new system.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the deficiency of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Shortage, lack, deficit, inadequacy, scarcity.

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the sensitive problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: Responsive, emotional, delicate, susceptible, touchy.

6.20.492. Fluently#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆfluËÉ™ntli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that is able to express oneself easily and articulately.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œfluentlyâ€ is to be in a smooth, easy, and effortless manner, especially when speaking a language.

What it really means: â€œFluentlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a way that is able to express oneself easily and articulately. It suggests that a new person can speak a new language very well. For example, a new person can speak fluently.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a way that is able to express oneself easily and articulately.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œspeak fluently,â€ â€œwrite fluently,â€ â€œread fluently.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe can speak English fluently, so he is a very good person.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who can speak fluently.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who can speak fluently.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who can speak fluently.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to speak fluently can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who can speak fluently.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people speak fluently.â€

Synonyms: Effortlessly, smoothly, articulately, eloquently, easily.

Opposite words: Haltingly, hesitantly, awkwardly, stumblingly.

Where it comes from: From Latin fluens (flowing).

6.20.493. Defeat#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆfiËt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To win a victory over (someone) in a battle or other contest; (Noun) An instance of defeating or being defeated.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdefeatâ€ is to win a victory over an opponent, or to cause someone to lose. As a noun, it is the state of being beaten.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œdefeatâ€ means to win a victory over someone in a battle or other contest. As a noun, â€œdefeatâ€ refers to an instance of defeating or being defeated. For example, a new team can defeat a new team.

When to use it: Use the verb to refer to the act of winning a victory over someone in a battle or other contest, and the noun to refer to an instance of defeating or being defeated.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œdefeat a new team,â€ â€œdefeat a new enemy,â€ â€œdefeat a new problem.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa bitter defeat,â€ â€œa new defeat.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new team is going to defeat the old one, so I am very excited.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the defeat of a new team.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the defeat of a new problem.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the defeat of a new team.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to defeat a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the defeat of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to defeat a new system.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Beat, overcome, conquer, vanquish; (Noun) Loss, failure, conquest, downfall.

Opposite words: (Verb) Win, succeed, triumph, surrender; (Noun) Victory, success, triumph.

Where it comes from: From Old French desfaire (to undo).

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to destroy a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to destroy a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to destroy a new system.â€

Synonyms: Ruin, demolish, annihilate, obliterate, devastate.

Opposite words: Create, build, construct, establish, preserve.

Where it comes from: From Latin destruere (to pull down).

What it really means: â€œDramaticallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a sudden and striking way. It suggests that a new thing is being done in a very big way. For example, a new thing can dramatically change a new thing.

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the problems that dramatically change the new system.â€

6.20.506. Coincidentally#

  • Pronunciation: /koÊŠËŒÉªnsÉªËˆdÉ›ntÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: By chance; as a result of a coincidence.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcoincidentallyâ€ is to be in a way that happens by chance, or to be a surprising parallel of events.

What it really means: â€œCoincidentallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done by chance; as a result of a coincidence. It suggests that a new thing is happening at the same time as a new thing. For example, a new thing coincidentally happened.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done by chance; as a result of a coincidence.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œcoincidentally happen,â€ â€œcoincidentally meet,â€ â€œcoincidentally find a new thing.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe coincidentally found the new thing, so he is very happy.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the problems that coincidentally happen.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the problems that coincidentally happen.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the problems that coincidentally happen.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s coincidentally idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the problems that coincidentally happen.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the problems that coincidentally happen.â€

Synonyms: By chance, accidentally, unexpectedly, serendipitously.

Opposite words: Intentionally, deliberately, purposefully, by design.

Where it comes from: From Latin co- (together) and incidere (to fall upon).

6.20.508. Publicly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆpÊŒblÉªkli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that is open to or accessible by the public.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpubliclyâ€ is to be in a way that is open to everyone, or in front of other people.

What it really means: â€œPubliclyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a way that is open to or accessible by the public. It suggests that a new thing is being done in front of a lot of people. For example, a new person can publicly speak.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a way that is open to or accessible by the public.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œpublicly speak,â€ â€œpublicly announce,â€ â€œpublicly show.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe is going to publicly announce the new thing, so a lot of people will know about it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who publicly do a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who publicly do a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who publicly do a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to publicly speak can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who publicly do a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people publicly do a new system.â€

Synonyms: Openly, openly, overtly, commonly, candidly.

Opposite words: Privately, secretly, confidentially, in private.

Where it comes from: From Latin publicus (of the people).

6.20.509. Elaborately#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªËˆlÃ¦bÉ™rÉ™tli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a detailed and complicated manner.

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the problems that are elaborately caused by a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the problems that are elaborately caused by a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the problems that are elaborately caused by a new system.â€

Opposite words: Simply, plainly, concisely, briefly, minimally.

Where it comes from: From Latin elaborare (to work out).

6.20.510. Suddenly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆsÊŒdÉ™nli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

What it really means: â€œSuddenlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done quickly and unexpectedly. It suggests that a new thing is happening very fast. For example, a new thing suddenly happened.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done quickly and unexpectedly.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œsuddenly happen,â€ â€œsuddenly change,â€ â€œsuddenly stop.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the problems that suddenly happen.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the problems that suddenly happen.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s suddenly idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the problems that suddenly happen.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the problems that suddenly happen.â€

Synonyms: Abruptly, unexpectedly, all at once, without warning, rapidly.

Opposite words: Gradually, slowly, steadily, predictably.

Where it comes from: From Old French sudein (sudden).

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆzaÉªÉ™rÉ™bÉ™l/

6.20.515. Substitute#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆsÊŒbstÉªtjuËt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: A person or thing acting or serving in place of another.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsubstituteâ€ is to replace or act in the place of another, or a person or thing that does so.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œsubstituteâ€ refers to a person or thing acting or serving in place of another. As a verb, to â€œsubstituteâ€ means to replace or act in the place of another. For example, a new person can be a substitute for a new person.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a person or thing acting or serving in place of another, and the verb to refer to the act of replacing or acting in the place of another.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new substitute,â€ â€œa temporary substitute,â€ â€œa permanent substitute.â€

    • (Verb) â€œsubstitute a new thing,â€ â€œsubstitute a new person,â€ â€œsubstitute a new idea.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new person is a new substitute for the old one, so he is a very good one.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the substitute of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the substitute of a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the substitute of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s substitute of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the substitute of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the substitute of a new system.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Replacement, stand-in, backup, proxy, successor; (Verb) Replace, swap, exchange, switch.

Opposite words: (Noun) Original, permanent thing; (Verb) Retain, keep, maintain.

Where it comes from: From Latin substituere (to put in place of).

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who conceal a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to conceal a new system.â€

Synonyms: Hide, cover, disguise, mask, camouflage.

Where it comes from: From Latin concelare (to hide).

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉ’bzÉ™rËˆveÉªÊƒÉ™nz/

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆsÉ›ptÉªv/

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to be a deceptive one for a new system.â€

Synonyms: Misleading, false, fraudulent, dishonest, cunning.

Where it comes from: From Latin deceptus (taken away, deceived).

6.20.523. Difference#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆdÉªfrÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A point or way in which people or things are not the same.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdifferenceâ€ is a distinction or a point of unlikeness between two or more things.

What it really means: â€œDifferenceâ€ is a noun that refers to a point or way in which people or things are not the same. It suggests that a new thing is not the same as a new thing. For example, a new thing can have a new difference.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a point or way in which people or things are not the same.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa big difference,â€ â€œa new difference,â€ â€œa lot of difference.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThere is a big difference between the two things, so I like the new one.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the difference of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the difference of a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the difference of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s difference with a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the difference of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the difference of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Distinction, variation, disparity, contrast, divergence.

Opposite words: Sameness, similarity, likeness, resemblance, equality.

Where it comes from: From Latin differentia (difference).

6.20.524. Accumulation#

  • Pronunciation: /É™ËŒkjuËmjÉ™ËˆleÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The acquisition or gradual gathering of something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œaccumulationâ€ is the process of gathering or amassing something over time, or the resulting collection.

What it really means: â€œAccumulationâ€ is a noun that refers to the acquisition or gradual gathering of something. It suggests that a new thing is being gathered. For example, a new thing can have a new accumulation.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the acquisition or gradual gathering of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new accumulation,â€ â€œa lot of accumulation,â€ â€œa slow accumulation.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThere is a new accumulation of new things, so I need to clean up.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the accumulation of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the accumulation of a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the accumulation of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s accumulation of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the accumulation of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the accumulation of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Collection, gathering, build-up, stockpile, hoard.

Opposite words: Dispersion, dissipation, distribution, dispersal, scattering.

Where it comes from: From Latin accumulare (to heap up).

6.20.525. Solution#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™ËˆluËÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A means of solving a problem or dealing with a difficult situation.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsolutionâ€ is a way to solve a problem, or the answer to a question.

What it really means: â€œSolutionâ€ is a noun that refers to a means of solving a problem or dealing with a difficult situation. It suggests that a new thing can fix a new problem. For example, a new thing can be a new solution.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a means of solving a problem or dealing with a difficult situation.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new solution,â€ â€œa perfect solution,â€ â€œa good solution.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI found a new solution to the new problem, so I am very happy.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to be a solution to the new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to be a solution to the new problem.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to be a solution to the new problem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s solution to a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to find a solution to a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to be a solution to a new system.â€

Synonyms: Answer, resolution, remedy, fix, key.

Opposite words: Problem, difficulty, obstacle, issue, dilemma.

Where it comes from: From Latin solutio (an unfastening, a solving).

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªkËˆstÉ›nÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action of extending something or the state of being extended.

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

6.20.527. Kindly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkaÉªndli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a kind manner.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œkindlyâ€ is to be in a gentle, friendly, or considerate way, often used as a polite request.

What it really means: â€œKindlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a kind manner. It suggests that a new person is being very nice. For example, a new person can kindly help a new person.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a kind manner.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œkindly help,â€ â€œkindly ask,â€ â€œkindly give.â€

      • â€œHe kindly helped me, so I am very happy.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to kindly help others can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who kindly help others.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people kindly help a new system.â€

Synonyms: Gently, warmly, benevolently, generously, thoughtfully.

Opposite words: Unkindly, cruelly, harshly, meanly, rudely.

Where it comes from: From Old English cyndelic (natural).

6.20.528. Cures#

  • Pronunciation: /kjÊŠÉ™rz/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To heal, to restore to health; (Noun) A medicine or treatment that cures a disease.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcuresâ€ is the act of making a person or illness healthy again, or a treatment that achieves this.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œcureâ€ means to heal, to restore to health. As a noun, â€œcuresâ€ refers to a medicine or treatment that cures a disease. For example, a new medicine can cure a new disease.

When to use it: Use the verb to refer to the act of healing, to restore to health, and the noun to refer to a medicine or treatment that cures a disease.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œcures a new disease,â€ â€œcures a new problem,â€ â€œcures a new thing.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa new cure,â€ â€œa good cure,â€ â€œa lot of cures.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new medicine cures the new disease, so it is a very good one.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the cures for a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the cures for a new problem.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the cures for a new problem.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s cure for a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to find a cure for a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to be a cure for a new system.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Heal, remedy, restore, fix, treat; (Noun) Remedy, treatment, medicine, solution.

Opposite words: (Verb) Worsen, aggravate, harm, damage; (Noun) Illness, disease, ailment.

Where it comes from: From Latin curare (to take care of).

6.20.529. Mutually#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆmjuËtÊƒuÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: (Of a feeling or action) experienced or done by each of two or more parties towards the other or others.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œmutuallyâ€ is to be in a way that is shared or done by two or more people toward each other.

What it really means: â€œMutuallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is (of a feeling or action) experienced or done by each of two or more parties towards the other or others. It suggests that a new thing is being done by two people at the same time. For example, a new person and a new person can mutually agree on a new thing.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is (of a feeling or action) experienced or done by each of two or more parties towards the other or others.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œmutually agree,â€ â€œmutually beneficial,â€ â€œmutually respectful.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œWe mutually agreed on the new thing, so we are both happy.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the mutually beneficial problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the mutually beneficial problems in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the mutually beneficial problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s mutually ideas can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the mutually beneficial problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the mutually beneficial problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: Reciprocally, jointly, collectively, together, in common.

Opposite words: Individually, unilaterally, separately, independently.

Where it comes from: From Latin mutuus (reciprocal).

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆkriËsÉªÅ‹li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is happening to an increasing extent; more and more.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œincreasingly difficult,â€ â€œincreasingly popular,â€ â€œincreasingly a new problem.â€

  • Examples:

      • â€œThe new problem is increasingly becoming a new problem, so we need to address it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the increasingly difficult problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the increasingly difficult problems in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the increasingly difficult problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s increasingly ideas can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the increasingly difficult problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the increasingly difficult problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: More and more, progressively, steadily, a growing number of.

Opposite words: Decreasingly, less and less, dwindling, gradually.

Where it comes from: From Old French encreistre (to grow).

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªmËˆprÉ›ÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: An idea, feeling, or opinion about something or someone, especially one formed without conscious thought or on the basis of little evidence.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œimpressionâ€ is an idea or feeling that a person forms about something, or the effect that something has on a person.

What it really means: â€œImpressionâ€ is a noun that refers to an idea, feeling, or opinion about something or someone, especially one formed without conscious thought or on the basis of little evidence. It suggests that a new person has an idea about a new thing. For example, a new person can have a new impression.

When to use it: Use it to refer to an idea, feeling, or opinion about something or someone, especially one formed without conscious thought or on the basis of little evidence.

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the impression of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the impression of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Feeling, idea, sense, notion, opinion, effect.

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÊƒÉ”ËrtËŒkÊŒmÉªÅ‹/

  • Word Type: Noun

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the shortcoming of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Flaw, defect, weakness, fault, deficiency, failing.

Opposite words: Strength, advantage, perfection, benefit.

Where it comes from: From short and coming.

6.20.535. Preliminary#

  • Pronunciation: /prÉªËˆlÉªmÉªnÉ™ri/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Denoting an action or event preceding or done in preparation for something fuller or more important.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpreliminaryâ€ is to be happening before the main event or action, or to be preparatory.

    • (Adjective) â€œa preliminary meeting,â€ â€œa preliminary report,â€ â€œa preliminary new idea.â€

      • â€œWe are going to have a preliminary meeting, so we can prepare for the main one.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the preliminary problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the preliminary problems in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the preliminary problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s preliminary ideas can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the preliminary problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the preliminary problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: Introductory, preparatory, initial, preceding, preparatory.

Opposite words: Final, concluding, ultimate, main, last.

Where it comes from: From Latin prae- (before) and limen (threshold).

6.20.536. Intuitively#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆtjuËÉªtÉªvli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: By means of intuition, without conscious reasoning.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œintuitivelyâ€ is to be based on a natural sense or gut feeling, rather than on careful thought or logic.

What it really means: â€œIntuitivelyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done by means of intuition, without conscious reasoning. It suggests that a new person just knows a new thing. For example, a new person intuitively knows a new thing.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done by means of intuition, without conscious reasoning.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œintuitively know,â€ â€œintuitively feel,â€ â€œintuitively understand.â€

      • â€œHe intuitively knew the answer, so he is a very smart person.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who intuitively know a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who intuitively know a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who intuitively know a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to intuitively know a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who intuitively know a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people intuitively know a new system.â€

Synonyms: Instinctively, instinctively, by gut feeling, naturally, spontaneously.

Opposite words: Logically, consciously, deliberately, rationally, analytically.

Where it comes from: From Latin intueri (to look at, to consider).

Where it comes from: From Latin protegere (to cover in front).

6.20.540. Invasion#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªnËˆveÉªÊ’É™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: An instance of invading a country or region with an armed force.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œinvasionâ€ is the act of entering a place with force, especially by an army, to take control.

What it really means: â€œInvasionâ€ is a noun that refers to an instance of invading a country or region with an armed force. It suggests that a new country is being attacked. For example, a new country can have a new invasion.

When to use it: Use it to refer to an instance of invading a country or region with an armed force.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new invasion,â€ â€œa foreign invasion,â€ â€œan enemy invasion.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new country is having a new invasion, so a lot of people are scared.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the invasion of a new country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the invasion of a new country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the invasion of a new country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s invasion of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the invasion of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the invasion of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Attack, assault, incursion, raid, encroachment.

Opposite words: Retreat, withdrawal, evacuation, defense, surrender.

Where it comes from: From Latin invasio (an assault upon).

6.20.541. Changeable#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆtÊƒeÉªndÊ’É™bÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Liable to change.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œchangeableâ€ is to be likely to change or vary, or to be unpredictable.

What it really means: â€œChangeableâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is liable to change. It suggests that a new thing can be changed. For example, a new plan can be very changeable.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is liable to change.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa changeable plan,â€ â€œa changeable weather,â€ â€œa changeable new idea.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new plan is very changeable, so we need to be ready for anything.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the changeable problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the changeable problems in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the changeable problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s changeable ideas can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the changeable problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the changeable problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: Variable, unpredictable, inconsistent, erratic, fickle.

Opposite words: Unchangeable, constant, stable, consistent, predictable.

Where it comes from: From Old French changer (to change).

6.20.542. Triumph#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆtraÉªÉ™mf/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: A great victory or achievement.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œtriumphâ€ is a great victory or success, or the feeling of joy that comes with it.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œtriumphâ€ refers to a great victory or achievement. As a verb, to â€œtriumphâ€ means to achieve a great victory or success. For example, a new team can have a new triumph.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a great victory or achievement, and the verb to refer to the act of achieving a great victory or success.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa great triumph,â€ â€œa new triumph,â€ â€œa feeling of triumph.â€

    • (Verb) â€œtriumph over a new thing,â€ â€œtriumph in a new competition.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new team had a great triumph, so they are very happy.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the triumph of a new group.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the triumph of a new group.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the triumph of a new group.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s triumph can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to achieve a triumph for a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to be a triumph for a new system.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Victory, success, achievement, win, conquest; (Verb) Succeed, prevail, win, overcome.

Opposite words: (Noun) Defeat, failure, loss, downfall; (Verb) Fail, lose, be defeated.

Where it comes from: From Latin triumphus (a public celebration of a victory).

6.20.543. Partly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆpÉ‘Ërtli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: To some extent; not completely.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpartlyâ€ is to be to a certain degree or extent, but not fully or entirely.

What it really means: â€œPartlyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done to some extent; not completely. It suggests that a new thing is being done to a certain degree. For example, a new thing is partly done.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done to some extent; not completely.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œpartly done,â€ â€œpartly true,â€ â€œpartly a new problem.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new thing is partly done, so I need to finish it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the problems that are partly caused by a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the problems that are partly caused by a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the problems that are partly caused by a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s partly ideas can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the problems that are partly caused by a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the problems that are partly caused by a new system.â€

Synonyms: Partially, somewhat, in part, to a degree, slightly.

Opposite words: Wholly, completely, entirely, fully, totally.

Where it comes from: From Old French part (part).

6.20.544. Irresponsibly#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉªrÉªËˆspÉ’nsÉ™bli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that shows a lack of responsibility.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œirresponsiblyâ€ is to be in a careless or reckless way, without thinking about the consequences.

What it really means: â€œIrresponsiblyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a way that shows a lack of responsibility. It suggests that a new person is being careless. For example, a new person irresponsibly did a new thing.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a way that shows a lack of responsibility.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œirresponsibly act,â€ â€œirresponsibly drive,â€ â€œirresponsibly spend.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe irresponsibly drove the car, so he got into a new accident.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who irresponsibly do a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who irresponsibly do a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who irresponsibly do a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to irresponsibly do a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who irresponsibly do a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the people who irresponsibly do a new system.â€

Synonyms: Recklessly, carelessly, foolishly, thoughtlessly, unwisely.

Opposite words: Responsibly, carefully, wisely, sensibly, prudently.

Where it comes from: From Latin ir- (not) and respondere (to respond).

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉ’kjÉ™ËˆpeÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A personâ€™s job or profession.

Where it comes from: From Latin occupatio (a taking, a seizing).

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to implement a new system.â€

Synonyms: Execute, carry out, enact, put into practice, apply.

Where it comes from: From Latin implere (to fill up).

6.20.547. Admit#

  • Pronunciation: /É™dËˆmÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To confess to be true or to be the case.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œadmitâ€ is to confess or acknowledge something to be true, often something that is difficult to say. It can also mean to allow entry.

What it really means: To â€œadmitâ€ means to confess to be true or to be the case. It is the act of saying that a new thing is true. For example, a new person can admit a new thing.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of confessing to be true or to be the case.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œadmit a new thing,â€ â€œadmit a new mistake,â€ â€œadmit a new fault.â€
