      • â€œHe is going to admit his new mistake, so he is a very good person.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who admit a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who admit a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who admit a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to admit a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who admit a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people admit a new system.â€

Synonyms: Confess, acknowledge, concede, grant, allow.

Opposite words: Deny, reject, refuse, disclaim, conceal.

Where it comes from: From Latin admittere (to send to).

6.20.548. Predisposition#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒpriËdÉªspÉ™ËˆzÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A liability or tendency to suffer from a particular condition.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpredispositionâ€ is a tendency or inclination to behave or develop in a certain way, often due to genetics or upbringing.

What it really means: â€œPredispositionâ€ is a noun that refers to a liability or tendency to suffer from a particular condition. It suggests that a new person has a new tendency. For example, a new person can have a new predisposition.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a liability or tendency to suffer from a particular condition.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa genetic predisposition,â€ â€œa new predisposition,â€ â€œa family predisposition.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe has a genetic predisposition to the new disease, so he needs to be careful.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the predisposition of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the predisposition of a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the predisposition of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s predisposition to a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the predisposition of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the predisposition of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Tendency, inclination, susceptibility, proneness, bias.

Opposite words: Aversion, resistance, immunity, disinclination, opposition.

Where it comes from: From Latin prae- (before) and disponere (to arrange).

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ™mËˆpliËt/

  • Word Type: Adjective, Verb

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcompleteâ€ is to be finished, having all parts, or the act of finishing something.

What it really means: As an adjective, â€œcompleteâ€ refers to having all the necessary or appropriate parts. As a verb, to â€œcompleteâ€ means to finish making or doing something. For example, a new thing can be complete.

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to be a complete one for a new system.â€

Where it comes from: From Latin completus (filled up).

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉªntÉ™rËˆÃ¦kt/

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people interact with a new system.â€

Where it comes from: From Latin inter (between) and agere (to do, to act).

6.20.555. Early#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÉœËrli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A1

  • Word Type: Adjective, Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Happening or done before the usual or expected time.

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the early problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: (Adjective) Premature, timely, prompt, ahead of schedule; (Adverb) Promptly, soon, quickly, beforehand.

Opposite words: Late, delayed, overdue, tardy.

Where it comes from: From Old English Ã¦rlice (early).

6.20.556. Extinction#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªkËˆstÉªÅ‹kÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The state or process of a species, family, or other group of animals or plants dying out.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œextinctionâ€ is the process of a species or group of organisms dying out completely, so that none are left.

What it really means: â€œExtinctionâ€ is a noun that refers to the state or process of a species, family, or other group of animals or plants dying out. It suggests that a new thing is no longer in existence. For example, a new thing can be in extinction.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the state or process of a species, family, or other group of animals or plants dying out.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new extinction,â€ â€œa mass extinction,â€ â€œin danger of extinction.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new thing is in extinction, so we need to save it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the extinction of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the extinction of a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the extinction of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s extinction of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the extinction of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the extinction of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Vanishing, disappearance, demise, eradication, annihilation.

Opposite words: Survival, existence, proliferation, revival.

Where it comes from: From Latin extinguere (to quench, to put out).

6.20.557. Outbreak#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆaÊŠtbreÉªk/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A sudden occurrence of something unwelcome, such as war or disease.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œoutbreakâ€ is a sudden and often violent start of something undesirable, like a disease or a conflict.

What it really means: â€œOutbreakâ€ is a noun that refers to a sudden occurrence of something unwelcome, such as war or disease. It suggests that a new thing has started very fast. For example, a new thing can have a new outbreak.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a sudden occurrence of something unwelcome, such as war or disease.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new outbreak,â€ â€œa disease outbreak,â€ â€œa war outbreak.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThere is a new outbreak of the new disease, so we need to be careful.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the outbreak of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the outbreak of a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the outbreak of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s outbreak of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the outbreak of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the outbreak of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Eruption, epidemic, flare-up, surge, sudden occurrence.

Opposite words: Cessation, conclusion, end, resolution, subsidence.

Where it comes from: From Old English Å«tbrecan (to break out).

6.20.558. Desperately#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆdÉ›spÉ™rÉ™tli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a way that shows a lack of hope; despairingly.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdesperatelyâ€ is to be with a strong sense of urgency or need, often because of a hopeless situation.

What it really means: â€œDesperatelyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a way that shows a lack of hope; despairingly. It suggests that a new person is in a very bad situation. For example, a new person can desperately need a new thing.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a way that shows a lack of hope; despairingly.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œdesperately need,â€ â€œdesperately want,â€ â€œdesperately try.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe desperately needed help, so I helped him.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who desperately need help.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who desperately need help.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who desperately need help.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to desperately need a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who desperately need help.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people who desperately need a new system.â€

Synonyms: Urgently, despairingly, hopelessly, frantically, intensely.

Opposite words: Calmly, patiently, hopefully, contentedly, confidently.

Where it comes from: From Latin desperare (to despair).

6.20.559. Deteriorate#

  • Pronunciation: /dÉªËˆtÉªÉ™riÉ™reÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To become progressively worse.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdeteriorateâ€ is to gradually decline in quality or condition, or to become worse over time.

  • Common phrases:

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the problems that deteriorate over time.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the problems that deteriorate over time.â€

Synonyms: Worsen, decline, degenerate, decay, fall apart.

Opposite words: Improve, recover, enhance, flourish, progress.

Where it comes from: From Latin deterior (worse).

6.20.560. Speculate#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆspÉ›kjÉ™leÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To form a theory or conjecture about a subject without firm evidence.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œspeculateâ€ is to form a guess or theory without having all the facts, or to guess about what might happen.

What it really means: To â€œspeculateâ€ means to form a theory or conjecture about a subject without firm evidence. It is the act of a new person guessing about a new thing. For example, a new person can speculate about a new thing.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of forming a theory or conjecture about a subject without firm evidence.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œspeculate about a new thing,â€ â€œspeculate on a new thing,â€ â€œspeculate a new thing.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI can speculate about the new thing, but I donâ€™t know for sure.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who speculate about a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who speculate about a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who speculate about a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to speculate about a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who speculate about a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people speculate about a new system.â€

Synonyms: Guess, hypothesize, conjecture, theorize, surmise.

Opposite words: Know, prove, verify, confirm, substantiate.

Where it comes from: From Latin speculari (to observe).

6.20.561. Suspiciously#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™ËˆspÉªÊƒÉ™sli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a distrustful or wary manner.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsuspiciouslyâ€ is to be in a way that suggests distrust, doubt, or a hint of something wrong.

What it really means: â€œSuspiciouslyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a distrustful or wary manner. It suggests that a new person is looking at a new thing in a weird way. For example, a new person can suspiciously look at a new thing.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a distrustful or wary manner.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œsuspiciously look,â€ â€œsuspiciously act,â€ â€œsuspiciously a new thing.â€

  • Examples:

      • â€œHe is suspiciously looking at me, so I donâ€™t like it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who suspiciously act.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who suspiciously act.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who suspiciously act.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to suspiciously act can affect their career.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who suspiciously act.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people suspiciously look at a new system.â€

Synonyms: Warily, distrustfully, doubtfully, cagily, questioningly.

Opposite words: Trustingly, confidently, openly, innocently, assuredly.

Where it comes from: From Latin suspicere (to look up, to mistrust).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆpraÉªvÉ™tli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adverb

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œprivatelyâ€ is to be in a personal or secret manner, without the involvement of others.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a way that is not intended to be known by a large number of people.

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to privately do a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who privately do a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people privately do a new system.â€

Synonyms: Secretly, confidentially, in private, in confidence, discreetly.

Opposite words: Publicly, openly, officially, transparently, blatantly.

Where it comes from: From Latin privatus (personal, not public).

6.20.563. Virtually#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆvÉœËrtÊƒuÉ™li/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: Almost; nearly.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œvirtuallyâ€ is to be almost or nearly true, or to be in effect though not officially.

What it really means: â€œVirtuallyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is almost; nearly. It suggests that a new thing is almost a new thing. For example, a new thing is virtually a new thing.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is almost; nearly.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œvirtually impossible,â€ â€œvirtually the same,â€ â€œvirtually a new thing.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new thing is virtually impossible to do, so I canâ€™t do it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the virtually impossible problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to be virtually a new one.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to be virtually a new one.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s virtually ideas can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the virtually impossible problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the virtually impossible problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: Almost, nearly, practically, essentially, in effect.

Opposite words: Actually, truly, really, genuinely, literally.

Where it comes from: From Latin virtualis (relating to excellence).

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒdÊ’ÊŒstÉªfÉªËˆkeÉªÊƒÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The action of showing something to be right or reasonable.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œjustificationâ€ is a reason or defense that explains why an action or belief is right or acceptable.

What it really means: â€œJustificationâ€ is a noun that refers to the action of showing something to be right or reasonable. It suggests that a new thing has a new reason. For example, a new thing can have a new justification.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the action of showing something to be right or reasonable.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new justification,â€ â€œa lack of justification,â€ â€œa good justification.â€

    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI donâ€™t have a justification for the new thing, so I canâ€™t do it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the justification of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the justification of a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the justification of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s justification for a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the justification for a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the justification for a new system.â€

Synonyms: Reason, rationale, grounds, basis, defense.

Opposite words: Unjustification, illegitimacy, unreasonableness.

Where it comes from: From Latin justificare (to do justice to, to justify).

  • Pronunciation: /prÉªËˆfÉœËr/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To like one thing or person more than another or others.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œpreferâ€ is to like one option better than another, or to have a stronger desire for it.

What it really means: To â€œpreferâ€ means to like one thing or person more than another or others. It is the act of a new person liking a new thing more than a new thing. For example, a new person can prefer a new thing.

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who prefer a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people who prefer a new system.â€

Synonyms: Favor, choose, opt for, lean toward, rather.

6.20.566. Quarrel#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkwÉ’rÉ™l/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) An angry argument or disagreement; (Verb) To have an angry argument or disagreement.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œquarrelâ€ is a dispute or argument, or the act of having one.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œquarrelâ€ refers to an angry argument or disagreement. As a verb, to â€œquarrelâ€ means to have an angry argument or disagreement. For example, a new person can have a new quarrel with a new person.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to an angry argument or disagreement, and the verb to refer to the act of having an angry argument or disagreement.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new quarrel,â€ â€œa big quarrel,â€ â€œa lot of quarrels.â€

    • (Verb) â€œquarrel with a new person,â€ â€œquarrel about a new thing.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe had a new quarrel with his friend, so he is not happy.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the quarrel of a new group.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the quarrel of a new group.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the quarrel of a new group.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s quarrel can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the quarrel of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the quarrel of a new system.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Argument, dispute, disagreement, conflict, feud; (Verb) Argue, disagree, bicker, squabble.

Opposite words: (Noun) Agreement, peace, harmony, consensus; (Verb) Agree, reconcile, get along.

Where it comes from: From Latin querela (a complaint).

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the vulnerable problems in the new system.â€

6.20.570. Happen#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆhÃ¦pÉ™n/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To take place; to occur.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œhappenâ€ is for something to take place or occur, or for an event to come about.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of taking place; to occur.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œhappen to a new thing,â€ â€œhappen to a new person,â€ â€œhappen to a new idea.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI donâ€™t know what is going to happen, so I am scared.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the things that happen to a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the things that happen to a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the things that happen to a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to make things happen can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the things that happen to a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help things happen to a new system.â€

Synonyms: Occur, take place, come about, transpire, unfold.

Opposite words: Stop, cease, prevent, avoid.

Where it comes from: From Old Norse happ (chance, good luck).

6.20.571. Defect#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆdiËfÉ›kt/ (noun), /dÉªËˆfÉ›kt/ (verb)

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) A shortcoming, imperfection, or lack; (Verb) To abandon oneâ€™s country or cause in favor of an opposing one.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdefectâ€ is a flaw or imperfection, or the act of abandoning oneâ€™s loyalty to a cause or country.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œdefectâ€ refers to a shortcoming, imperfection, or lack. As a verb, to â€œdefectâ€ means to abandon oneâ€™s country or cause in favor of an opposing one. For example, a new thing can have a new defect.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a shortcoming, imperfection, or lack, and the verb to refer to the act of abandoning oneâ€™s country or cause in favor of an opposing one.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new defect,â€ â€œa major defect,â€ â€œa lot of defects.â€

    • (Verb) â€œdefect to a new country,â€ â€œdefect from a new group.â€

  • Examples:

      • â€œThe new thing has a new defect, so I need to return it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the defect of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the defect of a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the defect of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s defect with a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the defect of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the defect of a new system.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Flaw, fault, imperfection, weakness, bug; (Verb) Desert, abandon, betray, turncoat.

Opposite words: (Noun) Perfection, strength, asset, advantage; (Verb) Remain, stay, adhere, support.

Where it comes from: From Latin deficere (to fail).

6.20.572. Reasonably#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆriËznÉ™bli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: In a sensible, fair, or logical way.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œreasonablyâ€ is to be in a logical, fair, or acceptable manner, often implying a moderate degree.

What it really means: â€œReasonablyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done in a sensible, fair, or logical way. It suggests that a new thing is being done in a good way. For example, a new person can reasonably do a new thing.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done in a sensible, fair, or logical way.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œreasonably good,â€ â€œreasonably priced,â€ â€œreasonably a new thing.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new thing is reasonably priced, so I can afford it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who reasonably do a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who reasonably do a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who reasonably do a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to reasonably do a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who reasonably do a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people reasonably do a new system.â€

Synonyms: Fairly, sensibly, logically, moderately, tolerably.

Opposite words: Unreasonably, illogically, unfairly, excessively, foolishly.

Where it comes from: From Old French raisonable (rational).

6.20.573. Interrupt#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒÉªntÉ™ËˆrÊŒpt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To stop the continuous progress of something.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œinterruptâ€ is to stop an action or conversation temporarily, or to break its continuity.

What it really means: To â€œinterruptâ€ means to stop the continuous progress of something. It is the act of a new person stopping a new person from talking. For example, a new person can interrupt a new person.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of stopping the continuous progress of something.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œinterrupt a new person,â€ â€œinterrupt a new thing,â€ â€œinterrupt a new idea.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe is going to interrupt me, so I canâ€™t talk.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the people who interrupt a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the people who interrupt a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the people who interrupt a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to interrupt a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the people who interrupt a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people interrupt a new system.â€

Synonyms: Break in, intrude, stop, suspend, disrupt.

Opposite words: Continue, proceed, resume, support, facilitate.

Where it comes from: From Latin interrumpere (to break in between).

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to help people dominantly do a new system.â€

Where it comes from: From Latin dominari (to rule, to dominate).

Where it comes from: From Latin indurare (to make hard).

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÉ’fÉ™r/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

  • Word Type: Verb, Noun

  • Simple Meaning: (Verb) To present or propose (something) for acceptance or rejection; (Noun) A presentation of something for acceptance or rejection.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œofferâ€ is to present something for someone to take or consider, or the proposal itself.

What it really means: As a verb, to â€œofferâ€ means to present or propose (something) for acceptance or rejection. As a noun, â€œofferâ€ refers to a presentation of something for acceptance or rejection. For example, a new person can offer a new thing.

When to use it: Use the verb to refer to the act of presenting or proposing (something) for acceptance or rejection, and the noun to refer to a presentation of something for acceptance or rejection.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œoffer a new thing,â€ â€œoffer help,â€ â€œoffer a new idea.â€

    • (Noun) â€œa new offer,â€ â€œa good offer,â€ â€œa job offer.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe is going to offer me a new job, so I am very happy.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the offer of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the offer of a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the offer of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s offer of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the offer of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the offer of a new system.â€

Synonyms: (Verb) Propose, present, provide, tender, suggest; (Noun) Proposal, suggestion, bid, deal, proposition.

Opposite words: (Verb) Withdraw, refuse, deny, reject, take back; (Noun) Refusal, rejection, denial.

Where it comes from: From Latin offerre (to present, to show).

Synonyms: Unskillfully, ineptly, inefficiently, clumsily, poorly.

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the problems that immediately happen.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the problems that immediately happen.â€

6.20.585. Cause#

  • Pronunciation: /kÉ”Ëz/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

  • Word Type: Noun, Verb

  • Simple Meaning: (Noun) A person or thing that gives rise to an action, phenomenon, or condition; (Verb) To make (something) happen.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œcauseâ€ is the reason or origin of an event, or the act of making something happen.

What it really means: As a noun, â€œcauseâ€ refers to a person or thing that gives rise to an action, phenomenon, or condition. As a verb, to â€œcauseâ€ means to make (something) happen. For example, a new thing can cause a new thing.

When to use it: Use the noun to refer to a person or thing that gives rise to an action, phenomenon, or condition, and the verb to refer to the act of making (something) happen.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new cause,â€ â€œa root cause,â€ â€œa direct cause.â€

    • (Verb) â€œcause a new thing,â€ â€œcause a new problem,â€ â€œcause a new idea.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new thing is the cause of the new problem, so we need to fix it.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the cause of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the cause of a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the cause of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s cause of a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the cause of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the cause of a new system.â€

Synonyms: (Noun) Reason, origin, source, root, factor; (Verb) Produce, create, lead to, result in, bring about.

Opposite words: (Noun) Effect, result, outcome, consequence; (Verb) Prevent, stop, hinder, avoid.

Where it comes from: From Latin causa (reason, motive).

6.20.586. Exhausted#

  • Pronunciation: /ÉªÉ¡ËˆzÉ”ËstÉªd/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Adjective

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the exhausted problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: Tired, fatigued, drained, worn out, weary.

6.20.587. Deficit#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆdÉ›fÉªsÉªt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The amount by which something, especially a sum of money, is too small.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œdeficitâ€ is a shortfall, or an amount by which something is less than what is needed.

What it really means: â€œDeficitâ€ is a noun that refers to the amount by which something, especially a sum of money, is too small. It suggests that a new thing is not enough. For example, a new thing can have a new deficit.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the amount by which something, especially a sum of money, is too small.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new deficit,â€ â€œa budget deficit,â€ â€œa trade deficit.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œThe new company has a new deficit, so it is not doing well.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the deficit of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the deficit of a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the deficit of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s deficit with a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the deficit of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the deficit of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Shortfall, shortage, lack, deficiency, inadequacy.

Opposite words: Surplus, excess, abundance, profit, gain.

Where it comes from: From Latin deficere (to fail).

6.20.588. Spontaneously#

  • Pronunciation: /spÉ’nËˆteÉªniÉ™sli/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adverb

  • Simple Meaning: As a result of a sudden impulse and without premeditation.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œspontaneouslyâ€ is to be in a way that is unplanned or impulsive, without any prior thought.

What it really means: â€œSpontaneouslyâ€ is an adverb used to describe something that is done as a result of a sudden impulse and without premeditation. It suggests that a new thing is happening without any planning. For example, a new thing can spontaneously happen.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is done as a result of a sudden impulse and without premeditation.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adverb) â€œspontaneously happen,â€ â€œspontaneously decide,â€ â€œspontaneously a new thing.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe spontaneously decided to go on a trip, so he is very happy.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the problems that spontaneously happen.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the problems that spontaneously happen.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the problems that spontaneously happen.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to spontaneously do a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the problems that spontaneously happen.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the problems that spontaneously happen.â€

Synonyms: Impulsively, unplanned, naturally, on the spur of the moment, instinctively.

Opposite words: Deliberately, intentionally, planned, premeditated, consciously.

Where it comes from: From Latin sponte (of oneâ€™s own accord).

6.20.589. Treatment#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆtriËtmÉ™nt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The manner in which one deals with or behaves toward a person or thing.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œtreatmentâ€ is the way someone acts toward a person or thing, or a method used to cure an illness.

What it really means: â€œTreatmentâ€ is a noun that refers to the manner in which one deals with or behaves toward a person or thing. It suggests that a new person is dealing with a new person or thing. For example, a new thing can have a new treatment.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the manner in which one deals with or behaves toward a person or thing.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new treatment,â€ â€œa good treatment,â€ â€œa medical treatment.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe gave me a good treatment, so I am very happy.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the treatment of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the treatment of a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the treatment of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s treatment can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the treatment of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the treatment of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Handling, management, cure, therapy, care.

Opposite words: Neglect, abuse, mistreatment, disregard, harm.

Where it comes from: From Old French traitier (to handle, to deal with).

6.20.590. Somatic#

  • Pronunciation: /sÉ™ÊŠËˆmÃ¦tÉªk/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Relating to the body, especially as distinct from the mind.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsomaticâ€ is to be of the body, or physical.

What it really means: â€œSomaticâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is related to the body, especially as distinct from the mind. It suggests that a new thing is related to the body. For example, a new thing can be a somatic problem.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is related to the body, especially as distinct from the mind.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œsomatic symptom,â€ â€œsomatic pain,â€ â€œsomatic new thing.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have a new somatic symptom, so I need to go to the doctor.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the somatic problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the somatic problems in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the somatic problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s somatic ideas can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the somatic problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the somatic problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: Bodily, physical, corporeal, corporal, organic.

Opposite words: Mental, psychological, spiritual, cerebral.

Where it comes from: From Greek sÅma (body).

6.20.591. Therapy#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆÎ¸É›rÉ™pi/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: Treatment intended to relieve or heal a disorder.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œtherapyâ€ is treatment for a physical or mental disorder.

What it really means: â€œTherapyâ€ is a noun that refers to treatment intended to relieve or heal a disorder. It suggests that a new person is getting a new treatment. For example, a new person can have a new therapy.

When to use it: Use it to refer to treatment intended to relieve or heal a disorder.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new therapy,â€ â€œa lot of therapy,â€ â€œa physical therapy.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI need to get a new therapy, so I am going to the doctor.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the therapy of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the therapy of a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the therapy of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s therapy can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the therapy of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the therapy of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Treatment, cure, remedy, healing, rehabilitation.

Opposite words: Disease, illness, disorder, affliction, sickness.

Where it comes from: From Greek therapeia (healing).

6.20.592. Chronic#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkrÉ’nÉªk/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: (Of a problem, especially a disease) persisting for a long time or constantly recurring.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œchronicâ€ is to be long-lasting or recurring.

What it really means: â€œChronicâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is persisting for a long time or constantly recurring. It suggests that a new thing is a long-lasting problem. For example, a new thing can be a chronic problem.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is persisting for a long time or constantly recurring.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œchronic pain,â€ â€œchronic illness,â€ â€œchronic new thing.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have a new chronic pain, so I need to go to the doctor.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the chronic problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the chronic problems in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the chronic problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s chronic ideas can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the chronic problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the chronic problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: Persistent, lasting, constant, recurrent, long-standing.

Opposite words: Acute, temporary, brief, fleeting, short-term.

Where it comes from: From Greek khronos (time).

6.20.593. Symptom#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆsÉªmptÉ™m/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A physical or mental feature which is regarded as indicating a condition of disease.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œsymptomâ€ is an indication or sign of a problem, typically a medical one.

What it really means: â€œSymptomâ€ is a noun that refers to a physical or mental feature which is regarded as indicating a condition of disease. It suggests that a new thing is a sign of a new problem. For example, a new thing can be a new symptom.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a physical or mental feature which is regarded as indicating a condition of disease.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new symptom,â€ â€œa major symptom,â€ â€œa lot of symptoms.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have a new symptom, so I need to go to the doctor.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the symptom of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the symptom of a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the symptom of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s symptom can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the symptom of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the symptom of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Sign, indication, manifestation, signal, warning.

Opposite words: Cure, solution, remedy, relief, non-symptom.

Where it comes from: From Greek symptoma (a happening, a casualty).

6.20.594. Neuroscience#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒnjÊŠÉ™rÉ™ÊŠËˆsaÉªÉ™ns/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The study of the brain and the nervous system.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œneuroscienceâ€ is the scientific study of the nervous system, particularly the brain.

What it really means: â€œNeuroscienceâ€ is a noun that refers to the study of the brain and the nervous system. It suggests that a new person is studying a new thing. For example, a new person can study neuroscience.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the study of the brain and the nervous system.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new neuroscience,â€ â€œa lot of neuroscience,â€ â€œa new neuroscience study.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI am studying neuroscience, so I am learning a lot about the brain.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the neuroscience of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the neuroscience of a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the neuroscience of a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s neuroscience ideas can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the neuroscience of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the neuroscience of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Brain science, neurology, cognitive science, neurobiology.

Opposite words: (No direct antonyms, as it is a field of study).

Where it comes from: From Greek neuron (nerve) and Latin scientia (knowledge).

6.20.595. Anticipatory#

  • Pronunciation: /Ã¦nËŒtÉªsÉªËˆpeÉªtÉ™ri/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Characterized by or arousing anticipation.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œanticipatoryâ€ is to be in a state of expectation or preparation for a future event.

What it really means: â€œAnticipatoryâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is characterized by or arousing anticipation. It suggests that a new person is getting ready for a new thing. For example, a new thing can be an anticipatory problem.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is characterized by or arousing anticipation.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œanticipatory grief,â€ â€œanticipatory new thing,â€ â€œanticipatory feeling.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI have an anticipatory feeling about the new thing, so I am excited.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the anticipatory problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the anticipatory problems in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the anticipatory problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s anticipatory ideas can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the anticipatory problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the anticipatory problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: Expectant, predictive, preparatory, prospective, waiting.

Opposite words: Unanticipated, spontaneous, surprising, unprepared, reactive.

Where it comes from: From Latin anticipare (to take before).

6.20.596. Renown#

  • Pronunciation: /rÉªËˆnaÊŠn/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: The state of being known and admired by many people for a particular skill or achievement.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œrenownâ€ is widespread fame and honor, often for a specific accomplishment.

What it really means: â€œRenownâ€ is a noun that refers to the state of being known and admired by many people for a particular skill or achievement. It suggests that a new person is famous. For example, a new person can have a new renown.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the state of being known and admired by many people for a particular skill or achievement.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new renown,â€ â€œworld-famous renown,â€ â€œa lot of renown.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe has a lot of renown, so he is very famous.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the renown of a new group.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the renown of a new group.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the renown of a new group.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s renown can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the renown of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the renown of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Fame, celebrity, distinction, reputation, acclaim.

Opposite words: Anonymity, obscurity, disgrace, dishonor, infamy.

Where it comes from: From Old French renom (fame).

6.20.597. Concert#

  • Pronunciation: /ËˆkÉ’nsÉ™rt/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: A2

  • Word Type: Noun

  • Simple Meaning: A musical performance given in public, typically by several performers or by a choir or orchestra.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œconcertâ€ is a public musical performance.

What it really means: â€œConcertâ€ is a noun that refers to a musical performance given in public, typically by several performers or by a choir or orchestra. It suggests that a new person is going to a new musical performance. For example, a new person can go to a new concert.

When to use it: Use it to refer to a musical performance given in public.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Noun) â€œa new concert,â€ â€œa live concert,â€ â€œa rock concert.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI am going to a new concert, so I am very excited.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the concert of a new group.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the concert of a new group.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the concert of a new group.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s concert can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the concert of a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the concert of a new system.â€

Synonyms: Show, performance, gig, recital, live music.

Opposite words: (No direct antonyms, as it is a type of event).

Where it comes from: From Italian concerto (agreement, harmony).

6.20.598. Hyperactive#

  • Pronunciation: /ËŒhaÉªpÉ™rËˆÃ¦ktÉªv/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: B2

  • Word Type: Adjective

  • Simple Meaning: Abnormally or excessively active.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œhyperactiveâ€ is to be unusually or excessively active, often in a way that is disruptive or uncontrolled.

What it really means: â€œHyperactiveâ€ is an adjective used to describe something that is abnormally or excessively active. It suggests that a new person is very active. For example, a new person can be very hyperactive.

When to use it: Use it to describe something that is abnormally or excessively active.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Adjective) â€œa hyperactive person,â€ â€œa hyperactive new thing,â€ â€œhyperactive a new thing.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œHe is a very hyperactive person, so I need to calm him down.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to address the hyperactive problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to address the hyperactive problems in the country.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to address the hyperactive problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s hyperactive ideas can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to address the hyperactive problems in the country.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to address the hyperactive problems in the new system.â€

Synonyms: Overactive, restless, energetic, frenetic, jumpy.

Opposite words: Hypoactive, inactive, calm, subdued, lethargic.

Where it comes from: From Greek hyper- (over) and Latin activus (active).

6.20.599. Reframe#

  • Pronunciation: /riËËˆfreÉªm/

  • IELTS/CEFR Level: C1

  • Word Type: Verb

  • Simple Meaning: To change the way something is expressed or viewed.

Underlying Meaning / Core Meaning: The core meaning of â€œreframeâ€ is to change the conceptual structure of something, or to look at it from a different perspective.

What it really means: To â€œreframeâ€ means to change the way something is expressed or viewed. It is the act of a new person changing the way a new thing is seen. For example, a new person can reframe a new thing.

When to use it: Use it to refer to the act of changing the way something is expressed or viewed.
  • Common phrases:

    • (Verb) â€œreframe a new thing,â€ â€œreframe a new problem,â€ â€œreframe a new idea.â€

  • Examples:
    • Daily Use:

      • â€œI need to reframe the new thing, so it will be better.â€

      • â€œThe new policy is designed to reframe a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe new law is designed to reframe a new thing.â€

    • Formal/IELTS Use:

      • â€œThe report notes that the new policy is designed to reframe a new thing.â€

      • â€œThe study examines how a personâ€™s ability to reframe a new idea can affect their creativity.â€

      • â€œThe document highlights the importance of having a clear and consistent plan to reframe a new law.â€

      • â€œThe new technology is designed to reframe a new system.â€

Synonyms: Rephrase, restructure, reinterpret, reconceptualize, rethink.

Opposite words: Maintain, preserve, keep, retain, stabilize.

Where it comes from: From Latin re- (again) and Old French framer (to make).
